column2: PHILADELPHIA, May 15.--At noon to-day the remainder of the assets of the Jay Cooke Co. estate were disposed of by auction, by order of Edwin M. Lewis, Trustee. The sale was held for the redemption of asset dividend scrip of the first and second issues, comprising many tracts of land in Minnesota and other sections of the West.

Emory, commanding the arctic steamer Bear, under date of St. John, May 3, in which he says the ice conditions are considered favorable. If easterly gales have prevailed in the arctic regions, as there is reason to believe, the ice will have set ...

PHILADELPHIA, May 15.--The General Methodist Episcopal Conference devoted to-day to the election of four Bishops. The galleries were crowded with visitors, and the aisles were so filled that business was transacted with difficulty.
CITY OF MEXICO, May 15, via Galveston.-- The Senate today ratified the reciprocity treaty with the United States. Only three members voted against it.
VICKSBURG, Miss., May 15.--The General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church of the United States convened in this city to-day, about 150 delegates being present at roll-call.

CINCINNATI, May 15.--Last evening J. Nelson Pooley, a business man of this city, living in Dayton, Ky., while in Mack's saloon, in Newport, was astonished upon attempting to make a remark to find that his power of speech was gone.

CHICAGO, May 15.--The remains of the late Cyrus H. McCormick were to-day placed in their last resting-place at Graceland. On last Monday Gov. Cleveland signed the new act making it a misdemeanor to manufacture cigars in the tenement-houses of the cities of New-York and Brooklyn.

A large number of people visited St. Patrick's Cathedral, in Fifth-avenue, yesterday, in hope of seeing the remains of the late Charles O'Conor, and they all appeared to be much disappointed when their request was refused.

ALBANY, May 15.--The manufacture of laws was delayed in the Assembly this morning while the sorehead Republicans and Democrats, (among whom the wearers of the collar of John J. O'Brien were the principals,) who have been criticized by THE TIMES for voting against a bill insuring purity of elections in New-York City, devoted themselves to that newspaper and its correspondent.

PHILADELPHIA, May 15.--Albert H. Moore of No. 1,711 Spring Garden-street, was for a year or two known as the owner of one of the finest dog kennels in the country. He was also known for a few months as the husband of a handsome woman, who made a stir in society at Saratoga by wearing $50,000 worth of diamonds at a hotel
ROCKPORT, Mass., May 15.--The steamer Faraday, with the American section of the Mackay-Bennett oceanic cable aboard, was expected to arrive here from Nova Scotia the first or middle of the week.

WASHINGTON, May 15.--The defense in the Swaim case was closed before the court of inquiry today, and Mr. Chandler called Mr. Bateman in rebuttal.
Templar Lodge, No. 203, F. and A.M., will work the second degree at their rooms, No. 161 Eighth-avenue, this evening.

CHICAGO, May 15.--A dispatch to the Journal from Quincy, Ill., says: "The Union Bank of this city failed to open its doors this morning. When the Marine Bank of New-York failed the Union Bank transferred its account to the Metropolitan Bank, and the closing of the doors of that bank yesterday is given as the cause for the suspension."

CHICAGO, May 15.--The Cattle market was weak all along the line to-day. In comparison with the closing prices of Wednesday there was no very pronounced change in shipping Cattle, but the market averaged about 10c. lower than Tuesday, and showed a further declining tendency at the close.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., May 15.--Gen W.H. H. Terrill, brother of Col. Charles M. Terrill, United States Army, is not expected to live through the night. Gen. Terrill is one of the best-known men in Indiana and has a national reputation.

The removal of the telegraph poles and the placing of all wires under ground will undoubtedly be of great advantage to our city. On the other hand, it will be a very serious injury to the race of arboreal men, since it will threaten them with complete extinction.
PRINCETON, N.J., May 16.--The Society of the Cincinnati this afternoon finished their triennial meeting in this place. The next meeting will be held in Newport in 1887.

PARIS, May 15.--Stagno, the tenor, made his debut in Paris to-night in the opera "Rigoletto." The critics consider his performance a failure.

Two additional failures were announced in Wall-street yesterday. One produced but little disturbing effect, while the other created a commotion. Until the unexpected suspension of Fisk Hatch, at 2:35 o'clock P.M., the situation in the Street was encouraging. The stock market opened with a general advance on Wednesday's prices, and remained fairly steady throughout the day.

In the United States Circuit Court, Criminal Branch, Nicola Vita and Philipo Santore, for passing counterfeit quarters and dimes, were sentenced--Vita to 18 months in the Albany Penitentiary, and Santore, who is an old offender, to four years in the Erie County Penitentiary.

The Twenty-second Regiment had a "field day" yesterday. Assembling in its armory at noon, it marched to the plaza in Union-square for review by the Mayor. The regiment wore its blue fatigue uniform. Line was formed with 10 companies of 16 files front.

Twelve engine companies and the crews of both fire-boats for three hours fought a fire at No. 20 Washington-street last night. The building is a five-story brick building, 100 feet deep, and having a frontage of 40 feet.

On attempting to open the street door to the house in which he lived, No. 1,977 Thirdavenue, at about noon yesterday, little Eddie Jewel, who lived with his mother on the top floor, found it fastened from the inside, and no amount of pushing on his part served to open it.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., May 15.--The biennial session of the Grand Council of the Catholic Mutual Benefit Association closed to-night with a banquet at the Judson House.

Mr. David Bidwell is in New-York. When Mr. Bidwell arrives here it is generally understood that the dramatic season is at an end. Mr. Bidwell is regarded as a theatrical barometer. He has been connected with the theatres of the city of New-Orleans for a great many years.

WASHINGTON, May 15.--Lieut.-Col. Albert P. Morrow, Sixth Cavalry, having completed the duty for which he was ordered to this city, has been ordered to return to his proper station.

The Yonkers police yesterday captured a wagon-load of stolen property in the possession of Charles Humphries. A baby carriage that was stolen Wednesday evening from a private residence was traced to Humphries's home.

PARIS, May 15.--Mr. Levi P. Morton, the American Minister, entertained a large company at a banquet last night. Among the guests were the Count of Paris and Lord Lyons, the British Ambassador.

BOSTON, May 15.--Financial Boston passed through to-day's excitement with apparently more ease than yesterday. Two small failures were reported--one of them of a private banking-house, and the other of a small brokerage concern--but these did not materially affect the street.

BERLIN, May 16.--The Tageblatt to-day positively asserts that Mr. M. Richards Muckle, of the Philadelphia Ledger, will succeed Mr. Sargent as United States Minister to Berlin. Mr. Muckle, the paper says, is an Alsatian by birth, but is persona grata to Bismarck.

Col. James H. Mapleson will sail for Europe this morning on the Inman steam-ship City of Berlin. The Colonel was found last evening at the New-York Hotel. "Yes," said he, "we sail to-morrow.

Complaints having been made by members of the Stock Exchange that the Hon. Russell Sage was purposely avoiding the service of notices by holders of his privileges, the matter was discussed at some length at the meeting of the Governing Committee yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 16.--A special to the Journal from Jamesville, Wis., says: "A heavy frost in this part, of the State this morning damaged the fruit and crops on the low lands. The water was frozen in many places."
OTTAWA, Ontario, May 16.--The report of the Canadian Commissioner of Fisheries issued to-day says that the value of these fisheries continues to increase.
ROME, N.Y., May 16.--In the case of John Spellicy, who was stabbed and killed on May 13 by Michael Boylan, the Coroner's jury to-day returned a verdict against Boylan, and he was committed to jail.

As Washington C. Patterson, a letter-carrier of Station B. approached No. 92 Willettstreet on his regular round about noon yesterday, the door of the house flew open and the whole family of Samuel Ellsner, a butcher, appeared in the entrance. "Give us a letter," was the simultaneous cry of all.
PHILADELPHIA, May 16.--Koitsi Bakaki, an intelligent, well-educated Japanese, started for Tokio to-day, carrying with him a trunkful of text-books and notes gathered principally in this city.
NYACK, May 16.--As an up-bound train on the Northern Railroad of New-Jersey was nearing the station at Ridgefield, N.J., this morning, the engineer saw an elderly women standing on the track.

A feeling of distrust and uncertainty prevailed in Wall-street up to 3 o'clock P.M. yesterday. When it was found, after the close of the Stock Exchange, that no disastrous failures had occurred during the day, this feeling changed perceptibly.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., May 16.--Sir Titus Salt, Charles Stead, of Saltaire, England, and William Donaldson, of Glasgow, the owners of 28,000 acres of mineral lands near Chattanooga, arrived here yesterday, and decided to erect two large blast furnaces on their tract with a capacity of 250 tons per day. The investment will reach $500,000, and will be expended within the next 15 month.

WASHINGTON, May 16.--This was the fourth and last day of the Spring meeting of the National Jockey Club. The first race was a mile dash, for maiden 3-year olds; purse $500, of which $100 to second horse. The run down the straight between Emma and Bullfield was fine.

NATICK, Mass., May 16.--A bricklayer, name unknown, lies in a critical condition at Saxonville, the result of an assault upon him with a flat-iron last night by Nicholas Drew during a drunken quarrel.
WORCESTER, Mass., May 16.--No bodies have been found in the ruins of the Pakachoag Mill, and it is believed that everybody who was in the building at the time of the fire has been accounted for.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., May 16.--There was great excitement on Change to-day, and wheat was hammered down over 2 cents in a few hours.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., May 16.--Tully H. Smith, a business man, of middle age, well connected and very wealthy, left his home at one of the fashionable hotels in this city last Saturday morning, and started on a business trip to Chicago.

Dapper little Mr. Spader, whose name is better known in combination with that of his partner, Mr. Gale, and still more easily placed when spoken of in connection with the present management of the Comedy Theatre, was in a state of great excitement last night.
HARTFORD, CONN., May 16.--At the meeting of the Yale Corporation to-day the matter of reorganizing the Medical School was referred to a committee to report at a future meeting.
PHILADELPHIA, May 16.--This was the last day of the Spring meeting at Suffolk Park. Following are the summaries.

HAZLEHURST, Miss., May 16.--The second day of the trial of the Penn brothers for the killing of R.B. Rials was begun this morning in the Copiah County Circuit Court. A severance has been granted, and the defendants will be tried separately. Dr. Robert G. Penn will be tried first. The morning hour to-day was occupied in impaneling a jury. Both cases will consume several days.

WASHINGTON, May 16.--In the Swaim court of inquiry, to-day. Mr. Bateman, who was recalled yesterday by Mr. Chandler, was again under examination. He testified that with respect to his stock transactions for Gen. Swaim's account that there were one or two transactions of which, in the usual order of business, Gen. Swaim should have been notified.

LONDON, May 16.--The Government has sent orders to Cairo directing that efforts be made to communicate with Gen. Gordon by other routes than Berber.

DES MOINES, Iowa, May 16.--AttorneyGeneral McPherson has begun suit in the name of the State in Cerro Gordo County to enforce the order of the Railway Commissioners, requiring the Iowa Central to operate its trains to Northwood.

ALBANY, May 16.--Bank Superintendent Willis S. Paine has given official notice to the County Clerk of New-York County of his refusal to issue a certificate authorizing the proposed Mutual Savings Bank of Harlem to transact the business of a savings bank under the laws of the State.

ATLANTA, Ga., May 16.--The assignment of John H. James, one of the wealthiest bankers of Atlanta, is announced to-day. His liabilities amount to nearly $500,000. The city is greatly agitated, and precaution is being taken to prevent a panic.

BALTIMORE, May 16.--The fourteenth quadrennial General Conference of the Methodist Protestant Church met in this city to-day, the Rev. Dr. G.B. McElroy, of the Michigan Confer ence, President, in the chair.

ASHLAND, Ohio, May 16.--George Andrew Horn and William H. Gribben, aged 24 and 29 years, respectively, were hanged here to-day for the murder of Harry Williams on March 25, 1883. Over 10,000 persons had collected, and it was feared that the mob would tear down the inclosure ...

CHICAGO, May 16.--It is reported that a combination has been effected between some north and south side Democratic ward politicians for the purpose of preventing the selection of Mayor Harrison as a delegate at large from Illinois to the Democratic Convention.

All day long yesterday Mr. Robert L. Cutting, Jr., sat like a martyr on a cane-bottom chair in a room on the top story of No. 169 Broadway as a witness in the Marie-Garrison suit. His friends dropped in during the day and whispered the latest news from the Street.

OTTAWA, Ontario, May 16.--A supplement to the report of the Minister of Inland Revenue, issued to-day, gives statistics of the Canadian canal traffic for the shipping season of 1883. Compared with that of 1882, there was an increase of $38,562 in the amount of canal tolls collected.
LONDON, May 16.--The opening prices on the Stock Exchange this morning were somewhat lower than last night's closing prices.
Application was made to Surrogate Bergen yesterday, in Brooklyn, for the appointment of a special guardian for Ludlow Valentine, the infant son of Mrs. Catharine A. Valentine.

MADRID, May 16.--Senor Punourosko, an extreme Conservative, has been elected President of the Senate.

WASHINGTON, May 16.--The House was industrious and expeditious to-day, going through with the Diplomatic, Army, and District Appropriation bills, and recommending them all for passage substantially as they came from the Appropriations Committee.

Mr. Augustin Daly's company are now acting in "Red Letter Nights" at the Park Theatre, Boston. This amusing trifle, which is acted with capital spirit, has pleased Boston audiences as well as it did the play-goers of this city.

A terrible tragedy occurred on the bark Myrtle, Capt. J. Carter, which left New-York Thursday morning with a load of naphtha, bound for the West Indies. Michael William Walsh, the second mate, killed a sailor named John Williams.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 16.--A meeting of the county organization of the American Prohibition Party was held at Warsaw, Wyoming County, to-day. Frank Caswell, President of the State Committee, presided.

NEW-ORLEANS, May 16.--The selection of James B. Eustis by the Democratic caucus at Baton Rouge to be United Senator, vice B.F. Jonas, the sitting member, has been fruitful of unfriendly comment to-day.
ITHACA, N.Y., May 16.--To-day President White issued a circular announcing the conditions under which fellowships and scholarships established by the Trustees of Cornell University would be granted.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., May 16.--This afternoon Oliver Utley, a rich Southwick farmer, 70 years old, was swindled out of $2,000 by threecard monte sharpers.

PIEDMONT, West Va., May 16.--A cavern has been discovered on the farm of Mr. David Smith, this county, which promises to rival in extent and beauty the famous Louray Cavern, in Old Virginia.

COLUMBIA, S.C., May 16.--The body of Bogan Cash was interred at 3 P.M. to-day in the orchard about 200 yards south of his father's residence.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 16.--The tenth Spring meeting of the Louisville Jockey Club began to-day under the most delightful conditions. The weather was clear, the air soft, the track fast, and about 15,000 people thronged the course, interested chiefly in the result of the Derby.
VICKSBURG, May 16.--The General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church met at 9 this morning.

ALBANY, May 18.--There is a general impression among Democratic politicians that Mr. Manning's State Committee, which will meet here on Wednesday, will favor saratoga as the place and June 12 or 19 as the time for the meeting of the state Convention. Opinion is divided between the two dates.

Clarkson, Secretary of the Canal-boat Owners and Commercial Association, that there are now 14 vessels lying in the slips set apart by law for the use of canal-boats, Dock Commissioner William Laimbeer said yesterday that the docks in question would be ready for the canal-boats when needed.
Capt. Forster Thursby and Capt. Cookesley, of England, are at the Grand Central Hotel.

PARIS, May 18.--The statement that a Fenian plot to assassinate the Prince of Wales was brewing is declared to be untrue. The Prince freely moved about the streets of Paris, and made many visits unattended. He left Paris for a suburban hotel last evening. The Prince refused to allow his carriage to enter the inner court of the hotel, or to permit the police agents to accompany him.

Rogers, who energetically and with some eccentricity conducts the business affairs of Miss Minnie Palmer, will probably be very deeply excited by the Associated Press dispatch which appeared in yesterday's newspapers, and which alluded to him as the husband of the amiable young lady in question.

OPELIKA, Ala., May 18.--The trial of James C. Abercrombie for Killing Marshal Hart begun on Thursday, and resulted yesterday in a mistrial. Abercrombie's defense was insanity.

A canoe voyage from Philadelphia to New-York by way of the Delaware River and the Delaware and Raritan Canal will be begun to-day by Col. Charles L. Norton and Mr. Henry W.B. Howard, of the New-York Canoe Club. The double cruising canoe Kittiwake will be used, with double paddles and two lateen sails. It is expected that the trip will be made in three days.

Wright's glassware establishment, at No. 225 Greenwich-street, was passing No. 59 Mulberrystreet last night, when James Parma, an Italian employed on Governor's Island, shot him in the right leg, above the knee, with a revolver, without provocation of any sort.

The actual revenue of the Hawaiian Government is declared by the Honolulu Gazette to be only $2,193,285.42. It further says, that as the country is now administered, a deficit is created of exactly $1,025,120.

District Attorney Fleming appeared for the people, and examined three seamen who witnessed the killing.

TROY, N.Y., May 19.--On Saturday morning an attempt was made to break open the safe of the Troy and Boston Railroad Com pany at Eagle Bridge, but without success, the only damage being the battering of the safe door. Better success was had at the Dalton House, where the safe was opened and $50 taken.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., May 19.--A young woman named Claudia Sams, also known as Bertie Daily, made two attempts to commit suicide to-day by plunging into the Tennessee River. She is thought to have at one time been a variety actress. She is about 23 years of age and says she was born in New-York City and that her parents now reside in Newark, N.J. She is now in charge of the Chief of Police.

CAIRO, May 19.--Two hundred rebels bombarded Suakin to-day, the attack lasting one hour. Two inhabitants were wounded, and the rebels succeeded in stealing 1,000 sheep. The British troops landed at the town and the rebels were forced to retire.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., May 18.--The First Assembly Democratic Convention, held here today, consumed 10 minutes and was uniformly run by E.J. Clark, one of the managers of Flower's canvass here. MILWAUKEE, Wis., May 19.--Several heavy frosts have fallen in the great fruit-growing belt of the North-west the past ten days, but owing to the backwardness of the season the damage has been very slight. The apple crop of Michigan and Wisconsin last year was a complete failure. The indications are that the apple, pear, cherry, and other small fruit crops in the Northwest will be unusually fine this year.

CHICAGO, May 19.--The Cattle received during Sunday and to-day numbered, 5,000 head; same time last week, 5,808 head. Nearly every one was disappointed in the character of the supply to-day. It was much lighter than there was any reason to expect. Consequently, the market developed a decidedly firmer tone, and suitable shipping cattle were wanted at a substantial advance.

Gerald Thomas Tully, Sub-Manager of the Preston Banking Company, of Preston, Lancashire, England, disappeared from his place of occupation and his home in October, 1883. An examination of his accounts showed him to be a defaulter to the amount of about 15,000. On Monday evening he was recognized while walking on Broadway by Joseph Toulmin, a shareholder in the Preston Bank, arrested, and is now locked up at the Eighteenth Precinct Police Station.

Just before 12 o'clock last night Adolph Adams, a young man, 21 years old, living at No. 122 Leonard-street, shot Laura Watson in the hallway of a disorderly house at No. 140 Forsythstreet, causing instant death. The couple had been carousing together. Adams was arrested and the Coroner notified.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., May 22.--The Democratic State Convention of Sullivan County convened here to-day and elected B.W. Winner, T.A. Neven and Frederick Hessinger delegates to the Saratoga Convention. The delegates were not instructed, but favor Tilden, with Flower as second choice.

In a few days Mr. GEORGE P. ANDREWS will vacate the position of Corporation Counsel to assume the duties of a Supreme Court Judge. Otto Emmentraut, age l7 years, of No. 257 East Fourth-street, was arrested on Tuesday night by Officer Meyer, of the Eleventh Precinct, on a charge of disorderly conduct, and, after being severely clubbed, was locked up in the station-house.

An intelligent-looking woman, neatly dressed, sat in Part II. of General Sessions, yesterday, under charge of having stolen $750 worth of jewelry from August O. Montant. She had light hair, wore spectacles, and her eyes were swollen with weeping.

The concert given at the Academy of Music last evening was the third of a series of entertainments gotten up by the Church Choral Union of New-York, an organization intended to diffuse musical culture among the choirs and Sunday-schools of the city, and likely, from present indications, to do a great deal of good work.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., May 22.--The new Trustees agreed on as a compromise when the postponement of the suit of Mayor Daniel N. Morgan and others against John Hurd and others was made before Judge Andrews, in the Superior Court last Tuesday, have been engaged all day in investigating the books of the Housatonic ...

The General Term of the Court of Common Pleas decided yesterday that the persons injured on the East Biver bridge last Decoration Day have no right of action for damages against the Trustees of the bridge on the alleged ground that they negligently failed to provide a proper police force to preserve order on the structure.
PORTSMOUTH, Ohio, May 22,--John Oehman, his wife, and a grown daughter were burned in their house on a farm four miles from here last night.

COLUMBUS, Ga., May 22.--Near Smith's Station, Ala., Frank Smith shot and killed John Thomas, colored. A dispute arose about a settlement, and Thomas made an attack upon Smith with a hatchet. Smith has not been arrested.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 22.--James C. Flood, with the son of J.L. Flood, left here for the Fast to-day. The latter is on his way to London, where he goes to establish a branch of the Nevada Bank.

EMPORIA, Kan., May 22.--The Republicans of the Fourth District renominated, by acclamation, Thomas Ryan for Congress.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 22.--The annual excursion tendered by the Junior to the Senior Class of Vassar College occurred this afternoon on the Hudson on board the steamer Mary Powell. About 75 ladies participated in the affair. Accompanying the excursionists were President Caldwell and some of the Faculty.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 22.--There was a good attendance at the races here to-day. The weather was warm and the track fast.
A new private park is being laid out on the grounds of the New York and Harlem Railroad Company on Thirty-fourth-street, from Lexington to Park avenues.

Henry W. Bonhage, tailor, made Mr. Charles A. Gambrill a coat for $35, but after it was twice altered it still did not fit, and Mr. Gambrill refused to take the garment. Mr. Bonhage brought suit. Mr. Frieze, a tailor, testified yesterday ...
PITTSBURG, Penn., May 22.--A conference between the iron manufacturers and a committee of the Amalgamated Association is in progress here. It resulted in a continuance of the dead-lock.
PHILADELPHIA, May 22.--The two events on to-day's programme at Belmont course were soon disposed of the favorites in each winning ...
ASBURY, Park, N.J., May 22.--The NewJersey Pharmaceutical Association continued their fourteenth annual meeting to-day.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., May 22.--Isaac M. Veitch, an old and well-known citizen, died suddenly this afternoon. Mr. Veitch was one of the best known Odd-fellows in the country, having been Past Grand Sire of the Supreme Grand Lodge of the World.

The partner of Jesse Grant, a younger son of the General, in the brokerage, business at No. 2 Wall-street is Stephen F. Moriarty, a bright young Bostonian, who left the law office of exGov. Gaston, of Massachusetts, to indulge here a fondness for speculative enterprises. Since his advent in this city he has interested himself specially in the practical use of electric storage batteries.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., May 22.--The bitter fight between the saloon keepers and the temperance men which has been raging here for some time was brought to a close this afternoon by the decision of the courts making known the names of applicants granted licenses and those refused.

The Delaware and Hudson Canal Company has applied to the Stock Exchange to have $3,500,000 of its new issue of stock (increase authorized $10,000,000) placed on the regular list. Part of the new stock will be ready for delivery on and after June 10.
The business men's boom for Arthur is a sham. It is run by the Republican machine, with a few business men displayed as figureheads. He cannot command the votes of his own party if nominated.
KINGSTON, Ontario, May 22.--The Governor-General and Lady Lansdowne dined with the Hon. Mr. Kirkpatrick last evening.
Two boys, Samuel McCloud, of No. 239 Monroe-street, and Peter Fitzsimmons, No. 444 Cherry-street, were playing with a loaded pistol last night. McCloud was examining the weapon, ...
BUFFALO, N.Y., May 22.--William H. Green, an Erie Railway brakeman, who has been but two weeks married, shot his wife at their rooms this morning.

LEBANON, Penn., May 22.--About 300 guests, representing society people of New-York and Philadelphia, arrived here to-day on special trains, and were run out to North Lebanon to the estate of Mrs. D.G. Dawson Coleman. Four or five gray-stone mansions in a spacious park comprise the splendid homestead of the wealthiest families of all Pennsylvania-Iron kings. Brussels carpet was laid for two squares to the ...

CINCINNATI, May 22.--Whisky dropped down in this market to-day from $1.11 to $1.01. The break was caused by an Iowa distillery, which has been causing trouble for some time by refusing to pay its assessment into the pool. The sale at $1.01 was of only 15 barrels, but it demoralized the trade, and it is the talk to-night that the pool has been hopelessly broken.

DANVILLE, Va., May 22.--The election passed without disturbance. The Democratic or White Party nominees were elected. Capt. W. P. Graves beats J.H. Johnston, the present incumbent, for Mayor by 402 votes. About 70 negroes voted the Democratic ticket. Gov. Cameron ...

STAUNTON, Va., May 22.--The early morning trains brought hundreds of people to the reunion of the Twenty-eighth Regiment New-York Volunteers with the Fifth Virginia to-day. Buildings were profusely adorned with flags and bunting. One man remarked that never before since the war has Staunton seen so many national ...

Dr. W.F. Fluhrer yesterday exhibited to a number of physicans, in the lecture-room of Bellevue Hospital, Bruno Knorr, the young German who attempted to commit suicide last January by putting a pistol bullet into his brain because his lady love had given him the mitten.

There arrived this week from San Domingo, by the steamer G.W. Clyde, Seflor Manuel J. Galvan, President of the Supreme Court of San Domingo, who comes as Minister Plenipotentiary to the United States and to establish an embassy in Washington.

ALBANY, May 22.--The Governor gave a hearing to-day on the Daly Underground Telegraph and Electric Light bill. The bill was opposed by various telephone and electric light companies in the city of New-York. The Western Union Tele graph Company did not oppose it.

The Siamese Embassy spent yesterday inspecting the institutions on Blackwell's and Ward's Islands as guests of the Commissioners of Charity, represented by Commissioners Brennan, Porter, and Hess. As Rebecca Jones sat in Ludlow-Street Jail last night she expressed anew her determination not to speak. She declared again that she knew nothing. She said she was becoming celebrated.

Unpaid interest on a big mortgage is the newest development of the troubles in Dr. Newman's church. The Board of Trustees decline to pay it, and patiently await a foreclosure. The Ranney people are afraid that the building will be sold over their heads, and that the Newman people will go off and build a new church with the round sum the property is expected to bring.

The presence of Gen. Robert Toombs in the city yesterday was the occasion for many of his friends to visit him at his old head-quarters at the Central Hotel and to greet him on the streets. Gen. Toombs has not been in Augusta, for over a year; in fact, he is averse to traveling about much at present.

PHILADELPHIA, May 22.--To-day's session of the Methodist Episcopal Conference was attended by a large number of spectators anxious to witness the consecration of the new Bishops. ITHACA, N.Y., May 22.--Much feeling has been aroused among the students of Cornell University by the employment of professional players by other colleges in the New-York State Intercollegiate Base-Ball Association.

There were more dootors on the witnessstand before the Surrogate yesterday in the suit to open the probate of Jesse Hoyt's will. Dr. George M. Dillow testified that he attended Jesse Hoyt professionally during the Summers of 1881 ...

While fishing from a small row-boat in Little Hell Gate, at about 6 o'clock yesterday evening, William and Louis Getterman, brothers, of No. 1,907 Second-avenue, accidentally upset the boat, and both were thrown into the water.

LONDON, May 22.--The Wycliffe celebration was concluded last evening with a great meeting at Exeter Hall. The Earl of Shaftesbury presided. Numerous distinguished clergymen and other persons of note were present.

Stone, Grand Marshal of the Decoration Day parade, was given a reception last evening at the Memorial Committee Head-quarters, Twenty-second Regiment Armory, by Dahlgren Post, No. 113, G.A.R., and Sedgwick Post, No. 186. DES MOINES, Iowa, May 22.--Bishop Perry, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Van Antwerp, this afternoon laid the corner-stone of the new edifice of St. Paul's Episcopal Church. The building, which is in a commanding location, will cost $28,000.

WASHINGTON, May 22.--Lieut.-Gen. Sheridan returned to Washington this evening from Sandusky, Ohio. Major-Gen. Pope left Washington to-day for San Francisco, to resume command of the Department of the Pacific.

Truth will to-day announce editorially that its ownership has changed hands. On and after Monday next the editor will be Mr. Thomas B. Connery, who for more than 20 years has been connected with the New-York Herald.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 22.--Associate Justice Stanley Matthews, of the United States Supreme Court, to-day decided the case, of Everett and others against Trustee Whitworth and others in favor of the defendants.

Lights streamed last evening from every window of the handsome four-story building which Mr. John Jacob Astor has erected on the north-west corner of Thirty-second-street and Seventh-avenue, for homeless boys of the Children's Aid Society.
WASHINGTON, May 22.--The Secretary of the Treasury this afternoon issued the one hundred and twenty-eighth call for the redemption of bonds.
ERIE, Penn., May 22.--Investigation shows that the suspended Erie County Bank is in a rotten condition. Not over $50,000 available assets is found with which to pay $300,000 of deposits.

A letter from Commissioner Evans, dated May 19, is published. It was written in reply to the complaint of a Philadelphian, who holds a very small amount, to the effect that he believed his claim had been "purposely hampered and delayed, that the middlemen iu New-York might be benefited." CAIRO, May 22.--The Egyptian Horse Artillery, the Seventh Battalion of Infantry, and the camel transport left Cairo for Assouan to-day.

CHICAGO, May 22.--The Transcontinental Association, which regulates all California business, met here to-day to make final arrangements for the carrying into effect of the new money pool arranged at the meeting in St. Louis a week or two ago.

LINCOLN, Neb., May 22.--The Democratic State Convention was called to order at 8 o'clock. One hour was spent over temporary organization, which was finally effected by electing B.A. Hinman, of Lincoln County, Chairman.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 22.--As rarely happens, both town and "gown" were interested parties here to-day in a matrimonial event and one of moment. CINCINNATI, May 22.--Returning from Washington, Murat Halstead says of the Presidential contest: "There is a growing chance for John Sherman, and if those actually for him do not waste time they may nominate him.
The following cable dispatch was sent by Jay Gould to William H. Vanderbilt on Wednesday afternoon:
Mr. Sage's office was nearly deserted yesterday, there being few brokers who presented privileges to him. Those that were presented were promptly met.

ST. LOUIS, May 22.--A party of horsethieves and whisky peddlers was overtaken in the Indian Territory a few days ago by several officers, and in the attempt to arrest them, George another mortally and a third sligtly wounded. Two of the officers were also slightly injured.

EASTON, Penn., May 22.--Sabato D'Alessandre, the Italian murderer, hanged himself in his cell in the County Jail to-day. He was alive at 12 o'clock when the Deputy Warden visited his cell, but at 1 o'clock was found by the Warden on the floor dead.
PITTSBURG, Penn., May 22.--The officers of the Penn Bank were busy to-day getting their affairs in shape for resumption to-morrow. Their clearances were made good to-day.

ST. LOUIS, May 22.--Mrs. Annie Moss attempted to kill William Bettlon in his bedroom at her house, in Pine-street, last night, by shooting him over the right ear.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., May 22.--The members of the Passenger Conductors' Life Insurance Society of the United States and Canada visited Long Branch to-day in a special train from Philadelphia.

It is said that United States District Attorney Elihu Root has expressed his determination to ask the United States Grand Jury, which will sit in June next, to indict Ferdinand Ward, James D. Fish, and John C. Eno, the first as a Director, and the other two as Presidents, of national banks, for fraud and embezzlement.
There was a meeting yesterday of the members of the Trunk Line Executive Committee, consisting of the Vice-Presidents and the representatives of the Boston roads.

CHICAGO, May 22.--Already the participants in the Republican National Convention have begun to arrive in the city, the advance guard being formed of newspaper correspondents and delegates who are anxious about quarters.

The installation of the Rev. Dr. Edward Payson Terhune as Pastor of the First Reformed Church of Brooklyn took place last evening at the church, on the corner of Bedford-avenue and Clymer-street, Brooklyn, Eastern District.

Justice Pratt, sitting at the Special Term of the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday appointed F.H. Smith as temporary Receiver of the Atlantic State Bank. The Receiver was appointed at the solicitation of Attorney-General O'Brien, who has begun an action to dissolve the bank on the ground that it is insolvent.

A specially lurid stage, gayly decorated with flags, flowers, bunting and all the magnificence that a picnic is heir to, drove up Broadway yesterday morning with 20 tastefully dressed children from the Madison-Square Theatre.
William H. Sweeney, a broker at No. 104 Nassau-street, was arrested by the Sheriff yesterday on an order granted by Judge Freedman, of the Superior Court.

DES MOINES, Iowa, May 22.--At Glenwood, about noon to-day, C.W. Wallis, a photographer, shot and killed John Clingersmith. The latter was son-in-law to Mrs. Wallis. Clingersmith had lately beaten Wallis severely in a fist fight, and had been insolent in his demeanor ever since. To-day he went to Wallis's ...

BALTIMORE, May 22.--The Baltimores defeated the Brooklyn Club here to-day by the score of 5 to 3. The home club got the-lead in the fourth inning and held it to the close. Clinton, after having six called balls and two strikes, hit the ball over the centre fielder's head and scored a home run.
The New-York, West Shore and Buffalo Railway has issued a small book describing the Summer homes and resorts accessible by that route.
CHICAGO, May 22.--The burning of the Hardin County Court-house, at Elizabethtown, Ill., Monday last, is the latest fruit of the longexisting feuds of many families in that county.

MILWAUKEE, May 22.--There are several interesting developments in the Medford tragedy to-day. The relatives of Dr. Singleton B. Hubbell have begun proceedings to set aside his will, which was probated the day after his death.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 22.--The St. Louis express train, on the New-York Central Railroad, ran into the Auburn Road freight train, at Brighton, at 11:50 o'clock to-night.

Carson, one of the surgeons who made the autopsy, of the skull of the murdered man. The schooner Charles E. Schmidt, which arrived yesterday from Charleston, S.C., was nearly two months in making the voyage, and had been given up by many as lost. Capt. Sharp reports that the schooner sailed from Charleston on March 26. On the fifth day out a violent gale ...

The champion ball-players of Boston are unhappy. They came here yesterday after a succession of victories, and were fully confident of defeating the New-York team. In this they made an error, and before the game was ended they had changed their opinion in regard to the ability of the representatives of this city.

Thomas Crough died on Monday at his home, No. 49 South Eleventh-street, Brooklyn, and his funeral was to have taken place yesterday. Mr. Crough had been a volunteer fireman, and some of his old associates assembled for the purpose of attending the funeral ceremonies.

WASHINGTON, May 22.--Had Mr. Stanton J. Peelle chosen to vote in his own behalf today, the seat in Congress which he has occupied as a Representative from the Seventh Indiana District would not have been given, as it was, to young William E. English, the son of the exDemocratic candidate for Vice-President. The proceedings to-day occupied several hours, and the House was in an uproar a good portion of the time.

DETROIT, Mich., May 22.--The American Baptist Publication Society, having its headquarters in Philadelphia, continued its meetings to-day. There were fully 1,500 delegates from all the States present.

The Tribune seems disturbed by the telegraphic news that the Cesnola antiquities at the Lawrence sale in London went for prices so trivial as reported, and meets the difficulty by denying that the objects in question ever formed part of Col. Cesnola's collection.

CHICAGO, May 22.--A serious row has broken out in the Western Export Association. A Des Moines distiller who refused to pay has assessment has been selling whisky in Cincinnati, and has broken the market there several cents.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., May 22.--A dispatch to the Journal from Winnipeg, Man., says the body of a wealthy Englishman named Falkenbridge was found in a bed at a hotel there today under circumstances indicating murder.

GREENSBORO, Ga., May 22.--The little village of Sharon, in Taliaferro County, one of the oldest in the State, is stirred up over a social sensation such as has never before disturbed it it the 84 years of its history.

LONDON, May 22.--The Anchor Line steamer Castalia, Capt. Ward, from Palermo for New-York, is grounded off Denia, Spain. She is in a bad position and has jettisoned part of her cargo. Rough weather prevents assistance from reaching her.
Nearly 200 men assembled at No. 209 West-street, in answer to an advertisement which appeared Wednesday in a German newspaper of this city and asked for 100 hands to work in a fish factory.

Some curiosity was developed in railroad and telegraph circles yesterday as to the new association of business men called in the articles of incorporation the Traders and Travelers' Union (co-operative.) The articles declared among other things that the subscribers unite their ...

CITY OF MEXICO, May 22, via Galveston.-- It is officially reported that Chief Salinas, Cipriano Arrayo, and Pedro Herrera, the trainwreckers captured by the Government forces, attempted to escape while on their way to Celaya and were all killed.

CAIRO, May 23.--Advices from Suakin state that pilgrims have arrived there from Berber, having been 18 days on their journey. They report that the tribes along their route were anxious to learn any news of the siege at Khartoum and Berber, as on the result thereof depends the success of the rebels.

The intercollegiate athletic meeting will be held to-day on the Manhattan Athletic Club Grounds, at Eighty-sixth-street and Eighthavenue. This is one of the great days for the colleges, and crowds of people generally witness the sports. Thirteen of the 17 colleges will be...

PITTSBURG, Penn., May 23.--This morning, in the Court of Common Pleas, was filed a petition of the rolling mill firms of Allegheny County praying for the granting of a license for a trade tribunal under the Wallace act, providing for voluntary trade tribunals.
MILFORD, Penn., May 23.--John P. Fletcher and a man named Johnson picked the lock of the Pike County Jail with a piece of tin last night and escaped.
Gen. W.L. Wooford, one of the most prominent of Georgia politicians, died at his home, in Cartersville, Ga., yesterday.

PARIS, May 23.--Levi P. Morton, the American Minister to France, has written a letter to Prime Minister Ferry denying that the House of Representatives had rejected the bill reducing the duty on works of art to 10 percent., or that the House applauded the vote.
MONTREAL, Quebec, May 23.--It is reported that the Bank of Montreal exported $8,000,000 in gold to New-York during the recent financial trouble in that city.

Mischievous rumors, detrimental to the financial standing of certain Wall-street banking houses and bankers' firms, have been so numerous of late that an organized effort is to be made to search out and punish their originators.

The Siamese Princes Nares and Sonapandit were the guests of the Police Department yesterday. They, the members of their suite, the interpreter, and Consul I.T. Smith were taken in carriages from the Fifth-Avenue Hotel in the morning by Commissioners French, Mason, and...

An inquest was held yesterday by Coroner Merkle in regard to the death of Mary Schenck, who was found on the pavement at Seventh-street and Second-avenue at 1:30 Thursday morning, and who was subsequently taken to Bellevue Hospital, where she died. The cause of death was rupture of the stomach.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 23.--While the congregation of Franklin-Street Presbyterian Church were singing the next to the last hymn, toward the close of the service Sunday evening, the shrill tones of a lady's voice were heard above the volume of melody.
CANANDAIGUA, N.Y., May 23.--The trial of William H. Francis for the murder of an old man named Hawkins was resumed to-day before Judge Dwight, of the Supreme Court.
NEW-ORLEANS, La., May 23.--Yesterday James A. Charbonnet, for 18 years clerk in the office of the United States Circuit Court in this city, died after a prolonged illness.

DES MOINES, Iowa, May 23.--The following case was decided in the United States Circuit Court today: Ou nov. 9,1882, George F. Hall, at Des Moines, at 8 A. M., gave the following message to the telegraph company: "Charles T. Hall, Exchange, Oil City, Penn.--Buy 10,000 if you think it Safe. Wire me."
PITTSBURG, Penn., May 23.--Notice has been given that an application will be made for a charter for the Western Pennsylvania Telegraph Company.

A second alarm was sent out last night for a fire which started from a gas-jet in Barnett Worken's millinery store, No. 500 Grandstreet. Worken, his wife, and child were asleep in a rear room, and they easily escaped to the street.

Schedules in the matter of the assignment of William F. Owens and George A. Mercer, stock brokers, for the benefit of their creditors, to Freling H. Smith, were filed in the Court of Common Pleas yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 23.--Major Ezra B. Kirk, Quartermaster, has been appointed to act as Inspector on certain recruiting property at the recruiting rendezvous, Louisville, Ky., reported as unserviceable and requiring the action of an Inspector, and for which Capt. Alexander B. MacGowan, Twelfth Infantry, recruiting...

There was a "May festival" held on Thursday afternoon at the Hoppock place, at Hastingson-the-Hudson, which was attended by a large number of the wealthy families now occupying their Summer residences in that neighborhood. Among the number was Miss Armenia Baird, daughter of Prof. Baird, of the New-York University, who lives at Yonkers.

A general meeting of lawyers was held in the room of the Supreme Court, General Term, yesterday, for the expression of the sentiment of the Bar at the loss it has experienced in the death of Charles O'Conor.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 23.--There was a good attendance at the races here to-day. The weather was warm and the track in good condition.
LIVERPOOL, May 23.--A leading weekly grain circular says: "Grain is dull. There is but little business on the spot. The tendency is rather weaker.

RICHMOND, Va., May 23.--The significance of the result of the town elections held in this State yesterday is to be found in Mahone's avoidance of making a contest in any of the white districts. One of the principal reasons for this course was to avoid the issue of Republicanism which would have been forced upon Mahone.

CONCORD, N.H., May 23.--It is reported here to-night on the best authority that the Boston and Lowell Railroad has leased the Northern and the Boston-Concord, and Montreal Railroads for 99 years, and that the papers were executed in Boston to-day. It is also stated that the first named corporation has laid plans for the election of a Board of Directors favorable to it at the annual meeting of the Concord Road next Tuesday.
SHREVEPORT, La., May 23.--The river has fallen 13 inches. The levee on Thomas C. Johnson's place gave way last night, doing much damage.

WASHINGTON, May 23.--J.O.P. Burnside and S.R. Bond, of this city, who went to NewYork in the interests of creditors of the missing oil broker, Levis, returned to Washington to-day and have called a meeting of the creditors for tomorrow, at which they will make their report.
Edward Losey and his father, James J., became engaged in a fistic encounter in Colesstreet, Jersey City, on Thursday night.

While playing in a barn yesterday afternoon, at Newark, Lulu Finnegan, aged 5, was shot and instantly killed by her cousin, Matthew Hennry, aged 10. The boy was playing with a gun kept for shooting rats, when it was discharged, the ball taking effect in the girl's brain. Death resulted instantly.

ERIE, Penn., May 24.--Adam Brabender, President of the wrecked Erie County Bank in this city, did not carry out his resolve to emigrate, but clandestinely returned to Erie to-night. He was observed, and had not been home long before a hundred depositors congregated in front of his house.

WARSAW, N.Y., May 24.--Salt was struck this morning at the eight-inch well of the Warsaw Salt Company. The hole is 1,520 feet deep, and cost the company $3,500 and the contractor $6,000. A year has been spent drilling this hole. It is the largest salt well in the world, and will supply more brine than three ordinary wells.

PHILADELPHIA, May 24.--The fire at the Atlantic Oil-works, at Point Breeze, which broke out about 11 o'clock last night, raged furiously all night and during to-day. About a dozen storage tanks burst before sunrise, and a great deal of burning oil distributed itself over the neighborhood. Efforts were repeatedly but unsuccessfully made to run off the oil that was contained in the sound tanks.

PITTSBURG, Penn., May 24.--In the Court of Common Pleas, this morning, Judge Stowe granted the iron manufacturers a license for the creation of a voluntary tribunal to adjust disputes between the employers and the employes in the iron rolling mill trade, upon the condition that the assent and agreement of the necessary number of the employer be obtained.

BOSTON, Mass., May 24.--The match game of lacrosse this afternoon on Jarvis Field, Cambridge, between the teams of Harvard and Yale, attracted a fair-sized audience. Here is a piece of German repartee. A Frenchman said to a Berliner: "Your Iron Cross, the highest Prussian order, is simply ridiculous--it has an intrinsic value of scarce 5 sous." To which the native of the Prussian capital replied: "I don't deny it, but it has nevertheless cost you two Napoleons."

NEW-ORLEANS, May 24.--The people of this city were considerably astonished to hear, as they did during the forenoon, that the Governor had ordered the entire militia force of this city under arms, to be ready at a moment's warning to march to the town of New-Iberia, in Iberia Parish, to suppress rioters.

Kidder, Peabody Co., representing Baring Brothers Co., admitted that they were creditors to the amount of $149,600. ALBANY, May 23.--The Republicans of the State of New-York are now represented in Congress by only 13 out of the 34 members. To the tidal wave of 1882 was due this complete overturning of the Republican majority in the Congressional delegations of previous years. The reapportionment of the State by the Democratic Legislature of 1882 was intended to secure, if possible, a Democratic majority in the delegation.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 25.--A thorough yet unsuccessful search of all the institutions and hospitals, both private and public, was made by THE TIMES'S representative yesterday for Miss Arabella Hazard, who disappeared from Cincinnati more than a week ago.

OTTAWA, Ontario, May 25.--Chief Papot and the other Indians who were reported on the war-path, have been persuaded to give up the celebration of the sun dance this year, and are on the way to their reserves. Official reports from Qu'Appelle Valley are to the effect that everything is quiet.

The Spring meeting of the American Jockey Club will, as usual, begin on Decoration Day. On the first day the sport will open with a dash of three-quarters of a mile, with allowances to maidens of 3 and 4 years. This will be followed by a dash of one mile for 3-year olds and upward, with penalties and allowances.

ATLANTA, Ga., May 25.--The melon season, which will open soon, promises to be of great interest in many respects. Last year, when 8,000 car-loads were thrown upon the markets in the North and West, much loss was caused by bad shipments and poor selection of a market.

Leipsic newspapers report that the value of the property left by the lately deceased wellknown book-seller is estimated at 4,052,000 marks, (about 202,600,) together with a valuable piece of landed property.

DENVER, Col., May 25.--The six-day heeland-toe walking-match between William Edwards, champion of Australia, and Frank Hart, the colored pedestrian of Boston, for $1,000, was concluded at the rink here at midnight last night, Edwards winning by nine miles and five laps.

DETROIT, Mich., May 25.--At the meeting of the Baptist Missionary Union yesterday the Finance Committee recommended the raising of $400,000 for missionary work abroad.

The large hall of Cooper Institute was filled yesterday afternoon with an audience which has assembled to participate in the closing exercises of the season of the Manhattan Temperance Association and to witness the public taking of the temperance pledge by Company D, Twelfth Regiment, which has been recently recruited from among the members of the association.

WASHINGTON, May 25.--To-morrow's session of the House of Representatives will probably be devoted to the consideration of the Wallace-McKinley contested election case, although the day prescriptively belongs to the Committee on the District of Columbia.

GALVESTON, Texas, May 25.--Threefourths of the counties of the State held Democratic conventions yesterday to select delegates to the State Convention at Fort Worth on June 11, to elect delegates to Chicago. OMAHA, Neb., May 25.--Hanley, one of the principals in the late prize-fight which was organized in this city and fought in Saunders County, of this State, after a trial lasting a week, was yesterday sentenced to three years' hard labor in the penitentiary. The case is to be taken to the Supreme Court.

PARIS, May 25.--M. Ferry, in the Chamber of Deputies, yesterday presented a bill for the revision of the Constitution. It proposes to change the law relating to the election of Senators so that the office of Senator shall not be lifelong, but that the term shall be for nine years.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 25.--The lynching of Miles Petty, a negro, at Elizabethtown, Hardin County, two weeks ago for an alleged assault on Miss Vaunont, a white girl, has caused great excitement among the colored population in that county.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 25.--New-Haven people, and others throughout Connecticut, who were dealing in stocks through the brokerage firm of Owens Mercer, of New-York, and had cash balances in the hands of the firm at the time of its suspension, will not fare so badly as they at first supposed.

PARISH, N.Y., May. 25.--The people of this town take much interest in the Orton-Tillapaugh stabbing case, an account of which appeared in THE TIMES two weeks ago. Orton was born here, and passed the early years of his life in the village or its immediate neighborhood.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 25.--Two wellknown Huntington ladies, who reside a short distance out of this city, and who are respectively the wife and daughter of a wealthy farmer, were arrested in Birmingham yesterday for the commission of a series of curious and unexplained crimes in shoplifting.

ST. LOUIS, May 25.--A sickening tragedy occurred at No. 1,410 South Compton-avenue this morning. Mrs. Augusta Edmunds, while laboring under a temporary fit of insanity, cut the throats of her three little girls and then severed her own throat. Two of the girls are dead. The mother and remaining child are in a hopeless condition. This is the woman's second attempt at suicide.

WHEELING, West Va., May 25.--A few miles west of Bridgeport, Ohio, last evening, two boys, each 16 years old, named George Culp and Frank Wilkens were playing on the bank of the creek. Suddenly Culp drew a revolver and, pointing it at his companion, cried: "Guess I'll shoot you; look out." He immediately pulled the trigger. The ball passed thorough Wilken's neck, inflicting a fatal wound. Culp says he was only in fun.

The farmers between the villages of Setauket and Stony Brook, Long Island, varied the customary monotony on Sunday by fighting fire. A small fire in the woods was fanned into increasing flame by a southerly breeze, and as the afternoon waned, hundreds of acres of woodland were ablaze. In spite of the exertions of the farmers and their employes much valuable timber was destroyed.

ST. PAUL, Minn., May 25.--Dispatches from various points in Dakota indicate that the reversion of Judge Edgerton's decision in the Capital Commission case, gives pretty general satisfaction, except, of course, to Yankton, and a few South-eastern towns.

ERIE, Penn., May 25.--Adam Brabender the fugitive President of the broken Erie Savings Bank, is an inmate of the County Jail, in which he is confined at his own request, to escape threatened violence by the mob which surrounded his residence all last night.

PROVIDENCE, May 25.--The regatta between the Sophomore and Freshman six-oared crews--between the "blues" and the "reds"-- took place yesterday afternoon on the Seekonk River, in the presence of a large crowd of students and their lady and gentlemen friends.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 25.--At an early hour this morning at Savannah, on the West Shore Road, occurred one of the most disastrous and fatal railroad accident which has occurred in Western New-York in a number of years. TROY, N.Y., May 26.--The boiler in Moore Wilson's paper mill, on King's Canal, between Cohoes and Waterford, exploded to-night. A fire alarm was sounded, and the Fire Department responded. The mill was operating night and day. It is supposed that six persons have been burned to death. At 11:30 o'clock one body was taken out of the ruins.

CHICAGO, May 26.--The funeral of the late Alderman Michael Gaynor, who was shot and killed by James Dacey, a political rowdy, took place here to-day at St.Patrick's Church. The assembled crowd filled the church and the streets in its vicinity.

WASHINGTON, May 26.--The Controller of the Currency said to-day, in answer to inquiries, that the statement of the condition of the NewYork banks, which was published on Saturday, did not call for any action on his part, inasmuch as it was made up from the averages of the State banks, as well as national banks, composing the associated banks.
The Board of Aldermen will not meet again till Monday, June 9.
LONDON, May 26.--The Court of Chancery has granted the Duke of Marlborough permission to sell the paintings in Blenheim House.

PORT JERVIS, N.Y., May 26.--Johnnie Corwin, 7 years old, while playing on the bank of the canal here this afternoon, fell in, and was going down the last time when a lad named Bradley jumped in and succeeded in bringing him to the surface and back to the shore. Bradley is only 9 years old.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, May 26.--The Scott law test case will be heard by the Supreme Court to-morrow. The result will be awaited with much interest.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 26.--Delegates to the National Greenback Convention are beginning to arrive freely, and the buzz of political gossip fills the air. Dr. Leonard says he looks for 700 delegates and 10,000 visitors.

The man who was found drowned on Sunday morning in Mud Creek, near Far Rockaway, was yesterday identified as Nelson Cash. He was employed by Price Coppins, cartmen, in East Thirteenth-street. On Saturday last he was sent with a light wagon to J.D. Cheever, in Far Rockaway.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 26.--The President arrived here at 2 o'clock on a special train. Lieuts. Burwell, Bull, and Parker met him at the station. He and party were driven immediately to the Naval Academy and introduced to the officers. Then there was a salute and a parade of the cadets. The party lunched with Capt. Ramsay, the Superintendent. After witnessing a howitzer drill in the afternoon, the President returned to Washington.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 26.--The first day of the last week of the Spring meeting of the Louisville Jockey Club was attended by showery weather, which, however, did not interfere either with the attendance or the condition of the track. The track was in good condition for racing, the dust being well laid by the frequent light showers.

AUGUSTA, Me., May 26.--The Kennebec Journal will to-morrow authoritatively deny the published statements that Senators Hale and Frye are opposed to Mr. Blaine's nomination for the Presidency. The Journal says both of these gentlemen strongly favor his nomination.

About 11 o'clock last night William Martin, aged 52 years, living at No. 53 Camdenstreet, Newark, N.J., beat his wife, aged 48, with a sharp instrument, and after kicking her in a brutal manner threw her down stairs, where she lay unconscious for some time. ATLANTA, Ga., May 26.--The interest created in pedestrianism in Georgia by the recent walking matches is very great. Nearly every town is getting up contests. A match for the championship of Georgia has been arranged between Atlanta and Macon, to take place in the latter city on Saturday, June 7.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 26.--George Emerson Lowell, a son of Judge John Lowell, of the United States Circuit Court, and a resident of Chestnut Hill, Boston, Mass., commited suicide in this city this morning. Young Lowell was a graduate of Harvard College of the Class of '83 and 21 years old.

CALAIS, Me., May 26.--Reports from up up the river state that a very heavy thunderstorm passed over that region Saturday evening. Ten men on a raft of logs in Grand Lake were knocked senseless by lightning, and several were seriously burned. One child was fatally hurt and four others were more or less, seriously injured while playing in an outbuilding,which was struck by lightning and nearly destroyed.

MATAWAN, N.J., May 30.--Isaac Hall, a special student at Glenwood Institute, left his home at Perth Amboy last night to row to Matawan. Hall was extremely popular among his fellow-students, and his death has cast a gloom over this place.

PITTSBURG, May 31.--At almost the last moment the danger of a long strike in the iron business has been averted by the manufacturers signing last year's scale, with some few additions. The conference committees met this morning to make a final effort to settle the question. The session was short, but decisive, for in less than half an hour the scale governing the wages was duly signed by the representatives of both sides.

WAUSAU, Wis., May 31.--William Thayer, of this city, shot and killed Frederick J. Beales, of Boonesville, N.Y., this morning. Both were clerks in the Marathon County Bank here.

CINCINNATI, May 31.--George Oliver was convicted of murder in the first degree to-day. A week ago to-day the Avondale "burker," Ben Johnson, was convicted in the first degree, and during the week Mary Savage was convicted of manslaughter.

A singular accident occurred the other day in Essex County. A six-year-old daughter of a farmer, playing in her father's barn, undertook to creep up from the cattle hay-rack through a scuttle to the hay-mow. Pushing open the trap door, which closed the spout leading to the manger, she had pushed herself partly through when the door fell, and catching her under the chin pinned her fast.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., June 1.--A short time ago J.H. Pitts, a prominent citizen of Monticello, as was printed in THE TIMES at that time, was driving along a cross-road near Bridgeville, and alighted from his wagon to kill a large black snake that he saw lying by the roadside. He attacked it with his whip, and it resented the assault so vigorously that Pitts was obliged to take to his heels.

Brevet Major-Gen. Henry W. Benham, formerly of the Corps of Engineers, United States Army, died yesterday at his late residence, No. 104 East Thirty-sixth-Street. His death was due to a complication of disorders, although up to within a week past he had been able to go about. He was surrounded in his last moments by Mrs. Benham and their two daughters, but his son, Lieut. Benham, is at present on duty in Washington Territory.

BALTIMORE, June 1.--Christopher Doyle, the hero of the Tivoli disaster of last Summer, was drowned to-day in Curtis Creek, near the city.

HANOVER, N.H., June 1.--The dispatch sent on Friday announcing the suspension of two Dartmouth College editors was erroneous. The Trustees were recommended to withhold their diplomas, but have taken no action.

CINCINNATI, June 9.--William Winselleiler, 24 years old, a workman in a watch-case factory at Newport, Ky., went to a house of illfame on Elm-street, Cincinnati, at 11:30 o'clock last night and cut the throat of one of the in mates named Nellie Barnett with a razor.

WASHINGTON, June 9.--The committee which has been investigating the star route trials will probably make no further effort to secure the attendance of ex-Senator Dorsey as a witness. Subpoenas, letters, and telegrams have been sent for him to appear, but their receipt has never been acknowledged.

A meeting of the Twentieth Ward Republican Association was held last evening at the Rink on Clermont-avenue, Brooklyn. The attendance was only fair. Resolutions were adopted indorsing the nomination of Blaine and Logan, and addresses eulogistic of the Chicago nominees were made by Gen. Conway, Timothy Cronin, H.W. Knight, and others.

On application of the United States Trust Company, Trustee of the first mortgage made by the New-York, West Shore and Buffalo Railway Company, under date of Aug. 5, 1881, to secure an issue of $50,000,000 of 5 per cent. bonds, exJudge Horace Russell and Theodore Houston have been appointed by Judge Charles F. Brown, ...

PETERSBURG, Va., June 9.--A heavy storm passed over Dinwiddie County yesterday afternoon, during which Phillis Paterson, residing near Poplar Grove, was struck and instantly killed by lightning. Another woman was stunned. The Baptist Church in the same vicinity was blown down and other damage done to property.
The Directors of the Louisville and Nashville Railroad held another protracted meeting yesterday to consider the plans submitted for a reorganization of the company.

The New-York Yacht Club will hold its annual regatta on Thursday next at 11 A. M. The yachts in starting will cross an imaginary line drawn from the judges' boat, anchored off Owl's Head, Long Island shore, ...

WASHINGTON, June 10.--Republicans of the sort who regard the party and its recent nominations at Chicago as invincible are devoting themselves to two subjects of discussion which indicate that under the boasting for Elaine and Logan there is fear that the Demoerats may make a good nomination at Chicago, and thus make the November fight end in a defeat for the Republicans.
WASHINGTON, June 10.---The Democratic Senators, aided by two or three Republicans, made another attempt to push the House Dioxican Pension bill through the Senate to-day, but did not succeed.

Sanitary Inspector Dr. John B. White and Officer Kennedy, of the sanitary squad, took a trip to Blissville, Lone Island, on May 10 to make their annual inspection of the swill-milk stables. They examined amone others the stables belonging to John F. Meyer. In one of them they found 31 cows fastened to stanchions.

The Special Grand Jury of the Court of Oyer and Terminer appeared before Judge Rarrett yesterday, and Foreman Merritt Trimble, after handing to the Judge a presentment, announced that the fury had completed its labors. Judge Barrett thanked the members for the faithful and patient manner in which they bad accomplished their work, and dismissed them.

For several seasons the Atlantic Yacht Club has had what yachtsmen call" hard luck" with its regattas, either a light wind or fog or both being the rule. ATLANTA, Ga., June 10.--The Supreme Court of Georgia to-day decided the case of the Southern Mutual Insurance Company. The company had accumulated a reserve fund of $1,200,000, and it was claimed by the company that the division of the surplus should be made only among the present policy-holders, and also ...

The Coney Island Jockey Club opened its June meeting yesterday in the usual successful manner, despite a clouded sky. as it did not rain the sport was not interfered with, and the dust rose in clouds at every movement of the horses.

Portions of the old Fox estate, comprising 260 1ots in One Hundred and Sixty-fifth, One Hundred and Sixty-seveath, and One Hundred and Sixty-ninth streets, Stebbins and Westchester avenues, and the Stebbins Boulevard, in the Twenty-third Ward, are to be sold at auction by James L. Wells, auctioneer, at the Exchange Sales-rooms, No. 11 Broadway, next Tuesday, beginning at noon.

Joseph New, game constable of the Township of Newtown, was arrested by Constable Meyers at 4 o'clock yester day morning on a charge of brutal assault preferred by his ward, Mary Felinck, 14 years of age. New, who is 56 years old, was arraigned before Justice McKenna.

A young man, slightly built and of medium height, stepped into Hall's Hotel, in Chatham-street, Monday night, about 9 o'clock, and registered as S. Montague, Newark, N.J. Yesterday morning another young man inquired at the hotel for Montague Levy.

SPRINGFIELD, Vt., June 10.--At 3 0'clck this morning the church bells rang out another alarm to the inhabitants, the experiences of yesterday's freshet seeming about to be repeated. From 70 A.M. the rain fell in torrents, and the brook soon resumed its dangerous proportions.

WASHINGTON, June 10.---Charles D. Colman, an attorney of Plymouth, Mich., in testimony given before the committee investigating the star route trials said that William A. Cook, one of the Government oounsel in the prosecution, accepted several hundred dollars to prevent the indictment of Dr. Colgrove, a star route oontractor.

While M. PASTEUR has been engaged in discovering a cure for hydrophobia, Col. HOUSTON, of Georgia, has discovered a cure for rattlesnake poisoning. In both cases the cure is brought about by inoculation with attenuated poison germs, and ...

POUGHKEEPIE, June 10.--Dull, leaden clouds and a chill atmosphere somewhat dampevened the ardor of the members of the Senior and Junior Classes of Vassar this morning while they prepared for Class Day exercises, which occurred this afternoon.

Mr. Gus Williams has inflicted a new popular melody upon the people, and the people seem to like it. "Pretty little dark blue eyes," which Mr. Williams sings in "Captain Mishler," bids fair to become as familar on the streets as "Sweet Violets."

ALBANY, June 10.--The Manning Democrats are watching with interest the canvass which the Hon. Reswell P. Flower is making for delegates to the State Convention. They proless to feel no uneasiness at the results of his labors.

By defeating the Louisville Club at Metropolitan Park yesterday the Mets took the load in the race for the championship of the American Association. This is the first time the Metropolitans have ever held the leading position, and they are now in the van with 21 games won and 8 defeats.

The decision of the Court of Appeals in the case of Martin L. Ehrgott against the city of New-York, which was handed down yesterday, not only awards the heaviest damages ever obtained against the city, but furnishes a precedent for nearly 20 similar cases now pending.

Anthony Comstook, of the Society for the Suppression of Vice, with his assistant, Joseph A. Britton, accompanied by Dectective Sergeants Doyle and Handy and Detective Phillips, of Superintendent Wailing's office, made a visit to No. 58 West Thirty-first-street yesterday.

The limit of time allowed to the Governor for the consideration of bills left in his hands at the close of the session of the Legislature expires with the present week. There are several measures of considerable importance still unsigned.
Col. J.O.P. Burnside, late disbursing otficer of the Post Office Department, to-day gave ball in the sum of $20,000, and was released from jail.

PHILADELPHIA, June 10.--The recent defalcation of Col. J.O.B. Burnside, a disbursing officer of the Post Office Department at Washington, was quickly followed by the flight from the national capital of George H. Levis, who had for a year or more been the manager there of an apparently prosperous petroleum brokerage business.

The nomination of Mr. Blaine does not change the views of its inexpediency that we have freely expressed. Harper's Weckly has said nothing upon this subject without careful consideration, and the fact of the nomination does not change its conviction, that the Republican campaign with the candidacy of Mr. Blaine must be a prolonged explanation and defense.

PHILADELPHIA, June 10.--The Criminal Court of Camden was the scene of more excite went this afternoon than on any occasion since the trial of Hunter for the murder of Armstrong. Judges Reed, Woolston, and Gaunt were on the bench.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., June 10.--One of the most brilliant weddings ever celebrated in Milwaukee occurred at 8:30 o'clock this evening, at All Saints' Episcopal Church, in the presence of a large and distinguished company.

QUEBEC, June 10.--There was an animated scene this afternoon in and about the Courthouse when the Eno case came up for a hearing on the application for the prisoner's release on a writ of habeas corpus.

The French language, in all its diversities, from the delicate accent of the Fauborg St. Germain to the dialect in use at Hoboken, was heard last night at the Masonic Temple, Twenty-thirdstreet and Sixth-avenue, on the occasion of the Masonic baptism and adoption of children by La Sinceriti Lodge, No. 373, F. and A.M.

WEST POINT, June 10.--The cadets tramped over the plain wrapped in their long gray overcoats this morning, and visitors sought sheltered corners on the hotel piazza. Thick clouds of fog and moisture hid the surrounding hill-tops from view. A cold north-east wind roughened the usually placid water of the Hudson into white-capped waves.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., June 10.--The people residing in the vicinity of Poke Hollow, a small mining village about four miles from this city, were startled from their slumbers last night by a loud report resembling the noise of an earthquake, and immediately followed by the shaking of their houses from the foundations, ...

Detective James K. Prise, of the Twentyninth Precinct, and his brother "Sam" went to the Bossmore Hotel on Monday evening for the purpose of watching a guest registered as C.J. Lambert, and who was suspected of being a sneakthief.

In Massachusetts, the old banner Republican State in the earlior days of the party, the feeling of dissatisfaction with the Chicago tioket is deep and aggressive.

The amendments to the Civil Service act of last year in this State mane some important changes in its scope and operation. They are included in two acts, chapter 357 and chapter 410, the latter bearing date five days later than the former.

A large hall in the Guernsey Building, No. 160 Broadway, was crowded yesterday afternoon with earnest business men from different parts of the State. They had been, called together to confer on the subject of tariff reform, and, if deemed expedient, to organize a NewYork State Revenue Reform League.

PITTSBURG, Penn., June 10.--This was the opening day of the Spring meeting of the Pittsburg Driving Park Association. A heavy rain fell for half an hour before the firs race, but the track was in good condition. The attendance was fair.

The funeral services of the late Gen. James Watson Webb were held yesterday morning in the Church of the Heavenly Rest, at 9 o'clock. The full surpliced choir of men and boys, headed by Assistant Bishop Potter, the Rev. Drs. S.H. Weston, E.J. Donald, and D.P. Morgan, marched in from the, vestry, singing as a processional hymn "Asleep in Jesus."
