The reckless waste of Croton water in this city has caused Chief Engineer Isaac Newton to address a letter to Commissioner Thompson calling his attention to the facts in the case, and urging him to appeal to the public to assist the department in economizing the supply.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 10.--When the people of this city and their guests awoke this morning to begin the second day of the semicentennial celebration it was to find the torrid heat of yesterday changed to an uncomfortable chilliness, and the blazing sun and baked pavement or yesterday replaced by cloudy skies and muddy streets.

Ex-Senator Roscoe Conkling was more than usually radiant and lovely when he sauntered into the Surrogate's Court yesterday morning to continue the inquisition, of which Dr. George M. Dillon is the victim, concerning the mental and physical condition of the late Jesse Hoyt, whose will is contested by his daughter.

The sub-committee of the Congressional Committee on Public Buildings and Grounds, which is at present taking testimony in Brooklyn relative to the manner in which the site for the proposed Federal building in Washingtonstreet was acquired, was told by Postmaster James McLeer, yesterday, that the site was not suitable.

As Keeper George Oesterriecher, of the Tombs, passed the cell of John Carpenter, the man who killed his wife and then tried to kill himself in a Third-avenue saloon on May 22, soon after 7 o'clock yesterday morning, he noticed the murderer walking back and forth with a sheet wrapped around his body.

STOCKTON, Cal., June 10.--The Democratic State Convention met here this morning with John H. Wise in the chair. In his opening address he said: "Let us, Democrats of California, send a delegation to Chicago for the old ticket-- Tilden and Hendricks.

The Executive Committee of the Independent Democracy of this city met last evening at Everett Hall, in East Fourth-street. Among the 100 persons present, representing every district in the city, were the Hon. James O'Brien, ex-Coroner Ellinger, ex-Judge Orlando L. Stewurt, ex-Judge Goedlet, John Mullady, Jerome Buck, the Hon. Charles Mallon, John Moncks, Cot. Charles K. Deutsch, James McGovern, exJudge Alker, David Hersch, and Capt. Jacob Hayes.

CAIRO, June 10.--Reports have reached here to the effect that the rebels, nine days ago, massacred Hussein Pasha Khalifa, commander at Berber, and all his family; the garrison, which was faithful to the Khedive, and the European traders who remained there.

The troubles in the Louisville and Nashvine Railroad Company continue to increase, and every day apparently brings forth a fresh complication. President J.S. Rogers handed in his resignation yesterday and declined to have any further voles in its affairs either as President or Director.

PHILADELPHIA, June 10.--The New-York nine won its fourth consecutive victory over the Philadelphias at Recreation Park to-day by a score of 10 to 6. Weak pitching, bad fielding, and one decision of the umpire which gave the New-Yorkers 6 runs were responsible for the defeat.

WASHINGTON, Jnne 10.--The following changes in the stations and duties of officers of the Corps of Engineers have been ordered: Major Jared A. Smith, in addition to his present Buttes, will report by letter to the Secretary of the Treasury for duty as engineer ...

Our Richmond dispatch says that it is believed there that Mr. BLAINE will take the stump in support of his own candidacy. This course would be somewhat unusual, but Mr. BLAINE is not a commonplace man, and he would not be very likely to refrain from stump-speech making because of late years candidates for the Presidency have left to others the task of firing the popular heart.

LONDON, June 11.--In the House of Commons to-day, Lord Edmund Fitzmaurice, Under Foreign Secretary, said that the report which reached London yesterday of an extensive massaere at Berber on June 1 was very difficult to believe.

WASHINGTON, June 11.--The Secretary of War, having learned officially by the record of the court of inquiry in the case of Gen. D.G. Swaim, of the action of Col. A.P. Morrow, Sixth Cavalry, in duplicating, triplicating, and even quadruplicating his pay accounts, has decided to order a court-martial for the trial of that officer.

A large number of imported Jersey cattle, the property of T.S. Cooper, of Linden Grove, Coopersburg, Penn., was sold yesterday at the Horse Exchange, at Broadway and Fiftieth-street. Although a few of the best cows did not bring the prices that were expected, the general average realized was very good and satisfactory to the owner.

The weather yesterday was cold and cloudy at Brighton Beach, but, nevertheless, a large crowd gathered at the track to witness the sport provided by the association. There were five races, and the favorites were successful in three of them.

Milton H. Smith, of Louisville, Ky., the First Vice-President and General Manager of the Louisville and Nashville Railroad, was yesterday elected President of the road, in place of J.S. Rogers, who resigned. A.M. Quarrier, the assistant to the President, and for years in charge of the finance and counting department, was made Vice-President, to take the place of Mr. Smith, Robert K. Warren, of the New-York office, ...

Application for an order authorizing an investigation into the managoment of the Park Department was made before Judge Lawrence, in the Supreme Court, late on Tuesday afternoon, by five citizens, representing the Council of Reform. Judge Lawrence kept the papers of the application until yesterday, when he refused to act in the matter, for the reason that he is related by marriage to Park Commissioner Olliffe.

Miss Viola Blodgett, a daughtor of the late Charles F. Blodgett, was married to Mr. James Armstrong Renwick, yesterday afternoon, in St. Mark's Church in the Bowerie. The Rector of the church, the Rev. Dr. Rylance, performed the ceremony. The bride wore white satin, trimmed on the front of the skirt with flounces of duchesse lace. Her veil was of tulle and secured with orange blossoms.

Two small-boys in Brooklyn, aged respectively nine and eleven, rose in insurrection against oat-meal the other day and ran away, taking a shovel with them. They proposed to live in the open air, and subsist upon potatoes to be dug with the shovel. Indeed, they were ready to face any hardship in order to escape from oatmeal.

WATERTOWN, June 11.--This has been a busy day for the Flower and Cleveland Democrats of St. Lawrence County. Money flowed like water, and victory can hardly be reckoned to-night. In the Second Assembly District Convention at Canton, which was distinguished for disorder, a Cleveland delegate moved to proceed to perfect the temporary organization, ...

The one hundred and thirtieth Commencement of Columbia College took place yesterday morning in the Academy of Music. The boxes and orchestra stalls were well filled with the admiring throng of sisters, cousins, and aunts who had gone to see the dear boys fairly launched into the "wide, wide world." At 10:30 the procession, headed by President Barnard, the Board ...

The Republicans who hope for the election of Mr. Blaine and the adoption of a "brilliant foreign policy" found a spokesman yesterday in Mr. McCoid, of Iowa, who, in the course of a speech on the River and Harbor bill, pitched into the members who have presumed to criticise appropriations for river and harbor subsidies and other schemes for spending the public money.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 11.--Five years ago Miss Butterfield, daughter of John Butterfield, once the proprietor of the hotel of that name in Utica, and a niece of Gen. Butterfield, of New-York, lost her heart to Lynhart Chubbick, a young and handsome clerk in a Utica store.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., June 11.--The annual meeting of the Milwaukee, Lake Shore and Western Railway was held at the general offices in this city to-day, 56,000 out of the 60,000 shares being represented. This line is owned almost exclusively by New-York capitalists.

The twelfth annual regatta of the Hudson River Yacht Club was sailed yesterday up the Hudson River to Yonkers and return. Of the 26 vessels entered in the race, 19 started and 16 finished. Stephen Bridge, William H. Arndt, J. Reisenweber, J.T. Hufnagle, and O. Chatfield had charge of the regatta, and Capt. H.H. Holmes, John W. Browning, J.T. Lynch, and Commodore Foulks acted as judges.

Mr. TILDEN'S letter is almost wholly retrospective. He recalls his letter of 1880 and the position he then took in declining the Democratic nomination. He places again in full view his services in the movement to reform the municipal government of this city and his administration as Governor of the State of New-York.

The publication of the subjoined letter from ex-Gov. Samuel J. Tilden to the Chairman of the Democratic State Committee has been foreshadowed in the Political dispatches of THE TIMES. As it was expected he would, Mr. Tilden refuses to again enter the Presidential race:

Meetings have been called of the stockholders of the Metropolitan, the NewYork, and the Manhattan Elevated Railroad Companies for the purpose of ratifying the agreement recently entered into by conference committees of the three corporations.

The Irving Hall Democrats held their primaries in nearly all the Assembly districts last night. With very few exceptions, the delegates were instructed for or are understood to favor the "old ticket." Several are, however, in favor of nominating Gov. Cleveland for President.

ATLANTA, Ga., June 11.--"I'll bet ten to one on the tall gal," said an excited sportsman in the armory of the Gate City Guards last night. Inside a singular sight was seen. The hall was fairly packed with the elite of Peach Tree and Decatur-street society. Fair belles, in all the profusion of extravagant dressing, and dudes wearing eye-glasses faintly cheered.

WASHINGTON, June 11.--In its action upon the Consular and Diplomatic Appropriation bill to-day the Senate introduced an innovation in the methods of legislating upon important public measures. The bill was called up at the earliest moment it could be reached under the rules, and Mr. Alliso repeated his tactics of yesterday by demanding a secret session, the only ...

BANGOR, June 11.--The Democratic State Convention will meet here next Tuesday for the selection of four delegates to the National Convention at Chicago and a candidate for Governor. The position of the Maine Democrats may now be stated definitely so far as the eastern and central portion of the State is conerned.

BUFFALO, June 11.--The Democratic caucuses to elect delegates to the conventions of the three Assembly districts in this city were held last evening. They were pretty generally contested, and it is not clear even yet what the contest was about. All the tickets were headed with Gov. Cleveland's name as a Presidential candidate, and no one confessed that he was not for Cleveland.

Lilly Severin, an attractive looking young Jowess, 15 years of age, was to be seen a few weeks ago behind the glove counter in Bloomingdale's store, at Third-avenue and Fifty-sixthstreet. She lived with her parents, Philip and Pauline Severin, respectable people, at No. 451 East One Hundred and Seventeenth-street. Mr. Severin is the superintendent of a down-town clothing store, and in good circumstances.
CHICAGO, June 11.--July 7, the day before the Democratic Convention opens, will see over a dozen clubs representing strong Jeffersonian principles assembled here from all parts of the country.

Not since the opening of the great bridge has Brooklyn seen her streets so crowded, and not since that event have the decorations of her public and private buildings been so elaborate, as yesterday, when the Society of the Army of the Potomac became the honored guest of the city and held its fifteenth annual reunion. The passage to its first reading of M. NAQUET'S bill permitting divorce in France by so decisive a vote as 156 to 115 indicates' that a revolution in the French law is impending. The advocate of the bill was probably within the facts when he declared that he "had the press and the country on his side."

The Joint Executive Committee, Freight Department, met yesterday, at Commissioner Fink's office, for the purpose of considering a modification of the contract for the division of the Chicago business, and the recommendation of Commissioner Fink for a revision of the percentages.

CLEVELAND, June 11.--Isaac A. Stanley, Paying Teller of the National Bank of Commerce, wns arrested this evening for embezzling $100,000 of the bank's funds. The fact has created a sensation throughout the city. The embezzlement and the discovery show a strange complication of affairs.

CHICAGO, June 11.--To-day Justice Harlan gave decisions in the cases heard before him this term, among them being the famous. "F. W." cases, in which John Flemming and Frank Loring are the defendants. Some time ago a party of bucket-shop operators organized the firm of Flemming Merriam in this city, and ...

The annual regatta of the New-York Yacht Club will be sailed to-day over the club course, which is from Bay Ridge along the west bank to the Sandy Hook Light-ship, then returning to a point in the Lower Bay a short distance below Fort Wadsworth. The length of the course is 38 nautical miles. The start will take place as near 11 o'clock as possible.

POUGHKEEPSIE, June 11.--Vassar had its commencement exercises to-day. The chapel was opened at 10:30 A.M., but long before that time the reception-rooms, parlors, and main corridor of the institution were filled with ladies and gentlemen, and mingling among them were members of the Senior Class and undergraduates endeavoring to make things generally pleasant.
The following securities were sold at auction in the Exchange Sales-room yesterday by Adrian H. Muller Son:
PITTSBURG, Penn., June 11.--The races were continued here to-day. The weather was fine, the track still, and the attendance fair.

WEST POINT, June 11.--The long-lookedfor visitors have come at last, but the fine weather has gone. A foggy, drizzly atmosphere makes everything and everybody damp and uncomfortable. The President and Secretary Lincoln are not expand before Friday afternoon. They will both be guests of Gen. Merritt, with Gen. Sheridan and Gen. Crook. Gen. Sheridan arrived to-day.

The inventory and schedules of the firm of O.M. Bogart Co., bankers and note brokers, who recently made an assignment for the benefit of their creditors to ex-Tax Commissioner John Wheeler, were filed in the Court of Common Pleas yesterday.

The "cave-in" of the village of Poke Hollow, in Pennsylvania, is perhaps the most extensive and disastrous accident of this kind in the annals of coal mining. The collapse showed how completely the surface of the ground over coal mines that have been worked for a long time comes to be honeycombed.

CURWINSVILLE, Penn., June 11.--This town has been visted by another disastrous flood, the second within three months. A storm of teriffic force broke over the town early last evening and the rainfell incessantly during the night. At 1 o'olock this morning Anderson Creek, which divides the town and empties into the west branch of the Susquehanna River, ...
ST. LOUIS, Mo., June 11.--The Spring meeting of the St. Louis Jockey Club opened today with clear and warm weather and a good attendance. The track was damp, but not muddy.

ALBANY, June 11.--There is great rejoicing here this evening among those Democrats who adhere to the fortunes of Gov. Cleveland and hope to see him installed in the Presidential chair. Daniel Manning returned this morning from a visit to Samuel J. Tilden, at Greystone, ...

The Executive Committee of the Brooklyn Young Republican Club held its firs meeting since the Chicago Convention in the Brooklyn Library Building last evening. There was great interest, and a full and thorough discussion of the duty of the club toward the Republican nominees.
WASHINGTON, June 11.--Mr. Butler offered the following resolution in the Senate today, which, under objection, went over one day:

Herr Von Eisendecker, the German Minister, called at the White House to-day, in company with the Secretary of State, and presented his letters of recall to the President. The usual formal speeches were exchanged.

BALTIMORE, Md., June 11.--On a mudscow anchored near the Seven Foot Knoll in the Chesapeake Bay a party of Baltimore society people spent the whole of last night in a drenching rain and cold wind. Forty young ladies and gentlemen passed through the terrors of a shipwreck and many of them barely escaped with their lives.

By invitation of the officials of the West Shore Road, a large number of prominent civil engineers went by special train to Buffalo on Monday, leaving the Weehawken station at 8:30 A.M., and reaching Buffalo a little after 10 o'clock the same evening. It was the first trip which a majority of the party had made over the new trunk line.

The report for the last quarter of the fiscal year of the Western Union Telegraph Company was presented by the President, Dr. Norvin Green, at a meeting of the Board of Directors yesterday. The report says that the net revenues for the quarter ended March 31 were $1,634,258.75, which, added to the surplus of $3,970,931.78 on Jan. 1, made a total of $5,605,190.53.

The limits of the revolt against the Republican nomination are not easy to define or even to ascertain. Its full strength can only be measured by the vote cast and the vote withheld in November. The press does not and will not give it complete expression.

BRADFORD, Penn., June 12.--The Producers' Association, which convened in this city yesterday, concluded its session this afternoon. It was probably the most important meeting ever held in the oil county.

Rumors about the condition and future of the Union Pacific Railroad were thick in Wallstreet yesterday, and the stook declined on them. Sidney Dillon, the President, was asked what truth there was in the report that a large amount, said to be $20,000,000, of the sinking fund had been used to support the stock.

PITTSBURG, Penn., June 12.--Helena Chindosch and Herman Androck were arrested and lodged in jail to-day, the former to answer to the charge of murdering her infant child and Herman Androck as an accessory. The case has many peculiar features.

READING, Penn., June 12.--Ex-Congressman Hiester clymer, who represented the Berks district four terms, died suddenly and unexpectedly shortly before 7 o'clock this morning from the effects of cerous apoplexy, aged 56. Up to 5:30 yesterday afternoon he was apparently in the enjoyment of excellent health.

PITTSBURG, June 12.--The races were continued here to-day. The weather was warm, the track fast, and the attendance good. The first race was for a purse of $400, of which $50 to the second; one mile. Starters: General Harding, (Bryant,) Boatman, (Withers,) Bouquet, (Miller.) Betting--General Harding, $100; the field, $25. General Harding won in a gallop by a length, with Boatman second and Bouquet a very bad third. Time--1:45. French pools paid $6.80.
The regatta and reception of the Atalanta Boat Club will take place to-morrow at the club-house on Harlem River at 3 P.M.

The qualifications of Mr. Grover Cleveland for the Presidency do not exist out of sight. The American people have carefully studied his actions and bearing for three years past. He is one of the rare men who has exceeded the expectations of the sanguine nad refuted the predictions of the cynical.

The reason that the opening of Starin's Glen Island, in Long Island Sound, yesterday, was not a popular outpouring was all on account of the weather. Through a mistake of the Olympian entry clerk the weather god was unaware of Mr. Starin's projected opening until noon, and then he discharged the sub-recording angel and cleared things up. But it was too late.

Amid the ferns, plants, and flowers which decorated the stage in the First Methodist Episcopal Church at Hoboken last night sat 42 proud and happy young graduates, resplendent in evening dress, who constituted the twelfth graduating class of the Stevens Institute of Technology.

The senate has in the last few days adopted the extraordinary course of discussing an item of the Consular and Diplomatic Appropriation bill in secret session. The sum involved is $250,000, and the ostensible purpose of the appropriation is the execution of the neutrality laws.

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 12.--New arrivals have come by steam-boat and by train since early morn, but not for many years has there been so few people here on the night of the graduating class ball as there are to-night. The June season promies to be dull to the last.

FLOWER is "prominently mentioned" in connection with the Democratic nomination is moved to inquire who Mr. FLOWER is and why he should be prominently mentioned.

The Society of the Army of the Potomac passed the second and last day of its reunion yesterday in the enjoyment of an excursion tendered the members by the city of Brooklyn, and a banquet at Manhattan Beach in the evening.

At a dinner given last evening to Gen. Guzman Blanco, ex-President of Venezuela, at Delmonico's, ex-Mayor Grace, who presided, proposed the health of the guest of the evening. Gen. Blanco, he said, had had the great honor of serving as constitutional President of Venezuela for two terms, comprising a period of seven years.

PINE VALLEY, Penn., June 12.--Jabez Graul and Josiah Willig, both farmers, reside in this neighborhood. On Wednesday Willig went off to market, intending to be absent two days. That night found Graul at the Willig domicile for the night, despits the remonstrance of the woman's eldest son, who left the house and stopped over night at the residence of a neighboring friend.

BOSTON, June 12.--A fire started this afternoon about 1 o'clock in the centre of the third floor of the building Nos. 152 to 158 Congressstreet, occupied by Balderston Daggett, agents for the New-Brunswick and National Rubber Companies.

Before United States Commissioner John A. Osborn, yesterday afternoon, argument was heard on the application of the British Government for the extradition of Gerald T. Tully, the defaulting Sub-Manager of the Preston Banking Company, of Preston, England, who was arrested in this city on May 21.

In the last number of the Atlantic Mr. J.G. WOOD undertook to defend the seaserpent from the attacks which have been made upon him by unscrupulous scientific persons. Mr. WOOD marshaled the evidence in support of the existence of the sea-serpent, and pronounced it to be conclusive.

BOSTON, June 12.--A brilliant company was gathered in the old town of Concord this evening, on the occasion of the marriage of Samuel Bowles, the head of the Springfield Republican establishment, and Miss Elizabeth Hoar, the youngest daughter of Judge E. Rockwoo Hoar.

BRIDEHAMTON, Long Island, June 12.-- The steamer Bermauda, bound for New-York from the West Indies, went ashore off the village of Amagansett, on the eastern end of Long Island, at 4 o'clock this morning. A dense fog overhung the coast at the time.

ATLANTA, Ga., June 12.--Intense excitement exists in the city to-day over an assassination which took place at 1 o'clock this morning. There lives on Ezzard-street the family of Mr. Charles Rose, Yard Master of the Atlanta and Charlotte Air Line Road.

WASHINGTON, June 12.--Nearly the whole session of the Senate to-day was spent in a discussion of the Mexican pension bill. The debate took a very wide range and little progress was made. Mr. Harris took charge of the bill, but he had no sooner called it up than Mr. Cullom asked to have it laid over until to-morrow that he might obtain some estimates from the Pension Office.

GLEN COVE, Long Island, June 12.--The peace-loving little village of Glen Cove was much startled yesterday afternoon by the widely circulated report that Elwood D. Lincoln, one of the best-Known young men of this part of Long Island, had deserted his bride at the altar, and had started for the South with a young lady who was reported to have a deserted her groom a few days ago.

The parade of the Fire Department and presentation of medals to two of its members attracted several thousand persons to Washington-square yesterday afternoon. A grand nand was erected in the shade of a grove of ailanthus trees at the head of South Fifth-avenue, on the southern side of the park.

An informal and social opening of the Health Home on Coney Island, a branch of the Children's Aid Society, took place yesterday afternoon. The party of ladies and gentlemen who attended it first visited the Summer Home at Bath, which was the gift of Mr. A.B. Stone.

Abaullhas had collected 100,000 men around Berber.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., June 13.--The money market is in a high state of fever. The banks, by calling in loans, have placed themselves in a tolerably safe condition, but mercantile houses are toppling over and going down every day. To-day the large cotton house of Hunt, Stewart Co. suspended.
LONDON, June 13.--The Tichborne claimant is to be released from prison on a ticket-ofleave.

NEW-HAVEN, June 13.--Society circles in this city to-day were startled by the fact that George Hinckley Jennings, the son of a wellknown business man and a book-keeper at J.B. Sargent Co.'s malleable iron-works, had pleaded guilty to theft, and had been sent to jail from the police court for six months.

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 13.--The crowds of handsome women who came here purposely to attend the graduating class ball vanished with the night. When the cadets marched out in the new white suits for a skirmish drill this morning, the place was almost deserted.
PITTSBURG, Penn., June 13.--The races were continued here to-day. The weather was warm, the track fast, and the attendance good.

TROY, June 13.--This morning the towboat Connecticut, formerly a passenger steamboat running between this city and New-York, reached Albany with a flotilla. "Commodore" Temple, the old riverman, was in charge.

Lowering clouds and a thick fog hung over the Upper Bay yesterday morning, and gusts of pelting rain swept over the waters, when the tug E. Luckenboch, having on board the Regatta Committee of the New-York Yacht Club, put off from Pier No. 3 East River and headed down the Bay.

The Metropolitans again defeated the Toledo Club yesterday, but it was after 10 innings and a very well-played game. The Toledo men have surprised the "Mets" by their good form, and instead of having a "walk-over" the local men have to play as well as they know how to win.

DETROIT June 13.--The second annual meeting of the Travelers' Protective Association of the United States was held here to-day. The objects of the association are the general improvement of the character and condition of the commercial travelers of the country.

PROVIDENCE, June 18.--The day which is distinctively the occasion of Commencement Week was celebrated here to-day with great brilliancy on the part of the Class of '84. The sky was more or less overcast during the day, with a growing tendency to clearing.
The Rev. Phillips Brooks is to preach the Baccalaureate sermon to the graduating class of Harvard College to-morrow.

WASHINGTON, June 13.--The Hon. Richard T. Merrick, of Government counsel in the star route prosecutions, was examined to-day by the committee investigating the trial of those cases. Messrs. Ker and Bliss were present. Throughout his testimony Mr. Merrick confined himself to facts and declined to express opinions.

William H. Vanderbilt arrived here late last evening, by the steam-ship Eros, which was sighted off Fire Island about dusk. The vessel did not come up to the city, but Mr. Vanderbilt was taken on board the mail tug and brought up, arriving at the Battery about 9 P.M.

COLUMBUS, Ga., June 14.--Mary Harvey, living on Jackson-street, attempted suicide by hanging. Her husband whipped her for some cause, and after he left she obtained a piece of rope, and, fastening one end around her neck, mounted a box and tied the other end to the limb of a China tree. She then kicked the box over, which left her suspended.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 15.--A sad drowning accident occurred at Fair Haven last night. The Columbus and Metropolitan Clubs crossed bats for the first time this season at Metropolitan Park yesterday, in the presence of 1,500 persons.

He was accompanied by Senator Eugene Hale, of Maine. The party left Boston at 9 o'clock in the morning. At Portland they were met at the depot by Collector ...

SCRANTON, Penn., June 16.--Several of the Scranton fire companies and a large force of miners have been at work all day endeavoring to extinguish a fierce fire which broke out early yesterday morning lu a culm-heap adjoining the Stetler Colliery, near Pittston, and which threatened the destruction of $250,000 worth of property, including the breaker.

Charles B. Thorpe owed Mrs. Eliza Blackwell, of No. 226 West Fortieth-street, for two months' board. When she asked him for the money he handed her a check on the Sixth National Bank for $26.85, signed by Newman, Fernbacher Co., undertakers, at No. 329 Bowery.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 16.--Thomas Ryan, of Hudson, a convalescing inmate of the Hudson River State Hospital, during the tem porary absence of the attendant yesterday cut his throat. He died in a few minutes.

The bronzed and genial features of Capt. William McMickan, which are as well known on the docks at Liverpool as on the wooden structures of West-street, this city, were seen yesterday in the dim recesses of the Brevoort House parlor by a TIMES reporter. Capt. McMickan had just completed his first trip in command of the Oregon, the recent acquisition of the Cunard ...

WHEELING, West Va., June 16.--An accident occurred at the water-works this evening by which one man lost his life. A well 52 feet deep, intended to receive a new pump, had just been completed, and the men, 10 in number, had been hoisted to the surface, when the timber lining gave way on all sides and the well caved in.
CINCINNATI, Ohio, June 16.--A meeting was held in the Burnett House parlors this afternoon to organize a movement in favor of Thurman. It was composed largely of friends of Senator Pendleton.

ATLANTA, Ga., June 16.--Delegates are arriving to-night to attend the State Convention, which meets here on Wednesday. The prevailing sentiment is in favor of instructing the Georgia delegates to Chicago to vote for Gov. Cleveland. Bayard's Dover speech throws a damper on the movement in his favor.

Mr. CYRUS W. FIELD has written a letter to THE TIMES asking for information on a matter of serious interest to him. He incloses copies of Judge VAN BRUNT'S opinion and findings in the suit of the Metropolitan Elevated Railway Company against the Manhattan and New-York Elevated Railroad Companies.

PORTLAND, Oregon, June 16.--The anual elections of the Oregon Railway and Navigation, Oregon Transcontinental, Oregon Improvement, and the Northern Pacific Terminal Companies were held here to-day. The following Directors were elected:

LONDON, June 16.--The Mark-Lane Express, in its weekly review of the British grain trade, says: "There have been scanty offerings of English wheat. The trade in foreign wheat off stands has not improved. The values are against the sellers.
The annual regatta of the Newark Yacht Club was sailed yesterday in Newark Bay. There was a good breeze from the south-west. The course was 10 miles in length, with two turns.

The Bridgeport (Conn.) Farmer, of June 14, gives some details of the killing of a boy in that city on Friday evening by the current from an electric light wire. "The wire," it says, "was securely hooked at the top, and hung, swaying in the wind, nearly reaching to the ground.
The County Democracy leave at 10:30 A.M. on special train from West Shore station, foot of West Forty-second-street. Tickets can be secured at station. HUBERT O. THOMPSON, Chairman. --Exchange.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., June 16.-The first of the college boat-races on the Thames will take place on Wednesday at 6 P.M., between the Harvard and Columbia University crews. Both crews pulled over the course on time this evening, and both crews covered the four miles in less than 25 minutes.

WASHINGTON, June 16.--Eager inquiries were heard to-day about the balls of the Capitol and in the cloak-rooms of the two houses as to the chances of an amicable settlement of the Democratic difficulties in the State Convention at Saratoga. While there is a fairly correct notion among the Democrats as to the nature of the disputes between the city ...

Since the opening of the Brooklyn bridge the receipts from passengers and vehicles have steadily increased, until now they average very nearly $50,000 a month. Some erroneous impressions having been spread abroad by means ...
INDIANAPOLIS, June 16.--Dr. Alexander Martin, President of Depauwe University at Green Castle, tendered his resignation to the Board of Trustees to-day. It was accepted.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., June 16.--The latest turn in the crank in the famous Myra Clark Gaines case was given to-night by Judge Billings, of the United States Court, in the case of G.T. Raoul against Myra Clark Gaines. Judgment is rendered for the paintiff in $10,000, and the assets, consisting of real estate in the jurisdiction ...

TROY, N.Y., June 16.--The police of Lansingburg and this city are looking for Alonzo Valentine, of No. 613 Whipple-avenue, in the burg. It is alleged by Ida Tallman, a little 12-year-old orphan girl, who resides with her ...

HARTFORD, Conn., June 16.--Tents are now being put up on Bushnell Park, and flags are flying and other decorations are displayed in the streets, in anticipation of the parade of Wednesday, when a statue of William A. Buckingham, war Governor of Connecticut, will be unveiled.

NORWICH, Conn., June 16.--The frost of Sunday morning and that of last night completed in Eastern Connecticut, Rhode Island, South-eastern Massachusetts, and probably throughout New-England, the work of the late May freeze. The June frosts were not so heavy as the frost of the "last Friday in May," ...

Many of the parents of the students of the Academy of the Sacred Heart, Clausen-onthe-Sound, Westchester, which is the Junior Department of Manhattan College, and a large number of the friends of the Brothers of the Christian Schools, assembled at the institute yesterday ...

BOSTON, Mass., June 16.-- W.F. Wade Sons, otherwise known as the New-England Hay Company, have failed. Liabilities, $25,000; nominal assets, $8,000. Arthur H. Bailey Co., dealers in canned goods, Commercial Wharf, have failed. Liabilities $19,000; assets, $8,000.
CINCINNATI, Ohio, June 16.--The announcement has been made to the congregation worshiping in St. Peter's Cathedral that marriages will hereafter be solemnized only in the morning.

NEWBURYPORT, Mass., June 16.--Richard H. Pinkham, aged 50 years, a business man of New-York, died suddenly at the Invalids' Home, in East Salisbury, last night. He was intending to return to New-York this morning.

William Taylor, who keeps a store in West Fourteenth-street, and whose case at the Yorkville Police Court was recently published was announced as the proprietor of a "Liliputian Bazaar." This designation is not exactly fair.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., June 16.--Dr. Robert Martin, Health Commissioner of Milwaukee, is in very hot water. Milwaukee has been fairly ravaged by scarlet fever and diphtheria the past year or two, and now it turns out that Dr. Martin has very generally ignored the law in regard to placarding houses.

PITTSBURG, Penn., June 16.--This was the fifth and last day of the Spring meeting at the Pittsburg Driving Park. The weather was superb, the track fast, the attendance large, and the betting up to the standard.

CINCINNATI, June 16.--At a meeting of the May Festival Association to-day the President, Mr. W.V. Hobart, presented a report which strongly favored the continuance of the festivals upon an elaborate scale.

WASHINGTON, June 16.--At a meeting of the Executive Committee of the National Jockey Club held this evening, William C. Daly, of Hartford, Conn., and the steeple-chase horse Jim McGowan, ruled off last October, were reinstated from and after August 1, next.

The Executive Committee of the Republican General Committee of Kings County met last evening, in Everett Hall, Fulton-street, Brooklyn, for the purpose of appointing a campaign committee. E.H. Hobbs occupied the chair.

LONDON, June 16.--Lord Edmund Fitzmaurice stated in the House of Commons to-day that the Government had received a dispatch from Cairo, from which there was reason to believe that the messengers who reported the fall of Berber were untrustworthy. He added, however, that Gen. Stephenson, commander of the English forces in Egypt, and Gen. Sir ...

TROY, June 16.-At the Columbia County Alms-house, at Ghent, this morning Mynard J. Turk, an old man, a former resident of East Nassau, hanged himself with a wire clothes-line. About a year ago Turk was charged with committing a serious assault on a little girl at East Nassau.

TRENTON, N.J., June 16.--There is a widespread of dissatisfaction among the honest and conscientious element of the Republican Party in this city over the Chicago nominations, and a large number of them do not hide their chagrin and intentions under a bushel.

TROY, June 16.-Mrs. George Aldrich, who recently eloped with a boarder at her house, has returned. She says it was all a trick to get even with her husband. He has refused to receive her with open arms, and she is stopping with relatives.

For some time past it has been rumored among the politicians who frequent the corridors of the Brooklyn City Hall that a number of free passes sent to the Aldermen by the Coney Island railroads and racing associations had been stolen.

SARATOGA, June 16.--The 3:30 P.M. train from New-York brought up a small crowd of Democratic politicians from New-York and Brooklyn, including 15 or 20 delagates representing the various factions. Among the Kings County delegates were Senator Jacobs, Augustus Van Wyck, James Shevlin, Anthony Barrett, and H.H. Wheeler.
TOLEDO, Ohio, June 16.--The failure of Charles R. Messinger, a large tobacco manufacturer of this city, causes much surprise to the business community. The assignment was made to David Bronson.

OTTAWA, Ontario, June 16.--Application has been made to the Customs Department to allow the importation of an article called tea dust. An analysis of this article shows it to be composed of tea, a plentiful admixture of sand, and other idgredients. The inland revenue authorities decided that the article was injurious to the public health and could not be admitted into Canada.
POUGHKEEPSIE, June 16.--The Democrats of the Second District of Dutchess County met in convention to-day.
A caucus of Democratic Representatives has been called for to-morrow night to consider the order of business in the House for the remainder of the session.

The archaeological treasures of the nation have just received a distinct and very characteristic addition in the shape of a collection, not yet, however, in the national possession, of 30 or 40 specimens of Greek pottery and other article, which, dating from a pre-historic period, cannot be regarded as later than from 1600 to 1400 before the Christian era.
President Arthur and Secretary Robert T. Lincoln went to South Oyster Bay, Long Island, on an early train yesterday morning, and spent the day as the guests of William Lloyd Jones.

EASTON, Penn., June 16.--The depression in the iron trade has caused a falling off of orders for ore from the mines in Williams Township, Northampton County, which supply the Glendon Iron Company furnaces, two miles from here.

One 50-cent bottle of Platt's Chlorides contains more radical disinfecting power than 10 pounds of chloride of lime or copperas. Although so very powerful, yet it is entirely odorless, and simply needs to be diluted with water before using.--Exchange.

MILWAUKEE, June 16.--The annual picnic of the Milwaukee Trades Assembly was given yesterday, and nearly $2,000 was cleared. To-day the police were notified that Anton Heilig, the Treasurer of the Assembly, had absconded, taking all of the money with him.

PITTSBURG, Penn., June 16.--The general strike of the river coal miners, ordered for today, indicates a lack of unanimity. Work is suspended in several mines, but the majority are still in operation. There is no enthusiasm among the miners, and one man seems to be waiting on another to take the initiative. The miners' officials say all will be out in a few days, while the operators pronounce the strike a failure.

WASHINGTON, June 16.--The general courtmartial convened at Jefferson Barracks, by special orders No. 10, has been dissolved, this order to take effect upon the completion of any case that may be before the court at the time of its receipt.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., June 16.--It is said reports of the failures of several large houses circulated to-day caused great excitement in commercial circles.
GALVESTON, June 16.--The News publishes crop reports from over 200 points in the State, covering 76 counties, embracing the agricultural district of Texas.

Before Judge Brown, in the United States District Court, yesterday, suit was begun by the owners of the Netherlands-American steam-ship Edam to recover $450,000 damages received in a collision with the British steamship Lepanto on George's Banks on the night of Sept. 25, 1882.

A steamer just arrived from Jamaica reports that on her voyage hither she sailed through a school of sharks 40 square miles in extent--the sharks being closely crowded together and apparently very hungry. The officers and crew of the steamer seemed to have fully recovered when the steamer reached port, and were unanimous in their story as to the sharks.
NYACK, N.Y., June 16.--The second annual reception of the Nyack Rowing Association, which occurred to-night, was decidedly the most brilliant event of the season along the lower Hudson.
WASHINGTON, Penn., June 16.--A 7months old child of Archibald Adams, of Jackson Township, Greene County, choked to death yesterday, the result of getting a green apple lodged in the windpipe.

Senator Gibson goes to Baton Rouge to-day in the interests of a bill which has been prepared and will be submitted to the Legislature, the object being to incorporate the Tulane University of Louisiana.

Another war in immigrant passenger rates broke out yesterday among the rival European steam-ship lines. The Inman Company opened the fight by reducing its rates from $18 for outward passage and $21 for prepaid tickets to $15 for both ways.

Brown Brothers, manufacturers of sheet brass at No. 80 Chambers-street, whose factory is at Waterbury, Conn., have become temporarily embarrassed, but arrangements are being made to settle their affairs, which will, it is thought, be successful. The business has been established many years, and was turned into a stock company Jan. 1, 1876, with a capital of ...

The fifth annual regatta of the East River Yacht Club was sailed yesterday. The steamer Columbia conveyed about 600 passengers over the course. The yachts got in line opposite the club-house at Pottery Beach, Greenpoint, and started in response to signals soon after 12 o'clock.

Mr. Ed S. Hance, of Port Oram, one of the strongest and best known young Republicans in this section, is outspoken in his opposition to Blaine, and says openly and above board that he will not support or vote for him.

In the rooms of the Lincoln Club, at No. 78 East Ninth-street, last evening, 54 Republican voters of the Third Assembly District listened nearly an hour and a half to a description of the enthusiastic manner in which Mr. James G. Blaine was made the Republican candidate for President.

LONG BRANCH, June 16.--About noon today, as Frank Maeder, the actor, with his brother, Frederick G. Maeder; his sister, Miss Mollie Maeder, and a friend, Mrs. Nellio Vaughn, were out riding, their horses shied at the water pipe at the New Jersey Southern Railroad Station.

The long-tried suit before the Surrogate of Miss Mary Irene Hoyt to open the probate of the will of her father, Jesse Hoyt, was continued yesterday. Henry Bailey, the professional nurse who attended Mr. Hoyt during his last illness, and who testified at a previous session of the ...
ST. LOUIS, Mo., June 16.--It rained here most of the day yesterday and all the forenoon to-day, rendering the track very muddy. Later the sun came out and the races were a success.

Members of the Carter families in this country assembled in the historic town of Woburn, Mass., on Wednesday, June 11, for the purpose of holding a national reunion. The meeting was held in the First Congregational Church and nearly 1,000 persons were present.
CITY OF MEXICO, June 16, via, Galveston. --The national elections passed off quietly yesterday. The results have not yet been announced.

TROY, N.Y., June 16.--A movement for a general shut-down of the knitting mills in this vicinity to-day failed. Not more than 40 per cent. of the required 75 per cent. responded to the proposed agreement for united action. The Cohoes mills are running as usual.

In the striking utterances of THE TIMES there is no want of appreciation of Mr. Bayard's exalted character and incontestable ability. But Mr. Bayard, it is contended, was not in active sympathy with the Northern cause at the beginning of the war and during the war. It can be established that he was a loyal man and gave no ...

PHILADELPHIA, June 16.--About 400 persons turned out at Pastime Park this afternoon to see the wrestling-match between Joe Acton, the champion catch-as-catch-can wrestler, and Matsada Sorakichi, the Japanese. At 4 o'clock the contestants stepped out on the grass.
Fine weather at last favored the sporting community, and yesterday a great crowd of people gathered at the Brighton Beach track to witness the excellent sport provided by the association.

SOUTHINGTON, Conn., June 16.--This is a place that can boast of but one Catholic church and one picnic ground. But it can also boast of a branch of the Clan-na-Gael. For years this society has replenished its treasury by holding a picnic at the public grove on the 4th of every July.
Yesterday afternoon four laborers who were intoxicated entered the hotel of Joseph Reed, at Kensico, and were ordered out by the bartender, Samuel Robbins.
Weather permitting, the ceremonies attending the unveiling of the Bolivar Statue in Central Park this afternoon will prove very interesting and attractive.
It is announced by cable that Anton Rubinstein will produce a new opera on an Eastern subject at the Stadt Theatre, in Hamburg, next Autumn.

A queer suggestion has been made by an ex-Collector of Key West, which is, moreover, extremely characteristic of the Blaine canvass. The Cubans residing in Florida and pursuing the vocations either of cigar-makers or of political refugees, are, upon this authority, enthusiastic for ...
DUBUQUE, Iowa, June 16.--At the National Military Encampment to-day the following troops arrived: The Ford Zouaves, of Chicago, with drum corps; ...
ROME, June 16.--Italy has sent an identical note to London and Berlin on the French policy in Morocco.

Olive, the 6-year-old daughter of John Chamberlain, met with a dangerous accident at the Hotel Brighton last evening. She was, with another child in the care of a nurse while her mother was absent, and getting on the balcony of a fire-escape, 20 feet high, fell to the sidewalk. Her skull and thigh were fractured.

LANCASTER, Penn., June 16.--Martin Lukens, a German about 50 years old, got up in his sleep last night, and walked out of the fourth story window of the Western Hotel. Luckily, he fell upon the roof of a shed about 35 feet below, and was not seriously injured.

ALBANY, June 16.--Gov. Cleveland is confined to the Executive Mansion by an acute attack of rheumatism in the knee, which will probably keep him in doors for some days. His sister, Mrs. W.E. Hoyt, of Fayetteville, is attending him.
Mr. G.S. Burnap, the artist, has just completed a portrait of Gen. Francis Marion, which was ordered by the South Carolina Society as its contribution to the South Carolina Room at Mount Vernon.

BOSTON, June 16.--The Committee of One Hundred chosen at the anti-Blaine meeting of Republicans and independents met to-day for organization. Col. Charles R. Codman was made President of the committee, and George S. Hale Vice-President.

PETERSBURG, Va., June 16.--The annual decoration of the graves of Confederate soldiers buried in Blandford Cemetery took place this afternoon under the supervision of the Ladies' Memorial Association. Business generally was suspended, and there was a large attendance of citizens.
Two lawyers, John W. Reynolds, of No. 27 Spring-street, and Henry Morange, of No. 132 Madison-street, met in the City Hall Park yesterday afternoon.
Suit for slander, in which the damages were laid at $1,000, was commenced some time ago by Emma Rickets, a servant, against Dr. Charles Jewett.

QUEBEC, June 16.--The critical point in the Eno proceedings has at length been passed, and in accordance with the terms of Judge Caron's decision rendered to-day, the prisoner will be retained in this city while the validity of his arrest on an extradition warrant is tested.

The proposed issue of Receivers' certificates to take care of the floating indebtedness of the Wabash Company is exciting much discussion in certain financial quarters. Some of the bondholders are disposed to dispute the assumption that the prospective certificates will have priority over the first mortgage bonds as liens upon the property.

CHICAGO, June 16.--An attachment suit was begun to-day by Manager John Hamlin, of the Grand Opera-house, against George W. Hyatt, Adolph Neuendorf, and N.J. Haines, Jr., proprietors of the Neuendorf Opera Company, ...

A small audience was scattered around on the benches in one of the lecture-rooms of the College of Physicians and Surgeons, at Fourth-avenue and Twenty-third-street, last night, when the New-York County Medical Association held its meeting. "The Summer Diarrhea of Infants," a paper by Dr. J. Lewis Smith, was begun by statistics which ...

ITHACA, N.Y., June 16.--The Cornell crew, Scofield, '85; H.S. Howland, '86; C.A. Raht, '85, and A.L. Cornell, '87, left to-night for Philadelphia. They row there Thursday with Columbia and the University of Pennsylvania crews in competition for the Childs Cup. The crew are in good shape. They will leave Philadelphia Friday night for Saratoga, where they row July 4 in the intercollegiate regatta.

The New-York State Revenue Reform League has issued an appeal to citizens to unite with it in securing the nomination and election of Representatives to Congress pledged to the cause of tariff reform.

MADISON, Wis., June 16.--The capital and seat of the State University is very much torn up over a fight between the liquor and anti-liquor interests. The fight between the factions is bitter, and for a day or two it looked very much as if a Cincinnati riot on a small scale could not be prevented.

The great yacht race around Long Island began yesterday afternoon under auspicious circumstances. True, there might have been a trifle more wind without worriment to even the lightest craft in the contest, but for lovers of beautiful marine views the day, calling out as it did all the sky-scrapers and moon-rakers of the schooners and the fancy kites of the cutters and ...
LONDON, June 16.--A loud explosion occurred this morning in a private house in South London which the police have been watching for a long time.

The Commencement exercises of the graduating class of the Brooklyn Collegiate and Polytechnic Institute were held at the Academy of Music in that city last evening. The house was liberally packed in all directions. Many ladies were present.

WASHINGTON, June 16, 1884. Senator Plumb reported favorably to the Sen ate to-day, from the Committee on Public Lands, the House bill to declare forfeited the unearned lands granted to the Atlantic and Pacific Railroad Company. The Republican Senators held a caucus this morning upon the Mexican Pension bill.

NEWBURG, N.Y., June 16.--Last Tuesday the proprietor of King's fur and straw hat factory, at Matteawan, Dutchess County, left that place and has not been seen since. Saturday was pay day, and as he did not return the conviction was deepened that he had absconded.

PHILADELPHIA, June 16.--William E. Cooke, a young man who was recently employed in this city as a designer, and who was arrested in Baltimore a few days ago as a fugitive from Philadelphia justice, was given a hearing at the Central Station to-day.

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 16.--Great interest is felt here in the meeting of the Directors of the Oregon Railway and Navigation Company at Portland to-day. T.F. Oakes, Vice-President and General Manager of the Northern Pacific, said yesterday that he believed the company would maintain its present independent position ...

The fifteenth annual picnic and games of the St. Patrick's Alliance of America, District No. 1, of this city, took place in Jones's Wood yesterday. During the afternoon there was a fair attendance at the athletic games, which was much increased in the evening when the dancing began. The games began with a one-hour go-asyou-please for professionals.
"Are you willing to give your views of the political situation, General?" asked a reporter of Gen. Benjamin F. Butler at the Fifth-avenue Hotel yesterday.

BOSTON, June 16.--The New-Yorkers were again beaten by the Bostons to-day. The victory was won by heavy batting. The fielding honors were even. Three singles were made in succession in the second inning, but no runs.

The General Committee of the GermanAmerican Independent Citizens' Association met last evening at Beethoven Hall, in Fifth-street, and passed resolutions strongly denouncing the nomination of Blaine and Logan.

The Polo Grounds yesterday might have been taken for a section of a prairie cut out of a Western State and put down on the outskirts of New-York. Buffalo Bill's Wild West Show gave performances in the afternoon and evening before large audiences.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 16.--At noon today Ernest Goltz, 17 years of age, was driving a load of stone out Superior-street. The wagon wheels sank into a hole, throwing Goltz from his seat directly under the wagon. A heavy wheel passed over him, crushing in his chest.

CHICAGO, June 16.--The first Presidential boom to get on the ground in advance of the Democratic Convention was that of Samuel J. Randall, which arrived to-day and opened up in State by stretching an immense banner across Lake-street, from the Commercial Hotel to the Public Library.

READING, Penn., June 16.--The remains of ex-Congressman Hiester Clymer were interred in Charles Evans Cemetery this afternoon, followed by many friends, members of the Bar, and a number of distinguished visitors, who arrived here on a special train from Philadelphia.

PRINCETON, June 16.--The Class of '84 have had most beautiful weather for their Class Day exercises, and the gay crowds that throng the old college town have enjoyed it to the utmost. At 10:30 the graduating class marched to the First Church and took their places on each side of the commodious platform, ...

The English fathers of the Chiesa Nuova in South Kensington seem disposed to revive in their new temple some of the traditions of the original Church in Rome. Yesterday, on the feast of their patron saint, Philip Neri, and for the first time, was attempted an English version, musically, of the elaborate vesper services which are common in Rome.

Solomon and Joseph Sommerich, composing the firm of S. Sommerich Co., wholesale dealers in millinery goods, at 635 Broadway, made an assignment yesterday to Jonas H. Goodman, giving preferences of $26,056, of which about $6,000 are contingent, being discounted notes.

Barbara Bowen, or Louisa Meyers, whose exploits were described in THE TIMES yesterday, slept at Police Head-quarters again on Sunday night. She had changed her dress and her hat, and on passing the officer on duty averted her head when she entered shortly before midnight and went to Matron Webb's quarters.

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 16.--Except in the Fourth District, but little interest is manifested in the coming Congressional elections in this State. It is generally conceded that Milo White will be renominated in the First District, Wakefield in the Second, and Strait in the Third.

The Receivers of the New-York, West Shore and Buffalo Railroad Company are endeavoring to perfect a plan for the immediate financial relief of that company. It is said that a million of dollars or more are needed to meet pressing demands and to contribute to the successful operation of the road.
CHICAGO, June 16.--William W. Miller, a prominent inciter of "Fund W," and who was indicted with Fleming and Loring, appeared this morning before Judge Blodgett and pleaded guilty.

LANCASTER, Penn., June 16.--William Wilson, Charles Thomas, and Lewis Parker, all colored men, were lodged in the county prison this morning on a charge of killing John Dixon, a Welsh Mountain colored man of notoriously bad character.

PITTSBURG, Penn., June 16.--Reports from the Monongahela River coal district, where the miners were ordered to go on strike to-day for a restoration of the district price of mining, 3 cents per bushel, are meagre and conflicting.

Inquirer."--None; the time has expired. The Grand Union Hotel of Saratoga opens for the season Saturday, June 28. Among the passengers who arrived yesterday from Havre on the French steam-ship Normandie were Gen. Max Weber and Gen. Potter.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 16.--Judge Simrall granted an injunction in the Vice-Chancellor's court to-day against the removal of the offices and head-quarters of the Knights of Honor from Kentucky. Gen. Frank D. Sloat, of New-Haven, Conn., Supreme Dictator, who is now here, has issued a ...

NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 16.--The State Democratic Convention will meet on Wednesday in the hall of the House of Representatives, in this city, to nominate candidates for Governor three Railroad Commissioners, and to select delegates to the National Democratic Convention.

Assistant District Attorney Parris presided over the deliberations of the Young Men's Democratic Club last evening at a special meeting in the club's rooms, No. 21 West Twenty-fourth-street. Several gentlemen stated their opinions as to what the club should do ...

BINGHAMTON, Penn., June 16.--W.A. Cooper, a prominent capitalist, of Montrose, Penn., who was shot by Joseph Drinker, in the street in that place on Saturday night at 9 o'clock, lies in a critical condition.

OTTAWA, Ontario, June 16.--An application has been made from Kentucky to the Department of Customs for permission to bring whisky into Canada and thence to New-York as ex-warehoused from this country. The ostensible object was to enable shippers to pay duties in New-York instead of in Kentucky. The application was refused.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., June 16.--NewZealand advices by the steamer Zelandia, which arrived here yesterday afternoon, are to the effect that the British iron ship Syria, from Calcutta for Fijia, having on board 480 coolies, recently ran on the Nasalie Reef. Seventy coolies were drowned. All the crew but three are missing.
Mr. Hammond, the owner of St. Gatien, began life as a stable boy at Newmarket. During the last few years he is said to have won $400,000 on the race course. By St. Gatien this year he wins $150,000.
The new North German Lloyd steam-ship Ems was thrown open for public inspection yesterday, and was visited by several thousand persons.

Some indignant mutterings went through the ranks of the Seventh Regiment when it was learned a day or two ago that the four or five companies of the Second Connecticut Regiment, in New-Haven, had invited the officers, but not the rank and file, of the Seventh, to a banquet to be given on the 20th.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 16.--The Citizens' Committee, which has been in consultation with a view of dispensing with Sunday base-ball games, have made their report.

The steam-ship Alene, Capt. Seiders, of the Atlas Line, which arrived yesterday from the West Indies, brought the crew of the Swedish brig Dagmar, which was wrecked near the mouth of the Magdalena River during the night of May 12, while attempting to reach the port of Barranquilla, South America. Capt. O.B. Anderson, of the lost brig, ...

JOHNSTOWN, Penn., June 16.--The Woodvale woolen mill suspended operations to-day for an indefinite period on account of the lack of orders. Three hundred employes are idle in consequence of the suspension.

The sentence to be imposed on James E. Kelly for pool-selling was suspended until yesterday, in order to allow Mr. Comstock to complete his battery of accusations. Yesterday the latter testified as follows at the Tombs:

ELLSWORTH, Me., June 17.--At 8 o'clock to-night a crowd of people gathered at Hancock Hall, literally filling it to overflowing. The Reception Committee, accompanied by a band of music, preceded Messrs. Blaine, Logan, and Hale from the residence of the latter to the hall, where a reception was held, hundreds shaking hands with the illustrious visitors.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., June 17.--While Mrs. Lizzie Hogan, of Walton, Delaware County, was telling her daughter that she intended to write to the girl's uncle, John Hogan, in South Carolina, and ask for some help from him, she ...

ITHACA, N.Y., June 17.--A large number of the Alumni and other friends of the present graduating class have been arriving in Ithaca for the last few days to attend the sixteenth annual Commencement exercises of Cornell University.

Ex-Policeman Patrick Casey. of Long Island City, was placed on trial yesterday morning before Judge Bartlett, in the Queens County Court, for the third time, for the murder of Sergeant Cuminskey, on March 11, 1883.

Upward of 2,000 people witnessed the unveiling of the statue of Gen. Simon Bolivar, in Central Park, yesterday afternoon, and most of them were obliged to stand patiently beneath the pelting rays of the sun while the ceremonies were in progress.

ERIE, Penn., June 17.--By returning to her burning house for some money Mrs. John Roth was this morning burned to death. A Newfoundland dog, which accompanied her, died at her side rather than leave her. The dog's body, when pulled out of the ruins was at first mistaken for the woman's.
