The Spanish bark Rafael Pomar, Capt. Pina, which arrived yesterday from Havana, brought the sole survivor, Dorson Steeves, of the brig G.P. Sherwood, which capsized and sank on the morning of June 14. Steeves was the mate of the lost brig, and was sent to the Long Island College Hospital.

Pig-tin is held in the New-York market for "spot" or immediate delivery at 19 cents per pound. While there is no real short interest in the market, the "spot" tin was yesterday said, at the New-York Metal Exchange, to be entirely controlled by Phelps, Dodge Co., Nos. 11 and 13 Cliff-street.

BOSTON, June 18.--A museum of natural history, liberally endowed, was recently founded at Tufts College, but until to-day the name of the founder was kept a secret. At the Commencement dinner President Capen announced that P.T. Barnum was the giver, and read a letter from him regarding the gift. In this letter Mr. Barnum wrote:

SARATOGA, June 18.--The convention is over. The Flower bubble has been pricked. It collapsed without a sound, and the friends of Gov. Cleveland are triumphantly pointing to the victory which they have won over an inane opposition. The contention, for a Democratic affair, was phenomenally quiet. There was no fight against the friends of Gov. Cleveland, at least upon the floor of the convention.
"M.H."--The lady, always. The Aqueduct Commission yesterday voted to modify the surveyed route of the new aqueduct through Jay Gould's swamp, near Irvington, so as to avoid the swamp entirely.

The well-shaded and hedge-encircled grounds of Rutgers College, in New-Brunswick, N.J., were overrun with visitors yesterday. The occasion was the one hundred and sixteenth Commencement of the college, and the graduates' ...

The Governing Committee of the Stock Exchange decided yesterday not to grant the petition of several of the members to suspend business on Saturday, the day after the Fourth of July. Business will begin, however, at 11 A.M. instead of 10 A.M. on the 5th, and the same rule will apply every Monday morning through the Summer.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., June 18.--The Democratic State Convention at Baton Rouge yesterday was of brief duration and well handled. It met at noon, disposed of its contests and permanently organized, and at 11 o'olock at night was ready for business.

A very painful and intricate affair has occurred near Wheeling, West Va. One of the features of the affair was an elopement, and three men, a widow, a girl, and some families and other parties were mixed up in it in a way that is simply maddening to the reader of the report sent out by a Wheeling collector of news.
An express train filled with listless, sleepy-looking passengers stood in the Pennsylvania Railroad station yesterday afternoon, on the moment of departure for Philadelphia.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Juue 18.--Last evening Dr. D. Magellrow, of Minneapolis, was robbed of $2,700 on the West Shore Road, near Kingston. About a year ago the doctor, who was a large manufacturing chemist in Minneapolis, was burned out, losing in the fire a large stock of goods and quite a sum of money.

ST. LOUIS, June 18.--It was asserted on 'Change to-day that a complete breaking in the white lead pool is imminent, through the threatened withdrawal of a St. Louis house, which complains that Chicago and Milwaukee manufacturers have been cutting rates in Minnesota and the North-west. Dealers stated to-day that they expect within a few days to see a tumble in the price of white lead from 6 to 5 cents.

BALTIMORE, June 18.--The tenth annual session of the National Catholic Union began in this city to-day. Archbishop Gibbons celebrated high mass and preached at St. Peter's Church, where an address was also delivered by the Rev. Dr. John S. Foley.
Sounds of attempted vocal music floated through the reception-room and the executive offices of the Produce Exchange yesterday about lunch time.
PARIS, June 18.--Le Matin this morning publishes an interview with the Portugese Minister at Paris.
WASHINGTON, June 18.--The resignation of Cadet Daniel F. Meskil, Fourth Class, Military Academy, has been accepted by the Acting Secretary of War.
OMAHA, Neb., June 18.--Thomas Stephens, who is traveling from San Francisco to Constantinople on a 50-inch bicycle, arrived here today. He left San Francisco on April 22.

The great yacht race around Long Island, which began at 4 o'clock on Monday afternoon last, was practically finished before noon yesterday the winners in two of the three classes having crossed the home line before 12 o'clock.

Many in the dry goods district were shocked yesterday afternoon by the announcement that Simeon Waldo Sibley, of the firm of J.L. Bremer Co., of No. 62 Leonard-street, had taken his own life at his place of business, and not a few were unable to believe that a man so prosperous, keen, and with a happy future assured should kill himself.

ITHACA, N.Y., June 18.--The Alumni Association of Cornell University was called to order at 10 o'clock this morning by the President, Judge Joseph B. Foraker, Class of '69. The large number of Alumni present showed the increasing interest manifested by the Alumni in the management of the university.

A goodly assembly of people gathered at the track of the New-York Driving Club, formerly the Gentlemens' Driving Park, yesterday, when the first of the two days of the June meeting took place. The grand stand was about twothirds full, and the club-house piazzas were crowded.

The Grand Trunk Railway of Canada and its Chicago line, the Chicago and Grand Trunk, have agreed to join the passenger pools covering the business both ways between the sea-board and Chicago, St. Louis, and points beyond.

WASHINGTON, June 18.--Mr. George Bliss, of New-York, was before the Springer committee to-day to answer the statements recently made by witnesses relative to the star route trials. Mr. Ker was present. Referring to Mr. Ker's testimony, Mr. Bliss said it seemed to be impossible for that gentleman to be accurate in dates and figures.

WASHINGTON, June 18.--The Utah bill was passed in the Senate to-day by a vote of 33 to 15. The bill, as finally passed, provides that the lawful husband or wife may be compelled to testify in prosecutions for bigamy, polygamy, or unlawful cohabitation. In such prosecutions an attachment for a witness may be issued without previous subpoena, when it shall appear to the Judge that the witness would unlawfully fall to obey a subpoena.
SARATOGA, N.Y., June 18.--The motion calendar in the Court of Appeals, will be continued to-morrow, commencing with No. 794.

BANGOR, Me., June 18.--Yesterday afternoon Mr. Blaine, Mr. Logan, Senator Hale, and Mrs. Blaine, Miss Dodge, and Mrs. Hale passed through here en route to Ellsworth, Mr. Hale's home. As the Democratic covention was in session here Mr. Blaine did not wish a demonstration.

ATLANTA, Ga., June 18.--The confusion into which the declination of Mr. Tilden to be the Presidential candidate of the Democratic Party threw the party in Georgia was plainly visible on the faces of the delegates as they gathered to attend the State Convention here today.

The following business was transacted at the Exchange yesterday, Wednesday, June 18: A.J. Bleecker Son, at public auction, sold buildings, with about 25 acres of land, known as the "Seaman property," on King's Bridge road, west side, adjoining lands of William B. Isham, Esq., at High Bridge, for $86,000, to John T. Mackenzie.

GREEN BAY, Wis., June 18.--J.H. Elmore, Receiver of Strong's Bank, received the following confession to-day from Henry Strong, the disgraced President of the bank, who ran away to Canada when it became known that he had stolen $200,000 or $300,000 of the bank's money, all of which he drooped in reckless speculations:
DENVER, Col., June 18.--The Democratic State Convention, held at Pueblo, elected as delegates to Chicago Gov. Grant, M.S. Waller, M.D. Crow, J.D. McGilvray, Dennis Sullivan, ...

CARMEL, N.Y., June 18.--The jury in the trial of ex-Jailer Chester W. Merrick, for the killing of a prisoner named Byrnes, rendered a verdict at 1 o'clock this morning of manslaughter in the first degree. The prisoner was brought into court at 8 o'clock this morning, but sentence was suspended until June 30.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 18.--The Times tonight publishes an interview with the Hon. Allen G. Thurman in connection with the Presidency.

BATAVIA, N.Y., June 18.--Thomas F. Fitzgerald, a lawyer, was arrested at his home, in Holley, Orleans County, this morning, by the Under Sheriff of this county, on a bench warrant charging him with forging the names of John Bodkin, his father-in-law, and Timothy ...

Fifty farmers, members of the Bedford Farmers' Club, assembled on the broad piazzas of the old Jay homestead, now the home of the Hon. John Jay, at Katonah, Westchester County, yesterday afternoon. Henry Pellew, who owns the adjoining farm presided.
BURLINGTON, Vt., June 18.--The Republican State Convention met here this forenoon. The Hon. Henry C. Ides, of St. Johnsbury, was chosen permanent Chairman.

NORTH ANSON, Me., June 18.--Frank Walker, a young farmer living in Embden, shot Albert Daggett, of Embden, last night, and he died this morning. Walker was married Sunday and a crowd of young fellows were serenading him, when he came to a window and fired three shots, one of which hit Daggett.

At a meeting of colored men last evenins in Turn Hall, in Gwinnett-street, Brooklyn, Eastern District, P.J. Drumins in the chair, a political organization was formed under the name of the Colored Men's Club of the Eastern District, Brooklyn. A motion to make it a Blaine and Logan club was voted down. After a heated debate T. Fortune was elected President and D. Marblay, Secretary.

The question of the consolidation of such of the down-town schools as have become of small use on account of the steady movement of population up town and of the disposition to be made of the teachers employed in them, received a pretty thorough discussion at the meeting of the School Commissioners yesterday afternoon, ...
QUEBEC, June 18.--The island of Anticost was sold to-day to F.W. Stockwell for $101,000.

BALTIMORE, June 18.--August Lydecker, alias George Klein, arrested some time since in New-York for having obtained property in this city by means of forged checks, pleaded guilty to-day and was sentenced to the penitentiary for two and a half years. In 1870 he was sentenced to four years and in 1875 to three for like offenses.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., June 18.--The seventh and last day of the St. Louis Jockey Club's Spring meeting saw an attendance greater than on any previous day and a fast track. The weather was clear and very warm. Most of the horses go hence to Chicago. The meeting here has been the most successful in many years. The new track will be ready for racing next Spring.

George William Curtis, Chairman of the conference held in the house of J. Henry Harper Tuesday evening, yesterday appointed the committee authorized by the resolutions passed by the conference, as follows:
Eighth Iowa District--W.P. Hepburn, Republican. Ninth Ohio District--W.C. Cooper, Republican.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: A paragraph, "Baldwin's Big Break," that appeared in to-day's Morning Journal, referring to the suspension of Carhart, Whitford Co., is misleading so far as I am concerned.

MONTREAL, Quebec, June 18.--Detective Cornish, of the United States service, left here to-day for Quebec, with a warrant singed by President Arthur, asking for the extradition of Eno on the charge of forgery.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., June 18.--J. Campbell Short and J.C. Martin, Presidential Electors on the Democratic ticket, have resigned because they do not approve of the platform adopted by the State Convention.
CHRISTIANIA, June 18.--The Crown Princess Victoria has become the mother of a son. This is the second son, the first having been born Nov. 11, 1882.

Unusually large drafts on some of the banks in this city have caused some comment in Wall-street during the last two or three days. President O.D. Baldwin, of the Fourth National Bank, said that the heavy drain on the banks was due to large demands on the part of railroad and coal corporations to pay their employes.

LONDON, June 18.--A jubilee in honor of the fiftieth birthday of the Rev. Charles H. Spurgeon, was given at the Holborn Tabernacle. The building was crowded, over 5,000 persons being present. Two Christian Nestorians from Persia were at the meeting.

In the United States Circuit Court yesterday James D. Fish pleaded not guilty to the indictment found against him by the United States Grand Jury. His attorney, S.G. Clarke. asked for time in which to consider the papers of indictment, and at his desire the case was adjourned until June 27. Fish's bonds were renewed.
The Joint Executive Committee (Passenger Department,) of the Eastern and Western Railroads will meet at Commissioner Fink's office to-day.
Timothy Eagan, a young man residing at No. 105 Sullivan-street, was very much in love with the 18-year-old daughter of John Glaspen, a shoe-maker, of No. 119 West Houston-street.

All the Park Commissioners were present at the meeting of the board yesterday. The plans submitted by the Trustees of the Metropolitan Museum of Art for the enlargement of the building were approved, and work on the extension will be begun at once.
There will arrive at the stockyard piers in Jersey City, this morning, the steam barge Bells, a mammoth floating refrigerator, which has just been completed in Philadelphia.

LANCASTER, June 28.--The Board of Trustees of the Franklin and Marshall College at this Commencement conferred the degree of A. M. on James Y. Shearer, of Sinking Springs, Penn. At noon the corner-stone of the Daniel Scholl Astronomical Observatory was laid with impressive ceremonies conducted by Dr. J.O. Miller, of York, and Dr. E.R. Eschbach, of Frederick, Md.

President Dodd, who, with the other managers of the broken Newark Savings Institution, was cited to appear in the Chancellor's Court to respond to the charge of contempt in having parted with the securities of the bank without permission of the court, filed his answer yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, June 18.--A few days ago the Water Inspectors discovered that Gen. Sherman was sprinkling the sidewalk in front of his handsome residence on Garrison-avenue, and on his being invited to pay the customary license he waxed wroth, declared that he had been advised ...
Mr. J.S. Goldsmith, the plaintiff in the suit against William M. Abbott, Erdward J. Baker, and the Franklin Bank-note Company, ...
LIVE OAK, Fla., June 18.--The State Convention of Independents met here to-day. Twenty-seven counties were represented.
PITTSBURG, Penn., June 18.--The second day of the improvised running meeting at Exposition Park had fine weather and a good attendance. The betting was lively.

In the United States District Court, yesterday, Judge Brown handed down a decision discharging from custody Gerald Thomas Tully, who was held for extradition by United States Commissioner Shields recently, on a charge of forgery preferred by the Preston Banking Company, of Preston, England.
OMAHA, Neb., June 18.--As a result of the recent indictments against Mayor Chase and Chief of Police Guthrie, the latter resigned last evening.

The suspension of Carhart, Whitford Co., clothing merchants, at Broadway and Canalstreet, was the absorbing topic of interest in commercial circles yesterday. The surviving members of the firm, Edmund H. Carhart, William H. Whitford, and John B. Van Wagenen, ...
WASHINGTON, Penn., June 18.--John Cassidy, a prominent citizen of this county, died suddenly of heart disease yesterday. While walking across the floor he fell and died instantly.

The second combination sale of Jersey cattle was continued yesterday at the Horse Exchange, at Broadway and Fiftieth-street. Over 80 animals were sold, and they realized over $23,000. Only a few cows and one bull brought what might be called fancy prices.

Mr. Warner's statue is of heroic size and is of bronze. It is honorably, but not altogether fortunately, placed. It is the chief ornament in that division of the much divided main floor of the Capitol which, from containing the flags carried by the gallant regiment of Connecticut in the war, is called Memorial Hall.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 18.--Passengers arriving in the Grand Central Station, NewYork, by the early trains this morning opened their eyes in sleepy amazement at the sight of a regiment drawn up in line at the entrance. The track was clear by 7 o'clock, and a train of 12 passenger cars and one baggage car was backed into the station.
BUFFALO, June 19.--The musical festival, which has been for several months in preparation, had a brilliant opening at Music Hall this evening. It is under the direction of Theodore ...

BLOOMINGTON, Ill., June 19.--The State Prohibition Convention, which met here to-day, nominated a State ticket, with J.H. Hobbs for Governor; Dr. Perryman, of Belleville, for Lieutenant-Governor, and Hale Johnson, of Jasper, ...

The Directors of the Texas Pacific Railroad will meet to-morrow and take some action in the matter of paying the July interest on its bonds. The interest falling due on July 1 is 7 per cent. on $8,602,000 of income land mortgage bonds, payable at the option of the company in ...

She was a very aged woman, in widow's weeds, nearly blind, and her avoirdupois gave the 300 notch a very close call. She was accompanied by two spinsters of middle age, who supported her on either side and frantically waved a Gates-avenue car to a stand-still in the shade of a Brooklyn maple.
CHARLESTON, S.C., June 19.--"I have a breech-loading double-barreled shotgun and a pistol at the parsonage, and I intend to defend myself if I am attacked. You can count on that."

TROY, N.Y., June 19.--Ex-Chamberlain Church, the defaulter, was arraigned in the Court of Sessions to-day, but Judge Fursman, being one of his bondsmen, refused to try the case, which went over to October.
Mr. Harvey N. Shepard is to deliver the oration before the city authorities of Boston on the Fourth of July.

WASHINGTON, June 19.--In beginning his testimony before the Springer investigating committee to-day Mr. Bliss said the question had been asked him why he did not try some other case than the Dorsey case. He continued: "I did my best to have some other case tried.

WASHINGTON, June 19, 1884. A joint committee from the New-York Cham ber of Commerce and the Maritime Exchange appeared before the Senate Committee on Commerce today and made arguments in support of the passage of the bill providing for the deepening of Gedney's Channel through Sandy Hook.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 19.--A thousand ladies and gentlemen assembled upon the campus of St. Stephen's College, Annandale, at noon to-day to participate in the twenty-third annual Commencement exercises. A large platform had been erected in the grove in front of ...

The pulpit of the Church of the Disciples was hidden from sight under a mass of flowers, which covered stairs, desk, and altar, last evening, and the front seats were filled with rows of young ladies, all in white, with corsage bouquets of red roses.
The Ursuline Academy Commencement was attended largely by the parents, relatives, and friends of the pupils at the convent, East Morrisania, yesterday afternoon.
A till Italian woman with iron-gray hair and a little dried-up Italian man stood in the Court of Special Sessions yesterday.

NYACK, June 19.--Considerable annoyance was caused to the people of this place this morning upon reading in the New York papers a dispatch, dated at Albany, announcing that there was a case of small-pox at South Nyack. The tendency of the item was to keep visitors away from this place.

CINCINNATI, June 19.--The Supreme Court Commission has sustained the decision of the Hamilton County District Court in the Archbishop Purcell case. Upon finding himself financially embarrassed the late Archbishop transferred several valuable pieces of property to his brother Edward, in order that the assignment ...

NEW-ORLEANS, June 19.--At 11:30 o'clock last night the levee above Carrollton, about 50 feet above the protection levee, caved in at the point where the levee is about 10 or 12 feet high and the crown of the levee about 9 feet wide.

NEWARK, June 19.--Robert Hann hanged himself to-night at No.15 Nesbitt-street. He is the same person who a few weeks since entered the Second Precinct Station-house and declared that he had shot his wife.

The fifth day of the Sheepshead Bay meeting will be long remembered by the many thousands of people present, as one remarkable for spirited contests and very fast time. All of the six races brought large fields of horses to the starting post, and from beginning to end the enthusiasm was unbounded.

Phoebus atoned yesterday for his remissness of the early part of the month by pulling off his coat and driving his chariot up the blue vault of heaven right into the torrid regions. The thermometer arose to the occasion and beat the record for the present year.

Mount Olivet Baptist Church, in Fiftythird-street, near Seventh-avenue, presented a picturesque appearance last night on the occasion of the jubilee service which was held by the colored congregation, who since last Sunday have been holding dedicatory services of a varied description.

BOSTON, Mass., June 19.--Two well-dressed men, who gave their names as George Daniels and George Biddle, were arrested here yesterday, having been noticed loitering in a suspicious manner in the vicinity of several banks.They were soon identified as Horace Hogan, alias "Little Horace," and Frank Buck, professional burglars and bank sneaks, well known to the police throughout the country

DEER PARK, Md., June 19.--In the Homeopathic Convention this morning Dr. Dowling, of New-York, as one of the committee on the question of an American co-editor-in-chief on the revision of the Materia Medica, made a report recommending that an editor be appointed to work in unison with Dr. Hughes, of England, and named Dr. J.P. Dake, of Nashville, Tenn.

BOSTON, June 19.--President Charles Francis Adams, Jr., of the Union Pacific, denies the report from Wall-street to-day that he has discovered or broken up any conspiracy whereby the Union Pacific Company has been robbed.

PHILADELPHIA, June 19.--The Methodist Episcopal ministers of this city met at Wesley Hall this morning, to take action relative to the death of Bishop Simpson. It was decided to invita all ministers of the city churches to attend...

CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 19.--"Ike" Stanley, the embezzling Teller, was released from jail to-day, having succeeded in getting bail in the sum of $15,000. Stanley's wife has become crazy and is now at a private sanitarium in Painesville. The presence of her husband, it is thought, may effect a cure.

Harris made his appearance here as agent of the Atlanta branch of the New-York Mutual Life Insurance Company, bearing a letter of indorsement from another agent indorsed by Gen. Joseph Johnston Co., head of the Atlanta office, to W. N. J.H. Reeves, brokers, local agents ...

The Yale and Princeton College nines played the second of their series of games for the college championship at Metropolitan Park yesterday afternoon. There were few spectators present, and the enthusiasm that generally attends games of this class was missing.

WASHINGTON, June 19.--The bondsmen of Col. J.O.P. Burnside, the defaulting disbursing clerk of the Post Office Department, notified Police Head-quarters to-night that they desired to surrender Burnside to ...

ATLANTA, Ga., June 19.--A well-dressed woman entered the City Prison to-day and asked for Chief Connelly. She gave her name as Mrs. Weaver and said that she wanted a young man, known among his friends and associates as J.R. Lumpkin, arrested.

MADISON, Wis., June 19.--The Board of University Regents met to-day, and the charges against President Bascom, made by Regent E. W. Keyes, were referred to a special committee, consisting of Regents Bingham, Hitt, and Koepper, to report on Sept. 3.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., June 19.--The Yale University crew took a short spin on the course to-day for the first time. They row in good time and form, and an improvement over last year's stroke is noticeable. The Harvard University crew were out three times, and speeded ...

AUGUSTA, Me., June 19.--Upon invitation of Col. Smith Gen. Logan and Senator Hale visited the Soldiers' Home at Togus to-day, arriving there at 12 o'clock.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 19.--Since the positive announcement that the Hon. Henry B. Payne would not allow his name to be used as a candidate before the Chicago Convention the friends of Gov.
Alexander J. Defossez, a theatrical manager, was arrested yesterday on a suit for limited divorce, instituted against him by his wife, Kate L. Defossez, in the Supreme Court.

The third trial was begun yesterday of Patrick Casey, for the murder of Sergt. Cummiskey, in the Queens County Court of Oyer and Terminer. A number of witnesses testified for the prosecution, which was closed. The story of the shooting was told as it was given at the time in THE TIMES.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., June 19.--Frank Schumacher, a laborer in the employ of the Milwaukee Cement Company, was instantly killed at the company's quarry at noon to-day.
The attention of Gatekeeper Francis Mahon, who was on duty on the elevated road at Sixth-avenue and Fifty-ninth-street at 7:45 o'clock yesterday morning, was drawn by a pistol-shot ...

On Monday last a tall woman, apparently about 55 years of age, was taken before Justice Naeher, in Brooklyn, on a charge of disorderly conduct. She had annoyed the police a good deal by reporting imaginary disturbances in different parts of the city, and she was finally taken into custody.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 19.--The annual meeting of the Corporation of Brown University was held this morning. The President's report says it is expected that provision will be made for instruction in Spanish and Italian.

DENVER, Col., June 19.--Mrs. Warren, wife of Bishop Henry W. Warren, of this city, has given $100,000 to the Denver University for the establishment of a department of divinity, to be known as "The Iliff School of Divinity," on the condition that others endow a single Professorship.

"The price of the adhesion of Tammany," says the Commercial Advertiser, "is the sacrifice of local reform. All that Mr. ROOSEVELT and his friends fought for and won will be practically repudiated and as fast as possible reversed if, with Tammany's help, Mr. CLEVELAND should be elected President."

Rebecca Jones, the contumacious witness whom all the majesty of the Surrogate's Court cannot induce to testify in the contest of the will of her employer, Louis C. Hamersley, refused to attend the trial of the suit yesterday, and, as it was adjourned until October, she will be obliged to remain within the confines of Ludlow-Street Jail all Summer.

POUGHKEEPSIE N.Y., June 19.--The ninetieth meeting of the Evangelical Lutheran Ministerium of New-York began here to-day. Fifty-four of the 74 regular Pastors were present. The Rev. P. Krug, of Newark, N.J., was elected President for the ensuing three years. The report of the retiring President showed that the churches were in a prosperous condition.

The wildcat which escaped from the university the other day was seen last evening just bofore dark between the houses of Milo Walley and Orin Cornelius on East Hill, near East Lawn Hotel. Two hounds were put on its track and followed it to the woods. There the dogs, however, wandered from the track and followed a rabbit trail.

LONDON, June 19.--The jubilee in honor of the fiftieth birthday of the Rev. Mr. Spurgeon was continued to-day. The Tabernacle was filled to overflowing. Dr. Parker and Mr. Newman Hall were among the distinguished persons present.

NEUFCHATEL, June 19.--The manager of the Cantonal Bank has committed suicide. He had been guilty of embezzling bank funds.

Heinrich Conried, of the Thalia Theatre, has just succeeded, after four years of effort, in effecting a contract to bring Adolf Ritter von Sonnenthal, the leading actor of the Kaiser Konigheit Hofburg Theatre of Vienna, which is under the special patronage of the Emperor, to New-York.

The interest in the case of ENO, renewed by the latest attempt to secure his extradition, gives especial point and timeliness to the decision by Judge BROWN in TULLY'S case which was published yesterday.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., June 19.--An accident occurred at a saw-mill run by Keys Brothers, near Kings Mills, in Sullivan County, this morning. A young man named Cubine, a son of William Cubine, was underneath the saw while it was in motion, clearing away the sawdust.

A man was found on the sidewalk in Manhattan-avenue, Greenpoint, early Monday morning, in a nearly unconscious condition, and taken to the Eastern District Hospital. When somewhat revived he said his name was John Mansten, a German laborer, about 45 years old,

WASHINGTON, June 19.--The investigation by a special committee of the House into the allegation that the Hon. W.H. English and other ex-members of the House had made improper use of the privilege of the floor was continued this morning. Congressman John D. White, of Kentucky, was called.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., June 19.--The Milwaukee Base-Ball Club has been playing so badly of late that the management has decided to discharge the manager, J.F. McKee, and nearly the whole club. The Directors are now negotiating ...

PHILADELPHIA, June 19.--About 5,000 persons witnessed the inter-collegiate four-oared boat-race for the George W. Childs Challenge cup, on the Schuylkill River to-day, which resulted in a victory for the Pennsylvania university crew, the present holders of the trophy. The course was one and one-half miles, straightaway.

DETROIT, Mich., June 19.--John Lowry, Jr., a resident of Norwalk, Ohio, has just been taken to Haughton, Mich., in charge of an officer, having been arrested a few days since in Dakota, where he was running a farm of a thousand acres.

WAVERLY, Tenn., June 28.--William H. Owens to-day shot and killed Wilson Larkin. Larkin had associated his own name in an indecent manner with Owens's wife, and an altercation arose between the two men. Owens got a gun, when Larkin ran away. Owens afterward, on his way home, was followed by Larkin with a navy pistol, threatening to kill him. Owens thereupon fired, killing Larkin instantly. The Coroner's verdict was justifiable homicide.

PARIS, June 13.--Col. Hennebert, the former Professor at St. Cyr, has written a book called "l'Europe Sous les Armes," which is remarkable. It comes on the heels of another remarkable book, the "Nation Armee," of M. de Goltz, a Prussian Major.

DOVER, N.H., June 28.--John G. Hill, who killed his wife with an axe at Great Falls yesterday, was arraigned this morning, pleaded not guilty, and was held for the Supreme Court. SOMERS POINT, N.J., June 28.--A large three-masted schooner sank during Friday night about eight miles at sea off Peck's Beach. Nothing has been learned of her name, destination, or the cause of her foundering. Divers will be set to work on the submerged wreck.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., June 28.--Charles Bishop, a butcher and caterer, disappeared on Tuesday last, leaving his wife and several children. It is supposed that he has gone to England to avoid the payment of his debts.

Gen. Nathaniel P. Banks has been invited to deliver the Fourth of July oration in Nashua, N.H.

The more books of this kind that are printed the better. They are not for the general; they are meant for the historian; and yet there is no lack of clearness in case the reader is not in the way of being thoroughly posted in Revolutionary lore.

GALVESTON, Texas, June 29.--A dispatch from Fort Worth to the News says: "Charles Herring, the murderer of Dr. B.W. Barradall, was captured to-night about five miles north of Fort Worth while eating supper in a farmer's house. He was brought here quietly and placed in jail. As soon as the fact of his capture became known crowds began to congregate about the corners and talk of lynching him."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 29.--John Traynor, the Maine fisherman, has decided to wait till the Saturday after the Fourth of July centennial parade here before starting on his rowing trip to Europe in his dory. The Captain will appear in the parade.
The Hon. William Bross, of Chicago, is at the Sturtevant House. Congressional Delegate M.E. Post, of Wyoming, is at the Fifth-Avenue Hotel.

CINCINNATI, June 29.--The name of Payne was hissed in the Democratic Convention of the Sixth Congressional District on Friday. A reporter, meeting Gen. A.V. Rice, one of the recently nominated Presidential Electors, asked what the hissing meant.

The cat-boat Barthenia, of Whitestone, Long Island, arrived off Market-street with a load of clams and oysters Saturday evening. At break of day yesterday her master, Charles Hyatt, and his father-in-law, E.S. Whitmore, were awakened by stealthy steps on the deck and the clanking of a ring at the bow to which the mooring rope was attached.

From an autopsy made yesterday Deputy Coroner Jenkins concludes That Abraham R. Warner, who was left dead on the pavement in Sixty-fourth-street, early Saturday morning, died of aggravated kidney troubles.

COLUMBIA, S.C., June 29.--Heavy rains, wind-storms, hail, and, in several counties, tornadoes have prevailed with more or less severity for the past 10 days in this State. In Laurens, Union, Greenville, Chester, Lancaster, and Richland Counties the winds have been destructive to crops and orchards, and in some localities to ...

The preliminary labor in Presidential years is a matter of organization, and calls for careful attention to details. The work in the campaign of 1872 was speedily taken in hand by the Republicans. Grant and Wilson were nominated at Philadelphia on June 6 in that year.

An exciting scene was witnessed yesterday afternoon at the Jardin des Plantes. A man leaning over the wall of the bears' pit, suddenly overbalanced himself and fell into the pit, a depth of some 12 feet. He was stunned by the fall and had his head cut open.
HELENA, Montana, June 29.--Major Allen, Piegan Indian Agent for Northern Montana, reports that the Indians are dying fast from the scant food supply at the agency.

Judge Mitchell delivered an interesting opinion in Philadelphia on Saturday in decision of an appeal taken by Mr. Henry C. Lea from the action of the Board of Revision of Taxes in taxing pictures hanging upon the walls of his residence as "furniture."

A carpenter was noticed on Saturday nailing a green pine tree on the apex of the roof of a new dwelling-house on Staten Island. A number of men with their sleeves rolled up were standing in the street below watching the man nailing the tree in its place.

At 5 o'clook yesterday morning James Richardson, a watchman employed by the United States Quartermaster's Department, was on Pier No. 59 North River when a cry caused him to look riverward and he saw a man with a white beard, bald head, and dressed in dark clothes ...

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, N.Y., June 29.--The great race this afternoon between the two news-dealers was won by THE TIMES, it being the first paper called for sale on the streets. The pony express of the opposition employed four horses, stationed three miles apart, and including Black Charley, Flying Dutchman, ...

In this country we endure without rebellion the income tax. It fails most heavily on mere professional people and tradesfolk, who make varying yearly sums by their honest industries. Such persons will submit dutifully to any exaction the State may impose.

ATLANTA, Ga., June 29.--An interesting case has been decided by Ordinary Calhoun, of Fulton County. It was brougt about by the habeas corpus case of William Pannion, a prisoner who had been found guilty of illegal voting.

CHICAGO, June 29.--Edward R. Marshall, the man with the "mutton-chop" whiskers, who is charged with uttering counterfeit Bank of England fifty-pound notes, is now locked up in the Des Plaines-street police station here on that charge.

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 29.--A Winnipeg special says: "Great excitement has been caused here by the notification from the Canadian Pacific to the Customs Department that on and after July 1 the company will refuse to pay customs officers for services rendered after hours.

TRENTON, N.J., June 29.--Richard Coleman, Jr., a brick-maker and a peaceably disposed man, was shot this afternoon by a desperate character named George Gregory on the outskirts of this city, and it is feared was fatally wounded.
The Government of India have received the reports of the preliminary examination of the oil-bearing strata which exist in the neighborhood of Sibi.

It is interesting to be told at this late date that a newspaper cannot be Republican and criticise Blaine's record. The Greeley Tribune is an independent Republican newspaper, but it does not shout with the crowd if it is wrong, nor worship every political god which happens to be set up in a convention.

Terence Flanagan, of No. 531 West Thirtieth-street, who is a peace officer, or "bouncer," at Miner's Eighth-Avenue Theatre, was at 2:30 o'clock yesterday morning chatting with an acquaintance at Twenty-seventh-street and Eighthavenue.

PARIS, June 10.--The reception of the French nobility by M. Meissonier was by far the most brilliant affair of the season. The lady patrons of the Asiles de Nuit had determined that outsiders should not come in, and it is quite safe to assert that the resolution was rigorously enforced.

I see a good many suggestions as to the appointment to the Provostship of Eton. I would suggest that the salary should be reduced. The Provost has nothing to do, and for this a salary of 2,000 per annum and a house are almost too high pay.

I think the epitaph, a copy of which I inclose, and to which some friends of mine drew my attention, in Edwinstowe Churchyard, on the edge of Sherwood Forest, will amuse your readers. Time had permitted the venerable stone to sink too low to leave the last words visible.

JOLIET, Ill. June 29.--Later developments in the case of the gang of counterfeiters near this place seem to indicate that Adam Williams, who was arrested on Friday, was not the leader, as was at first supposed.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., June 29.--The Ninetieth Commencement of Williams College opens with that condition so important to enjoyable Commencements--fair weather. It is perhaps appropriate, in view of the general success of the college during the past year.

The people who are interested in the public playing of base-ball on Sunday in Columbus, Ohio, are acting in a very silly way. There seems to be no question that the law of Ohio forbids the playing of ball on Sunday, and that the Judge who dismissed the writ of habeas corpus made out for the catcher of the club had no choice.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 29.--Church circles in Cleveland are greatly excited over several remarkable cures, said to be in answer to prayer by Dr. Hickman, Pastor of Woodland Methodist Church, and by members of that church.

COHOES, N.Y., June 29.--St. Agnes's Church, at this place, J.F. Lowery, Pastor, was consecrated to-day by Bishop McNierny. The odifice was crowded and several visiting clergymen were present. Only one other church in this diocese, that at Syracuse, is free from debt.

France has just admitted into fellowship the latest addition to the great family of European coins. For many years the Swiss Republic transacted its commerce with its own paper and with the gold of other nations.

John Williams, a colored man, of No. 37 Sullivan-street, fell asleep on the string-piece of a pier in West Washington Market, yesterday afternoon.

A horse belonging in Brewster, Conn., on Wednesday walked across a high bridge on the New-England Road, making his way on the tin guard outside of the ties. This is 80 feet high, about 200 feet in length, and nearly 1 foot in width. Very few men have the nerve to make the attempt. The animal was loose on the roadbed, and to avoid capture crossed the bridge.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 29.--About 5,000 spectators witnessed the first game here between the Metropolitan and Columbus Clubs this afternoon, which, in accordance with an agreement between the Law and Order League and the management of the home club, will be the last Sunday game of the season.
MADRID, June 29.--The authorities have ordered a quarantine against all English shipping, unless England adopts precautions against the spread of cholera.

Senator Cullen adorned the Yorkville Policy Court yesterday, and he mounted the stand when R.E. Cushing was placed at the bar. The latter wore a jumper in lieu of a coat; his hat was missing and his eyes had been blackened.
The Democratic State Convention refused emphatically to restrict in any way the freedom of the delegates who will represent South Carolina in the National Convention.

WINNIPEG, June 29.--General Manager Van Horne, of the Canadian Pacific, speaking of the company's intention regarding branch roads, says: "We intend to build them just as soon as we can raise the money.

A sensational trial was concluded a Moscow a few days ago, resulting in a sentence of deportation to Siberia against a woman named Bulakh for keeping a rich orphan girl, of whom she had charge as governess, in a state of wretched confinement and semi-starvation for nearly 30 years in order to obtain possession of her fortune of 50,000.

LONDON, June 29.--At the meeting yesterday of the conference upon the Egyptian question Earl Granville briefly stated the financial proposals to be considered by the conference. The conference then adjourned to allow the finance experts to examine the proposals. The date of the next meeting has not been fixed.

WESTERLY, R.I., June 29.--While waiting for an event they ardently hope to see, the good people of the Second Advent Church, in Wyoming, just east of this township, are involved in an uncomfortable religious war.

At the meeting of the Central Labor Union yesterday the plumbers' delegates stated that their union intended soon to open a number of shops, where all the locked-out plumbers would be employed.

A slender-built, auburn-haired young Scotchman, fashionably dressed in a black cutaway diagonal coat and black derby hat, walked out of the Fifth-Avenue Hotel on Saturday, about 1 o'clock, and strolled leisurely down Broadway. From the curiosity with which he regarded the stores and the people it was evident that he was a stranger.

NORWICH, Conn., June 29.--Members of the tribe of Pequot Indians in Indiantown, between Ledyard and Stonington, are in the city seeking counsel, with a view to putting a stop to the vandalism which has been practiced upon the cemetery for many years by white curiosity hunters. The Pequots were the original possessors of this country, powerful and warlike; now there are less than a hundred of them.

"White good temperance people are decrying liquor," said one of the leading physicians of the city, "they seldom stop to think how much harm is being done by the abuse of a beverage to which many of them are devoted.
GREEN BAY, Wis., June 29.--The creditors of Strong's bank have brought suit against the officers, Directors, and shareholders to secure the payment of moneys due them.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., June 29.--The eightyfourth Commencement of Middlebury College began to-day with the baccalaureate sermon by President Hamlin, from the text-Hebrews, xii., 26, 27.--"Yet once more I shake, not earth only, but also heaven," This evening an address was delivered before the Young Men's Christian Association by the Rev. Dr. I.E. Raukin, of Washington.

AMHERST, Mass., June 29.--The baccalaureate sermon at Amherst College was delivered to-day by President Seelye on the general theme of the "Transfiguration." In addressing the graduating class he directed attention to the social question.

A gentle breeze, tempered by contact with white-crested waves far out at sea, blew in upon Coney Island all day yesterday. The sky was clear, with just a suggestion of haze tinting the distant purple of the low-lying hills beyond Raritan Bay.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 29.--George Anderson, a Niles brakeman, on going home last night, was told by his wife that T.J. Truxel, a nail feeder, recently from Wheeling, had come to the house and insulted her, Anderson went out to find Truxel, and an altercation ensued. Words came to blows, and when the men were parted Anderson had a deep knife-cut in his side that will probably prove fatal.

Shortly before 7 o'clock last evening, after the prisoners in the penitentiary on Blackwell's Island had been locked up, Deputy Warden Charles Osborne and Keeper P.H. Callahan started for New-York in a row-boat.

Focardi was a poor Italian sculptor. He happened one day to be in Preston, a grimy, smoky Lancashire town. He was lodging in an obscure quarter of the town casting about for work. One morning he rang for his breakfast-- once, twice. But no answer came.

William Lee hired the basement of No. 292 West Twelfth-street from Mrs. Sarah E. Armstrong, an elderly, stout, auburn-haired lady, who has the upper part of the house. Friday Lee's child, born a week before, died, and he put crape on the front door bell.

TRENTON, June 29.--The attitude of the New-Jersey delegates to the National Democratic Convention as to the candidates for the Presidency has become a matter of considerable speculation among New-Jersey politicians.

MARTINSBURG, West Va., June 29.--At the Pendleton County Poor-house, a few days ago, Barney Shaver and Amanda Sisson, paupers, quarreled, during which Amanda beat Shaver over the head with some blunt instrument. A few hours afterward Shaver was found dead in bed, with wounds on the head. The Coroner's jury returned a verdict of death from brain disease, which excites some comment.

It is believed that the Grand Jury of Kings County will make presentments this morning in the Court of Sessions, Judge Moore presiding, against a score of Coney Island and Sheepshead Bay pool-sellers.

PORTLAND, Oregon, June 29.--Yesterday, two boats capsized at the mouth of the Columbia River, owing to rough weather. Capt. Olsen, a prominent pioneer citizen of Astoria, Samuel Blair, James Craig, and four others, unknown men, were drowned. The bodies of Olsen and Craig were recovered. All the others were swept out to sea and lost.

Friends of Ireland gathered in the meeting-room of Branch No. 20 of the Parnell Land League, in St. Boniface School, No. 312 West Forty-seventh-street, last night, to assist in swelling the Parliamentary fund.

Few things are more absurd than the official detective in the presence of a crime which is not in his list and the facts of which are not covered by any of his limited stock of theories.
The anxiety felt generally throughout Southern Russia regarding the crops owing to the long-continued drought is now very considerably increased by the reappearance of locusts in several districts.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 29.--Dr. C.A. Taft the leading homeopathic physician in Connecticut, who died Thursday, was supposed for years to have had only one lung, the other having been exhausted in early life by a pulmonary difficulty.

NEW-ORLEANS, June 29.--State Treasurer Burke gives notice that the interest maturing July 1 on Lousiana consols will be paid by the State National Bank, the fiscal agency in NewOrleans, where Consols and coupons have to be stamped, to conform to the recently adopted debt amendment.

ALBANY, June 29.--Notwithstanding the reports of anti-cleveland deals arranged by John Kelly and Ben Butler, the managers of the Governor's campaign feel as confident now of success at Chicago as they have at any time since Mr. Tilden's letter of withrawal appeared.

"I'm glad Billy had the sense to marry a settled old maid," said Grandma Winkum at the wedding. "Gals is hity-tity, and widders is kinder overrulin' and upsettin', but old maids is kinder thankful and willin' to please."

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 29.--O.C. Barrows, a very prominent citizen of Bristol, and book-keeper for the National Rubber Company, has admitted a defalcation of about $5,000. He has been in the employ of the company 20 years.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., June 28.--This resplendent city by the sea is to-day in a state of gorgeous superficiality. That means that the drives are well filled with carriages and the walks with pedestrians.

ROME, June 29.--Enormous crowds attended the celebration of St. Peter's Day. The streets were filled with thousands of carriages. A great many policemen were on hand, but no disturbance occurred. St. Peter's, where the celebration was held, was filled.

Prince Victor's windfall is still shrouded in mystery. All kinds of sources have been attributed to the alleged income of 40,000f. a year. It was first stated to be a gift from M. Moet-Auban, next of Princess Mathilde, and then of the Empress Eugenie, but all these statements have been positively contradicted.

LYNCHBURG, Va., June 29.--On account of the failure of the air-brakes to work the Vir ginia Midland morning express ran at an uncontrollable rate of speed on to the bridge over the James River, one and a half miles north of this city, and the corner of the smoking car struck the upright girders, throwing it from the track.

DES MOINES, Iowa, June 29.--The Hon. William Stone, of Mills County, father of the Hon. John Y. Stone, who led the Iowa delegation at the National Republican Convention, repudiates Blaine and Logan, and affirms that he will support Butler for President.

A fight occurred last evening in the tenement-house at No. 442 West Twenty-eighthstreet, and Catherine Reddy, a young woman, was struck on the head with a hatchet by a sexagenarian termagant, Bridget McNamara, who was arrested. At the Roosevelt Hospital the woman's injury was considered serious, as there were indications of a fracture of the skull.
--The paper edition of Mr. Lathrop's "Newport," the novel published a few months ago by the Scribners, in the first week after publication reached a sale of 3,000 copies.

CHICAGO, June 29.--W.F. Vilas, of Wisconsin, and others of the National Democratic sub-Committee who live in the vicinity of Chicago, went home to spend Sunday, and, as a consequence, there has been very little visible anteconvention work done here to-day, though any ...

ST. LOUIS, June 29.--Samuel Emmert, a farmer, living near Nameoki, Ill., shot and killed a negro named Isaac about noon yesterday. Isaac had made an insulting proposal to Emmert's wife, and when shot was in the act of drawing a weapon. Emmert surrendered himself to the authorities, but was released when the facts of the case were disclosed at the Coroner's inquest.

COLUMBUS, Ga., June 29.--There have been several cases of small-pox in Harris County, carried there by a family from the British Honduras. Mayor Grimes received a telegram from Cataula stating that Dr. Ed Degraffenreid, ...

Rogers died on Tuesday last, in the ninety-third year of his age. His mind had for some time past given way, and his death may be considered as a release. He was a man who did very benevolent things, which no one would ...

The home of the Paris correspondent of the Times is on the second floor of a modern Parisian house in one of the broad avenues which radiate from the Aro de Triomphe. From our English point of view the rooms might seem small and overcrowded with furniture; from the French point of view they seem cozy and gay, and sufficiently artistic in their disorder.

STATE CAMP OF INSTRUCTION, PEEKSKILL, June 29.--The Rev. C.A. Meury, of Brooklyn, Chaplain of the Thirty-second Regiment, delivered a sermon in the German language before the soldiers who are undergoing camp life this morning.

The Atlanta man who is alleged to have handled dynamite so long that his system is impregnated with the compound and he is liable to explode when properly ignited ought to be warmly approved by the Irish Invincibles.
The Anchor steam-ship Anchoria, which arrived from Glasgow on Saturday, towed the steam-ship Carmona into St. John, Newfoundland, on June 23.

CINCINNATI, June 29.--Mrs. Elise Bethune, widow of John G. Bethune, of New-York, has brough a suit against Thomas J. Nichols, of Paris, Ky., to recover possession of $50,000 worth of race-horses which, her petition says, were assigned in trust to Nichols. The petition was filed in the United States Court at Covington, Ky.
MENASHA, Wis., June 29.--John Strang, a lumber-dealer, has gone into bankruptcy with liabilities of $40,000; assets, $20,000. The suspension was caused by a depression in the market.
One of the tales which old-time gossips of Hingham loved to tell was that of three maiden ladies whose family through all the Revolution remained loyal Tories to the backbone.

It is very evident from the tone of sentiment in Washington that there is little prospect that the tariff will be made a controlling issue in the Presidential canvass.
A New-Haven dispatch says Barbara Gangel, "a saleslady, aged 15 years," has been arrested for stealing from her employers. That was certainly unladylike.

Charles McCarron, of Seventh-street, Hunter's Point, made a brutal assault on his wife yesterday morning. He had been beating and abusing her all night, and at 4 o'clock in the morning attempted to kill her.
MARLBOROUGH, June 30.--Trains on both sides of the Hudson have been well filled to-day by tourists en route for the Catskills.

CHICAGO, June 30.--The few members of the Democratic National Committee who are in the city paid a visit to-day to the Exposition Hall, where the alterations in progress were pointed out by Architect Adler. It was stated that under the new plan the only persons who will have seats on the stage will be the members of the National Committee, the officers of the convention, and the official reporters.
LEWISTON, Me., June 30.--The Hon. C.A. Boutelle has resigned his position on the Republican State Committee, and is succeeded by John L. Entler, of Bangor.

LONDON, June 30.--A match game of cricket was begun to-day at Cheltenham, between the Philadelphia team and the Gentlemen of Gloucester. The Americans went to the bat first, and in their first inning scored 162 points.

The laying of the corner-stone of the new building of the Bloomingdale Reformed Church, at Sixty-eighth-street and Broadway took place last evening. When completed it will have a front of 127 feet on Broadway and 97 feet on Sixty-eighth-street.

The recent action of the Western Union Telegraph Company in erecting on Friend-street a line of very large poles, intended to carry a hundred wires or more, has had the effect of inducing the tariff association of the Boston underwriters ...

WASHINGTON, June 30.--The House will have to hurry up with unusual celerity if it is to adjourn this week, which, by the way, very few members now believe it will. It did not make any haste to-day, but listened to speeches upon the Fortifications Appropriation bill.

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 30.--A furious gale of wind from the north-west swept through the State to-day. It was first noticed at Aberdeen, Dakota, at 7:30 A.M., and reached St. Paul at 12:30, making the distance of over 400 miles in five hours.

The General Term of the Court of Common Pleas has decided to sustain the injunction orders obtained by the National Steam-ship Company and its General Agent, F.W.J. Hurst, against the Produce Exchange and George W. Cazhart, a freight agent of the Erie Railway.

BOSTON, Mass., June 30.--The single scull race on the Charles River this afternoon between John McKay, of Halifax, and Patrick E. McInerney, of Lowell, for a purse of $500, was won by McKay in 21:35 . The distance was three miles, with a turn. At the turn McInerney fouled the stake and McKay gained a lead of eight lengths. This was reduced to three lengths at the finish.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., June 30.--A party of Amherst Seniors roused the whole neighborhood of that part of Amherst village known as Eaststreet early Sunday morning by riotous behavior.

The funerals of Mr. and Mrs. Amos Woodruff will take place at their late residence, No. 70 West Forty-sixth-street, to-day, at 4:30 P.M. Mrs. Woodruff died on Saturday last, while the death of Mr. Woodruff occurred yesterday. Mrs. Woodruff's death was caused by paralysis, from which she had been a sufferer for nearly two years. Mr. Woodruff died of pneumonia.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., June 30.--The Equitable Building, in which all the Gould and Wabash Railroad general offices are located, was purchased today by the Equitable Life Assurance Society of New-York from the Mercantile Trust Company, of the same city. The price paid is stated to have been between $375,000 and $400.000. The building was formerly owned by the Equitable Life Assurance Society.
Senator Murtha presided last evening at an informal meeting of Democratic ward leaders, in Jefferson Hall, Brooklyn, for the purpose of arranging the details of the journey to Chicago.

BOSTON, June 30.--Congressman Ray, of New-Hampshire, tells his friends that he has determined not to be a candidate for re-election, and that he intends to announce it in an open letter which will soon be published. This means that he has made up his mind to be a candidate for the United States Senate to succeed Mr. Blair.

The most obvious comment on the debate which occupied the House yesterday over the Fortifications bill is as to its extreme untimeliness. The question of what the United States can and ought to do to put its coast in a state of defense, in case of a foreign war, is difficult, and is not likely to be definitely solved in this generation.

KEOKUK, Iowa, June 30.--A construction train on the Chicago, Burlington and Kansas City Railroad went through the temporary bridge over the Grand River, near Sumner, Mo., tonight. The engine, five cars, and a caboose are in the bed of the stream. It is reported that 10 men are missing and that a number of others are injured.

A very dangerous fire broke out at 7:15 o'clock yesterday morning on the second floor of the five-story brick buildings Nos. 1, 3, and 5 Catharine-street, which are one structure, owned by several persons, whose agent is B.M. Levy, of No. 111 Fulton-street.

BUFFALO, N.Y., June 30.--The recent musical festival in this city proves to have been an unusual financial success. A guarantee fund of $22,000 was subscribed and 10 per cent. of it called in, but now that the accounts have been settled the managers find themselves able to return the whole of this money, and there will be 500 left as net profit over all expense.

The representation of "Olivette" at the Cosmopolitan Theatre last evening was by no means the most impressive that popular opera has had in New-York, but it was vastly superior as an entertainment to the performances that have taken place in the house during the past two weeks.

PHILADELPHIA, June 30.--Maria F. Markham, after 14 years of waiting, has obtained from the Common Pleas Court, No. 3, a divorce from Arthur T. Markham, who is known to theatre-goers as actor Frank Mordaunt.
