HUDSON, N.Y., June 30.--The Nonpareil Club left Rondout at 1:30 this afternoon and arrived here at 6:30. They were received at Rondout by the Cornell Hose Company and the Canoe Club. They were received here by the Hoysradt Boat Club. They leave for Albany at 9 o'clock to-morrow morning.

To-day St. Petersburg took its turn in witnessing a dazzling imperial pageantry such as Moscow was treated to during the coronation festivities of last Spring. The occasion of this repetition of some of the outdoor splendor of the coronation was the state entry of her Grand Ducal Highness Princess Elizabeth of Hesse ...

BALTIMORE, June 30.--Joseph J.C. Dougherty, late chief clerk in the money order division of the Baltimore Post Office, arrested on the 18th inst. for embezzling $3,200, was brought before United States Commissioner Rogers to-day. He waived an examination and was committed to jail to await trial in September next.

MILFORD, Penn., June 30.--George Smith, who was found guilty of the murder of Frank Heitz on the night of May 12, was sentenced today by Judge Seeley to be hanged. The date of the execution is to be given by the Governor of the State.

LONDON, July 1.--The Standard this morning says: "Influential Irish-Americans have urged Mr. Parnell to issue an address to the Irish voters in America requesting them to support Mr. Blaine in the presidential contest, in the hope that his election would result in fomenting difficulties between England and the United States. Mr. Parnell has heretofore declined to accede to a request of this nature."
BERLIN, June 30.--It is announced that at the next session the Government will submit to the Reichstag a scheme for greatly enlarging the navy.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 30.--A decided sensation was created in this city to-day by the disclosure of the fact that the present Grand Jury has indicted three of the leading gamblers in this city. For the past two years this city has borne the unpleasant reputation of being the "pride of gamblers."

It is hardly worth while speculating, as some of our contemporaries have taken to doing, upon what would happen if Gen. BUTLER should be nominated by the Democratic Convention. That is one blunder which the Democrats are not likely to commit.

The National Woman's Christian Temperance Union gave a reception last evening in No. 16 East Fourteenth-street in honor of Mrs. B. Pearson, of Nottingham, England, the VicePresident of the British Woman's Temperance Association, and President of the Nottingham branch, and an active member of the British Woman's Suffrage Association.

MARLBOROUGH, June 30.--The steamboats City of Kingston and James W. Baldwin, of Rondout, and the propellers Miller and Hasbrouck, of Poughkeepsie, land here every evening for freight, which during the Summer months is composed almost wholly of berries, peaches, grapes, and other small fruits.

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 30.--John T. Harrington died at Harrington's Mills on Friday, aged 101 years. Mr. Harrington was born near Albany, N.Y., in 1783. He married a cousin of President Van Buren, and during his younger days engaged somewhat in politics. He was a soldier in the war of 1812. His youngest son is 65 years of age.

CHICAGO, June 30.--Suit was brought today by Mrs. Annie Fanning against the Right Rev. Patrick Terry, Pastor of St. Patrick's Catholic Church, of this city. The complainant alleges that her uncle, Michael Lanning, died 20 years ago, ...

By the aid of one of the cast-iron rules of the Senate, Mr. Morgan, of Alabama, succeeded to-day in defeating the proposition of the Senate Committee on Commerce to provide for a Board of Superintendence to protect NewYork Harbor from being made the dumpingground for New-York and its surrounding cities.

TROY, N.Y., June 30.--This evening at 8 o'clock the remains of the late William A. Beach arrived, and were taken to St. Paul's Church. The pall-bearers for to-morrow are Judge C.R. Ingalls, Counsellor Levy Smith, Counsellor Esek Cowen, John B. Pierson, President of the Troy City Bank, and Controller John D. Spicer.

WASHINGTON, June 30.--A board to consist of Lieut.-Col. R.N. Batchelder, Deputy QuartermasterGeneral; Capt. J.H. Gilman, Commissary of Subsistence, and Capt.V. McNally, Ordnance Store-keeper, will assemble at the War Department to-morrow to examine into the present system of purchasing, distributine, and accounting for supplies and property pertaining to the War Department and its bureaus, ...

TORONTO, Ontario, June 30.--The Montreal stock market opened quiet to-day, and prices were steady, but declined slightly at the close. Federal Bank stock sold down from 62 to 53. The Federal business will be considerably curtailed, and the branch office in Montreal, as well as the other branches, will be closed in the course of time. At Toronto all is quiet, and the Federal Bank business has resumed the even tenor of the way.

Bill Sykes's bulldog was a beast with a face that was human as compared with that of the biped who reeled across the ring in MadisonSquare Garden last evening. A crowd of 6,000 persons watched the man climb the stairs with unsteady step and crawl under the rope, assisted by his friend, "Billy" O'Brien.

NORWICH, June 30.--Church "lawn parties" have been very fashionable in this city. Two or three hundred church members, ladies and gentlemen, in Summer attire, gather on the lawn of a fellow-member, play tennis and croquet, and eat ice-cream under the trees.

CLEVELAND, June 30.--The New-York base-ball team again profited by the Cleveland's errors and won their game to-day with ease. Heavy hitting by Ewing, Connor, and McKinnon, and errors by McCormick, Briody, and Murphy account for the result.

CINCINNATI, June 30.--Mrs. Eliza Blakenly to-day obtained a verdict for $5,000 damages against Chris. Green, a saloon-keeper, in a suit under the provisions of what is known as "the Adair liquor law," which makes a saloon-keeper amenable to the wife of a drunkard if he continues to sell him liquor after being warned by her not to do so. Her husband died from the effects of drink.

John Carpenter walked unsteadily as he was led into the Court of General Sessions yesterday for trial for killing his wife, Mary, on May 26, in Third-avenue. His face was haggard, his eyes glared wildly, and his hair was bristling, while his head was swollen and scarred by another attempt at suicide in the Tombs yesterday morning by beating himself with the buckler on the "muffler" that encased his hands.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 30.--The pay car of the West Shore Railroad is here this afternoon to make the April payments. There are no prospects to-day of a strike here.

Jacob Basch, Charles J. Basch, and Henry L. Basch, composing the firm of Jacob Basch Sons, manufacturers of shoddy and flocks and dealers in wool and wool waste at No. 95 Reade-street, with mills at Passaic, N.J., and ...

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., June 30.--Mary Kelly, a respectable Irishwoman, was murdered in her room, at No. 400 Henry-street, at noon today, by John R. Caldwell, 56 years old, a painter by trade and a drunkard by habit, who had a room in the same house, which is occupied by George Donnelly, janitor of the Merchants' Exchange.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 30.--Intelligence reached this city to-day of the shooting and fatal wounding of John Vanters, Town Marshal, at Turner Station, Henry County, at that place Saturday by a desperado named Lucien Evans. An old grudge was the cause of the shooting.

The residents of New-Rochelle take great pride in their new public school building. It was completed last Winter, and was formally opened on Washington's Birthday. The building is situated on the summit of a hill, fronting on Trinity-street, between Church and Centre avenues. It is two stories high, and a view is obtained from its windows a long distance up Long Island Sound.

When a Bible was held out to Mrs. Michael Kelly, on her appearance as a witness in Judge McCarter's court, at Newark, yesterday, against her husband, whom she had had arrested for beating her, she recoiled from it.

WASHINGTON, June 30.--Mr. W.H. English, of Indiana, appeared to-day before the special House committee appointed to investigate the charge made against him of using improperly the privileges of the House floor. Mr. English said that before the Committee on Elections made its report on the English-Peelle case he called at the homes of Messrs. Turner, Cook, ...

CARMEL, N.Y., June 30.--The adjourned session of the Putnam County Circuit Court convened here to-day, and had for its business the trial of the negro James Riley, charged with the murder of Mrs. Hannah Sunderlin, of Patterson, ...

SANDUSKY, Ohio, June 30.--To-day, while a farmer named John Cruise, who resided near here, was crossing one of his fields he was attacked by a vicious bull, which gored him to death. The deceased man was 60 years of age and leaves a family.

James Quinn, the boy who was accidentally shot on Sunday, in One Hundred and Eighthstreet, between Fifth and Madison avenues, by a playmate, John Kelly, of One Hundred and Eighth-street and Madison-avenue, died last evening at No.63 East One Hundred and Eighthstreet. Kelly, who was remanded at the Harlem Police Court yesterday by Justice Gorman, was much affected when told of Quinn's fate in the Twenty-third Precinct Station-house.

TORONTO, Ontario, June 30.--The first twelve of the Toronto Lacrosse Club, which on Saturday, in the match with the celebrated Shamrock Club, or Montreal, maintained the title of champions of the world, have accepted an invitation of Erastus Wiman to visit NewYork on the 8th and 9th of July, for the purpose of playing a series of matches with the American lacrosse team on its return from England.

PHILADELPHIA, June 30.--Mary Kelly, aged 30 years, who is employed as a laundress, was shot and killed about 12:15 this afternoon by John Caldwell, 56 years old. Both the murderer and his victim live on the third floor of a house near Eleventh and Lombard streets.

The Chairman of the Stock Exchange announced yesterday that by resolution of the Governing Committee contracts in the Exchange which mature on July 4 must be settled July 3. Contracts maturing July 5 and 6 may be settled July 7.

Mr. Hopkins, who was connected with A.T. Stewart Co. for 25 years before the dissolving of that firm, and who is now managing the Hilton estate, was seen yesterday by a TIMES reporter, to whom he told the following story: "I got on a Broadway car, No. 164, at Fourteenthstreet, at about 5 o'clock on last Saturday afternoon, having in my hand a lighted cigar, which was more than half-smoked up.

BALTIMORE, June 30.--An ardent young lover and an irate old father has a lively duel with pistols this morning in the north-western section of the city. It was not a duel after the style of the Virginia code, but a regular fusillade.

A Boston Judge upset a whole courtroom of lawyers the other day by an unprecedented ruling. He was listening one morning for an unending time to testimony, good, bad, and unreliable, in regard to the width of a certain street.

In Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday, Judge Lawrence heard the motion for the continuance of the injunction obtained by Charles A. Fuller, restraining the Mayor and his fellow-Commissioners of the Sinking Fund from letting the franchises for ferries to be operated between Bay Ridge and the north shore of Staten Island, respectively, and Pier No. 1 East River. Ex-Judge Ashbel Green, appeared for Mr.Fuller.

Tammany Hall and the County Democracy are vying with each other to see which organization shall take the largest crowd to the Chicago Convention and create the greatest sensation during the trip and on their arrival. Each organization has seven delegates, but the County Democracy has the advantage of a definite candidate--Gov. Cleveland--for whom it is unanimous, while Tammany Hall is divided on ...

The famous soldier and Indian cheif, Gen. Ely S. Parker, who was chief of staff to Gen. Grant during the war, and wrote out the terms of Lee's capitulation, recently sent the following letter to Mr. William C. Bryant, of the Buffalo Historical Society:

CLEVELAND, June 30.--Daniel Dekarek, a Bohemian living on First-street, hanged himself this evening. His wife found him hanging in the garret. When cut down life was extinct. He was 50 years of age and prominent among his people.
LONDON, June 30.--The Mark-Lane Express, in its weekly review of the grain trade says: "The weather has continued most favorable for improving the strong and helping the weak crops.

MILFORD, Penn., June 30.--The case of the Commonwealth against George Jacob Schmidlin was called this morning on a rule for a new trial. After hearing the evidence and the argument of counsel the Judges refused to grant a new trial, and Schmidlin was sentenced to be hanged. He received the sentence with calmness.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 30.--Henry Utasch left his home in Butternut-street at 4 o'clock yesterday morning and wandered to Round-top Hill. Sitting down among the bushes he pulled from his pocket a knife, closely resembling a three-corner file, and plunged it into his throat, inflicting a terrible gash. He then cut both wrists and stabbed himself eight times in the body. When he was found he was alive, but he died at 9 o'clock this evening.
PITTSBURG, Penn., June 30.--Mr. B.F. Jones, Chairman of the Republican National Committee, has returned home and talks freely about the campaign.

BUFFALO, N.Y., June 30.--The statement of the grain trade of this ciiy for the season up to date shows it to be lighter than for several years. The receipts of grain by lake are but 14,602,219 bushels, against 21,766,234 bushels up to the same date last year.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., June 30.--Alexander Barnett and George Lodge, of Scranton, and Hugh Mills and his wife Amanda, of Pike Brook, recently arrested for manufacturing and passing counterfeit money, had a hearing before United States Commissioner Hahn this afternoon.

An arrangement has been made by the Missouri Pacific Railroad Company by which the Mercantile Trust Company will cash the coupons due to-day on the New-Orleans Pacific bonds. The trust company will hold the coupons uncanceled subject to redemption.
Three alarms were sent out at 7:45 o'clock last night for a fire which broke out on the third floor of the four-story buildings at Nos. 502 and 504 West Forty-fifth-street.
Amos R. Eno has transferred the premises No. 922 Broadway, for $138,750, to Charles W. Burgoyne.
The Campaign Committee of the Repub-- lican General Committee of Kings County was to have met for the purpose of organization last evening in Tax Collector Tanner's office.

Twelve good men and true decided in 1879 that Washington E. Hall had made a defective certificate to a return from the election for Alderman in the Sixth District, and that Thomas Boland had made fraudulent returns from the same election.

McDONALD's STATION, Penn., June 30.-- A gang of Italian railroad laborers had a fight here early this morning, during which Carmine Poppe was shot twice by Antoine Petre and fatally wounned. Petre escaped. All the participants in the affair were intoxicated.
CHETOPA, Kan., June 30.--There is great consternation among stock men having ranches in the Indian Territory.

Toulon is undergoing punishment for the unspeakable filthiness of her streets and houses. Although filth will not in any temperate climate generate cholera, it provides the conditions which are most favorable to the rapid propagation of cholera germs in case the latter are imported.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., June 30.--A petition for an injunction has been filed by the attorney of John McCaull against Charles E. Ford, to restrain the latter from producing Planquette's opera of "Nell Gwynne" at Uhrig's Cave in this city. The matter has been postponed until tomorrow so that Ford may be notified.

WASHINGTON, Penn., June 30.--This afternoon the remains of John M. Rowe, who died in New-York Friday last, were incinerated in the Lemoyne Crematory. The body was accompanied by Robert Nulty, of New-York, to whose daughter Mr. Rowe was engaged to be married.

Joseph J. Stewart, counsel for Samuel J. Francis and his wife, Mary Elizabeth, who were committed to the Queens County Insane Asylum on Saturday on the certificate of Mrs. W.D. Wood and P.M. Wood, of Jamaica, visited his clients in the asylum yesterday.

MONTREAL, Q uebec, June 30.--The firm of H. Merrill, one of the oldest and best known dry goods houses in the city, being unable to meet the last payment of a compromise arranged about 16 months ago, to-day made an assignment.
Three petitions for the right to lay tracks in the streets of New-York were presented to the Board of Aldermen yesterday.

Chancellor Runyon granted an order yesterday preparatory to the restoration of the heretofore defunct Dime Savings Institution to the hands of its managers. At the time of its suspension Chancellor Runyon permitted the Directors to manage it under his supervision.
The counsel for the Council of Political Reform appeared before Judge Barrett, in the Supreme Court, yesterday, but John E. Parsons, of counsel for the Park Commissioners, did not appear.
TROY, N.Y., June 30.--Brother Gabriel, of Troy Provincial Seminary, says that the report that several Boston students took their books home and would not return to the seminary is untrue.
MAYVILLE, N.Y., June 30.--The Supervisors of Chautauqua County met in special session to-day to investigate the affairs of the County Treasurer.

It is announced by telegram from Madrid that the concession granted for laying a cable from Portugal to America, via the Azores, has been transferred to a joint stock enterprise entitled the American, British and Continental Cable Company, (limited.)

At a meeting of the Blaine and Logan Campaign Club of the Twenty-third Assembly District last evening, at No. 2,291 Third-avenue, Richard Taylor, the Treasurer, said that Chester A. Arthur had been his first choice, but when the convention gave him Blaine he declared that he was the man for him.

In the Court of General Sessions, yesterday, Adolph Adams, age 21, was on trial before Judge Gildersleeve for killing his wife, Mary, on May 20, in a disorderly house, No. 140 Forsythstreet. Adams's wife was an inmate of the house.

The President has signed the bill providing for a National Bureau of Labor as an adjunct of the Department of the Interior. Whether it is to prove useful or not depends altogether on the qualifications of the Commissioner who is to be placed at its head.

An Avalanche reporter yesterday went through the inquests returned during the year and found some very unique examples of "English as she is wrote." There were a great many inquests held upon persons who died from spasms, malarial fever, congestion of the brain, chills, old age, and natural causes. The following are the causes assigned for the deaths of some of the parties:

PARIS, June 16.--Never was a popular fete more completely organized for full success than that of the press a few days ago. At 2 o'clock an eager throng had begun to pour into the two principal entrances--one at the Porte de la Maette and another half-way down the avenue of ...
TOULON, June 30.--Between 6 o'clock last night and noon to-day six deaths from cholera had occurred here.

READING, Penn., June 30.--The question of approving the bonds of the Schuylkill Valley Railroad to indemnify the Philadelphia and Reading, over whose property the new road wants to construct its line, was argued in court today. Counsel for Philadelphia and Reading contended that one railroad has no right to take the franchises of another for railroad purposes, and ...

TORONTO, Ontario, June 30.--This city began a celebration to-day in honor of the fiftieth year of its incorporation. In the municipal historical parade the floral display made by the Fire Department was the finest ever seen here, and drew cheers from the crowds all along the line of the procession.
The Hon. D.D. Stewart, who was President of the State Senate of Maine in 1865, has addressed the following letter to the editor of the Bangor Commercial:

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, June 30.--It is stated that a line of British-Chilian sailing vessels of suitable tonnage will shortly establish a new trade between here and Valparaiso. This line will eventually be replaced by a regular steam-ship line. William Wingfield Bonnyn, Chilian Vice-Consul at Halifax, is the promoter of the scheme, and is seconded by London and Valparaiso firms, which are aiding in the project.
PLYMOUTH, June 30.--While a gang of 25 convicts were at work here one of the number threw a large stone at the solitary Warder which struck the officer in the head, inflicting a stunning blow.
PHILADELPHIA, June 30.--Adolph Proskauer, well known as a restaurateur in this city, attempted to commit suicide at the Hotel Lafayette, Cape May, late on Saturday evening.

WASHINGTON, June 30.--After a secret meeting of the Springer committee to-day the Chairman announced that the committee did not think it was necessary for W.A. Cook to appear again as a witness. He had asked for an opportunity to reply to the testimony of Gens. Swaim and Boynton.

There arrived at the New-York Hotel last week two families of distinguished and wealthy lawyers, of Havana, Cuba. One was Francisco Figuera, a stalwart man of 30, and his wife. The other was Santiago Alonso Barroeta, a tall, well-knit man, with the blackest of hair and whiskers, his wife and his uncle, Ramon Barroeta, an errect and military-looking gentleman of 60.

PHILADELPHIA, June 30.--When George F. Burkley, a corset manufacturer at No. 135 Girard-avenue, descended to the kitchen in the rear of the store at 9:30 o'clock this morning, he found the body of his wife lying on the floor.
MOBILE, Ala., June 30.--A negro attempted an assault upon a white woman at Georgiana, Ala., on June 24, and when arrested confessed next day while waiting transportation to jail.

Industry and trade in Russia are depressed. Complaints, says a correspondent, increase every day. Money is scarce and credit hard to get. Among the small manufacturers failures are frequent occurrences. The stock market is extremely dull.

It was the favorite's turn at Sheepshead Bay yesterday, for they won five successive races, and the knowing ones were consequently in a happy frame of mind when the sport ended. The racing was not of an exciting nature, for the majority of them were won easily and it was only in the fourth race that any excitement was manifested.

The new law "removing certain burdens from shipping" entering American ports goes into effect to-day. Congressman Nelson Dingley, Jr., of Maine, the author of the new law, spent about an hour with Collector Robertson yesterday, discussing the provisions of the act and explaining such points as the Collector desired to be enlightened upon. Besides abolishing hospital fees, the new law provides:
The Oregon and California Railroad line was surrendered to its owners by the Oregon and Transcontinental Company yesterday under the agreement by which the lease of the first named road was canceled.
NEW-ORLEANS, June 30.--This morning John Sores, a coal-passer on the Morgan Line steam-ship Chalmetta, appeared before United States Commissioner Hunt and made affidavits that on Sunday, June 22, ...
The President to-day nominated ex-Congressman Henry B. Neal, of Ohio, to be Solicitor of the Treasury.

CINCINNATI, June 30.--Ex-Gov. Bishop, in an interview to-day, made an interesting disclosure regarding an understanding he claims to have had with Mr. Tilden in 1880. At that time the ex-Governor was prominently spoken of as the Democratic candidate for the Vice-Presidency, and in the convention he ranked next in point of strength with William H. English.

The stockholders of the Manhattan Railway Company met at No. 71 Broadway yesterday noon for the purpose of ratifying the new merger agreement of June 5. The terms of the agreement were stated to the meeting as below:

STATE CAMP OF INSTRUCTION, PEEKSKILL, June 30.--The gallant Thirty-second got its first taste of the hard work of camp life to-day, and so did the separate companies--the Twentysixth from Elmira, the Twenty-ninth from Oswego, and the Thirteenth from Jamestown. Col. Finkelmeier is determined that his regiment ...

LONDON, June 30.--In the House of Commons to-day Mr. Gladstone moved that the vote of censure of the Government's Egyptian policy be given precedence of all other business. This motion was defeated by a vote of 190 to 148. The rejection of the motion was wholly unexpected.

SING SING, June 30.--The total earnings at Sing Sing Prison for the month of June were $19,778.08, and the expenditures $13,776.87, leaving a profit for the month of $6,001.21. The profits for Auburn Prison for June were $468.
BOSTON, June 30.--The supreme officers of the Knights of Honor, an organization having a membership of about 150,000 throughout the country, are engaged in a contest ...
Judge A.R. Wright has written a letter to the Rome Courier in which he asks the question: "Why might not the Chicago Convention nominate Butler and Carlisle?"
The last Legislature passed a bill authorizing the closing of Fourth-avenue, between Forty-second and Forty-fifth streets, and the opening of a street the same width directly east of the present one.
PROVINCETOWN, Mass., June 30.--From June 7 to this date the 16 vessels from this town employed in the mackerel fishery have landed 3,500 barrels of mackerel, nearly all being small fish.

WASHINGTON, June 30.--The back-set which Cleveland has been suffering here as a candidate, in consequence of the assiduous adverse arguments put forth by the Tammany agents and newspapers in the capital, has been overcome to a great extent by correspondence ...

Twenty-three indictments against men who have been engaged in pool-selling at the Sheepshead Bay race track during the June meeting were handed to Judge Moore by the Grand Jury, in the Kings County Court of Sessions, yesterday morning.
The condition of the market in the Produce Exchange has been somewhat erratic of late and rumors of financial trouble have been in circulation for several days.

Policy Justice Jacob M. Patterson enjoyed a rousing reception last evening in Beethoven Hall, in Fifth-street, on his return from the Pacific coast. The members of the Patterson Association were out in full force, and most of the well-known faces in the Tenth Assembly District were seen in the audience.

ROME, Ga., June 30.--Several negroes have died under mysterious circumstances here lately. Robert Holmes, colored, practicing medicine without authority has been arrested, and has been bound over for malpractice.

The Ladies' Day of the Knickerbocker Yacht Club was favored with bright weather and a fine southerly breeze, which sent the little craft with their fair crews flying over the white caps which covered the course. According to the racing regulations, the crews were to be composed equally of ladies and gentlemen, and in honor of the occasion the lady tars turned out in novel and striking costumes.
Corporation Counsel Taylor, of Brooklyn, has written a letter to City Works Commissioner Fleeman, in which he says he has considered the bearing of the Underground Wire law ...

CINCINNATI, Ohio, June 30.--St. Joseph's Catholic Orphan Asylum, situated near the Cold Springs, six miles back of Newport, was entirely destroyed by fire to-day. The asylum was founded and supported by the St. Bonifacius Society, of Newport.

NEW-ORLEANS, June 30.--News has been received here of the assassination, in St. Bernard Parish, of a young man named Maipero. He was called out of his bed by a crowd of armed men during the night and shot.
CHICAGO, June 30.--The house of Fairbanks, Palmer Co., subscription book publishers, of Nos.133 and 135 Wabash-avenue, was closed by the Sheriff this morning.
CHICAGO, June 30.--There was a fair attendance at the races at the Chicago Driving Park to-day. The weather was warm and the track fast.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, June 30.--Brier Hill, a suburb of this city, was the scene last night of a horrible affair. Four children of Mrs. Ann Murphy went to bed about 9 o'clock, and about 11 o'clock smoke and flames were discovered issuing from their bedroom window.

BALTIMORE, June 30.--"Please bury my ring and the lock of hair in the grave with me," was the request written on a little package containing the above named articles in the room of Walter Terrell, 20 years of age, who shot himself this morning at his residence in this city.

The conditions upon which cyclists have just been admitted to the London parks are worth attention here, where the question is still in dispute. Some of the smaller parks are still kept closed, on the ground that already the traffic is excessive. This is intelligible.

NEW-ORLEANS, July 1.--This morning John H. Vincent, second engineer of the Morgan steamer Chalmette, was brought before United States Commissioner Hunt on a charge of manslaughter on the high seas. He was arrested on Monday, but was granted bail in $1,000 for his appearance.
Fire broke out on the fourth floor of E. Greenfield's Son Co.'s candy factory, No. 44 Barclay-street, at 9:20 o'clock last night.
The gates of the Brighton Beach track will be opened again to the public to-day, and racing will be resumed with the following programme:

AUGUSTA, Me., July 1.--The Hon. James G. Blaine delivered the diplomas to the graduating class of the Hollowell Classical and Scientific Academy this afternoon, accompanying the ceremony with a brief review of the history and progress of the institution.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., July 1.--The trial of Edwin Botheras, the murderer, who killed William Nichols at Hazleton on March 1, was concluded yesterday afternoon. The jury, after being out all night, came into court this morning with a sealed verdict finding Botheras guilty of murder in the first degree. Sentence was deferred.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., July 1.--An interesting Alumni meeting was held this morning in the college chapel. Vice-President H.E. Scudder, '59, was in the chair, and the Rev. Mr. Everett, '59, lead in prayer.
A Norwich doctor was called to a frightened family Thursday to attend to the paternal head of the house, who had swallowed at a gulp one ounce of laudanum.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 1.--James G. Blaine is expected here in eight or ten day's to visit Gen. Ekin. He will be accompanied by Mrs. Blaine and one of the daughters, who will spend the Summer with Mrs. Ekin. Mr. Blaine will only be here a day and a night. He will be handsomely entertained. Gen. Ekin is a cousin of Mr. Blaine.

ITHACA, N.Y., July 1.--After an exceedingly hot day, a cyclone of rain and hail, of terrific force, which had been gathering all the afternoon, struck this village to-night. The water fell in sheets, flooding the streets, some of which are filled with fallen trees and huge limbs. Great alarm was felt, but no lives were lost.
VICTORIA, British Columbia, July 1.--An explosion at the Wellington Colliery, yesterday, at Nanaimo, killed 24 miners and injured a number of others.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 1.--By superior play, both at the bat and in the field, the Brooklyn Club to-day succeeded in winning their second game from the home club by a score of 6 to 0. Kember's pitching was effective and his support admirable.

President Bartlett, of Dartmouth College, writes thus to the Republican: "Your special dispatch from Hanover in Friday's Republican stated that two young men 'were granted diplomas by the Trustees contrary to the recommendation of the Faculty.'
The Controller's statement of the condition of the city finances June 30 was made public yesterday.

CHICAGO, July 1.--Allan Pinkerton, the head of the famous detective agency, who has been dangerously ill for the last three weeks, died at 3:05 o'clock this afternoon at his residence, No. 554 West Monroe-street. Some time ago Mr. Pinkerton fell and bit his tongue, and gangrene, which set in, resulted in his death.

COLUMBUS, July 1.--The new Columbus Board of Trade rooms were formally opened tonight, with a large attendance. Judge Thurman, the first and only honorary member, delivered an address, touching mostly on local matters.

Coroner Merkle yesterday commenced an investigation in the case of Josephine Cress, an infant 3 months and 22 days old, who died on Monday at an institution known as the St. Vincent de Paul's Nursery, at No. 692 East ...

When the River and Harbor bill was under consideration in the House of Representatives Mr. Thomas P. Ochiltree, of Texas, successfully urged the striking out of the item for the improvement of the channel between Galveston Harbor and the Gulf of Mexico.

The Chairman of the Stock Exhange gave notice yesterday that the first mortgage registered 7 per cent. bonds of the Delaware and Hudson Canal Company, amounting to $3,465,000, and the Central Pacific. Railroad State Aid 7 per cent. bonds, amounting to $1,500,000, having matured, had been dropped from the regular list.
RICHFIELD SPRINGS, N.Y., July 1.--The whole village is ablaze with electric lights tonight. In front of the Spring House and the new American Hotel are five 3,000 candle-power Remington are lights.

Adelaide Paw, of No. 119' Mechanic street, Newark, was arrested on a charge of malpractice yesterday. The complaint is made by Lydia Kitchen, who alleges that the woman Paw did the act at the solicitation of Charles Wiegand, who had betrayed her. A number of instruments were found in Mrs. Paw's house. She was released on $2,500 bail.
ST. PAUL, Minn., July 1.--Preparations are being made on an extensive scale for the annual meeting of the Society of the Army of the Tennessee at Lake Minnetonka, Aug. 13 and 14.
BINGHAMTON, N.Y., July 1.--Gen. Hiram D. Rogers, a veteran of the late war, formally accepted command of the Twentieth Separate Comnany N.G.S.N.Y., otherwise known as ...
COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 1.--The Metropolitan Club played their second game on the home grounds this afternoon before a large audience.
BOSTON, July 1.--Isaac Jacobs, a middleaged Jew, was brought here to-night from NewYork, where he was arrested yesterday on a larceny warrant, but is held here on the ...

The Tammany Hall Committee on Organization held its last meeting prior to the Chicago Convention in the cave of Tammany Hall last evening. From reports made by the Chairmen of the district associations it was ascertained that between 575 and 600 Tammany men will descend upon Chicago at 4 o'clock next Sunday afternoon.

PHILADELPHIA, July 1.--There was quite a crowd at the city banks to-day where interest and dividends were being paid. The amount disbursed in the city on Government, State, city, and other loans mounted, it is estimated, to fully $11,000,000.

BUEFALO, N.Y., July 1.--Frank Williams, a burglar, was sentenced in the Court of Sessions this morning to Auburn State Prison, on one charge for five years and on another for two. Sidney Kellogg, his accomplice, was indicted for receiving stolen property, and was committed for five years. Keilogg has been arrested 18 times, and has already served three terms of imprisonment. He committed his last offense three days after being released.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 1.--The Young Women's Christian Association of this city acknowledges to-day the receipt of a check for $1,000 from C.P. Huntington, of New-York.
The payment of the 60 per cent. dividend to the depositors of the defunct Newark Savings Institution was begun yesterdey morning.

In the United States District Court, before Judge Butler, yesterday, Joseph Reitz, whom Commissioner Bell had committed in default of $300 bail for taking a packet from "an authorized depository for mail matter," was given a hearing upon habeas corpus.

PHILADELPHIA, July 1.--The Siamese Embassy arrived here this morning and were escorted through the Mint, Girard College, Fairmount Park, and other places of interest. They left for New-York in the evening.

BURLINGTON, Vt., July 1.--The Republican State Committee met here to-night and elected as Chairman Warren Gibbs, President of the Vermont Life Insurance Company, of this city. Carroll S. Page, of Hyde Park, was elected Secretary.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, July 1.--Bremner Hart, shipping and West India merchants, one of the leading mercantile firms of this city, have suspended payment and are to make an assignment. Their liabilities and assets are unknown.
PHILADELPHIA, July 1.--The Pennsylvania Railroad Company introduced to-day a new ticket system, designed to do away with the clumsy coupons.

BALTIMORE, July 1.--Proposals for $115,000 of city bonds, payable in 1925, and bearing 4 per cent. interest per annum,, were opened today. The bids aggregated $448,000, and the bonds were awarded at premiums ranging from 10.78 to 14.25.
PATERSON, N.J., July 1.--On Saturday night a young man while crossing the Falls Bridge heard a man walking behind him. Suddenly the footsteps stopped and he heard a plash in the water.

THOMASVILLE, Ga., July 1.--The continued rains have seriously damaged truck, and without a speedy cessation the melon crop will be cut very short. No fruit has been put on for several days, and many of the vines are already dead or dying.

BOSTON, July 1.--Anti-Blaine Republican and independent organizations are forming this week in different towns. To-night an organization was effected in the town of Quincy, the home of the Adamses, and later in the week others will be completed in Chelsea, Winchester, and other places.
TROY, July 1.--The stone of the builder Steenbergh has been rejected, but shall become the head of the corner.
ST. JOHN, New Brunswick, July 1.--Wallace Ross left yesterday for Oak Point, N.Y. He received a letter on Saturday announcing that Teemer had covered his deposit.
REYNOLDSVILLE, Penn., July 1.--A fire started between 1 and 2 o'clock this morning at Driftwood, Cameron County, and destroyed the principal portion of the town before the flames were subdued.
Capt. Bowlby, of the ship Rhein, which arrived yesterday from Antwerp, reports that on June 26, when 300 miles east of Sandy Hook, he sighted a large vessel on fire.

The injunction suit brought by Peter M. Biegen, of Westchester County, against the Baltimore and Ohio Telegraph Company was decided by Justice Cullen, in Supreme Court, Chambers, Brooklyn, yesterday. Mr. Biegen, who is the owner of an extensive farm in the township of Greenburg, in Westchester, brought ...

John Carpenter gazed vacantly on the floor of the Court of General Sessions yesterday while the charge against him for killing his wife, Mary, in Third-avenue, on May 26, was being reviewed by his counsel in summing up. Counsel urged at length that Carpenter was insane when he commitied the deed, a theory which was vigorously combated by Assistant District Attorney Fellows.
MADRID, July 1.--In the Chamber of Deputies yesterday Senor Valdosera introduced a bill providing for an improvement of the situation of affairs in Cuba.

In submitting a report that there had been no agreement in conference on the Naval Appropriation bill, Mr. RANDALL gave several reasons for the firmness with which the House conferrees had adhered to the decision of the House.

At 11 o'clock last night, while Lizzie Kent, of Seventh-avenue and Twenty-eighthstreet, was passing through East Twenty-fourthstreet she was attacked by two colored men, who dragged her into the stable of Solomon Mehrbach, at No. 132 East Twenty-fourth-street, and brutally assaulted her. She was taken to Bellevue Hospital. Charles Harrison was arrested on suspicion or being one of the assailants.
BALTIMORE, July 1.--The managers of the Union Association base-ball clubs met here to-day at the Eutaw House and were in consultation all day.
ALBANY, July 1.--Deputy State Treasurer E.K. Apgar started for Chicago this afternoon, to complete the arrangements for the care of the New-York delegation during the Democratic National Convention.

BALTIMORE, July 1.--Spot wheat to-day reached the lowest point since the organization of the Corn and Flour Exchange of this city. The bid gas 94 cents, and the market closed dull. The absence of a foreign demand and the incoming heavy crop are attributed as the causes for this, the lowest price for more than 30 years.
LONDON, July 1.--The match game of cricket between the Philadelphia team and the Gentlemen of Gloucester which was begun yesterday at Cheltenham was resumed to-day.

Inasmuch as Mr. J.S. Clarkson could not be induced to accept the Chairmanship of the Republican National Committee, it is greatly to be regretted that an effort was not made to induce him to serve as Secretary.
PITTSBURG, Penn., July 1.--John Donaldson, while walking along Ohio-street, Allegheny City, last night, was attacked with all the symptoms of hydrophobia.

ATHENS, Ohio, July 1.--The general coal miners' strike that has been inaugurated throughout the Hocking Valley threatens to be attended by more serious consequences than any similar movement since the development of the coal resources in this section of the State.
CHICAGO, July.--The portraits of Thomas Jefferson, Stephen A. Douglas, Andrew Jackson, and Horatio Seymour are to adorn the Democratic Convention hall.

Mister John Lawrence Sullivan departed for his Boston home at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon, after a brief, but memorable, visit to the Metropolis. He arrived on Monday morning, accompanied by his wife and a whole train full of admirers.

LONDON, July 1.--The London correspondent of the Manchester Guardian says: "The conference has given a favorable reception to England's financial proposals regarding Egypt. It is expected that the deliberations of the conference will reach a successful result."
A neatly attired young woman went early yesterday morning to Felix Mayer's baths, No. 29 Delancey-street, and was given a bathroom in the rear of the establishment.
Frank White, the champion light-weight pugilist of America and the proprietor of the "Champions' Rest," in the Bowery, is an intimate friend and ardent admirer of John L. Sullivan.

HAVANA, June 26.--A report is current that Capt.-Gen. Castillo recently consulted the various provincial Governors of the island regarding the adoption of more vigorous measures for the repression of the revolutionary factions.

Prior to the failure of M. Morgan's Sons, last week, the banking firm of J. Allard Co., of Paris and London, dispatched to them three letters containing $31,000, which sum was to be used here for the house sending it.

A story was in circulation yesterday that a plan had been matured for causing an advance in the stock market. Mr. Gould, the story went, sent word to Mr. Vanderbilt that the time had come for such a move.

The meeting of the Coney Island Jockey Club was brought to a close yesterday under circumstances that were thoroughly exciting. There have been days when the favorites and their backers have been badly left, but yesterday was exceptional in this regard.
Two novel Parisian lockets, studded with diamonds, and valued at $600 each, were seized by Custom-house Inspectors yesterday.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 1.--A steel-finishers' syndicate, representing all the plow and blade manufacturers in the United States, is in session here. The object is to form a pool for mutual protection and for the advancement of prices.
In defense of the conduct of the Seventh Regiment at Hartford recently Mayor Bulkley, of Hartford, has written a letter to Col. Emmons Clark, in which he says:

Full and reliable advices to the Chronicle declare that the crop prospects throughout the country are magnificent. In the States of Georgia and South Carolina, in the territory traversed by this paper, and in the section tributary to Augusta such a cheering outlook had not been seen in many years.
Patrick Drennan, a deaf-mute, 25 years old, was found on Monday night drunk in Christopher-street.
DES MOINES, Iowa, July 1.--The Des Moines races of the Iowa circuit began to-day at the State Fair Grounds, but were not remuneratively attended.

"Yes, Sir! Steel is having a great boom," remarked Civil Engineer Edward H. Dorsey to a TIMES reporter who ran across him the other day. "I have been investigating the relative merits of iron and steel for 18 months past, during which I've made two trips to Europe.
TORONTO, Ontario, July 1.--A cable dispatch from London to the Globe says: "The annual meeting of the Canada North-west Land Company was held to-day.
And now that plank in the Republican platform relating to the appointment to office in the Territories is torn up, spit upon, and thrown away.

MILES CITY, Montana, July 1.--The committee appointed by the citizens of Eastern Montana to-day telegraphed Secretary Teller urging the immediate removal of the Northern Cheyenne Indians now on the Tongue and Rosebud Rivers.

It appears that the Prohibitionists who, in the interests of religion and morality, have nominated for the Presidency that Christian statesman, ex-Senator POMEROY, betterknown as "Old Subsidy POM," are only a part of the Prohibition Party.

WASHINGTON, July 1, 1884. The joint resolution introduced yesterday by Mr. Cameron, of Pennsylvania, directing the Secretary of the Treasury to redeem $10,000,000 worth of trade dollars at their face value was, on motion of Mr. Morrill, to-day referred to the Committee on Finance by a vote of 36 to 20. Similar action was taken regarding the resolution for an investigation into the condition of the New-York banks.

The schooner Ella A. Warner, Capt. Holbrook, which arrived last night from Philadelphia, ran into the schooner Eloise, from Bangor to Philadelphia, off the New-Jersey coast, at 2 A.M. yesterday, during a dense fog.
The weights assigned to the several entries in the Long Branch Handicap, to be run at Monmouth Park on Friday next, was made known after the selling sweepstakes at Sheepshead Bay yesterday.

The members of the Siamese Embassy returned to this city last evening on their journey back to Siam. They expressed themselves as well pleased with what they has seen of America, and spoke with regret that their plans did not permit them to spend a week longer on the fishing grounds among the Thousand Islands. They will sail for England on Saturday.

Detective James K. Price, of the Twentyninth Precinct, had been puzzled for several weeks over a number of mysterious thefts occurring at the boarding-house of Mrs. Stillson, No. 45 West Thirty-first-street, and did not solve the mystery until yesterday, when he arrested ...
The famous America, owned by Gen. Butler, is still hauled up at the navy-yard, Charlestown, and is likely not to go into commission this year.

BALTIMORE, July 1.--There has been trouble in the Baltimore Post Office for three weeks past, and the trouble culminated to-day when two of the sureties for Col. Harrison Adreon, the Postmaster, telegraphed to the Postmaster-General at Washington asking to be released from his bond.

The default of the Denver and Rio Grande Railroad Company yesterday on its July interest was not unexpected. That road has been having a hard time during the past Winter and Spring, and recent reports concerning its earnings have not encouraged holders of its bonds that the interest would be paid.

According to the reports of several vessels which arrived here yesterday the storms of last week caused much damage to shipping. Capt. Marston, of the schooner Emerson Robes, from Cardenas, states that on June 28, in latitude 33 and longitude 74 , he spoke the yacht Gipsey, which was bound from Panama for this port.

The consideration of military-bills which are neither on the private calendar nor merged in the annual Appropriation bill is nowadays such a novelty that the House must have been startled last week to find that it had passed in rapid succession half a dozen of these measures.

PHILADELPHIA, July 1.--The Times tomorrow will publish an account of some very dramatic scenes which took place in the courthouse at West Chester, Penn., to-day during the examination into the sanity of Mrs. Phoebe Eldridge, a wealthy lady connected with some of the most prominent families of the State.

JAMESTOWN, July 1.--In April, after a long suit, the Supreme Court removed Alexander M. Lowry as Trustee of the funds of his niece, E. Margaret Cook, and directed him to pay $50,000 to Robert Newland, her temporary Trustee. An application for a Receiver for Mr. Lowry's ...
A meeting of the Directors of the Metropolitan Elevated Railway was held at the Windsor Hotel last evening. The subject under consideration was the new merger agreement.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., July 1.--The Citizens League has decided to attempt the enforcement of the Sunday law, which demands that all saloons shall be closed on that day.

The brokers at the Windsor are laughing at the story of a heavy bill which a dentist sent to Gen. Blanco, the Venezuelan President, last week, for professional work for Mrs. Blanco and two of her daughters.

WASHINGTON, July 1.--First Lieut. William P. Duvall, Fifth Artillery, has been ordered to repair to this city and report to the Adjutant-General for special duty. First Lieut. James M. Jones, Fourth Artillery has, on his own application, been relieved from duty at the Military Academy, to take effect Aug. 28, and will then proceed to join his battery.

PHILADELPHIA, July 1.--The Press will publish to-morrow the following strange case: H.C. Shock, a draughtsman employed at Roach's ship-yard, was arrested at Chester today on the charge of desertion brought by his wife, now living in this city.

The Rev. W.B. Derrick, Pastor of the Bethel African Methodist Episcopal Church, has declined to serve as a candidate for one of the Electors at Large on the Republican ticket. He indignantly repels the charge that his withdrawal is on account of the charges that he is not an American citizen.

TORONTO, Ontario, July 1--The military parade to-day was the largest that has ever taken place in the Dominion, there being nearly 5,000 troops from different parts of Canada present, embracing all arms of the service except the Engineers. The whole were under command of Lieut.-Col. Denison.

SCRANTON, Penn., July 1.--The sudden and mysterious disappearance of the wife of exJudge Stanton from her home and children in Kansas City, Mo., has caused a profound sensation here, where her husband has been a prominent figure in local politics. William H. Stanton has been elected. District Attorney, member of the Assembly, State Senator, Congressman, ...

KEY WEST, Fla., July 1.--Diaz, the Cuban who came back in the schooner Shavers, was convicted to-day. He was charged with violation of the neutrality laws by aiding in fitting out an armed expedition against a friendly power. The jury were out but a short time. Judge Locke has not yet passed sentence.

GASTON, Oregon, June 21.--Can you not do something to stay the tide of immigration that is pouring into Oregon? What with last year's short crops; the adjustment of business to the cash system, and the retirement of capital by the

BALTIMORE, July 1.--At a picnic of the colored Baptist Union Sunday-school at Loch Raven, in Baltimore County, this afternoon, a difficult occurred, when Edward Coates, colored, shot Walter Harris, also colored, in the skull. Harris was brought to the City Hospital, where his wound is declared to be mortal. Coates was arrested.
ALBANY, N.Y., July 7.--The Nonpareil Rowing Club, of New-York, arrived here at 9 o'clock to-night. All the members of the crew are in good health and spirits.
There will be no question among honorable men of any country that the application made to Mr. LOWELL by certain Scotch holders of the bonds of the Oregon Railway is highly indecent.

BRUNSWICK, Me., July 1.--The Hon. James G. Blaire has accepted the invitation of the officers of Bowdoin College and will be in attendance on Commencement Day, July 10. He will be the guest of Gen. Chamberlain.

Two-thirds of the congregation that met in St. Thomas's Church yesterday to hear the Episcopal burial service read over the body of Abraham R. Warner were his associates in the Argonauta Boat Club and other athletic organizations.

Edward Isaacs, a diamond merchant, at No. 32 Maiden-lane, was arrested yesterday by Detective Sergeants King and Lyons, on warrants issued by Justice Smith, presiding at the Tombs Police Court, charging him with grand larceny.

John Dwyer, a laborer, living at No. 448 West Fifty-fifth-street, was a prisoner yesterday at the Jefferson Market Police Court charged with having stabbed and dangerously wounded Frank McKenna, a hod-carrier, of No. 232 West Thirty-second-street.
Much interest among members of the Produce Exchange centres in the game of baseball that has been arranged to be played in Washington Park, Brooklyn, this afternoon, between ...

NEW-ORLEANS, July 1.--As the debt amendment to the Constitution recently adopted provides that coupon Nos. 21 and 22 of the Louisiana consolidated bonds must be stamped "Interest reduced to 2 per cent. per annum" and that all subsequent coupons must
When Thomas Cassidy returned to his apartments, at No. 38 Downing-street, on Monday night, he found his wife drinking beer and carousing with the Whalen family.

The unpleasantness which occurred at the New-York Hotel Monday evening between Senors Ramon Barroeta and Santiago Alonso Barroeta and Francisco Figuera, wealthy and distinguished Cubans, and which subsequently culminated in a street fight, was the subject of an examination before Justice O'Reilly, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, yesterday.

D.W. Chapin, the conductor of car No. 164 of the Broadway and Seventh-avenue line, tells a very different story of his trouble with J.M. Honkins on Saturday afternoon last from that given by that gentleman.

SELIN'S GROVE, Penn., July 1.--A.K. Gift, of Middleburg, and Samuel Lentz, one of the Directors of the South Pennsylvania and Seaboard Railroad, which is soon to be built through the lower part of Snyder County, were in this place to-day and along the line securing the right of way.
There was an unusually cheerful feeling in wall-street yesterday, and the market advanced considerably, in consequence, it was believed, of the outpouring of money for July interest and dividends.
DETROIT, July 1.--To-day's base-ball game was loosely played on both sides, but the Detroit's errors were more numerous and far more costly.
LONDON, July 1.--The race for the July Stakes was run to-day at Newmarket, and was won by Luminary. Lord Hastings's b.c. Melton was second; and Mr. F. Jennings's ch.c. Present Times third.

The members of the Young Men's Democratic Club, of Brooklyn, who attended, the meeting last night in their rooms, in Courtstreet, were informed that they had been called together to consider the advisability of indorsing some one of the prominent candidates for President in their party.
TROY, N.Y., July 1.--The funeral of William A. Beach took place this afternoon from St. Paul's Church, the Rev. Dr. Francis Harrison officiating.

CHARLESTON, S.C., July 1.--The rebellion in the African Methodist Episcopal Church has been brought to a temporary close here through the efforts of Bishop Turner, of Georgia, who came here at the instance of the conference.
JAMESTOWN, N.Y., July 1.--The Republican County Committee had a meeting at Mayville to-day. From every direction came the most encouraging reports.

Among the callers yesterday at the National Republican Head-quarters were Congressman Boutelle, of Maine; George Bliss, Osborn Birdsall, of Binghamton; Dexter A. Hawkins. and Frederick W. Holls, of New-York.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 1.--The Cleveland Driving Park Company offers a purse of $4,000 to Jay-Eye-See and Clingstone, both to enter and start on Thursday, July 31.

WASHINGTON, July 1.--The fiscal year closed yesterday shows a reduction in the public debt of $101,000,000, against $133,000,000 for the preceding year. An examination, however, of the column of interest-bearing debt shows that this debt has been reduced during the year nearly $112,000,000, which represents a permanent ...

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 1.--W.T. Dixon is a member of the Woodland Cemetery Board and a leading Democratic politician of the First Ward. His official coadjutors are George Judson, a Democrat, and J. Fries, a Republican. Dissensions have existed in the Cemetery Board for some time, and, have culminated by the ...
