UTICA, July 1.--For the past two weeks the absence of William Wielman from his home in Frankfort has given rise to various surmises. He is about 40 years old and has borne an excellent character in the community.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 1.--The selection of ex-Senator Thurman as a delegate at large to the Democratic National Convention of July 3 reminds the public that Payne and Hoadly do not comprise all the Presidential timber in the Buckeye State.
The proposed reorganization of the Rochester and Pittsburg Railroad Aug. 1 by foreclosure of the second mortgage bonds was not favorably received by some of the bondholders in this city yesterday.

PARIS, July 1.--There were three deaths from cholera at Marseilles last night and four at Toulon. The railway stations at both cities are filled with refugees who are eager to get away. Italy has sent a transport to take the Italians home from the plague-stricken cities.
BRADFORD, Penn., July 1.--John Head, of Middletown, N.Y., a drunken and dissolute man, was shot in a house of ill-fame on Pig Island to-day.
Special Treasury Agent Norris Winslow, of the Lake Champlain District, has lately been investigating the smuggling of horses into this country from Canada.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 1.--There is not much probability of the temperance people putting a third ticket in the field in this State. The con vention or mass-meeting called for July 24 has been postponed until the 31st. To-day Dr. J.A. Houser, a leading Prohibitionist said; "The ...

NEW-ORLEANS, La., July 1.--A bill passed the House to-day prohibiting the opening of places of public business on Sunday; also a bill declaring unlawful contracts for the sale of articles for future delivery.

FLUSHING, Long Island, July 1.--William Johnson lives in College Point, Long Island, and for many months has been persistent in his devotion to Miss Emma Anderson, who has been as persistent in discouraging it. The desperate nature of Johnson's love and the stony heart of the lady have long been the subjects of gossip among ...

The last auction sale of lots on the Fox estate, in the annexed district and on the line of the elevated railroad extension, has made yesterday by James L. Wells, at the Exchange Salesroom, No. 111 Broadway.

CINCINNATI, July 1.--Capt. George N. Stone, of this city, the former owner of Maud S. has received a dispatch from Mr. W.H. Vanderbilt, saying that he will spend a few weeks at Sharon Springs, and will send Maud S. back to Cincinnati with instructions for Mr. Bair to keep her in good condition until he wants her for road use.

WASHINGTON, July 1.--Ex-Senator Kellogg, at his own request, was permitted to make a statement before the Springer committee today relative to his connection with the star route cases. He said: "A number of witnesses before

An elderly man, dressed in a broadcloth suit, to which clung an air of faded respectability, stood up before Justice Smith, in the Tombs, yesterday, and caressingly stroked his long white beard, which covered his breast down to the sixth button of his vest.
William C. Rhinelander, who shot John Drake, was taken from the Tombs to Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday, on a writ of habeas corpus, his counsel intending to move for his admission to bail.
The table of accidents on the street railways of New-York City for the year ending Sept. 30, 1883, was omitted from the annual report of the Railroad Commissioners by the printer's error.
CHICAGO, July 1.--The attendance at the race meeting at Washington Park to-day was very large. The weather was warm and the track in good condition.

DAYTON, Ohio, July 1.--Henry Hafer and Joseph Ostermeyer were brought before the United States Commissioner here yesterday, and pleaded guilty to making and passing counterfeit half and quarter dollars.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 1.--A party of 30 persons from this State, representing the friends of Judge Field, left here this afternoon in a special car to attend the National Democratic Convention at Chicago.
Detective Roche, of the Third Precinct, Brooklyn, last evening arrested James Murphy, age 10, on a charge of causing two fires which have recently occurred on the banks of the Gowanus Canal.

WASHINGTON, July 1.--Mr. Randall, of Pennsylvania, submitted the report of the conference committee on the Naval Appropriation bill, announcing an inability to agree. The explanatory statement which accompanies the report specifies the chief items of disagreement

The Brooklyn Board of Education held its annual meeting last evening at the head-quarters of the department in Red Hook-lane. Mr. Tunis G. Bergen was re-elected President, and Col. Robert Payne was chosen Vice-President in the place of the late Dr. Doane.
The Tammany opponents of CLEVELAND's nomination are trying desperately to make it appear that the workingmen of the State are hostile to the Governor.

Two gentlemen in light Summer attire were sipping chilled champagne in Delmonico's Broad-street cafe yesterday. A third gentleman, apparently eager for a cooling drink, was hurrying by when he caught sight of the two friends.
The July meeting of the New-York and Brooklyn Driving Association was commenced yesterday at the driving park, Parkville. Long Island, and will be continued until July 4.
To a not inconsiderable portion of the population down town on the east side the annual Commencement of Grammar School No. 1, in Vandewater-street, is perhaps the principal event of the year.

The wholesale jewelers of this city and Providence, R.I., had an "outing" yesterday. The Providence contingent arrived in this city by the steam-boat Massachusetts yesterday morning. They numbered 150, and every man wore a straw bat and carried a cane.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 1.--At the University of Virginia this morning the joint celebration of the literary societies took place. The Hon. S.J. Randall, of Pennsylvania, who was expected to address the societies, was unable to be present. The celebration of the Jefferson literary Society took place at 8 o'clock this evening.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 1.--For several months the Columbus, Hocking Valley and Toledo Railway Company has been reducing the number of workmen in its shops, and to-day closed them because of lack of work.

KEOKUK, Iowa, July 1.--In the wreck of the construction train on the Chicago, Burlinging and Kansas City Railroad which fell through the Grand River bridge last night, about 25 men were thrown into the river.
A crowd gathered around a little platform erected in One Hundred and Twenty-fifthstreet, near Eighth-avenue, last night, to listen ...

DECATUR, Ill., July 2.--The National Prohibition Camp-meeting, under the auspices of the National Association, opened here yesterday at the fair grounds, and will continue for 10 days. Dr. Davies made an address of welcome, which was responded to by President Haney, who declared that the meeting had nothing whatever to do with political affairs, after which Francis Murphy spoke.
ALBANY, N. Y., July 2.--The monthly bulletin of the State Board of Health for May shows the death rate in New-York was 24.41 per 1,000.

ASSOUAN, July 2.--It is rumored that 12,000 Arabs have attacked and cautured Debbeh by assault. It is said that 3,000 of the garrison and inhabitants were killed. The Mudir of Dongola and a number of officers have gone in the direction of Debbeh, with what object it is not known.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 2.--A long series of official irregularities, possibly reaching over a number of years and involving an unknown amount of money, has just been brought to light in the County Treasurer's office. If statements, that are made by persons who are in a position to know the facts are correct, a number of ex-officers are involved in the affair, but ...

POTTSVILLE, Penn., July 2.--The Coroner's jury investigating the cause of the collision on the Northern Central Railway, near Shamokin last week, by which three men were killed, resumed the taking of testimony this morning, and this afternoon rendered a verdict. They find that Eisenhart, conductor, and Bennett, the engineer of the freight train, were responsible.

LOUISVILLE, July 2.--The city is convulsed with gossip to-day over an order issued by Gen. Taylor, Chief of Police, directing the art stores to remove from their show-windows the steel engraving of a French painting called "The Double Star." The picture is that of two female ...
The following sales of securities at auction were made by Adrian H. Muller Son, in the Exchange Sales-room, No. 111 Broadway, yesterday noon:

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., July 2.--In Williams College to-day the first Benedict prize in Latin was awarded to E. L. Dixon, '86; the second to A. V. Taylor, '86; honorable mention, J. L. Kilbon, Jr., '86; W. D. Mapes, '86. In Greek-- first, Dixon; second, Taylor; honorable mention, G. H. Flint, '86. In mathematics-first, Dixon; second, Mapes; honorable mention, J. ...

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 2.--Rumors have been circulating all day in business circles to the effect that Andrews, Hitchcock Co., one of the largest coal-dealing houses in the city, were embarrassed, and had asked an extension from their creditors.
Township Collector Alexander Anderson, of West Hoboken, was charged three weeks ago by a member of the Township Council with being a defaulter to the amount of $3,000.
PITTSBURG, Penn., July 2.--The National Broadway Bank of New-York has brought a suit against William McCreery, of this city, to recover $100,000 on four promissory notes of $25,000 each.
NEW-ORLEANS, July 2.--Yesterday died and to-day was buried Charles Briton, a Swede, an architect, artist, and civil engineer.

CANAJOHARIE, N. Y., July 2.--Fifteen hundred people attended the races at the Palatine Driving Park this afternoon. There were three entries for the first race, for a purse of $1,500. Daisy, of Fultonville, was the winner, after five heats, the best time being 2:40 . The free for all purse of $300 was won by Lottie, of Waterford; best time, 2:40.

Controller Grant and Assistant Corporation Counsel La Combe, of this city, and Corporation Counsel Payne and Treasurer Bleckweim, of Long Island City, met the Queens County Board of Supervisors yesterday afternoon to try to settle the question of the transfer of Riker's Island to this city for hospital purposes.

That band of horny-handed tillers of the soil who compose the famous Farmers' Club of the American Institute visited Glen Island yesterday, by invitation of the Hon. John H. Starin, to observe the effect produced by grafting clamchowder upon ice-cream. The farmers who accepted Mr. Starin's invitation, which is the first the club has received during the 50 years of its ...

ST. PAUL, July 2.--In the suit of Drennan, Starr Everett against the London Assurance Company for $6,000 insurance, a decision was rendered in the United States Circuit Court to-day against the plaintiffs because of the admission of David M. Arndt to the partnership subsequent to the execution of the policies.

BALTIMORE, July 2.--There was an interesting and very impressive ceremony at the Catholic Convent of Mount de Sales, on the Frederick road, yesterday, when Miss Nannie Riggs, daughter of Mr. Thomas Riggs, a prominent merchant of this city, took the white veil. Miss ...

Some time ago the licenses of the saloonkeepers of Mount Kisco, Westchester County, expired, and no more were granted. The last dealer to close his place was Daniel Vail. When he gave up his business he moved to Connecticut, but he left a considerable part of his stock in his cellar.

At a meeting of the Emigration Board yesterday, a consultation was held between the Commissioners and the agents of the leading European steam-ship lines in regard to the feeding of immigrants who are detained at Castle Garden while waiting for trains on which they are provided with tickets.

ALBANY, July 2.--The special express train on the New-York Central Railroad due at 2:20 this afternoon ran through an open switch here into a freight train. Two engines and six cars were wrecked. A brakeman was also injured. The passengers were badly shaken up and frightened.

WASHINGTON, July 2.--Mr. Randall scored another victory in the House of Representatives to-day by securing the passage of the Fortifications Appropriation bill reported by a minority of his Committee as a substitute for the measure prepared by the majority of that committee.

Finer weather for racing than that which favored the Brighton Beach Association yesterday could not be desired, and a large crowd of people filled the grand stand and quarter stretch. The track was in fine condition and the racing was of an exciting character, for the favorites in the three first races were beaten and the mutual ...
BERLIN, July 2.--The German Government has given to an English firm of ship-builders an order for constructing the largest torpedoboat ever built.

PORTLAND, Me., July 2.--At a meeting this afternoon of the backers of Teemer and Conley-William Spelman and E. Morris--it was announced that George Foster, of Boston, who had been intended for referee, was unable to serve, and Peter O'Connor, of this city, was selected instead. Both Teemer and Conley are at Lake Sebago actively training for their contest on July 4. Both oarsmen are in good trim and confident of success.

A shabbily dressed young man of medium height, with a dark, sun-burned complexion and an unprepossessing face, was led into the Tombs Police Court by Roundsman Murphy and Policeman Hanley yesterday and charged with the murder of Edwin Kelland, keeper of a billiard saloon at No. 44 John-street, Kingston, N. Y. Louis Willett, the alleged murderer, aged 19, was ...

BOSTON, July 2.--There is no feasting or rejoicing at the home of the modern Hercules. His friends are grim and gloomy and snap and snarl at everybody who comes within their reach. John L. Sullivan's friends are sick as well as himself.

SANDUSKY, Ohio, July 2.--The residence of Sidney Hosmer, of this city, was robbed last night during the absence of the family. The burglars secured, about $600 worth of silverplated forks, knives, spoons,
Under date of June 17 Controller Grant advertised for proposals for the purchase of $1,000,000 worth of four different kinds of stocks and bonds of the city of New-York, as follows:

A committee of seven, consisting of Judge Daniel O'Reilly, H. S. Beattie, R. A. Cunningham, Charles Reilly, Bernard Kenney, James McCartney, and Judge White, has been appointed to take charge of all arragements in regard to transportation to Chicago and rooms for the County Democracy delegates when the arrive there.
The Independent Republican Committee, of which George William Curtis is the Chairman, has secured permanent head-quarters at William and Cedar streets, where the work of the committee will be done.

It was, of course, expected that the report of failures in the United States and Canada for the quarter ending with the 30th of June would show a very decided increase in the amount of liabilities, resulting from the disturbances in Wall-street in the early part of May.

Last night Inspector Byrnes had in custody at Police Head-quarters three of a band of rascals, who, if the stories told by one of them are true, have been systematically robbing the elevated railroad companies, and who had planned to make $100,000 by means of forged five and ten cent tickets.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., July 2.--Another and probably the final chapter in one of the saddest family tragedies ever known was enacted to-night in the Southern State Prison at Jeffersonville. Col. Hobert M. Goodwin took poison and died in his cell at 10 o'clock to-night.

ROME, N. Y., July 2.--The celebration of the seventy-fifth birthday of Henry Wolf, and the fiftieth anniversary of his wedding, on the coming Fourth of July, for which great preparations had been making at Mullin Hill, in this county, and which was to have been a notable ...

WASHINGTON, July 2.--The House Committee on Foreign Affairs to-day informally agreed to report a resolution expressing the sentiment of the House as favorable to the negotiation of a reciprocity treaty between the United States and Canada.

Thomas Cooney, a Ninth-avenue car driver, of No, 271 Tenth-avenue, halted his car at Broadway and Fulton-street yesterday at 10 o'clock. His horse was covered with foam and he was shaking like an aspen leaf. A crowd soon collected to watch the animal.
Further evidence has been secured by Detective Roche, of the Third Precinct, Brooklyn, connecting James Murphy with a number of fires of incendiary origin which recently occurred in South Brooklyn.

The number of business failures in the United States during the six months ending July 1, as shown by the reports of R. G. Dun Co., was 5,510. This is an increase of 873 over the failures reported for the first six months of 1883. The liabilities for the last six months aggregate $124,000,000, while for the first six months of 1883 ...

There was little activity in the National Republican Head-quarters, No. 242 Fifth-avenue, yesterday. Callers were few during the day, and the large reading-room on the first floor, though lighted last evening, was deserted.
Hodges, Hersey Co., manufacturers of straw goods at Nos. 569 and 571 Broadway and at Monson, Mass., announced their failure yesterday.
LONDON, July 2.--An important conference of leading Conservatives of the midland counties was held at Birmingham to-day.

ALBANY, July 2.--Chairman Daniel Manning, of the Democratic State Committee, joined Commissioner of Public Works Hubert O. Thompson on the limited express to-day, and started for Chicago with the Cleveland boom. The "Boss" was accompanied by Mayor A. Bleecker Banks, Superintendent of Insurance ...

Margaret Brown, alias Harkins, a whitehaired, wrinkled woman, 67 years of age, who according to the police records has been a criminal for 50 years, was arrested yesterday by Detective Thomas Adams, as she was leaving the penitentiary on Blackwell's Island, where ...
BALTIMORE, July 2.--The five cotton duck mills of William E. Hooper Sons, at Woodberry, Baltimore County, have shut down, probably until September.
CHARLESTON, S.C., July 2.--Alarming reports continue to pour in as to the damage to the crops by the recent rains.

PHILADELPHIA, July 2.--A fair-haired little boy about 13 years old alighted from a Pennsylvania Railroad train in this city at 3 o'clock this morning. He was alone, and had traveled all the way from Quincy, Ill., in the hope of finding here a home and a father and mother.

CHICAGO, July 2.--The dispiriting intelligence has reached some of the workers in the Democratic ranks that the taps have been turned off the Flower "bar'ls" since the Saratoga fizzle, and that the dry season has actually set in.

BOSTON, July 2.--Isaac Jacobs, the Polish Jew who was brought off here from New-York last night and who is suspected by detectives of being the murderer of Mrs. Etta G. Carleton, of Watertown, was arraigned in the Cambridge ...

Lizzie Kemp, age 22, of Plain View, Va., who was brutally assaulted in Mehrbach's stable, on Twenty-fourth-street, between Third and Lexington avenues, Tuesday night, appeared in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday morning.

Mr. AUGUSTIN DALY will sail from NewYork on the steam-ship Alaska next Saturday morning, taking with him the members of the excellent comedy company he has formed during the last five years. New-York play-goers will await with interest the verdict of the London critics upon the work of these clever people.

PATERSON, N.J., July 2.--City Clerk Will Hague left his desk at the City Hall Monday afternoon and he has not since returned there. As City Clerk he was ex officio Register of Licenses, issuing all liquor licenses granted by the Aldermanic committee.

PARIS, July 2.--Between 10 o'clock last night and 10 this morning there were five deaths from cholera at Toulon. There were two deaths from the same disease at Marseilles last night. The reports of cholera at Lyons are denied. It is stated that the sanitary condition of the city is excellent.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., July 2.--A substantial victory was gained by the Stratford tong oystermen over the steam dredgers to-day, the State Fishery Commission declining to allow A. J. Beardsley Son to dredge the Housatonic River, as they claimed, to deepen the channel and thus benefit it.

The lockout and strike of the plumbers have been ended, and this morning the men will return to their work. An arbitration committee of the men and the "bosses" was in session yesterday at Clarendon Hall, and the terms of settlement were agreed upon as follows:

Norman Munro's yacht anchored just beneath the bridge a few days ago on the NewYork side, and the Captain, Luke Townsend, asked and received permission to let it lie there from the watchman of the docks, Thomas Connery, of No. 229 William-street, to whom he showed all the men who should ho permitted to go on the yacht.
WATERVILLE, Me., July 2.--The Commencement dinner at Colby University to-day was an elaborate affair. Profs. Pepper, Caldwell, and Fernaid made brief after-dinner speeches.
The Park Commissioners yesterday decided to have band concerts in Central Park on Sundays instead of on Saturday afternoons during the remainder of the season.

A lady of tall and commanding presence, with a small head, clear-cut features, and closely trimmed blonde hair, was the central figure of a group that commanded general attention on the deck of the Gallia at noon yesterday. Now and then a little cry of admiration was heard as a steward hurried into the Captain's deck-room near by with a pyramid, a harp, ...
CINCINNATI, Ohio, July 2.--President McGill, of the Cincinnati and Eastern Railroad, was killed to-day by falling out of the door of the baggage car of an incoming train.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., July 2.--The graduating exercises at Amherst College took place today. Gov. Robinson and his staff and a large number of the Alumni were on the stage.
PANAMA, June 23.--Heavy rains have fallen throughout the isthmus, particularly on the Colon side, which have seriously injured the-canal earth-works.

MOBILE, Ala., July 2.--Dr. J. W. Blow, a prominent citizen of Georgiana Ala., is now in custody at Greenville charged with cutting up the negro who attempted an outrage at Georgiana last week. Another citizen, A. K. Spinney, has been arrested also, and warrants are out for two others.
Thomas Morris, a gigantiC colored man, began a suit at Paterson yesterday against Cooper Hewitt for a balance of wages, which he claims amounts to $226.
HAVANA, July 2.--The boiler of the Spanish man-of-war Ligero exploded at Las Nuevitas to-day with great violence. Three persons were killed outright and five others were severely injured.

A dozen or more sweltering New-Yorkers, who expected to get away from city heat today and bask in the breeze-tempered sunshine of the sea-side, having to that end engaged rooms at the Neptune House, Rockaway Beach, were last evening looking up quarters elsewhere or had abandoned the contemplated trip.

TORONTO, Ontario, July 2.--The trades and industrial day celebration took place here to-day. At about 11:30 the procession started down Yonge-street and along the route to the exhibition grounds, requiring an hour and a half to pass a given point.
BOSTON, July 2.--The schooner Nina Page, Taylor, master, from Barrington, Nova Scotia, reports: "June 28, at 8:30 A. M., off Seal Island, while floating east by north, half north, ...

MOBILE, Ala., July 2.--The assets of the firm of Gardner Gates, the former the President of the National Cotton Exchange of America, have to-day been reassigned to the firm, the creditors expressing the belief that their interacts can be best cared for in that way.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 2.--The third and last game of the series here between the Metropolitan and Columbus Clubs was played this afternoon in the presence of 1,500 persons, a large number of ladies being present.

MILO, N. Y., July 2.--On May 3, Sprague Hoban, butchers, of Penn Yan, purchased a steer of Mrs. Sutton, of this place. As it was being driven to Penn Yan it broke away and escaped. A search of several days failed to find it. Yesterday it was discovered by some boys in a brush lot on Mrs. Sutton's farm.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 2.--Charles Crocker filed an affidavit to-day in answer to Mrs. Colton's application in her suit now being tried at Santa Rosa against Messrs. Stanford, Crocker, and Huntington, in which she asked for a custodian to be appointed to receive and hold the several ...

EAST SAGINAW, Mich., July 2.--William Edinger, a German merchant, for 20 years a resident of this city, disappeared mysteriously on Sunday night. He is supposed to have had $1,200 to $1,500 in his possession. His family apprehend foul play, claiming that there is no motive for his intentional absence.

WHEELING, West Va., July 2.--The contest for the Gubernatorial nomination on the Democratic ticket between the friends of E. Boyd Faulkner and E. M. Wilson is being waged with great bitterness on both sides, and threatens to cause a serious split in the party if Wilson succeeds, as now seems probable.
ALBANY, July 2.--The break in the canal at Palmyra has been repaired. Navigation was resumed yesterday afternoon.

Judge Gildersleeve delivered the charge to the jury yesterday, in the Court of General Sessions, in the case of Adolph Adams, charged with shooting his wife, Mary, at No. 140 Forsythstreet, on May 20, and the jury retired at noon. After an hour's deliberation the jury brought in a verdict of guilty of manslaughter in the second ...
Vessels which arrived here yesterday brought further reports of the damages which were caused by the gales of last week.

WASHINGTON, July 2.--After numerous and prolonged consultations with the members of his Cabinet President Arthur to-day sent to the House of Representatives his veto of the bill for the relief of Fitz John Porter. The House immediately passed the bill despite the objections of the President, but there is every reason to believe that the measure is killed for ...
LONDON, July 2.--Gen. Franz Edward Todieben, the famous Russian soldier and engineer, is dead.

ALBANY, July 2.--Following are the aggregate items of resources and liabilities of the banks of discount and deposit in New-York City, which are operated under the State laws, as shown by the quarterly reports of the respective banks made to the Superintendent of the Banking Department under date of June 14.

The annual graduating exercises of Grammar School No. 48, in West Twenty-eighthstreet, were held yesterday. The relatives and friends of the Class of '84 assembled in large numbers, and, judging from the manner in which they applauded the blushing misses, enjoyed the programme.

People who are obliged to work for a living complained more of the overpowering heat yesterday than they have so far for the Summer. Once before, on June 25, the mercury scored a higher figure, bus on that day a delightful north-west breeze swept through the streets at the rate of 12 miles an hour and absorbed the perspiration from the great multitude of overheated faces.

That Asiatic cholera is now epidemic in two of the Mediterranean ports of France can no longer be doubted. In. spite of the prompt and stringent precautions which the French Government will take, if they have not already been taken, the spread of the disease throughout France can hardly be prevented.
PHLLIPSBURG, N. J., July 2.--The Delaware Rolling Mill was sold this afternoon to Dennis Reilly, of Easton, Penn., for $24,600, which was $3,000 less than the bid at a prior sale.

The select committee of the Assembly to investigate complaints regarding expenditures on the building and repairs of State arsenals and armories, of which Gen. N. M. Curtis is Chairman, returned from Watertown and resumed its investigations in this city yesterday. John A. Wood, the architect who drew the ...

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 2.--Two hundred and thirty saloon-keepers, members of the Liquor League, refused to pay the Scott law tax and employed counsel to test its constitutionality. Judge Blandin this morning granted a temporary injunction to prevent County Treasurer Whitbeck from collecting the tax from those saloon-keepers who have not paid.

The will of the late Frederick R. Mayer was presented for probate in the office of the Surrogate yesterday. In it Mr. Mayer gives the bulk of his property to his relatives and near friends, and makes the following provision: "I ...

The second and last week of Mrs. Langtry's engagement in San Francisco drew gross receipts to the amount of $14,300, which the lady said to the manager of the theatre represented the largest week's business she had ever done in America. Mrs. Langtry has given bonds in the suit brought against her by Mr. Greenwall, the Australian manager, and has made deposits in ...

It was stated yesterday that an arrangement had been made by which the Atchison, Topeka, and Santa Fe and the St. Louis and San Francisco Railroad Companies had leased the Atlantic and Pacific Railroad upon the terms of paying its fixed charges.
ALPARETTA, Ga., July 2.--There has been considerable excitement created here by the movements of a colored emissary named Jones Steel, a preacher and a politician, formerly of South Carolina.

CHARLESTON, S. C., July 2.--Peace once more reigns in tho African Methodist Episcopal Church. A love feast was held last night in the seceding church here which continued until an early hour this morning. Bishop Turner presided, and the scene was very affecting.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., July 2.--Mrs. Ida E. Whitinect, a member of Dan Mason's theatrical company, now playing at the Sans Souci Garden, died very suddenly this evening in her room at the City Hotel.

BUFFALO, N. Y., July 2.--The dead body of Patrick McGinness, a worthless fellow, who had made a precarious living by playing the fiddle at sailors' boarding-houses, was found early this morning in the back yard of Charles Flynn's saloon, on Ohio-street.

Joseph Price and Charles Russell, representing the London holders of the common stock of the New-York, Ontario and Western Railway, and R. Van Ress, representing the Amsterdam holders, have completed their inquiry into the condition of the road and its relations to the NewYork, West Shore and Buffalo Railway. Mr. Price, the Chairman of the London committee of the ...

WASHINGTON, July 2.--Paragraph 3, special orders of June 28, has been amended so as to read: "The extension of leave of absence granted Second Lieut. Henry H. Benham, Second Infantry, in special orders June 21, 1884, is further extended one month." Capt. Charles H. Hoyt, Assistant Quartermaster, on being relieved from duty at the Military Academy.

BOZEMAN, Montana, July 2.--The Northern Pacific Railroad has just discharged all the white laborers employed on section and gravel train work west of Livingston, and has filled their places with Chinamen brought from the Pacific slope.

The bodies of two little babies lay on the table in the parlor of Mrs. Mary Josephine Ward's "St. Vincent de Paul Nursery and School for Children," at No. 692 East One Hundred and Sixty-fourth-street, yesterday afternoon. In the play-room outside three chubby babes rolled about on the floor and laughed and crowed as merrily as though there was no, token of death ...
ROCHESTER, N. Y., July 2.--The Grand Jury rose this morning and brought into the Court of Oyer and Terminer seven indictmentsfive sealed and two open.

PEORIA, July 2.--The Democratic State Convention, which was called to order at 12:30 P. M., was opened with prayer by the Rev. J. C. Bruce, of Peoria. When Chairman Oberly, in his speech, asked the question, "Shall we, in spite of the declination of Mr. Tilden, nominate him for President of the United States?" the convention rose and cheered vociferously.
The Cleveland Club of Baltimore has received the following letter from Gov. Cleveland:

While some workmen were making excavations on the left bank of the Seine, near the western side of the ancient refectory of the Cordeliers, in Paris, recently, thick and solid walls, belonging to some Roman edifice, were brought to light. Along the Rue Racine several wells have been uncovered, in the bottom of which fragments of Roman pottery were found.

HORNELLSVILLE, July 2.--Joel Stout and his brother William, employes of the tannery at Alton, were hauling bark from the woods on Monday, and Joel was driving down a steep and narrow hill as his brother was on his way with his team up the hill, the former with a load and the latter going after one.

Thomas H. Nairne, 38 years old, employed as clerk in the office of Van Schaick Co., brokers, No. 32 Broad-street, shot himself in the head yesterday at No. 52 West Forty-fifthstreet, dying almost immediately. Mr. Nairne was unmarried and lived in lodgings in Lexington-avenue.
INDIANAPOLIS, July 2.--The Brooklyn Ball Club won the third game of their present series here by superior batting, they finding but little difficulty in hitting the balls pitched by McAuley.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., July 2.--The Plymouth Savings Bank, an institution that has always enjoyed the confidence of the public, closed its doors at noon to-day, without giving any satisfactory reason therefor.

DETROIT, July 2.--In the base-ball game here to-day Merrick pitched for the Detroits for six innings, and then was hit hard. Gillespie led off for New-York in that inning with a home run, and Hankinson, Richardson, Caskins, Ewing, and Connor made singles, and Ward a doublebase hit. Gillespie closed the inning by striking out.
KINGSTON, Ontario, July 2.--Great fires are burning in several of the adjacent townships, perhaps to the number of 100.
Mme. Materna, Herr Winkelmann, and Herr Scaria sailed yesterday for Germany on the North German Lloyd steam-ship Elbe.

Yesterday saw the beginning of the Democratic hegira to Chicago. Commissioner Hubert O. Thompson and ex-Mayor Edward Cooper took an early train to the West. They were brimful of enthusiasm for Gov. Cleveland.

CLEVELAND, July 2.--The Cleveland Driving Park has entered into the spirit of the controversy that is going on as to the merits of the two or three of the greatest horses on the trotting turf and comes out with a magnificent offer, which Mr. Gordon will accept and which Mr. Case--if his challenge is not buncombeshould be glad to do. The offer is as follows:

CARMEL, N. Y., July 2.--The trial of the negro James H. Riley, for the murder of Hannah Sunderlin, ended at 6 o'clock to-day with a verdict of murder in the second degree. Sentence was suspended until Tuesday next.

George F. Cummings, a stockholder of the New-York Concert Company, served papers yesterday, in a suit commenced by him in the Supreme Court, against the New-York Concert Company, Rudolph Aronson, James D. Fish, Ferdinand Ward, Albert Weber, and the other Directors of the Concert Company, enjoining ...

ALBANY, July 2.--A letter has been received by the State Board of Health from A. W. Lozier, M. D., relative to the present condition of Sea Cliff, in which he declares the waters of the creek and bay are as much discolored as ever, and that the nuisance has been abated but little, if at all, by the manufacturers.

GETTYSBURG, Penn., July 2.--As early as Monday evening veterans, members of the Grand Army of the Republic and their friends, began to arrive here to participate in the memorial dedications of the week. Yesterday morning a procession was formed, including about 100 men of the Seventeenth Connecticut Volunteers, in ...

It appears to be judicially decided that a barber has no right to "scrape" a customer with a dull razor under pretense of shaving him. No decision has been given in precisely these words, but in the case of RUTH versus MINALDI, which was tried recently, the verdict of the court virtually carried with it that decision.

TALLADEGA, Ala., July 2.--All the employes of the Anniston and Atlantic Railroad, except those running on regular passenger trains, struck yesterday on account of a reduction of 10 per cent. in their wages. Fifty hands struck several days ago, but the matter was then adjusted and all returned to work.

NYACK, N. Y., July 2.--The first case in Orangetown for violation of the excise law is on trial in this place to-night. The alleged offender is James E. Sarvent, of Piermont, who is said to have sold liquor without a license on June 7. The afternoon was devoted to the selection of a jury. The trial will probably last all night. There is great excitement, and a large crowd is present.
LONDON, July 2.--The race for the July Cup at the Newmarket meeting to-day resulted in a walk-over for Lord Arlington's 5-year-old br. m. Geheimniss, by Rosicrucian, out of Nameless.

A popular superstition prevails that wheresoever a body of college students are gathered together in one place to witness a game of base-ball the highest known quantity of noise exists; but the united forces of Yale, Harvard, and Princeton, with Brown University and a few theological seminaries thrown in could do ...
WHEELING, West Va., July 2.--A telegram from Lexington, Va., gives details of a fight which came off there Tuesday between two well-known students of the Virginia Military Institute at Lexington.
MOBILE, Ala., July 2.--Capt. Price Williams, commander of the Mobile Rifles, resigned to-day to take active charge of the inter-State drill which will take place of Mobile next year.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 2.--The annual meeting of the Music Teachers' National Association opened at Case Hall this morning. The attendance is quite large, many musical celebrities being present.

NEWBURG, N. Y., July 2.--The second trial of Bernardino Cassiano for the murder of Silviatore Rocco on Oct. 1, 1882, ended at Goshen to-day in the disagreement of the jury. In the first trial the verdict was murder in the first degree.

The points made by the President in vetoing the bill providing for the restoration of FITZ JOHN PORTER to the rank of Colonel in the army, fortified as they are by an able opinion of the Attorney-General, appear to us to be simply unanswerable.

The concluding testimony tending to show how Peter McCormick came to his death on Sunday, June 22, was taken by Coroner Robinson and a jury in the City Hall at Long Island City last evening. Dr. De Witt Hitchcock made a brief statement, in which he said that he and Dr. William J. Burnett had made an autopsy on the body of McCormick, and had found that death re- ...

A cable dispatch received at the Metropolitan Opera-house yesterday afternoon announced that the formal contract between Mr. Gye and the Directors had been drafted in accordance with the views of both parties, and that it only awaited their signatures, the Directors of the opera-house being represented in London, as mentioned already in these columns by Mr. Rives.
WASHINGTON, July 2, 1884. The President has approved the act granting a pension to the widow of Major-Gen. Judson Kilpatrick.
CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 2.--The exercises held to-day closed the session of 1883-4 of the University of Virginia. There were 49 graduates, 34 of whom were from the law school.
The emplopes of the New-Jersey Central Railroad threaten to strike unless they receive their pay to-day, or to-morrow at the latest. The men have usually been aid on the 10th of each month.

John R. Bartlett, Henry C. Andrews, George C. Gorham, and Albert P. Fisher are the incorporators of the North America Insulated Cable Company, whose certificate was filed in the County Clerk's office yesterday.

Mrs. Fair, when she was divorced from the Senator, applied for $4,000,000 alimony. The Senator gave her $5,000,000. After she had it she did not know what to do with it, and went to her ex-husband for advice. He cheerfully invested it for her, and now manages all her money affairs. This is Fair if anything is.

James P. Cole, William H. Pindar, and August C. Speth, the men arrested for conspiracy to defraud the elevated railroad company by the manufacture of spurious five and ten cent tickets, were formally arraigned before Justice O'Reilly, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, yesterday afternoon, for examination.

In a neighboring town this year the Public School Committee decided to substitute addresses from well-known speakers on educational topics for the usual show exercises of graduation in which members of the class spread their wings and soar.

FORT SMITH, Ark., July 3.--The enforcement of the "permit" laws is causing considerable excitement in the Choctaw Nation, and arousing an opposition that may cause their repeal. Under the Choctaw law every white man in the nation, or his employer, is required to pay a heavy permit tax in order to live in the nation.

It is stated by authority that Roscoe Conkling will under no circumstances lend his support to any Presidential candidate whomsoever. It is not probable that the election will be postponed on that account.

Albert G. Arnold, 29 years of age, of No. 107 East Tenth-street, attempted to commit suicide last evening at 11:30 o'clock by shooting himself in the right breast. He was removed to Bellevue Hospital. The wound is considered dangerous.

PROVIDENCE, R.L., July 3.--The United States ship Saratoga, Whiting, commander, arrived at Newport this afternoon, 43 days from Teneriff. All on board are well. There had been much anxiety about the vessel because of her long passage.

The question to be decided by the people is whether the country shall have pure and honest government. The Democracy of the country cares nothing for the local politics of New-York beyond learning from Gov. Cleveland's course in that State that he would make a good Chief Magistrate for the whole country.

At a late hour this afternoon the Elections Committee of the House of Representatives agreed to report in favor of the contestant in the case of Craig against Shelley, from the Fourth District of Alabama. It is rather tardy justice

Some days ago Mr. Cable, the eminent New-Orleans novelist, returned to the city from a visit to the State of Alabama, where he had gone to fulfill some literary engagements, and shortly thereafter a reporter found opportunity to call on him.
Lightning recently struck a tree on Gov. Stanford's ranch, and the Chinamen employed on the place could not induced to pick up the debris as they considered that it was the work of an evil spirit.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., July 3.--Col. J.R. Winston, of North Carolina, Chairman of the committee to notify Gen. A.M. West, of Holly Springs, Miss., of his nomination for Vice-President by the Greenback-Labor Party, received a letter from Gen. West formally acknowledging the receipt of the notification of his nomination.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 3.--The State Prohibition Convention met this evening to adopt a platform and to select delegates to the National Convention at Pittsburg. About 100 persons were present. J.M. Hunter, the permanent Chairman, presided. A prohibition platform

President Arthur has nominated Col. Watson C. Squire, formerly of Ilion, to the office of Governor of Washington Territory, the term of Gov. Newell, the present incumbent, having expired. Col. Squire has many friends in this vicinity. He lived a number of years at Ilion.

ALBANY, July 3.--The commission upon the forest preservation met and organized at the Controller's once to-day. Prop. C.S. Sargent, of Harvard University, was chosen Chairman, and Edward M. Shepard Secretary. The commission will have a public hearing at Saratoga.

William C. Rhinelander was once more taken before Judge Lawrence, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday, on a writ of habeas corpus. Attired in a brown suit, and having his eyes hidden by a pair of glasses, he sat in the court-room and listened to arguments for and against his admission to bail, as if he were not at all interested in their result. Ex-Judge Curtis

Col. McLeod, although not a bad man at heart, uses very rough language in his intercourse with his family. On returning to his home from his place of business a few days ago he found his wife very much excited over the outrageous conduct of a tramp, who, being dissatisfied with the food given him by Mrs. McLeod, had abused her in a most outrageous manner.

TROY, N.Y., July 3.--About 11 o'clock this morning J. Horace Jones, proprietor of the "Ivy Green" restaurant, had trouble with his wife in the dining-room, near the bar. He struck her several times in the face, causing blood to flow. During the trouble C.E. Petley,

CAZENOVIA, N.Y., July 3.--A magnificient meteor passed from above the pole star to the western horizon at 8:25 o'clock this evening, leaving a trail that remained visible for 10 minutes. Before the trail disappeared it became sinuous. The light of the trail was much greater than that of the meteor.

The order of Heptasophs, or Seven Wise Men, was formed in the South about 33 years ago. Originally the order, which was organized in New-Orleans, admitted only native Americans. A few years ago this distinction in class was removed, and now all men who believe in the existence of a Supreme Being and possess healthy constitutions are eligible to membership.

The latter was found lying by the roadside at Brady's Cave one morning two weeks ago unconscious. His skull was fractured, and when

Superintendent Thayer, of Fairmount Park, has drafted a series of rules regulating the dress of oarsmen of the Schuylkill Navy while within the precincts of the park which are designed to remove all objections as to dishabille.

In the first months of 1860 times were tough on the Comstock. The Winter of 1859-60 was terribly severe, as all old settlers well remember. Supplies could not be brought over the mountains from California, and before Spring many on the Comstock went hungry to bed about three nights in the week.

BOSTON, July 3.--Whittemore, Cabot Co., dry goods commission merchants, have made an assignment to John B. Smith, of Hillsboro Bridge, N.H., a large consignor to the firm. The anount of the liabilities is not yet known, but will he large. The firm owned and operated the South Shore Mills at Hingham.

CINCINNATI, July 3.--The Trustees of the Miami University of Oxford, Ohio, have decided to reopen the college in September next, with a Freshmen class. R.W. McFarland, who was Professor of Mathematics in the college when it closed, has been chosen President.

TORONTO, July 3.--Lieut. Gordon, R.A., Deputy Superintendent of the Canadian Meteorological service, left to-day for Halifax to make the final preparations for embarking July 22 with a corps of observers for the Hudson Straits expedition. The ship Neptune, 685 tons, has

BOSTON, July 3.--It is now known upon excellent authority that a definite arrangement has been completed, by all the parties in interest, whereby the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe and the St. Louis and San Francisco Railroads have leased the Atlantic and Pacific Railroad upon the terms of paying its fixed charges.

OMAHA, Neb., July 3.--A severe wind storm visited Eastern Nebraska last night. Two soldiers on their way from the city to the fort were struck by a falling tree, and one of them, Henry Gardner, was killed. The other, a private named Wamestoff, had both legs broken.

NEW-ORLEANS, July 3.--A marble monument of Margaret Houghey is to be unveiled and dedicated next Wednesday afternoon. Ex-Gov. Frank T. Nichols will deliver the oration. Father Herbert. (Jesuit priest,) and the Rev. Dr. Palmer, (Presbyterian.) will officiate.

NORFOLK, Va., July 3.--The first annual regatta on the Elizabeth River, under the auspices of the Norfolk Gymnasium Association, took place here to-day. There were three skiff entries in one race, and two whale-boats from the United States ships Franklin and Passaic raced one mile with a turn. The Franklin's crew won the race, which was for a purse of $50.

At 5:45 o'clock last evening a heavy column of smoke was noticed issuing from the rear of the three-story brick building at No. 153 Crosby-street, and an alarm was sent out from the box opposite Police Head-quarters in Mulberry-street. At that moment an alarm came in to the Head-quarters of the Fire Department for the fire at Walker and Elm streets.

BOSTON, Mass., July 3.--The night watchman employed at the factory of the Revere Rubber Company, on Eastern-avenue, Chelsea, discovered flames, at 3 o'clock this morning, issuing from one of the dye-houses in the rear of the factory. Owing to a scarcity of water the firemen's efforts were of little avail, and the entire factory and connected buildings were speedily in flames, except the three store-houses.

MALVERN, June 28.--The Hon. William Stone, of Mills County, father of the Hon. John Y. Stone, who led the Iowa delegation at the National Republican Convention, repudiates Blaine and Logan, and affirms that he will support the wily Ben Butler for President. Verily, the Hon. John Y. did not inherit his enthusiasm from his illustrious ancestors.

At 11 o'clock this morning the Houdon statue of Washington, bought with the contributions of the children in the public schools of this city, will be unveiled in Riverside Park, at Ninety-third-street. The exercises will include speeches by School Commissioner Wood. Gen. Viele, Mayor Edson, and Stephen A. Walker, music by Cappa's Seventh Regiment Band, singing by school children, and orations by two boys.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 3.--This city was profusely decorated to-day, and to-night the principal streets are crowded with people. The occasion is an unusual one. The Grand Army of the Republic began its semi-annual encampment here to-day; to-morrow there will be the Independence Day celebration, which will be given especial interest by the dedication of the soldiers' and sailors' monument just erected in Lafayettesquare. CHICAGO, July 3.--The funeral of Allan Pinkerton took place from his late home, No. 554 West Adams-street, this afternoon. The services were conducted by the Rev. Dr. Thomas, and the floral tributes were very numerous. The eulogy was delivered in an impressive manner by Stated Attorney Mills. The pall-bearers were F. Warner, R.J. Linden, D. Robertson, C.D. Eames, P. Foley, John H. Cleary, S. Bridgeman, and J.G. Horne. The remains were interred in Graceland Cemetery.

PANAMA, July 3, via Galveston.--The Superior Court of Panama yesterday impeached Dr. Cervera, President of the State of Panama, for bribery, and named Gen. Ruiz, the Second Vice-President, as President.

On the top floor of Cyrus W. Field's new nine-story building on the Battery is a restaurant which is patronized by the tenants of the numerous offices. Among the tenants are many young women who are employed as operators on type-writers, Mr. Field and "Uncle Rufus" Hatch are also regular patrons of the place.

ELLENVILLE, N.Y., July 3.--The granite brow and broad sides of the Shawangunk, so great a wilderness of crags and tangled bushes to most people, will furnish a richer harvest to many during the next six weeks than the more inviting meadows and cultivated acres of the fertile valleys will to most of their possessors.

FLUSHING, July 3.--This village is suffering from an insect plague. A few days ago it was noticed that the leaves on several trees along Main-street were withering away. A more careful examination resulted in the discovery that the trees were literally covered from trunk to topmost branch with worms about half an inch in length. On the ground under the trees were thousands and thousands of dead insects.

TORONTO, Ontario, July 3.--The Flurry in Federal bank stock has about ended, and the outlook of stairs is now much more promising. The new General Manager, Mr. Yarker, has entered upon a policy of vigorous retrenchment.

GLOUCESTER, N.J., July 3.--The Gloucester City Savings Institution was closed to-day, and a notice of its suspension was posted in front of the building. The President said to-day that he expected the bank would reopen its doors in a few weeks and pay dollar for dollar. It is said that the liabilities are $150,000, and the face value of the assets $155,000.

CHICAGO, July 3.--The attendance at the races at Washington Park to-day was large. The weather was warm and sultry and the track in excellent condition.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., July 3.--W.H. Cooper, the Montrose banker who was shot by "Joe" Drinker, a crank, in the streets of that town on the night of June 14, died to-day at 2:30 o'clock. He had laid for over two weeks in a critical condition, but the chances of his recovery had for some time been growing brighter.

TROY, July 3.--The regatta of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association occurs at Saratoga Lake to-morrow afternoon at 4 o'clock. The crews are all in good condition. It is thought the race will be between Cornell and the University of Pennsylvania, the former being the favorite.

LONDON, July 3.--In the House of Commons to-day the Right Hon. Joseph Chamberlain, President of the Board of Trade, announced the withdrawal of the Merchants' Shipping bill.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, July 3.--John R. McLean, by a shrewd move and the help of Gov. Hoadly, to-day captured the entire organization for the Democratic campaign in this State.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 3.--Calvin Wells, speaking of the report that he would decline the position of Presidential Elector on the Republican ticket of Pennsylvania because of the organized opposition of the Labor Party against him, stated to-day that he had not yet reached a conclusion on the subject, but unless the conviction could be forced upon him that his resignation would further the interest of his part he would stick.

Unless some unexpected obstacle come up there is very little doubt that the present session of Congress will come to an end on Saturday night or Sunday. The various conference committees are working night and day in order to get through by Saturday.

On Saturday last William M. Haight, the manager of Miller's Hygienic Hotel in West Twenty-sixth-street, discovered a lad, who was ostensibly peddling polishing powder, prowling about the hotel. Believing that the lad was there for a dishonest purpose, Mr. Haight turned him but of the house. Soon after it was discovered that the room of H.W. Fields had been entered and robbed of jewelry valued at $153.

WASHINGTON, July 3.--Acting Assistant Surgeon Walter D. McCaw has been ordered to proceed from Richmond, Va., to Fort Leavenworth, Kansas, and report to the commanding General, Department of the Missouri, for assignment to duty.

Notice was given in the Cotton exchange yesterday morning that the firm of Johnston Brothers, cotton brokers, were unable to meet their obligations. The firm has an office in the Cotton Exchange Building, and their financial troubles began about 10 days ago.

BRENHAM, Texas, July 3.--Treasurer Leib, of Washington County, was arrested here this evening on a charge of defalcation. Bail was fixed at $5,000 for his appearance, but he failed to secure bondsmen. His defalcations will amount to from $20,000 to $27,000. His bondsmen will protect the county from loss.

QUEBEC, July 3.--The final decision with reference to the extradition of Eno, which was to have been rendered to-day by Judge Caron. has been postponed until Monday, the Judge stating that he had not yet obtained possession of the whole record. The missing portion is understood to be the depositions of witnesses which the court stenographers refused to hand over until they were paid for their work.

LONG BRANCH, July 3.--The Long Branch District and Messenger Company went into operation yesterday. It is started with 150 subscribers. George W. Curtis is President; J.W. Curtis Secretary and Treasurer.

LYONS, N.Y., July 3.--Canal-boats have been unable to move through this section for over a week because of a serious break in the Erie Canal bank at Palmyra last week. ALBANY, N.Y., July 3.--The Governor this afternoon pardoned Thomas Chestnut, convicted in Westchester County of rape. Chestnut was sentenced to 10 years in Sing Sing in 1879.

BOSTON, July 3.--Gov. Robinson has issued a requisition on the Governor of Illinois for the delivery of Franklin J. Moses, once Governor of South Carolina, who, it is charged, by personating George D. Bryan, obtained from Thomas W. Higginson, of Cambridge, the sum of $34, and thus rendered himself liable to the penalties for false personation.

Dillabaugh, a newspaper correspondent, was to-day committed for trial on the charge of conspiring against the dignity of the Queen, in aiding and abetting in the destruction of public buildings here. CHICAGO, July 4.--There was a very large attendance at the Washington Park races today. The weather was warm and damp. The track was in good condition.

BUFFALO, July 4.--Probably never in the history of Buffalo have so many strangers been present within her bounds at one time. The hotels were literally packed, though the majority were guests of the citizens.
According to Mr. SPENCE BATE, an English scientific person, the coming man will have no teeth. He alleges that as man advances in development the teeth are gradually evolved into brain matter.

PARIS, July 4.--The formal presentation of the Bartholdi statue of "Liberty Enlightening the World" by the French Government to the United States took place in the Gauthier workshop to-day. Mr. L.P. Morton, United States Minister to France, was present and received the statue in the name of his Government.
LONDON, July 4.--Mr. Gladstone was indisposed to-day and was absent from Parliament. The trial of the Fortescue-Garmoyle breach of promise case has been postponed until November.
FLUSHING, Long Island, July 4.--The fifth annual regatta of the Nereus Rowing Club took place on Flushing Bay this afternoon, and was witnessed by 2,500 people.

The late Rev. David Niles Bentley, of Norwich, Conn., bequeathed $3,000 to the missionary society of the Methodist Church at Philadelphia, in addition to the legacies heretofore published.

HARRISBURG, Penn , July 4.--At a meeting of the Directors of the Harrisburg Baseball Club this evening it was decided to withdraw from the Eastern League and disband the club.

Paris has found a net sensation in a bird charmer, who has been astonishing the boulevardiers with his powers. A bet was made between him and a M. Loizey, a gentleman who was rather skeptical in such matters.

PHILADELPHIA, July 4.--The Metal Workers' National Union effected an organization at Mullerschen's Hall to-day by the election of Bernard Irmer as Chairman. Fifteen delegates were present, representing local unions in Chicago, Milwaukee, New-York, St. Louis, Cincinnati, and Philadelphia.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., July 4.--A disease something like the epizootic has made its appearance here. Several valuable horses have been attacked, and in nearly all with a fatal result. The disease first appears in the form of a cold and then extends to the throat and lungs; inflammation of the bowels follows and death ensues.

AMSTERDAM, N.Y., July 4.--By the terms of a will made by Reinhart Heller and wife, in 1873, each was to leave his or her property to the other until death or marriage intervened, when it was to revert to their children. Mrs. Heller died last September, leaving a hotel, barns, and sheds in this city valued at $14,000. Recently Mr. Heller determined to marry again, and became engaged to Mrs. Louisa Schoendorf, of Fonda.

NEWARK, N.J., July 4.--The observance of Independence Day passed off very quietly here, there being no parade or other public demonstration, except fireworks this evening.

LONG BRANCH, July 4.--This wooden city by the sea is evidently fast losing its reputation as a fashionable watering place, and is becoming instead a mere picnic ground for sportsmen and excursion parties. So far as permanent guests are concerned the east end is already condemned.

BERLIN, July 4.--The anniversary of the independence of the United States was celebrated by the American colony here by a banquet and afterward a ball at the Zoological Gardens. The dining saloon at the gardens was handsomely decorated with the Stars and Stripes and the German flag. Toasts offered to the health of...

A fire occurred yesterday morning in the lumber yard of O.B. Dowd, Nos. 504 and 506 East Eighteenth-street, which is supposed to have been caused by firecrackers thrown among the lumber by boys. Before the fire was extinguished $1,000 worth of lumber was destroyed.

Walter Shaw, 33 years old, attempted to commit suicide last evening at the house of his sister, Mrs. Bell, No. 970 Fulton-street, Brooklyn. Shaw took a revolver in each hand and, pointing the weapons at his head, fired. Both bullets took effect, but neither seemed to penetrate the brain, Shaw, who is a victim of epilepsy, was taken to the City Hospital. His recovery is doubtful.

There was a great crowd at Brighton Beach to witness the holiday races, there being six of them, run over a heavy track, and two of them surprised the knowing ones, especially the last race, in which the mutuals paid $106.80.

TARA, Ontario, July 4.--A boiler in Rogers's sawmill exploded to-day, completely demolishing the building. William Walker, the engineer, was killed and D. Bennett and another workman, whose name is unknown, were seriously and probably fatally injured.
Mr. Weise's handsome volume, with fac-similes of many rare maps, examples of the labors of former cosmographers, contains the gist of what is known in regard to the discovery of America.

Dr. P.H. Flood was called to Wellsbore yesterday morning to attend the Hon. C.G. Fairman. The doctor returned last evening and reported Mr. Fairman as being very ill, the trouble being inflammation of the bowels. When asked if Mr. Fairman's condition was dangerous he said that he was a very sick man, but that he might recover from the attack.

The Picayune has received the catalogue of the officers and students of the University of Mississippi, at Oxford, Miss., for 1884. The total number of students is 276, against 259 in 1883. The post graduates number 9, an increase of 3.

TOULON, July 4.--Dr. Koch, a member of the German Cholera Committee, and head of the Cholera Commission, who has offered his services to the French Government to ascertain the character of the epidemic, has arrived here. Dr. Borel, a naval physician, died to-day from cholera. It is thought that the disease has now reached its highest point. It will probably continue with lessened effect during the hot weather. There were seven deaths here to-day.
John King, Jr., of Baltimore, is at the Brevoort House. The Rev. Herrick Johnson, of Chicago, is at the Gilsey House.
Forty quarts of milk are furnished daily to the Sick Children's Mission by James Stillman from his alderney stock farm on the Hudson.

The Society of Tammany, which discovered America, obtained the independence of the United States, and wrote the declaration thereof, and which now turns the crank that whirls the earth and supervises all sublunary things--that is, if their orators speak the truth-- held their annual jubilee yesterday in the hall of their order, with an accompaniment of music, patriotism, beer, and enthusiasm.

SARATOGA, N.Y., July 4.--Five thousand persons assembled at Saratoga Lake this afternoon to witness the intercollegiate regatta. A strong wind blew all day, making rowing dangerous. Referee Garfield and the judges went over the course at 8 o'clock this afternoon, when they decided the water was too rough, and the race was postponed till 10 o'clock, sharp to-morrow morning. The crews are all in good form and spirits.

BUFFALO, July 4.--For several months there has been much dissatisfaction among the employes of the Buffalo, New-York and Philadelphia Railroad on account of the failure of the company to pay salaries on time.

Policeman McCullogh, of the Eleventh Precinct, took Charles Matty, of No. 229 East Twenty-seventh-street, into the Essex Market Police Court yesterday on a charge of intoxication.

DENVER, Col., July 4.--The most notable event of the Fourth in the State occurred at Swan City, a small mining camp, where the miners, not being supplied with fireworks, blew up the Post Office with giant powder. No one was injured.

The steamship Aurania, of the Cunard Line, arrived from Liverpool yesterday, but, owing to the fog, did not pass Quarantine. After the had anchored there two tugs were sent down to her for those passengers who were anxious to reach the city immediately.

The anniversary of American independence was celebrated in this city yesterday with some of the old-time enthusiasm which the perennial "old citizen" remembers to have characterized it in the days of his youth, so far as noise and the expenditure of powder were concerned.
PEEKSKILL, July 4.--There has been the usual Fourth of July rain this afternoon, to the intense disgust of the occupants of the State Camp, who give way to-morrow to the First Provisional Regiment.

MANCHESTER, July 4.--The Guardian, in its commercial article, says: "Business is moderate. Prices are well supported. A strong cotton market increases the firmness of sellers, but the supply of yarns and goods being sufficient, merchants are not disposed to anticipate future wants. The strike at Burnley does not affect the prices or demand."

TRENTON, N.J., July 4.--A potter named Jones, who has been but two weeks in this country, was drowned to-day while bathing in the creek between Morris Island and Morrisville. He leaves a wife and seven children in England.

WATERVILLE, July 4.--The faces of hop growers are wreathed in smiles. Prices are going up, and the vines are looking well--not so well on the whole as last year, but well enough to assure a profitable season if the fruiting corresponds with present promises.

Elnathan Lucas, who died at his home in this city recently at the advanced age of 85 years was a pioneer, and settled in Northern New-York in 1809. Mr. Lucas kept a faithful record of his life up to 1871, together with a very complete genealogy of the Lucas family, and the volume, though yellow with age, still remains as clean and neat as if recently written.

Michael Clark caroused on Thursday night with John Lahey. William Tyson, and James O'Keefe, all boys about 16 years of age. At 6 o'clock yesterday morning all were under the influence of beer, and lay on a lumber pile at Tenth-avenue and Fifty-sixth-street. O'Keefe had a revolver, and in some manner shot Clark in the back of the head, inflicting a wound which is considered fatal.

Recently while John Mason, a carpenter, was engaged in putting a new floor in the basement of Hezekiah Champion's house, New London, he found between the lathing and sheathing of the house an iron hoop, such as is rolled by children. He took it home for his children to play with, telling his wife where it was found. She immediately took possession of it.

Charles Reade was a voluminous writer but of the extent of what he has left behind him it is impossible as yet to speak. LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 4.--The Brooklyn Club was twice defeated by the Louisvilles today. SPRINGFIELD, Mass., July 4.--The celebration at Woodstock, Conn., to-day was in every way a success, although the crowd perhaps was not up in numbers to former years. Much local interest had been excited by the return of Gen. McClellan to visit the old homestead of his ancestors.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, July 4.--A storm which partook of the nature of a cyclone swept through the southern portion of this city at 6 o'clock this evening. A funnel-shaped cloud, moving with great rapidity and giving out a roaring sound, was one of the distinguishing phenomena.

TORONTO, Ontario, July 4.--To-day was set apart for the parade of the secret and benevolent societies, and, everything being ready, the procession started down Yonge-street, with banners flying and bands playing, making a magnificent spectacle.

BOSTON, July 4.--The annual meeting of the Society of the Cincinnati was held to-day at the Parker House. These officers were elected: President--Samuel C. Cobb; Vice-President-- Charles D. Homans; Treasurer--Winslow Warren; Assistant Treasurer--Gamaliel Bradford; Secretary--Francis W. Palfrey; Assistant Secretary--Daniel G. Harking, Jr.

TRENTON, N.J., July 4.--There was a commotion created here this afternoon by the arrival of the canal boat Josiah Brook, of NewYork, having on board the body of a man named David Hollenbeck, who was shot in the fore cabin of the boat about five miles below Bordentown. The body lay on the floor of the cabin with a pistol wound in the left eye, and the forehead blackened with powder.

NORFOLK, Va., July 4.--The State Regatta of the Virginia Association of Amateur Oarsmen took place in this city to-day. An immense crowd was in attendance. RICHMOND, July 4.--The Republican managers are quietly organizing the party in this State for the coming Presidential campaign. At present Mahone's hand has not been recognized in this work. As soon as Congress adjourns it is understood that the Senator will open his headquarters at Petersburg and begin the work of organization with vigor.

HONG KONG, July 4.--The French allowed the Lang-sow garrison three days to surrender before they were attacked. The officers of the garrison replied that they had no orders to surrender. The French officers who were taken prisoners are well treated.

The Guion steamship Alaska, which sails for Liverpool this afternoon, will carry as pas-- sengers Augustin Daly and his theatrical company, the first complete American dramatic troupe that has ever ventured to cross the Atlantic to give performances.

PHILADELPHIA, July 4.--Thomas Bacon a young married man, living at Pulaski and Pent streets, had his right arm blown off and his face and legs lacerated this morning by the explosion of a dynamite cartridge with which he intended to celebrate the Fourth. He died at the Gen. mantown Hospital this afternoon.

When Secretary McCook finished reading the Declaration of Independence at the opening of the Senate's session to-day he sat down without reading the names of the signers of that document. Mr. Hoar at once demanded to hear these names and Mr. McCook had to give them.

A well-known Boston gentleman keeps pigeons at his country place, near Milton. The birds lived in the barn until recently, when he built a hen-house, with a dove-cot in its second story. The barn was then boarded up and the pigeons invited to enter their new home.

The Pall Mall Gazette gravely informs its readers, under a prominent head line, that "the Democratic. State Convention has elected 72 delegates to the Chicago Convention and instructed them to vote as a unit there on all questions." It says nothing to show where the convention was held--whether in New-York State or Texas, or in Rhode Island.

HAWLEY, Penn., July 4.--A number of curious mishaps are reported as having happened on the farm of Adam Haser, in the township of Dreher, this county, on three successive days last week, two of which narrowly escaped terminating fatally.

BOONE, Iowa., July 4.--The gold medal authorized by the State of Iowa at the Nineteenth General Assembly to be awarded to Kate Shelby, the heroine, was presented to her to-day at Ogden. In the absence of Gov. Sherman, Mr. Walker Given, his private secretary, made the presentation speech, to which Prof. John F. Curran, of Angus, responded on behalf of the recipient. There was a large crowd in attendance.

DETROIT, July 4.--The baseball game this morning was close and exciting throughout, and was won by Ward's remarkable catch of what looked like a home run by Weidman, with the bases full, in the eighth inning.
Patrick Kirwin, of No. 211 North Sixthstreet, Brooklyn, went on the Prospect Social excursion yesterday, with his wife and family.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., July 4.--Last night at Fort Payne, Ala., Henry Sorsby returned from hunting, and in placing a heavily loaded gun against the wall in his room the hammer struck something and the gun was discharged. The charge entered Sorsby's head, tearing his brains out and leaving his skull in a frightfully mutilated condition. He died instantly. He was of good family, and lived at Birmingham, Ala.

MONTREAL, Quebec, July 4.--A fire this afternoon, which commenced in the Prince of Wales's Hotel, destroyed 19 houses, and was threatening Messrs. Dows' brewery at last advices. The telegraph wires are burned and nothing further can be learned to-night.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 4.--At noon today an explosion occurred in the store of Stinard Brothers, East Genesee-street. There was a large stock of fireworks in the establishment, including huge bombs and torpedoes, which were accidentally ignited.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 4.--Reports as to the various crops throughout Tennessee show that the condition of corn, as compared with that of the same month last year, is 93 per cent., cotton 87, tobacco 95, and the wheat yield 112 per cent.

TORONTO, Ontario, July 3.--At a meeting of the proprietors of the newspaper and job printing offices to-day, a resolution was passed arranging for a reduction in printers' wages from 33 1/3 cents to 30 cents per 1,000 ems, to take effect Monday week. The reasons given for the reduction are the hard times and the small business doing. The Typographical Union will meet tomorrow night to discuss the situation.

WHEELING, West Va., July 4.--James Turner, a young man of 29, was murdered about two miles from Tunnelton, this State, this afternoon by a friend named Harry Taylor. The two had been drinking together and started home the best of friends. It is supposed they became involved in a drunken quarrel which led to the murder. Taylor was arrested.

CHICAGO, July 6,--The Cleveland boom received additional impetus to-night, and the New-York opposition to the Governor was correspondingly depressed, when it became definitely known that the kings County delegation had taken action that was favorable to Cleveland.

BALTIMORE, Md., July 6.--Henry Strobel and Maurice B. Jamison, two young men of this city, were drowned yesterday while bathing in Back River, in Baltimore County. Their bodies were recovered this afternoon.

The Rev. Dr. A. Emilianus Kinner is conducting a retreat at St. Patrick's New Female Orphan Asylum, at Madison-avenue and Fiftysecond-street. Spiritual exercises are held four times each day. The retreat will end on next Saturday.

CINCINNATI, July 6.--The City Directory for 1884, now in press, will show an increase during the year of 11,500 names. CINCINNATI, July 6.--The strike in the Hocking Valley, the important mining region of Ohio, still continues and is beginning to be felt. The strike is against a reduction from 70 to 60 cents a ton for mining.

An organization of retail butchers known as the Eastern Butchers' Protective Association has been in existence for several years, having for its objects the prevention of the sale of dressed beef brought from the West and the encouragement of the sale of that dressed here.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 6.--News has been received here that Detective Parker, of this city, has secured Frank H. Cushman, who embezzled $4,000 from the Merchants' National Bank at Havre, France, and the greater amount of the money. He is expected to sail on the steamer Amerique to-day.

NEW-ORLEANS, July 6.--During the period of extreme high water and when some of the principal crevasses occurred Congress appropriated quite a sum of money for the purpose of procuring and distributing rations among the destitute.

GALVESTON, Texas, July 6.--A special to the News from Fort Davis says: "A courier has arrived, bringing the intelligence that Mexicans, disguised as Indians, raided the Abbott and Dukes ranch, 50 miles south of here, killing two herders. ST. PAUL, Minn., July 6.--Reports from all quarters of the Red River Valley indicate the most favorable conditions for growing crops. It is estimated by many that the average yield will be 25 bushels per acre.

PHILADELPHIA, July 7.--A new juvenile "Jesse James" gang has sprung up in the northern part of Camden, but, unlike the gang recently dispersed, these boys disdain to sneak into houses to steal, relying on the straightforward point of a revolver to compel people to surrender their valuable articles.
A letter from Bordeaux, describing the prosperous vegetation in the Department of the Gironde, says that the vines have not looked so well in the past 10 years as they do now.

DUBUQUE, Iowa, July 7.--This is the fourth day since the prohibition law was to go into operation. So far it has had but little visible effect upon the liquor interests of this city. The breweries were closed on Sunday, but to-day they are all running as usual.
The Rev. Edward M. Deems, Pastor of the Westminster Presbyterian Church, in West Twenty-second-street, returned to this city last Sunday from a three months' visit to Europe.

J.P. Johnson Howard has written a letter to John J. Freeman, editor of the Progressive American, declining to be a candidate for Presidential Elector at large on the Republican ticket in this State. Mr. Howard had been strongly urged for a position on the Electoral ticket as the representative of the colored Republicans.
GALVESTON, Texas, July 8.--C.C. Leib, the defaulting Treasurer of Washington County, has been surrendered by his bondsmen and lodged in the County Jail.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 8.--The strike of the molders at New-Castle ended to-day, Baldwin Co. withdrawing their notice of reduction. The same action has been taken by Bradley Co., of this city, and work will be resumed on Thursday.
ALLIANCE, Ohio. July 8.--Bailey Co., the proprietors of one of the largest canning factories in Eastern Ohio, at Marlboro, have made an assignment. Their assets and liabilities are not known.
LIVERPOOL, July 8.--The match game of cricket between the American eleven and the Gentlemen of Liverpool, which was begun yesterday, was resumed to-day.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 8.--The eleventh annual National Soldiers' Reunion will be held at Caldwell, Ohio., Sept. 17 and 18. The reunion will be non-political and composed of privates only. Private Dalzell is Chairman of the Committee of Arrangements.

Inspector Byrnes received a circular from Chief of Police Harrigan, of St. Louis, yesterday asking for the arrest of a man bearing the assumed name of C.H. Newman for obtaining money and goods under false pretenses.

Eighteen guardians of the peace, arrayed in bright knee breeches and shirts, assembled at Washington Park, Brooklyn, yesterday, to play a game of baseball. They were picked nines of the New-York and Brooklyn police forces, and had come prepared to settle the question of the championship.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., July 8.--Waterbury is affected with a cholera infantum epidemic. There have been four deaths from the disease within two days. Many other cases are reported.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 8.--The annual meeting of the General Freight Agents' Association of the Middle States was held here to-day.

It appears that an offer of $125,000 from some German speculators for the sole right to produce "Parsifal" was rejected by the heirs of Wagner before the mysterious American offer of $250,000 was made. Wagner's Executor declares that "Parsifal" shall never be performed out of the Bayreuth theatre.

WASHINGTON, July 8.--The exodus of statesmen and politicians caused by the meeting of the Democratic National Convention and the adjournment of Congress left comparatively few persons here who took more than a passing interest in the news from Chicago.
