Amateur photography has bacome so universal an accomplishment among young people who spend their Summers out of town and wish to reproduce their whilom dwelling places and the scenes of interest about them for future amusement, that a society was formed three months ago, called the Society of Amateur Photographers, of New-York.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 8.--The tenth annual national convention of the Emerald Beneficial Association met here this morning. The session will last several days. Fifty delegates are present from New-York, Ohio, Indiana, Pennsylvania, Illinois, Virginia, Canada, and the District of Columbia.

PETERSBURG, Va., July 8.--The Swift Creek and Blandford cotton factories have stopped work, throwing out of employment a large number of hands. Other cotton factories here are only working half time, as is also the case with many tobacco factories. The cause is the dull season and the overproduction of goods.

CHICAGO, July 8.--John Kelly and his followers asked the Democratic Convention this afternoon to break the unit rule and to declare that the instructions given by the Saratoga State Convention were not binding. The convention said no by a vote of 332 to 463. This vote and the debate that preceded it were the only important features of the convention's first session.
CAZENOVIA, N.Y., July 8.--A valuable horse belonging to the Rev. Dr. F.L. Norton has been poisoned at that gentleman's country place, it is alleged, by a discharged coachman.
COLUMBUS, Ohio., July 8.--The Ohio Coal Exchange has decided to import Swedes and Hungarians to take the places of the 3,000 men now locked out in the Hocking Valley and to start the mining machines.
TORONTO, Ontario, July 8.--A meeting of the National Great Priory of Canada was opened here this morning, a large gathering of Sir Knights from all parts of the Dominion being present.
ALBANY, July 8.--The State Board of Health has issued a long memorandum concerning the cholera, a copy of which has been sent to every local board in the State.

DETROIT, Mich., July 8.--Two girls, Mary Maney and Millie Zurtch, 12 and 13 years old, respectively, living in this city, took the ferryboat Sunday afternoon and went to Sandwich, on the opposite side of the river, three miles below here, where the Sulphur Springs make a favorite place of resort.

Commissioners Wales and Viele sat and listened yesterday to the testimony furnished by the Council of Political Reform in the investigation of the Park Department, and divided their time between laughing heartily at the nature of the evidence and suggesting questions to the counsel of the board.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 8.--Gov. Cleveland was at the executive chamber all day attending to the duties of his office with his usual industry and regularity. The proceedings of the Chicago Convention, which are eagerly watched by his hosts of personal friends here, seem to give him little concern.

The firm of A. Dyett Co., stock brokers, at No. 80 Broadway, sent an announcement of its suspension to the Stock Exchange yesterday afternoon. The intelligence occasioned but little surprise in "the Street" and had no perceptible effect on the market.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 8.--The centennial anniversary of the establishment of the University of the State of New-York and of the organization of the Board of Regents is being celebrated in connection with the annual university convocation which opened this morning.
ERIE, Penn., July 8.--A noted shover of counterfeit money, Luke S. Currier, was arrested for operating here.

C.P. Huntington was asked yesterday how much of a dividend the Central Pacific Railroad was likely to declare. He answered that he did not know as there would be any dividend; he would be glad if somebody would tell him. It was reported in Wall-street yesterday afternoon that Mr. Huntington and Jay Gould had engaged in a confidential chat in the former's office.

PHILADELPHIA, July 8.--The libel in the divorce suit by a woman who claims to be the wife of Hiram S. Maxim, the inventor of the system of electric lighting which bears his name, was filed in the Common Pleas Court here last September.
LOCKPORT, N.Y., July 8.--The glass blowers of Canada and the United States represented by delegates assembled in annual convention in this city this morning, and will hold a four days' session here.

PHILADELPHIA, July 8.--The first of the annual series of eight-oared races for the Sharpless Cup, a handsome piece of solid silver valued at $500, will be rowed over the national course on the Schuylkill Thursday afternoon.

ST. LOUIS, July 8.--The steamtug H.C. Coleman exploded her boilers at Elliott's Landing on the Missouri River, seven miles from Booneville, last night. All the crew, consisting of three white men add four negroes, except Capt. Thompson, were killed. The boat was torn to pieces, the pilot house being blown 200 yards away.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 8.--The International Park Commissioners met at the Cataract House, Niagara Falls, this morning, several of the parties interested being represented by counsel.

BOSTON, July 8.--At a meeting of the Directors of the Boston Union Baseball Club today Bond and Brown were expelled from the club. The charges against these players were at games on the part of Bond, and insubordination and drunkenness on the part of Brown.

DANVILLE, Va., July 8.--B.F. Richardson killed his brother Albert with a chair in Henry County on Sunday last. The murderer is said to have been a moonshiner, and was abusing his mother, when Albert resented it and a quarrel ensued.

WASHINGTON, July 8.--An army retiring board having found First Lieut. Thaddeus H. Capron, Ninth Infantry, unfit for active service, he has, with the approval of the Secretary of War, been granted leave of absence until further orders on account of disability.

A great race of steam yachts is being arranged by the American yacht Club, which includes among its members the owners of nearly all of the large pleasure steam vessels in this vicinity. George S. Scott, the banker, and President of the Richmond and Danville Railroad, is the Commodore of the club.

NYACK, July 8.--Leading from Nyack over the mountain to Rockland Park is a remarkably pleasant road, well shaded, and affording a delightful drive for those who desire to avoid the dust of the public highway known as the turnpike.

The detectives attached to the Eighteenth Police Precinct were yesterday puzzling their minds over a rather peculiar case of shooting which occurred on Tuesday night in the tenement house No. 410 East Sixteenth-street. A man and a woman were wounded during the affair.

CHICAGO, July 9.--No trouble was experienced by chicago in getting a game from New York. In fact, but for a wild throw by Corcoran in the eighth inning, the visitors would have been shut out entirely as McKinnon thereby reached second, and was batted home by Caskins.

C. Bunnell, who resides near Courtland, in this county, was in town to-day, accompanied by his son Eddie. The latter is one of the most remarkable specimens of human development in this section, and we doubt if his equal exists in the whole country.

There was some commotion in the sugar trade yesterday in cunsequenee of the announcement that the old and reputable house of J. De Rivera Co., No. 117 Pearl-street, was embarrassed. This firm has had extensive dealings in sugar and hemp for many years.

TROY, N.Y., July 9.--About a year ago John Wilson met Winifred O'Brien in Dublin. They courted for a while and, according to the story of Winifred, he made her believe that true happiness lay in her coming to America with him, as his wife, without the usual marriage ...

ALBANY, N.Y., July 9.--The Governor has appointed the following persons as members of the State Board of Pharmacy: under chapter 361 of the Laws of 1884: Alfred B. Husted, Edward S. Dawson, Jr., Curtis H. Haskin, J. Hungerford Smith, and Clark Z. Otis.
A series of attractive and instructive entertainments is now in progress at the UnionSquare Theatre.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., July 9.--The ninth annual convention of the National Amateur Press Association met in this city this morning. About 100 members from all parts of the country were in attendance. Frank E. Arnett, of Columbus, Ohio, First Vice-President, presided to-day.
An engine on the Prospect Park and Coney Island Railroad became disabled by the breaking of a valve stem yesterday while drawing a train down the incline between Brooklyn and Parkville.

A Southern Senator well known in Georgia had occasion to visit New-York on business. He went to the station, bought his sleeping car ticket, boarded the train, and went to bed.

Leon Davis, 25 years old, of No. 285 West Twelfth-street, was arrested on Tuesday for forging orders for tickets, using the names of Albert Pulitzer, of the Morning Journal; Joseph Pulitzer, of the World, and Benjamin Wood, of the Daily News.

The programme for to-day at Monmouth Park is very good one, and promises some fine sport. There are six races to be decided; among them the Monmouth Oaks and the Monmouth Cup. The latter will probably be a duel between Barnes and Drake Carter, as Monitor is entered in the first race, and is not yet in condition to struggle with the crack 4-year-olds. Mayor Barnert, of Paterson, N.J., having sent a message to the Board of Aldermen declaring that members of the Finance Committee had "known of the defalcation of City Clerk Will Hague for weeks before he disappeared," the matter was referred to a special committee for investigation.

BOSTON, July 9.--A large representation of the members of the National Association of Commercial Travelers attended the annual meeting of that body held this forenoon at the Merchants' Association rooms. Delegates were present from all over the country, even California being represented.

Viewed from a distance, Florida politics seem in a bad condition for a Presidential year. They are full of conflicting interests, diversified opinions, passion, distrust, and recrimination, the only ray of light being the fact that the Republicans are in almost as unsettled a condition as the Democrats.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 10.--At Sandy Hill this morning Hiram S. Kenyon, aged 75, severed his jugular vein with a razor and was found dead in his bedroom shortly afterward by members of his family. He leaves quite a family, three of his sons being in business in Sandy Hill.

READING, Penn., July 10.--Mrs. Maria Lengleskindt, aged 72 years, residing on Maplestreet, below Cotton, this city, died a few weeks ago from general debility, leaving one daughter and a granddaughter.

Two families of assisted immigrants, who were discovered at Castle Garden on Sunday last by Commissioner Stephenson, were placed yesterday on the steamship Assyrian Monarch which will take them back to England. The immigrants did not wish to return, and attempted to leave the Garden. They were pursued, however, by the clerks, who finally drove them into a corner and secured them.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, July 10.--On Sunday the Furness Line steamship Lincoln City ran on the rocks at Isaacs Harbor. A telegram was received at this port for assistance, and tugs were at once sent to the stranded steamer.

WASHINGTON, July 10.--It was reported to-day that the discovery had been made in the Post Office Department that certain of the employes of the stamp division had been stealing large quantities of new stamps in sheets and disposing of them to outside persons, and that such depredations had been going on for a long time, the value of the stamps thus taken being estimated at several thousand dollars.

ALBANY, July 10.--Democratic politicians are anxiously awaiting for the balloting to begin at Chicago. Gov. Cleveland's friends are of the opinion that he will be nominated before an adjournment is taken to-night.

The Staten Island Athletic Club had its annual regatta in the Kill Von Kull yesterday afternoon. Its clubhouse at New-Brighton was crowded with ladies and gentlemen from Brighton Terrace and this city. An orchestra, furnished music on the second floor of the clubhouse. The races began at 3 o'clock.

LONDON, July 10.--The News's special from Assouan says: "The treachery of the Mudir of Dongola is at last confirmed. The Christians in the town are imprisoned, and have been compelled to turn Mohammedan to escape the vengeance of the Mudir. El Mahdi has made the Mudir his Emir.

Sept. 9, Admission Day, will be celebrated with great pomp in this city by the Order of the Native Sons of the Golden West, of which new society there are two flourishing parlors in Sacramento, and over 30 in the State. Gold was discovered by James W. Marshall at Coloma Jan. 10, 1848.

DUBLIN, July 10.--A fund is being raised here to indemnify Mr. O'Brien, editor of United Ireland, for the expenses attending his defense of the libel suit brought against him by Mr. Cornwall, ex-Post Office Secretary.

WASHINGTON, July 10.--The report of the Department of Agriculture for July relative to cotton represents that rains have been excessive during June over the entire breadth, the temperature low, the plants too succulent and generally late for the season.

GALVESTON, Texas, July 10.--A special to the News from Hearne, this State, says: "Near Sutton Station yesterday a quarrel arose between Warren Mass and Alexander Ward, brothers-inlaw, which culminated in Mass's shooting and instantly killing Ward. The murderer was arrested."

The beneficent work of the Children's Aid Society can only be fully appreciated after a glimpse of the little ones whom the society is caring for at its two seaside retreats--the Summer Home at Bath and the Health Home at Coney Island.

BRUNSWICK, Me., July 10.--The Commencement exercises of Bowdoin College occurred to-day. Gen. Chamberlain and the Hon. Joseph Titcomb were elected Trustees to fill vacancies. Nothing toward selecting a permanent President of the college was done.

PETERSBURG, Va., July 10.--Eaton Mills, who was convicted in the Circuit Court of Halifax, N.C., last May of the murder of John Henry Porter in December, 1882, and sentenced to be hanged to-morrow, has obtained an appeal to the Supreme Court for a new trial of the case, to be heard at the October term of the court.

RALEIGH, N.C., July 10.--The Republican State Committee met here yesterday. Eight members resigned, and their places were filled by men who are not Federal officeholders. Dr. J. J. Mott was continued as Chairman and M.V.B. Gilbert was elected Secretary.

A recent exhibition of orchids in Horticultural Hall was said to be the finest and rarest of any that has ever taken place in this country. Many of them were from the wonderful greenhouses of ex-Gov. Ames, at Amesbuy, where he has expended $100,000 on the growth of orchids alone.

Never since she began to exhibit her peculiar powers to a skeptical public has the Georgia phenomenon faced such an angry, howling lot of people as a portion of the spectators in Wallack's Theatre last night. The house was crowded with men, women, and children.

HAVANA, July 10.--The English steamer has arrived from St. Thomas, bearing dates to July 5. At San Domingo, May 26, a fall in the price of sugar caused a monetary crisis and many estates ceased work. Ex-President Cesario Guillermo presented an act of submission to the Dominican Government and he will therefore be allowed to reside in the country as a private citizen.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., July 10.--The second day's session of the National Amateur Press Association has largely attended to-day. Thomas G. Harrison, of Indianapolis; Henry E. Legler, of this city, and Bernard Ginsberg, of Detroit, were elected judges of the association for the ensuing year.
PARIS, July 10.--Admiral Courbet telegraphs that he has occupied a town on the Chinese coast.

BALTIMORE, July 10.--This morning, while the steam tug J.A. McDougall was lying at the Broadway Ferry, Joseph Young, a fireman, removed the plate from the manhole of the boiler and placed a lighted lamp on the inside to aid him in finding a leak.
BUFFALO, July 10.--The defalcations of Howard Young, the local ticket agent of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad Company, aggregate over $1,800.

The sugar planters have done that which lay nearest to them in the way of reducing the cost of production and saving themselves from bankruptcy this Fall, viz.: have curtailed expenses in every way and cut down wages.

The French steam yacht Nubienne, which ran ashore on Wednesday on the South Brother Island, at the entrance of the Sound, lies at present at the sectional dock at the foot of Rutgersstreet. It is hoped that she will sail this evening. The damages sustained are not of a serious character ...
The first Summer meeting at Monmouth Park was brought to a close yesterday with an excellent series of races, which were run on a fast track and in the presence of a large crowd of spectators.

WASHINGTON, July 10.--Representatives Cox, of New-York, and Ryan, of Kansas, to-day called upon the Postmaster-General and had an interview upon the subject of the letter carriers' annual leaves of absence.

TORONTO, July 10.--The Grand Lodge of Canada of A.F. and A.M., which has been in session liere yesterday and to-day, has elected the following officers: Grand Master--Hugh Murray Hamilton; Deputy Grand Master-- Henry Robertson. Collingwood; Grand Senior Warden--George R. Van Zant, of Markham;

Bernard Keegan, aged 50, and his son, William, aged 28, residents of Glen Head, Long Island, were on their way home from Flushing on Wednesday night. Both were under the influence of liquor and quarreled on the way home.
LONG BRANCH, July 10.--The annual meeting of the Morocco Manufacturers' National Exchange was held at the Howland Hotel today.
LONDON, July 10.--The Supreme Tribunal of Hesse has issued a decree of separation between Mme. Kalomine and the Grand Duke of Hesse, who were recently united in a morganatic marriage.

SPRINGFIELD, July 10.--Adolph Bertrand, a Holyoke saloon keeper, who recently complained that he had been robbed of $2,590 now confesses that it was taken from him by a confidence man, who pretended to be foolish and gave a him a bag of "gold" to keep in return for his money. After the two had departed the bag was found to contain scrap iron.

WASHINGTON, July 10, 1884. The Secretary of the Treasury to-day appointed John Collins to be Inspector of Foreign Steamboats for the District of New-York and John Meehen to be Local Inspector of Hulls for the District of New-York.

CHICAGO, July 10.--The race meeting at the Chicago Driving Park to-day was signalized by the most remarkable performance ever witnessed on a race track. Westmonts, the young pacer, traveled one mile with a running mate in the remarkable time of 2:01 . This is the fastest time ever made by either a pacing or a trotting horse and beats all records by several seconds.
WASHINGTON, July 10.--Mr. Cannon, Controller of the Currency, to-day directed that an assessment of 100 per cent. be levied on the shareholders of the Marine National Bank, of NewYork.

WASHINGTON, July 10.--A rumor was current here to-day that Senator Logan would go to New-York to-morrow to meet and consult with Mr. Blaine, but it is denied to-night by the Senator. He says, however, that he will probably go to New-York within a few days.

ERIE, Penn., July 10.--Recorder Marvin has issued a warrant for the arrest of R. Petit, Cashier of the Erie Savings Bank, who it is alleged has stolen $140,000. When the constable reached Petit's surburban villa the Cashier had disappeared.

BRATTLEBORO, Vt., July 10.--Ithamer Hadlock, of North Troy, Vt., was arrested today by Marshal Henry for smuggling. Hadlock's building which is situated near the Canada line, and other property of his, were seized. He is said to be an old offender whom the Government has been in pursuit of for the past 10 years.

The last Prince of Orange was flagrantly a stunted offshoot of a wornout stem. He had a colorless complexion, unless when a hectic flush suffused the sharp cheekbone. The ossature was weak and the muscles accorded with it.

QUEBEC, July 10.--The British steamer Fylgia, from Pictou, Nova Scotia, with coal, is reported ashore at Red Point. The vessel will probably be a total wreck. She is 963 tons, and owned and insured in England. She has been engaged in the coal trade between Pictou and Montreal all the season.

WASHINGTON, July 10.--By direction of the President, First Lieut. J.C. Bush, Fifth Artillery, has been detailed as Professor of Military Science and Tactics at the Collegiate and Commercial Institute, New-Haven, Conn., to take effect Sept. 1, 1884.

MONTREAL, July 10.--It appears that the stocks in the cotton trade are heavier than many would like to see them. Although many mills have stopped in whole or part, the quantity of cotton still on hand is large. The project to send a cargo to Great Britain has been abandoned as impracticable. One large factory now working will stop as soon as the present stock of raw material is exhausted.
CHICAGO, Ill., July 10.--The Washington Park races had warm weather, a fast track, and a very large attendance to-day.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 10.--Maud S., while exercising this afternoon, trotted a mile in 2:12 .

A butcher was fined the other day 1s. for selling tuberculous meat. To-day a butcher was fined $5 for playing cards. In the one case the butcher's sin was against the public; in the other it was likely a brother butcher he was sinning against. Perhaps that accounts for the Recorder's method of balancing the scales of justice.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., July 10.--Frank P. Germain, a young grain operator, suspended today, while trying to carry 100,000 bushels of wheat against the market. The failure had no effect upon the market. Germain's business can be straightened out, and will liquidate all his indebtedness except about $5,000.

A dramatic scene was enacted yesterday at the inquest in the case of Michael Reilly, who died at his home, No. 1,608 Fulton-street, Brooklyn, on Tuesday, from the effects of injuries received in a fight with Michael Whalen, at Division-avenue and Wilson-street, on Sunday last.
CENTRALIA, Penn., July 10.--Three men, John Kiamus, Aber Rice, and Borie Sponemitz, were fatally inured last evening by the premature explosion of a blast.

PHILADELPHIA, July 10.--The eight-oared shell race for, the Sharpless Cup, which took place over the national course on the Schuylkill River this afternoon, was won by the Columbia crew, of Washington, D.C.

Alfred Goldsmith, an Englishman, 27 years old, who says that he is a waiter and without friends or a home in this city, was arrested shortly before noon yesterday by an officer of the Seventeenth Precinct, charged with having stolen $20 from the house of Mrs. Sarah Vanderwelan, No. 59 East Fourth-street, where he had boarded some time ago.
MARLBOROUGH, N.Y., July 10.--The raspberry crop in Ulster County is so large that the factories which make the cups in which the berries are shipped are unable to supply the demand.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., July 10.--The morning session of the Glass Blowers' Convention was mainly devoted to the work of the organization of the league and was secret in its character. The price schedule was considered in the afternoon. The convention will probably adjourn to-morrow.

HANOVER, N.H., July 10.--The concluding session of the Philological Association was held to-day and the following officers were elected: President--Prof. Goodwin, of Harvard; Vice-Presidents--Profs. Peck, of Yale, and Merriam, of New-York; Secretary and Treasurer-- Prof. H. Wright, of Dartmouth.

PHILADELPHIA, July 10.--An officer of the Philadelphia and Reading Coal and Iron Company stated to-day that the matter of suspending production during August had not yet been the subject of even informal discussion, but that if the other companies demanded a week's stoppage in that month the Reading Company would not oppose the movement, although it would be better satisfied with full work.

BALTIMORE, July 12.--Augustus Slater, arrested on the morning of the 8th inst. for the murder of the gambler William McGowan, was brought before the City Court to-day on a writ of babeas corpus. He was admitted to bail in $5,000 to await the action of the Grand Jury, Jerome Diggs becoming his surety.

SUMMIT, Ulster County, N.Y., July 12.-- The success of the new Grand Hotel is unparalleled, although the height of the season is not yet reached. The Otological Society also intend making the Grand Hotel the place for their Summer meeting.

Mrs. Catherine E. Smith, aged 65, was found dead in the rear room of the tenement house No.43 Hamilton-street, yesterday afternoon. She had purchased Paris green from a drug store in Catharine-street, ostensibly to kill cockroaches, and committed suicide by swallowing a quantity of the stuff in a glass of beer.

BOSTON, July 12.--William Edwards, (colored,) during an altercation last night at Hingham with Joseph Burke, (white,) over the respective merits of certain prominent prize fighters, stabbed Burke, inflicting wounds which will probably prove fatal. Edwards was arrested this morning, and asserts that he stabbed Burke in self-defense.

Train No. 7 was 24 minutes late, but the other train was on time.

WHEELING, West Va., July 12.--A letter from Spencer, Roane County, states that a quartz vein has been found on the farm of Thomas Castno, of Spring Creek, in the eastern part of the county. PHILADELPHIA, July 12.--With regard to the statement made recently that Blaine medals were being made at the United States Mint in this city, Col. Snowden, the Superintendent, says it is not true. VIENNA, July 13.--As the train which left Pola after the one on which was the Emperor Francis Joseph was passing through a gorge near Podgoritza, it was discovered that the rails had been misplaced. The discovery, however, was made in time to stop the train before a disaster occurred. The criminals had evidently mistaken this train for the one containing the Emperor.

While the night watchman in Martin Worn Son's furniture manufactory, at Humboldt and Seigel streets, Brooklyn, was sitting in the engine room just before 1 o'clock yesterday morning, he was startled by an unusually heavy crash of thunder, and a shock as though the building, which had been struck by lightning, had been shaken by an earthquake. He ran up stairs and plunged out into the rain.

PARIS, July 13.--During the 24 hours ending at 9 o'clock to-night there were 57 deaths from cholera at Marseilles and 36 at Toulon. Two Sisters of Charity were among those who died at Toulon.

A destructive and voracious enemy of the beet root has appeared in Germany. It is a black bug, and was first seen in Silesia, where, in the District of Leopschutz, upward of 50 acres of beets were completely ruined. One cultivator, on a patch of less than 10 rods square, killed 1,800 bugs.

The magnificent red brick house and carefully laid out arounds of Sir Roderick W. Cameron, at Clifton, Staten Island, wore a smiling aspect yesterday. PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 13.--The Central Labor Union, representing every industry in the State, met last night and took action refusing to support Blaine or Cleveland, and favoring an Anti-Monopolist candidate, probably Butler. A committee was appointed to confer with all other State associations of the country.
PHILADELPHIA, July 13.--The Deane divorce case, of which an account was published in THE TIMES a few days ago, on Friday made another sensational turn.

MARLBOROUGH, N.Y., July 13.--The seemingly unaccountable disappearance of pretty Mrs. Annie Wade, an account of which appeared in THE TIMES of to-day, is explained. Mrs. Wade, who had gained a reputation in Marlborough and vicinity for modesty and timidity, eloped with a railroader from Fultonville, N.Y., named Patrick Ward.

Fireworks blazed from Weehawken to the foot of West Forty-second-street at 10:30 o'clock last evening, marking the course of the triumphal County Democracy across the river to its native heath on its return from Chicago.
Yesterday, in obedience to the command of the people at home, the Democrats of the National Convection nominated Groves Cleveland as their candidate for President of the United States.

LONDON, July 13.--A great demonstration was held in Hyde Park to-day in favor of the London Municipal Reform bill. Twenty thousand persons were present. Resolutions were adopted denouncing the present system as a danger and a disgrace, and urging the Government to reintroduce the bill at the next session of Parliament.

TROY, N.Y., July 14.--The body of George Ober was found, on Saturday, hanging in a barn near Ironville, Essex County. Ober was last seen a week ago with two strange men, who are missing. DES MOINES, Iowa, July 14.--The people of Lion, Decatur County, are excited over the finding, on Saturday night, two miles north of that town, of the body of an unknown young man, whose throat had been cut from ear to ear. NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., July 14.--The loom fixers at the Wamsutta and Potomska Mills struck to-day on account of a reduction of wages to $1.50 per day. WILKESBARRE, Penn., July 14.--Senator Eckley B.Coxe and J.K.Bogert, delegates to the Chicago Convention, were tendered a recention upon their arrival home to-night. About 9,000 people were in line. Mr.Coxe, who is a coal operator and a large employer of labor, said the Democratic Party was always the friend of labor and opposed to monopoly. The Democratic platform adopted at Chicago was one that the workingmen of Pennsylvania, could support. He predicted Cleveland's success in November.

ASHLAND, Penn., July 14.--The barn of Thomas Lee, a farmer at Roaring Creek, was struck by lightning Satureday night and destroyed, with all its contents, including eight head of cattle. Two of the farmer's sons and a man named Kohler were fatally injured by falling timber while attempting to rescue the stock. The loss is about $5,000; no insurance.

TORONTO, Ontario, July 14.--During a game of lacrosse on Saturday a fight ensued. One of the players, Charles A. Martin, was knocked down and brutally kicked by another player named Charles Thompson. Thompson was arrested and admitted to bail. Martin lingered in great agony until this morning, when he died. Thompson cannot be found.

QUEBEC, July 14.--the steamship Warwick is ashore two miles below Fox River. The passengers and crew will be landed as soon as the weather permits. She lies in a bad position on the rocks in seven feet of water forward.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 14.--This morning at 1 o'clock the town of Owenboro, in Western Kentucky, was taken possession of by a masked mob of about 100 men, on horseback, who made a fierce attack on the County Jail in search of Richard May, a nogro, confined on a charge of assaulting a young woman, daughter of a prominent farmer. The mob have been organizing for a week.

PHILADELPHIA, July 14.--The schooner Deborah H.Diverty, Capt. Francis Williams, of Cape May, N.J., and a well-known trader at this port, left Philadelphia in the early part of June with a cargo of coal consigned to Richmond, Va., and in due time arrived and discharged.

PARKER, Penn., July 14.--While a gang of railroad laborers were at work this morning on an excavation near here on the Clarion River the embankment caved in, killing two instantly, and, it is thought, fatally injuring two others.

HAVANA, July 10.--Last year the Official Gazette published an order from the Minister of the Colonies that the remaining surtax of 5 per cent. on export duties on tobacco should be abolished from july 1 of this year, but the shippers of tobacco find that the Custom House continues to charge the old tax.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 14.--The Summer trotting meeting of the Pittsburg Driving Park Association will begin to-morrow and continue four days, and next week the Summer meeting of the Exposition Park Association will be held.
MARSEILLES, July 14.--There were 32 deaths from cholera here lest night, and 4 between 9 o'clock this morning and noon.

GALVESTON, Texas, July 14.--A dispatch to the News from San Antonio says: "Parties in the western part of the State confirm the report that the sheep and cattle industries in that part of the State are threatened with annihilation by the drought. Sheep men are arriving daily at Eagle Pass seeking ingress to the Mexico water holes. The streams on the American side of the Rio Grande River are dried up.

A peculiar disease afflicts the wife of an Episcopal minister now residing in a small town in Minnesota, near the Wisconsin line. The minister is well known over the Northwest, and the facts here narrated were driven by the reverend gentleman himself. A dozen or so years ago he married a wealthy young lady of the little Minnesota town, and has resided there much of the time since.

WASHINGTON, July 14.--As a result of the recent discovery that a clerk in Third Assistant Postmaster-General Hazen's office had been stealing postage Stamps for several months, Postmaster-General Gresham to-day asked for and received the resignation of T.P. Graham, chief of the postage stamp division in Gen. Hazen's office.

PARIS, July 14.--The anniversary of the fall of the Bastile was celebrated here to-day with great eclat. The houses were decorated with flags and bunting. Two reviews of troops were held. They were witnessed by thousands of persons, who cheered the soldiers heartily. Great crowds also attended the open air concerts and other places of amusement. The weather was fine.

TRENTON, N.J., July 17.--During last night a convict named Mathew Scanlon, from Hoboken, age 23 years, committed suicide by hanging himself in his cell in the prison here.

PHILADELPHIA, July 17.--The Medical News of next Saturday will say: "The progress of cholera during the past week has been such as to warrant the belief that it will spread throughout Europe during the next 30 days, and may reach our shores at any time.

Members of the Electric, Manufacturing, and Miscellaneous Stock Exchange assembled in small groups in the large trading room of that Exchange yesterday and discussed the exciting events of the previous day's meeting. The expressions of opinion were varied.

MONTREAL, Quebec, July 17.--A serious land slide occurred to-day on the Canadian Pacific, between Montreal and Hochelaga, a portion of the embankment in the rear of Molson's Terrace giving way, carrying with in timber props and gravel with resistless force. The embankment has been considered unsafe, and the company recently awarded a contract to have it substantially rebuilt with a stone front.

GRAND FORKS, Dakota, July 17.--To-day in the District Court all the indictments against Col. Uline and 11 others charged with the murder of the Ward brothers at Devil's Lake in April, 1883, were dismissed.
IRONTON, Ohio, July 17.--On Tuesday H. Campbell Sons, proprietors of the Mount Vernon and Sarah Furnaces, made an assignment to John H. Moulton for the benefit of their creditors.

ST. PAUL, Minn., July 17.--D.E. Swan, chief clerk in the local Treasurer's office of the Northern Pacific Railroad, is a defaulter. He was arrested at White Bear yesterday, where he had secreted himself in the woods.

WASHINGTON, July 17.--A telegram was received to-day by Gen. Lockwood, father of Lieut. Lockwood, of the Greely party, from Lieut. Greely, in which the latter conveyed the news of Lieut. Lockwood's death, and stated that he had immortalized himself by leading a party to the furthest point north that has ever been reached.
CHICAGO, July 17.--The business of the book-publishing house of David C. Cook, of this city and Elgin, Ill., has been transferred to the David C. Cook Publishing Company.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., July 17.--A singular suit is now on trial in this city before Referee Judge Marcus Lyon, of Tompkins County. In December, 1881, Robert S. Phelps, eldest son of the late Judge Phelps, died.

PROVINCETOWN, Mass., July 17.--The new steam yacht Electra, of New-York, on a trip to Marblehead, arrived here this morning with her owner, Elbridge T. Gerry, and party on board. After a brief stay she proceeded to Marblehead.
Mr. A.J. Ketcham has resigned the Cashiership of the Dover Plains National Bank, after 19 years' service.

ST. LOUIS, July 17.--David Toomey, a laborer, who was stabbed in the street yesterday by John Carr during a quarrel about a woman, died this morning.
Dr. Elisha Ould is suing for the annulment of his marriage with Josephine Ould. They were married in 1881. Dr. Ould says that the defendant was the wife of Alexander Harner when he married her.
Julian White, Son Co., commission dealers in notions at No. 86 Leonard-street, suspended yesterday in consequence of their intimate relations with Edmund Yard, Jr., Co., on accommodation notes.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 17.--At New Straitsville yesterday the entire Pinkerton police force, who are there to prevent trouble among the miners, was arrested.
QUEBEC, July 17.--Detective Taylor, who has been here in the interest of the prosecution in the Eno case has gone to New-York.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 17.--For some time past a movement has been on foot to bring a pressure upon the authorities to enforce the law relative to the closing of saloons on Sundays.

Yesterday the Pilot Commissioners sent to the Corps of Engineers for information about the soundings on Diamond Reef. A great many pilots are inclined to agree with Mr. Calvin in the belief that he did not run the steamship Vincenzo Florio on Diamond Reef at ail.

The release of Frank Sherwin from jail in Albany, where he was held pending a stay of proceedings under the most extraordinary sentence on record for contempt of court, is entitled to passing comment.

The completion of the Central American Pacific Railway from the ocean to Guatemala City, 70 miles, was yesterday announced by cable. The road has been built by United States capitalists. While Mary Carroll, aged 12 years, of No. 2,446 Fourth-avenue, and Lizzie Overacker, aged 10 years, of No. 760 Tremont-avenue, were bathing last evening in the Bronx River, above Keller's icehouse, they got beyond their depth and were in great danger of drowning.

A general sense of propriety, rather than definite information, may have given rise to a report that the amount subscribed in furtherance of a testimonial to the late Sir Michael Costa would be expended on some "storied urn or animated bust" consecrated to his memory.

It is the opinion of certain of the advocates of Mr. BLAINE that GROVER CLEVELAND, has had no experience in public affairs. It is true that he has been an admirable Mayor of an important city, and an exceptionally able and upright Governor of the chief State of the Union, but it must be confessed that he does lack that practical acquaintance with public affairs which certain other prominent men have enjoyed.
WASHINGTON, July 17.--Eighty promotions have just been made in the Pension Office, not under the provisions of the civil service rules but upon the recommendations of chiefs of bureaus or divisions.

WASHINGTON, July 17.--Lieut. L.V. Caziarc, Second Artillery, for a few years in charge of the correspondence division of the Signal Office, Washington, D.C., has been relieved from that duty and ordered to join his regiment.

It is said in a telegram from Vienna to a London newspaper that the authorities of the city of Vienna have decided to establish a large public library which shall be devoted exclusively to newspapers. No institution of the kind is believed to exist.
The monument erected at Shelter Island by Mary and Phoebe Gardiner Horsford--daughters of Prof. E.N. Horsford, of Harvard University--to the memory of Nathaniel Sylvester was unveiled yesterday.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 17.--A crowd of over 8,000 persons visited Homewood this afternoon, to witness the attempt of J.M. Hill's famous pacer, Westmont, to lower his record. The track-was fast and the weather all that could be desired.

The examination of Fisk Hatch in the matter of their transactions with the now defunet Newark Savings Bank was resumed yesterday afternoon before Commissioner Knight but with closed doors, as heretofore. Some of the counsel engaged in the case have protested against secrecy in the matter, and it as possible that the further examinations in the case may be made publiciy.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 17.--John C.S. Harrison is the Receiver of the Indiana Banking Company which closed its doors last August. There is great uneasiness for fear that the assets of that institution may be in such shape as to add further to the complications.

On behalf of the intelligent citizens of St. Joseph, the Herald extends a hearty welcome to Prof. Richard Proctor, the eminent English astronomer and scientist. He comes to pass at least a season here, where his wife, we believe, was born and raised.

TROY, N.Y., July 17.--It has just been discovered that the Rev. Mr. McChesney, Pastor of the Methodist Church at West Amsterdam, is in indigent circumstances. The congregation owe him, it is alleged, salary since February.

Numerous complaints have been made to the police recently by the officers of the Harlem and New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad Companies in relation to boys and young men riding on the freight cars while passing through the city to and from the up-town stations.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., July 17.--General Manager Henderson, of the Indianapolis, Bloomington and Western Railway, has been gathering information as to the condition of corn, wheat, and oats along the various divisions of that system in Ohio, Indiana, and Illinois. Reports have just been received from about 70 points.

In his will Mr. Wolcott devised his body to Laura Vasar, that she might bury him so that when she died she could be laid beside him.

Miss Gertrude Griswold sang in concert in London last night. A number of Americans, M. Waddington, the French Ambassador: the Marquis de Casa laiglesia, the Spanish Ambassador; members of the nobility, and members of the House of Commons were present.

The Republican vote of the First Ward of the city of Brooklyn is about 2,000. Last evening 75 persons gathered in and around No. 172 Montague-street to attend a special meeting of the Republican Association of the ward. Alderman Theodore D. Dimon presided.

ELMIRA, N.Y., July 17.--John R. Lynch, of Mississippi, the temporary Chairman of the late Republican National Convention, telegraphs that he will speak in Elmira on Aug. 12, at the emancipation celebration.
CINCINNATI, July 17.--Peter Neider was instantly killed this morning by being caught in an elevator at C.S. Rankin Co.'s establishment in this city.
NATCHEZ, Miss., July 17.--The Grand Lodge of Knights of Honor of Mississippi closed a three days' session here this evening. One hundred and twenty-four members were present.

The rapping of a policeman's club and the loud barking of a dog were heard very early yesterday morning by some of the residents of the block in West Twenty-first-street, between Sixth and Seventh avenues.
NEWBURYPORT, Mass., July 17.--The news of the finding of the Greely party was received at the home of the famous commander with profound joy.

Encouraging advices with regard to the progress of the independent movement were received in abundance at headquarters yesterday. It is now certain that the conference of Tuesday next will be well attended, and that plans for substantial organization can be made with reasonable promise of earnest and effective work.
MEADVILLE, Penn., July 17.--The Conneaut Lake regatta closed this morning with a race for a consolation purse. There was a full list of entries.

The General Committee of the County Democracy of the Nineteenth Assembly District met at Eighth-avenue and Twenty-first street last evening to complete arrangements for the formation of a Cleveland and Hendricks campaign club.

LONG BRANCH, July 17.--Leon Abbett, the Democratic Governor of New-Jersey, has come back from the Chicago Convention full of enthusiasm for Grover Cleveland. "New-Jersey gave me 7,000 majority," he said yesterday, "although the opposition declared that I would be beaten.

READING, Penn., July 17.--The three days' session of the Junior Order of United American Mechanics came to a close to-day. The most important business transacted was the approval of the State Councilor's recommendation making colored men eligible to the order. The national body will now take up the color question, and if approved by them colored men will be admitted to the order.
NEWBURYPORT, Mass., July 17.--The Advisory Board have decided to continue the strike of the lasters at E.P. Dodge Co.'s factory, notwithstanding the announced removal of the firm to Portsmouth.
MARSEILLES, July 17.--There were 21 deaths from cholera here last night. At 8 P.M. there had been 15 deaths since 11 A.M.

Among the passengers of the Inman steamship City of Richmond, which sailed for Liverpool yesterday, were the very Rev. M. McCabe, V.G., Capt. William Buckley, Capt. B, Carter, the Rev. G.H.S. Sommerville, the Rev. W.F. Taylor, and the Rev. A.G. Hibbard. The Rev. Dr. Anstice, Prof. J.N. Davidson, Dr. Louis Hensen, and the Rev. Mariano Canalini sailed on the steamer Gellert, of the Hamburg-American Line.
CHARLESTON, S.C. July 17.--A Republican mass meeting was held here to-night in front of the City Hall. About 1,000 people were present, one-third of whom were white Democrats.
TROY, N.Y., July 17.--Frederick Miner was to-day lodged in jail for non-support of his family. He is the husband of three different women.
LONDON, July 17.--A game of cricket between the American team and the Gentlemen of Surrey was begun at the Oval to-day. The latter team, in their first inning, scored 190.

READING, Penn., July 17.--Burglars bored through the front shutters and gained entrance last night to the store of J.S. Focht and the Post Office at Windsor Castle, Berks County. They carried off jewelry, clothing, silks, postage stamps, letters, and other articles. The goods taken are worth $2,000.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 17.--The sixth annual convention of the Business Education Association of America assembled this morning in the rooms of the Rochester Business University, on State-street.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 17.--The misunderstandings that have existed for some time past between the Rochester City Street Railway Company and the drivers employed by it culminated this morning in a general strike of the drivers.

Detective Jennison, of the Boston police force, went to Police Headquarters yesterday with a requisition from the Governor of Massachusetts for the arrest of Lewis Bishop, the actor, known professionally as Lester Bishop and Lester Fisher, who shot himself on Thursday ...

The national encampment of the Grand Army of the Republic will be held at Minneapolis, Minn., on July 23 and 24. The election of a Commander-in-Chief to succeed Gen. R.C. Beath, of Philadelphia, will form part of the important work of the encampment.

BOSTON, Mass., July 17.--The Executive Committee of the independents met to-day and discussed the question of establishing local organizations throughout the State. Arrangements will be at once begun for starting clubs in all the cities and larger towns. Additional delegates to the New-York conference are J. Otis Wetherbee, of Boston; Edward H. Huntington, of Quincy, and Charles S. Paislee and W. C. Laughton, of Boston.

A New-Haven man has written a letter to the Morning News, of that city, in which he tells of feats done by a 7-year-old girl that closely resemble those of Miss Lulu Hurst. He says: "This girl, by placing her hands on a hard-wood dining table, made it impossible to hold the table still.

BALTIMORE, Md., July 17.--Dr. James R. Clegg, a medical practitioner who was not recognized by the regular profession, but who had attained notoriety here for questionable practices, died early this morning from an overdose of morphia self-administered.

ADOLPHUS W. GREELY, First Lieutenant Fifth Cavalry, Acting Signal Officer and Assistant; married. Lieut. Greely had been connected for a very long time with the Signal Service. During the war he was an officer of a volunteer regiment, and was brevetted for his gallant conduct. Shortly after the war he was detailed for duty in the Signal Service.

TROY, N.Y., July 17.--Orlando Shaw, of North Creeh, has just discovered about three miles north of that place a bed of shot ore. So far the vein has been traced 50 rods and crops out in many places. Mr. Shaw intends to make arrangements to develop the mine.

ATHENS, Ga., July 17.--People were up all last night in anticipation of an attempt by the negroes to burn the town, owing to their indignation at the proceedings of the day before, when the city was filled with an immense throng of negroes in attendance on University Commencement, and the police had orders to keep the sidewalks and store doors cleared.

A singular occurrence took place yesterday on the county bridge at Argentine, Kan., which was watched with great interest by many.
DUBLIN, July 17.--A prominent stock broker of Dublin, who is implicated in the offenses charged against Mr. Cornwall and others, has fled to avoid arrest.
BOSTON, Mass., July 17.--A meeting of Republicans and independents of Concord, the home of the philosophers, opposed to Blaine and Logan was held to-night for organization for campaign work.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 17.--A parallel to the celebrated Wheeler strangling case occurred here late last night. Frank E. Hutchins, a machinist, strangled his mistress, Nettie Simms, because she refused to live with him. Hutchins, when arrested, expressed great joy over the deed.
Postmaster-General Gresham stated positively to-day that the letter carriers will receive their leaves of absence, as provided by law.

WASHINGTON, July 17.--The jury in the case of Ross, the colored man, who has been on trial here for killing another colored man in a house of prostitution in this city last Spring, to-night brought in a verdict of manslaughter. Sentence was suspended pending an application for a new trial.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 17.--Secretary Chandler was found at Mr. Edward Kinsley's residence at West Point this evening reading dispatches from the Acting Secretary at Washington relative to the Greely rescue.

The hearing will be continued on Monday next.
ST. JOHN, Newfoundland, July 17.-- Twelve fishermen belonging to the Gloucester schooner Abbie T. Morris were rescued yesterday 40 miles eastward of St. Pierre Island.

WASHINGTON, July 17.--A report that started in Chicago the day after the Democratic Convention adjourned to the effect that a reorganization of Tammany Hall, involving the displacement of John Kelly as head of the concern, would be made before the active work of the campaign begins, has been repeated here with some particulars.

TOPEKA, Kan., July 17.--The Republican State Convention--reassemble this morning. Judge J.C. Strong Chairman of the Committee on Resolutions, presented the committee's report, saying that it was unanimous, and that it had been arrived at through a desire for harmony and in a spirit of concession. This is the platform:

LONDON, July 17.--In the House of Lords to-day the Earl of Wemyss moved that the House proceed to consider the Franchise bill provided the Government would undertake to present at the Autumn session a bill for the redistribution of seats in the House of Commons.

HARRISBURG, Penn., July 17.--This afternoon notices were placed in the Harrisburg Cotton Factory of a suspension of work for an indefinite period, after Saturday next. The cause is said to be a decline in prices of manufactured goods and stagnation in the markets. About 200 employes will be thrown out of work.

William Valentine, an old and wealthy resident of Roslyn, Long Island, who in March, 1882, was brutally beaten, robbed, and left for dead near his own house by the negroes Edward Albertson and James Eto, (afterward convicted and sentenced to 20 years' imprisonment each in Sing Sing,) died early yesterday morning; aged 73 years. Mr. Valentine never fully recovered from the effects of the assault, and his death is directly attributed to it.

A monument erected in Woodlawn Cemetery in memory of Dr. James M. Austin, who died in December, 1881, was presented yesterday to his family by the Masonic fraternity of the State of New-York.

For more than a quarter of a century one of Greenpoint's most respected and popular citizens has been Mr. William W. Johnson, a real estate and insurance broker, who had an office at No. 451 Manhattan-avenue and who lived with his wife and four children at No. 125 India-street. Johnson was a prominent member of Olive Leaf and other lodges of Odd Fellows and other societies, and was also something of a society man.
DES MOINES, Iowa, July 17.--A dastardly and revolting attempt at fraud was perpetrated at Redding, five miles south of Mount Ayr, last night.

PORTLAND, Me., July 17.--In the Supreme Court, Law Term, to-day, in the case of Sergt. Dennis Kelly, who, when in charge of Fort Popham, fired at and mortally wounded young Smith, of Charlestown, Mass., the full bench gave a decision surrendering the prisoner to the United States authorities.
LONDON, July 17.--A dispatch to the Times from Assiout says that the remainder of the Turkish battalion at that place mutinied and were disarmed. Their ringleaders were sent to Cairo.

TITUSVILLE, Penn., July 18.--The Staley well, 300 feet southeast of Grace, was drilled into sand this morning and made 45 barrels in the first half-hour. At noon it was doing 70 barrels per hour, and this evening is doing 65 barrels strong, and has not been touched.

ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, July 18.-- Sergt. Long, of the Greely party, who was the first to respond to the welcome tone of the steam whistle of the steam launch, says that he and Sergt. Brainerd were the first to hear the sound, and they helped each other to crawl out ...
PANAMA, July 18, via Galveston.--There is much sickness in this city. In one hospital there are over a dozen cases of yellow fever and 100 cases of dysentery.
NEWBURYPORT, Mass., July 18.--A movement has been started here for a grand public reception to Lieut. Greely upon his arrival home.
PORT JERVIS, N.Y., July 18.--Emma Taylor, aged 10 years, daughter of Gilbert Taylor, is missing.

NEW-ORLEANS, July 18.--The Crescent City joins in the general sentiment, of thanksgiving at the return of Lieut. Greely from the scenes of his triumph and perils, as in a measure she claims him as her own.

W.B. Somerville, of the Western Union Telegraph Company, speaking by authority, for the management, said yesterday: "The pooling arrangement between the Baltimore and Ohio, Bankers and Merchants', and the Postal Telegraph Companies, will not affect the policy of this company so far as is now known. We believe that the new combination will hurt us less ...
AUGUSTA, Ga., July 18.--To-day at noon Sam Williams, the negro murderer, was hanged at Waynesboro, Ga. He ascended the scaffold cool and collected, and spoke a few words pleading self-defense.

KEARNEY, Neb., July 18.--Joseph Vance, aged 7 years, and his brother Roy, aged 10, were fatally burned here last night while lighting a fire. They used kerosene oil and the can exploded. The mother, who sent them to start the fire, is frantic.
BINGHAMTON, N.Y., July 18.--Considerable interest is now felt in the investigation at present going on here regarding the death of James Cutler, a patient in the State Insane Asylum in this city.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., July 18.--The people of this city were thrown into great excitement this evening by an explosion which shook the entire town. The explosion occurred at 8:30 o'clock, and was heard and felt at a distance of 10 miles.
CHARLESTON, S.C., July 18.--The murderers and ruffians have been active in South Carolina during the past week. John Gethers, a colored sailor, was murdered here last night on board a sloop.

CHARLESTON, S.C., July 18.--A special to the News and Courier from Cherow, S.C., says: "Information has just been received here that J. Hawley Douglass, who was generally thought to be the person who led the posse that killed Bogan Cash, was shot down to-day while at work in his field.

DETROIT, Mich., July 18.--Gen. Butler and his friends have claimed Michigan as one of their political strongholds. Major N.S. Boynton, Chairman of the Anti-Monopolist State Central Committee, was interviewed here to-day regarding Butler's plans and prospects.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., July 18.--In an interview to-day the Hon. R.P. Flower said the Democratic platform was all that could be desired, and with so admirable a ticket as Cleveland and Hendricks the Democracy ought to ...
BALTIMORE, July 18.--A meeting to ratify the nomination of Blaine and Logan was held this afternoon by the colored people at Irving Park, midway between Baltimore and Washington.
WASHINGTON, July 18.--The following circular letter, concerning letter carriers' leaves of absence, has been sent to Postmasters:
SOUTH BRISTOL, N.Y., July 18.--William H. Francis was convicted last month of murder in the second degree for the killing of Benson Hawkins in this place.
PITTSBURG, Penn., July 18.--Another break occurred in the river coal miners' strike yesterday by the resumption of Brown Co.'s pits with the old diggers.
SUAKIN, July 18.--A skirmish took place here to-day between the patrols and the rebels. The latter retreated with the loss of one man.
PITTSBURG, July 18.--A company has been formed for the purpose of building and operating a crematory on the outskirts of this city.

The premises at the southwestern corner of Greenwich and Warren streets are owned by Charles F. Mattlage, a produce dealer. The elevated railroad passes in front of them, and a station stands at the west side, partly in Greenwich-street and partly in Warren.

RICHMOND, Va., July 18.--Congressman john S. Wise, who is one of Mahone's most trusted lieutenants, has accepted an invitation from the Chairman of the Republican State Committee of Indiana to make some speeches for Blaine and Logan in that State during the present campaign. He will also make one or two speeches in Philadelphia in behalf the same candidates.

Patrick Hughes, who was found concealed on Thursday night in the one-story and attic shanty of his brother Charles, at No. 549 West Fortieth-street, was sent to the Smallpox Hospital on Blackwell's Island yesterday morning.
CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., July 18.--The meetings here are now in full operation. The School of Languages and the Teachers' Retreat are well attended.

TROY, N.Y., July 18.--News has just reached here of the capture, at Kansas City, of John, alias "Walk Off," Connors, and the necessary papers are now being made out for his transfer to this city. He is wanted here for murder.

MONTREAL, July 18.--A number of visiting bicyclists from Chicago, Detroit, and the West will arrive in this city on Sunday evening, and will be handsomely entertained by the Montreal Bicycle Club, who have arranged a programme for their reception.

LA GRANGE, Ga., July 18.--Troupe County has a bad lot of negroes, if the prevalence of heinous crimes can establish such a fact. Last week an assault upon a widow by Willis Hardin led to his summary execution by citizens who were never known before to countenance a violation of the law, yet they felt that the time had come for making an example.
J. Westlake and T.W. Powell, the representatives of the English holders of Erie Railway stock, visited the offices of the road yesterday and were received by President Jewett.

The friends of the missing Warner D. Hatch received no tidings of him yesterday, though active search was made in all possible directions. No person answering his description has been seen at Long Branch, nor can it be learned that he was in this city after 12:15 ...

BOSTON, July 18.--Charles E. Brown was examined before Commissioner Hallett to-day on a charge of passing counterfeit sovereigns, and was held in $3,000 for trial in the September term of the District Court.

Four witnesses appeared before Referee Robert Bonynge yesterday, and testified that the painting of Mrs. Milbank, for which her husband, Luther A. Milbank, refuses to pay Artist Abram A. Anderson $1,000, is a good picture of the lady.

MADRID, July 1.--Minister Foster, who reached here some time ago, returns with full instructions to complete the negotiation of a commercial treaty between Spain and the United States, and also one which will provide for the adjustment of the claims of the citizens of the respective countries.
The Boston Advertiser of yesterday says that Theodore Roosevelt is visiting Henry Cabot Lodge, and agrees with him in supporting Blaine.

A shaggy cur, with a froth-flecked coat and glaring eyes, ran down Rector-street toward the elevated railway station at about 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon, Snapping at persons on the sidewalk and creating a panic among pedestrians.
The expected strike of the bricklayers on Monday formed the theme of conversation yesterday at the Builders' Exchange.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 18.--An officer on board the United States ship Portsmouth, at Newport, yesterday, while showing his wife some new rifles, put into one of them a ball cartridge by mistake for a blank one, and snapped the weapon.
M. Pasteur's experiments with the virus of hydrophobia are going on with unbroken success.

The heads of the four families of assisted Hebrew immigrants who arrived last Tuesday on the steamship India, and were detained at Castle Garden, sent a communication yesterday to the Commissioners of Emigration asking to be allowed to join their friends here, who, they said, were willing and able to support them.

CHICAGO, July 18.--The leading produce markets were active to-day and again stronger, with a decided buying pressure from outside, the previous strength here having awakened the exterior speculative spirit after a rather long nap. The smallness of the present available supply was the key to the situation which all agreed upon, while differing in opinion as ...

WASHINGTON, July 18.--Lieut.-Gen. Sheridan, Acting Secretary of War, left Washington this morning for New-York on a tour of inspection of Madison Barracks and Forts Porter and Niagara, on the northern frontier. He expects to return to this city next week.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 18.--As was anticipated, the banking house of A. J.C.S. Harrison did not open its doors this morning. The bluff and nonchalant manner of Mr. J.C.S. Harrison yesterday and last night did not seem to stave off the inevitable.

LANCASTER, Penn., July 18.--Two eastbound freght trains on the Pennsylvania Road collided near Bainbridge this morning while rounding a curve. Twelve cars and an engine were completely wrecked, and both tracks were blocked for several hours.

CINCINNATI, July 18.--The Supreme Court Judges have all been requested in succession to preside at the Campbell disbarment trial, and they have all replied that they cannot make it convenient to do so.

MARSEILLES, July 18.--There have been 58 deaths here from cholera during the 24 hours ending at 9:50 to-night. Cholera has made its appearance at Arles, situated 44 miles from here. Three deaths from the disease have occurred there.

Officer C.E. Jellison, of Boston, whose papers for the requisition of Lewis B. Bishop or Lester Bishop, who shot himself at No. 58 Lexington-avenue on the 10th inst., are in proper form, found his prisoner under guard at his lodgings yesterday.

MONTREAL, July 18.--Cattle shippers here fearing the introduction of the foot and mouth disease through the importation of animals from the Western States, where the scourge is said to exist, have communicated with the authorities at Ottawa, asking that a rigid inspection of cattle be instituted at the international boundary.
NEWBURYPORT, Mass., July 18.--The Advisory Board of the Lasters' Union and E.P. Dodge have satisfactorily arranged matters, and the latter's lasters will return to work on Monday.
PETERSBURG, Va., July 18.--The Grand jurn has been engaged to-day in examining witnesses in reference to the affairs of the Planters and Mechanics' Bank, which made a deed of trust May 19.
LONDON, July 18.--The eldest daughter of Matthew Arnold is engaged to be married to Frederick Whitridge, a New-York lawyer.
COHOES, N.Y., July 18.--A man giving his name as William Campbell was arrested here this evening.
Thomas Donohue, aged about 29 years, son of Nicholas Donohue, of Union Corners, was killed by an express train on the New-Haven Railroad, between Pelhamville and Mount Vernon, at noon yesterday.
John F. Henry, President of the National Anti-Monopoly organization, called on Gen. Butler at the Fifth-Avenue Hotel yesterday. In talking to a reporter afterward he said:

MONTREAL, July 18.--The customs authorities have made a formal seizure of 10 Campbell printing presses now in use in Montreal printing offices and imported from New-York, for alleged market value in the United States.

The irregularities brought to light in the accounts of trusted employes of Arnold, Constable Co. by the investigation of the frauds of Cornelius O'Leary, formerly receiving clerk for the firm, are apparently of much greater proportions than at first rumored.

WASHINGTON, July 18.--Rear-Admiral Nichols, Acting Secretary of the Navy, and Gen. Hazen, Chief Sighal Officer, had a conference today at which it was concluded to suggest to Commander Schley that he bring the survivors of the Greely party from St. John's to Portland, Me., where they can remain until better prepared to stand the change of climate.
RICHMOND, Va., July 18.--All is not serene in the Republican camp in Virginia. The two Electoral tickets put up by the Mahone and Straightout wings are still in the field.

Peter McCullough, of No.639 Waterstreet, and Joseph Smith, of No.234 Divisionstreet, two small boys, aged respectively 11 and 10, stood in the Essex Market Police Court yesterday on a charge of burglary.
TORONTO, Ontario, July 18.--The Royal Commission resumed its session to-day. Mr. Lyon, member of the Provincial Parliament, was recalled.

The Texas Pacific Railroad Directors yesterday discussed the question of whether the interest on the Texas Rio bonds and on other divisional bonds, which falls due Aug. 1, shall be paid. Nothing was decided upon, but it is stated that only a part of this interest will be paid in cash.
LONDON, July 18.--The cricket match between the American eleven and the Surrey Gentlemen was resumed at the Oval to-day.
The Executive Committee of the Irving Hall Democracy last evening held its first meeting since the National Convention. Mr. Elliot Sandford presided.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 18.--No street cars were run to-day, as the aspect of the strike of the drivers did not change until 3 o'clock this afternoon, when Daniel W. Sharpe, Register Inspector of the Rochester City and Brighton Railroad Company, tendered his resignation, which ...

ATLANTA, Ga., July 18.--In Chauncey, M. Henry Fleetwood has developed a curious trait of insanity. Under the belief that the Lord will provide, he refuses to wear any clothes, and tears them to shreds when forced upon him. He imagines that he is heaven and that he must go unclothed, as that is the way the pictures represent the little angels to be.

DES MOINES, Iowa, July 18.--The Hon. John A. Kasson has tendered his resignation as Congressman from this district, taking effect July 14. His successor will be chosen at the November election. Mr. Kasson will sail for Germany about the middle of August.
BRATTLEBORO, Vt., July 18.--Johnny and Freddie, 10 and 13 years old, son and nephew of William Steers, were drowned in Whetstone Brook, where they were bathing, this noon.

MARLBOROUGH, N.Y., July 18.--Postmasters along the line of the West Shore Railroad between Weehawken and Albany were officially notified to-day that on and after Monday next additional facilities for sending and receiving mails will be afforded.

Among the visitors to the National Republican Committee, in Fifth-avenue, yesterday, were C.A. Logan, United States Minister to Chili, who has been home on leave of absence since April, but who will return to his post next week.
John T. Raymond has attended almost every performance given by Lulu Hurst at Wallack's in a vain effort to solve the mystery which permits the phenomenon to break umbrellas and lift chairs.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 18.--In the Court of Common Pleas, at Newport, to-day, William H. Shea, 22 years old, was convicted of the murder of Eugene Barker, a policeman of Newport, while resisting arrest on the 22d of April last. The case has been two days on trial. The defense was temporary insanity, induced by jealousy. Shea was sentenced to State prison for life.

MILLEDGEVILLE, Ga., July 18.--John Smith, a notorious negro theif, escaped from jail here. He at once went to the house of Nathan Morse, who had had him arrested. Not finding him in the house, Smith went in and took Morse's gun, and finding Mr. Morse in the field, shot him and then escaped. The wounded man will recover.

Judge Delehanty, of Long Island City, rendered his deeision yesterday morning in the case of the People against Patrick Ryan. Mr. Ryan was arrested for playing ball on Sunday on an inclosed ground in Long Island City, it being claimed that he had violated the Penal Code in regard to sports and public shows on Sundays.
CHICAGO, Ill., July 18.--The second day of the Chicago Driving Park races had a good attendance. The weather was warm but breezy and the track fast.

The Coney Island excursion boat Thomas P. Way was run into off Communipaw, last night, by the New-Jersey Central Railroad ferryboat Plainfield. A portion of the guard rail of the excursion boat was carried away, but the Plainfield way only slightly damaged. None of the passengers of either boat were injured.
This will be the fourth day of the midsummer meeting at Monmouth Park, and another excellent programme as offered for the amusement of the sport-loving community.

BRIGHTON BEACH, July 18.--The first race here to-day was for non-winners; one mile. Auction pools--Ligan, $100; Regret, $50; Ben Woolley, $30; Tony Foster, $20; the field, $40. Ligan won, Regret second, Ben Woolley third. Time--1:46. French pools paid $10 35.
BOSTON, July 18.--In the peculiar divorce suit of Miller against Miller, founded on the marriage laws of New-York, Judge Colburn, of the Supreme Court, to-day dismissed the libel.

Four years ago the National Broadway Bank, at Park-place, was very much annoyed by several counterfeits of their fifty-dollar bills, which were so good that they were received by several banks before the fraud was discovered.

The Commissioners of Palo Pinto County, Texas, have notified the New-York Police of the disappearance of the County Treasurer, George C. Lewis, who on the 2d inst. absconded with $6,000 of the county's money.

An impromptu but animated discussion of the issues of the political campaign was held in the rooms of the Young Men's Democratic Club in Brooklyn, last evening. The club got through with its routine business, and received the report of the committee that went to Chicago to urge the nomination of Grover Cleveland ...
PARIS, July 18.--It is officially announced that China has given France the first measure of satisfaction.

OTTAWA, Ontario, July 18.--The Mayor of Ogdensburg, N.Y., and Alderman George Hall, of that city, had an interview with the Commissioner of Customs yesterday, regarding the tonnage dues on Canadian vessels entering the United States, which the recent bill passed in Congress decided to remit.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 18.--Gov. Cleveland arrived at the State camp of instruction at noon to-day. He came from Albany, and was accompanied by two nieces, the Misses Hastings, and Adjutant-General Farnsworth, Paymaster-General Rich, and Col. Cassidy, of his ...
Steamship Richmond, Crossman, Newport News, , with mdse. and passengers to Old Dominion Steamship Co.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., July 18.--The widow of Capt. Matthew Webb, the English swimmer who lost his life a year ago in the foolhardy attempt to swim the Niagara River Rapids, has purchased of the Lockport Marble Company, in this city, a handsome granite monument eight feet in height, which will be placed in Oakwood Cemetery, Niagara Falls, over the remains of the Captain on Monday next.
NEW-ORLEANS, July 18.--George Drury, Collector of Internal Revenue for this State, today tendered his resignation to the President.
PITTSBURG, July 18.--Henry Bloom, a Baltimore and Ohio Express Company messenger, was arrested to-day charged with the robbery of a package containing $10,000.
RALEIGH, N.C., July 18.--Messrs. Duke Son, of Durham, N.C., are having a large well dug to be used in their tobacco factory.

RICHMOND, Texas, July 18.--As Hannah Burton, aged 12 years, was returning from school yesterday she was met by Web Hetten, an ex-convict, who assaulted her, after which he killed her and buried her body near John's Creek, eight miles from here.

CHICAGO, July 18.--There was a further and material decline in prices of shiping Cattle to-day. Notwithstanding a decrease in the receipts of more than 1,000 head the supply was far in excess of the demand, and trading was extremely slow at a decline from yesterday of 10c.@25c.
T.M. Stewart, a carpet cleaner at No. 326 Seventh-avenue, has recently suffered to a great extent from the ingenious devices of a man who has victimized a number of Stewart's customers.
A Cleveland and Hendricks Campaign Club was organized at Hempstead, Long Island, on Thursday night.
White dresses and white Knickerbocker suits were the favorite articles of wearing apparel yesterday afternoon on the New-Brighton (Staten Island) Cricket Grounds, and there were a great many of both.
Two skeletons, one of a man, the other of a woman, were found buried beneath the Ferry-street filling, Hoboken, yesterday morning.
CINCINNATI, July 18.--The time for paying the Scott liquor law tax of $100 on beer and saloons and $200 for places where stronger drinks are sold expired to-day.
The steamship Burgundia, which arrived from Marseilles last Tuesday, and was quarantined because she came from a port where cholera prevails, was allowed to come up to the city yesterday.

DES MOINES, Iowa, July 18.--The Commissioners appointed by the Governor under the law authorising the establishment of a new insane asylum reached a vote this morning, and selected Clarinda, Page County. The last Legislature appropriated $50,000, and the Commissioners adopted the plans of a Des Moines firm.

BOSTON, July 18.--The session of the National Association of General Baggage Agents closed to-day. The next meeting will be held at Baltimore on the third Wednesday in June, 1885.
GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., July 18--8 P.M.-- For the third time within a year the neighboring town of Cedar Springs is being swept by fire. The conflagration started this afternoon in a large lumber yard.

In the United States Circuit Court yesteraay Judge Wheeler handed down a decision setting aside the sale of 100,000 Chatham Railroad bonds, made by Hermann R. Baltzer and William G. Taaks, of this city, to Henry Louis Bischoffsheim, on London.

The Grand Jury yesterday indicted William C. Rhinelander for assault in the first degree, in shooting Lawyer John Drake in the shoulder on June 19, at his office, No. 79 Cedarstreet. There are two counts in the indictment. Rhinelander will be arraigned for pleading on Monday in the Court of General Sessions.

GENTLEMEN: In accepting the nomination for the Presidency tendered me by the Republican National Convention I beg to express a deep sense of the honor which is conferred and of the duty which is imposed. The German Blaine and Logan Central Campaign Club met last evening at No. 385 Bowery, where a large transparency, bearing the portraits of the candidates and the words "Protection of American Labor," was placed over the windows of the building.
TORONTO, Ontario, July 18.--The village of Alliston was visited to-day by a large fire, which has destroyed the largest factory in the place.

Judge Van Brunt yesterday appointed the Mercantile Trust Company, in the place of James D. Fish, as Trustee of the rolling stock sold to the Toledo and Indianapolis Railway Company in May, 1883, by McKee, Fuller, and others.
NORWICH, July 18.--The third annual meeting of the National Croguet Association is to be held in this city to-morrow.
TORONTO, Ontario, July 18.--An important step was taken to-day by the Directors of the Northern and Northwest Railway, who let the contract to construct and rail the new extension to the north.

Gen. Logan will leave here on Saturday night with the Grand Army delegates from the Department of the Potomac to the national encampment, which meets at Minneapolis on Wednesday next.

ALBANY, July 18.--Ex-Senator William H. Barnum arrived on an early train this morning, and directly after breakfast had a conference with Mr. Daniel Manning in reference to the management of the Democratic campaign.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 18.--A diver has examined the sunken schooner off Corson's Inlet, New-Jersey, and finds her to be the Deborah H. Diverty, to Albany from Richmond, with coal.

LONDON, July 18.--The Manchester Guardian says: "Business is small and prices are low. The market is fairly active."
MONTREAL, July 18.--To-morrow the Montreal Lacrosse Club will play the Toronto team who recently defeated the Americans in New-York for the championship of the world.
The question of who was the first person to volunteer for active service in the war of the rebellion has been recently discussed.

TROY, N.Y., July 18.--This was College Day at Round Lake. The Rev. Dr. Henry Darling, President of Hamilton College, delivered an address on "Should the Education the American College Gives be Wholly Religious?" he taking the affirmative. The Rev. Dr. Sims, Chancellor of the Syracuse University, read an address on "The Church of the Future as an Educator."
The fast 2-year-old filly Cricket will run to-day in the colors of Appleby Johnson, that firm of bookmakers having purchased her yesterday from Mr. Pierre Lorillard for $2,000.
DETROIT, July 18.--Potter, Beattie Co., general merchandise and lumber, of Ovid, made an assignment to-day. The firm was a large one. This is the third failure there within two days.
EASTMAN, Ga., July 18.--In Montgomery County, two months ago, William Browning, a substantial citizen, 80 years of age, married his second wife.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 18.--The Homewood trotting meeting closed to-day. The weather was clear and pleasant, the attendance very large, and the track in fine condition. The racing was exciting, but not remarkable. Following are the summaries:
