CORTLAND, N.Y., July 23.--During the afternoon performance of the Barnum, Bailey Hutchinson Circus to-day, a cyclone struck the main tent and destroyed it in less than three minutes.

WASHINGTON, July 23.--The Star says: "Representative Converse, of Ohio, will not be a candidate for renomination. He told a reporter last evening that his family demands his attention, and he has decided to retire from public life. He has already written to decline the nomination. As yet there is no prominent candidate for his place."

WASHINGTON, July 23, 1884. The Treasury Department has decided that the provisions of the Dingley Shipping bill prescribing the duties of Shipping Commissioners do not apply in the case of vessels of less than 50 tons burden engaged in the coasting trade.

Mr. Trelvar, who has charge of the correspondence department of the Custom House at this port, is supposed to possess a very accurate knowledge of the routine business of this branch of the Government's service.
Roundsman Griffin, of the Nineteenth Precinct, noticed a young man poorly dressed trying the doors of St. Patrick's Cathedral, at Fifth-avenue and Fiftieth-street, at 2 o'clock yesterday morning.

EASTON, Penn., July 23.--Henry Bachman was arrested here to-day for adultery on complaint of his wife, who lives at Wilkesbarre. Mrs. Marietta Hoch, a widow, went his bail, and later both departed for Binghamton, N.Y.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July, 23.--An accident which narrowly escaped being attended with lamentable consequences, occurred to-day at Gorman's Station, on the Nashville, Chattanooga and St. Louis Railway, by a passenger train dashing into an improperly locked switch. The engine, baggage car, and one coach were derailed and almost demolished. George Warren, the porter, was injured, and conductor House was bruised.

CAIRO, July 23.--The Mudir of Dongola telegraphs that he has defeated 5,000 of the followers of the Mahdi, near Debbeh, and captured 300 Remington rifles. The rebel losses were very heavy.

The last Legislature authorized the issue of $2,000,000 in city bonds to purchase sites and erect buildings for public schools in this city. President Walker thought that $1,000,000 was enough for the present, and yesterday the Board of Estimate and Apportionment directed the Controller to issue bonds to that amount, bearing not more than 3 per cent. interest, and payable in 20 years or less.

Barnard, discoverer of comet "B," furnishes the following position of the comet on July 20: Right ascension, 15 hours, 57 minutes and 46 seconds; south declination, 37 , 11', 14'"; daily motion in right ascension, 1 minute and 46 seconds; daily motion in declination, 20' of arc, a very slow motion. The comet is larger now, and has a small nucleus.

The Misses Kate and Teresa Bennett have a swimming school at Fort Hamilton this season. A long pier runs out to the spot where the building is moored, just above the fort. This was thronged yesterday afternoon, the gathering being made up for the most part of ladies.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 23.--An Italian railroad laborer named J. Divichey jumped from a moving train with his back to the locomotive, at Deal Beach, this morning. He was thrown under the cars and completely cut to pieces.

A wind sprang up suddenly from the southwest about dusk yesterday and whirled clouds of dust through the streets, blinding the eyes and filling the ears of the unwary people who were caught out of doors.

BLOOMSBURG, N.J., July 23.--All of those poisoned at the Robins tea party are better, except Miss Augusta Robins and Miss Bessie Fulmer, both of whom are worse and extremely low. They have had relapses and may not recover. None of the patients are able to leave their rooms.

The Campaign Committee appointed at the last meeting of the Young Men's Democratic Club met yesterday afternoon at the office of John F. McIntyre, No. 170 Broadway, to organize.

HACKENSACK, N.J., July 23.--The call was issued to-day at Paterson for the holding of the Democratic Nominating Convention for this Congressional District at Morristown, on Aug. 13. This is about a month earlier than usual, and two reasons are given in explanation.

BAR HARBOR, Me., July 23.--From Baffin's Bay to Panama, according to an extremely well informed American, this is the only little strip of the coast where the mountains dip into the sea.

HAVANA, July 23.--The Gaceta publishes to-day a decree dated Madrid, June 5, providing for a uniform export duty on sugars. Henceforth clayed, centrifugals and refined sugars will pay a duty of $1 per 100 kilogrammes, and muscovadoes, molasses, and meladoes, 88 cents per 100 kilogrammes.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., July 23.--The grand parade of the Grand Army of the Republic was delayed in forming, but when in motion the veterans were received with tremendous cheers by 60,000 people who thronged every street on the line of march.

SANTIAGO DE CHILI, July 23.--via Galveston.--The last session of the Chamber of Deputies was occupied by Minister Balmaceda's speech on the separation of the Church and State. He spoke in favor of secularization and civil law, but considered that the time had now arrived to place the church in the condition of a simple private institution. He feared that the influence of the church on society would always be stronger than State authority.

BOSTON, July 23.--Private advices received in this city state that the bark Rambler, Capt. King, from Iloilo for Boston, has been lost at sea. She was owned by Edward Lawrenco, of Boston, and was partly insured here.

SCRANTON, Penn., July 23.--The announcement that there would be no stoppage of work at the coal mines during the month of August has been received here with great satisfaction, and a general revival of business throughout the anthracite region is looked for.

WASHINGTON, July 23.--A court of inquiry under the presidency of Major James Biddle was organized a few weeks ago at the request of Capt. Emmet Crawford, of the Third Cavalry, for the purpose of investigating the latter's management of the San Carlos Indian Agency, complaints of which had been made by Indian Agent Wilcox.

JACKSON, La., July 23.--An engineer named Amos was shot and killed by Everett Stratten, a fireman on the same engine. Stratten claims to have acted in self-defense.

CHICAGO, July 23.--The legal fight over the estate of Wilbur F. Storey, proprietor of the Chicago Times, grows more complicated every day, and a small army of lawyers are getting their fingers into the pie.

CINCINNATI, July 23.--William Wilson Haner, the inventor of the Haner bombs, who has a small factory at No. 615 Main-street, Covington, recently received an order for 3,000 of his bombs charged with dynamite.

The General Committee of the Twentythird Assembly District County Democracy held its first meeting since the nomination of Cleveland and Hendricks, at the headquarters, No. 2,114 Third-avenue, last evening.

DENVER, Col., July 23.--A work trian, with 40 bridge hands, was passing through Black Canon, west of Gunnison, this morning, when a spark from the engine ignited a box containing giant powder. A terrific explosion followed, killing John Lynch, John Morris, and J. Wolsen, bridge hands, and wounding a number of others. The cars and engine were badly wrecked.
CINCINNATI, July 23.--The District Court decided a case to-day favorable to four Cincinnati banks, in which the County Treasurer had sued for an aggregate of $120,000 in back taxes.

NORRISTOWN, Penn., July 23.--A large part of the body of the murderer John May, which was stolen from the grave some time ago, was found in a thicket near the Potter's Field to-day.

MARSEILLES, July 23.--In the 24 hours ending at 9 P.M. to-day, there have been 44 deaths from cholera.

SARATOGA, N.Y., July 23.--Miss Marion Foster, the artist, boards at the Healey cottage. Early this morning two burglars climbed into a window in her room. Miss Foster fired twice at the intruders, wounding one of them. They then jumped from the window. Miss Foster is an invalid, and is now critically ill, having fainted immediately after the shooting through fear that she had killed the man.

The Executive Committee of the independent Republicans met at headquarters, No. 35 Nassau-street, yesterday, and announced the organization of the National Committee appointed at Tuesday's general conference.

During the past year the aggregate of beer produced in Germany was 39,250,000 hectolitres, valued at 700,000,000 marks, a sum which represents in the retail trade the enormous total of 1,500,000,000 marks. The export of German beer to foreign countries has increased very heavily in late years.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., July 23.--The five days' national temperance camp meeting held under the auspices of the National Temperance Society and Publication House, commenced here to-day.
HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, July 23.--The Nova Scotia 5 per cent. loan of $400,000 has been allotted to Charles Armand, of this city, who represents an English house. The premium is 8 per cent.

SARATOGA, N.Y., July 23.--The second extra day had a light attendance. The track was very heavy. The second and third races were run in a heavy thunder and rain storm.

Washburne, of this city, the dedication of the Washburne Memorial Library at the Norlands, in Livermore, Me., which has been fixed for Aug. 27, has been postponed until next year.

DAWSON, Ga., July 23.--George Clark, a young negro in the employment of Mr. Jennings, made an assault on Mrs. Jennings while her husband was away. The lady successfully defeated his purpose and her cries brought to her rescue a trustworthy servant. Clark effected his escape, but was subsequently arrested by the Sheriff and as now in jail. Much excitement prevails.

ROCHESTER, July 24.--The Monroe County branch of the Irish National League held its annual picnic at Maple Grove this afternoon and evening. This evening John Devoy, of NewYork, and Alexander Sullivan, of Chicago, President of the Irish National League of America, addressed a large audience.

PHILADELPHIA, July 24.--The new iron steamer, EL Paso, the second now being built for the Morgan Steamship Company, of New-York, was successfully launched this afternoon from the shipyard of William Cramp Sons. The christening was done by Miss Alice White, daughter of M.M. White, a well-known banker of Cincinnati. This steamer when completed will run between New-York and New-Orleans. The contracts now at Cramps' yard for the Morgan Line amount to $1,500,000.

MILWAUKEE, July 24.--A tidal wave was felt to-day in the Menominee and Milwaukee Rivers. It was most noticeable at the "straight cut," as the entrance to the river is called, where the waters receded three feet, returning again in about 15 minutes. Above the dam in the Milwaukee River, two or three miles from the straight cut, swimmers who were standing in shallow water were completely submerged by the returning waters.

KEY EAST, N.J., July 24.--This was children's day at the Seaside Sunday School Assembly. The usual children's hour was led by Mrs. S.W. Clark and Miss Emily A. Rice.
Gen. Neal Dow has written the following letter to the Rev. C. Clark, Jr., editor of a NewJersey prohibition paper:

A new steamboat, built for the Providence and Stonington Steamship Company, was launched at Noank. Conn., yesterday, in the presence of a large number of spectators. The new boat slid into the water without a hitch and floated as gracefully as a duck. Her name is the Nashua, and she is designed for traffic on the Sound.
DENVER, Col., July 24.--Durango is greatly excited to-day over the arrival of Red Jacket with 40 warriors, highly painted and heavily armed.

NEW-ORLEANS, July 24.--The community has settled down to the belief that some zealous physicians were in too great haste in declaring that we had a genuine case of yellow fever, and that it was only a case of what is known as "hemorrhage malaria."

BOSTON, Mass., July 24.--A meeting of the creditors of Whittemore, Cabot Co., dry goods dealers, was held to-day. C.C. Billings, on behalf of the investigating committee, reported that the books had been examined, and that the liabilities were found to be $382,513, of which $22,000 is secured.

BERNE, July 24.--All meeting of the Salvation Army here have been prohibited. DUBLIN, July 24.--MR. Tuke's committtee has decided to cease operations for the present. LONDON, July 24.--At the Wimbledon rifle contest to-day the Elcho Shield was won by the Irish team. Its score was 1,583. The score of the Scotch team was 1,476; that of the English team 1,474.

ALBANY, July 24.--Several thousand people turned out this evening to welcome ex-Mayor John Swinburne on his return from the West, whither he went after the late municipal election to recuperate his health.
The threatening appearance of the sky last evening was not enough to overbalance the effects of a warm and sultry day, and people went to Coney Island in droves.

PHILADELPHIA, July 24.--The Athletics lost another game to the Metropolitans, of NewYork, to-day, by a score of 13 to 5. The crowd numbered over 3,000.

BOSTON, July 24.--The case of the will of Stephen Woodman, of Amesbury, which has been before the Probate Court of Essex County, contested by some of the heirs on the ground of the testator's insanity, was concluded to-day, the court admitting the will to probate.
The stock market took an upward turn yesterday which astonished both the "bears" and the "bulls" and filled the hearts of the lastnamed animals with joy.

An unsuccessful attempt was made last evening to arrest Mrs. Mary J. Burtis, the wife of Al Burtis, the Coney Island pool seller. Two men called at her residence, No. 107 West Fortieth-street, and asked to see her on urgent business. Mrs. Burtis was out, and her sister responded to the summons.

NORWICH, Conn., July 24.--Mrs. Wilcox, of Norwichtown, the aged mother of Postmaster Wilcox, of this village, passed her ninety-ninth birthday last Saturday. She expresses the wish that she might live one year longer at least, which would complete the century.

The storm was quite severe, and dam aged crops to a considerable extent.

The Prohibitionists of the Thirty-third Congressional District have nominated Mr. Edward Evans, of Tonawanda, as their candidate for Congress. And now, if the Republicans could be persuaded to indorse that nomination, the good people of the Thirty-third District would be represented in the House by an able, active, and conscientious man, whose political opinions have always been in harmony with the best thought and aspirations of their party.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., July 24.--An eccentric person called "The Count," known in certain circles in all the larger cities of the country, is under arrest at Waukesha. The charge against him is swindling a bank in Stockholm, Sweden, out of a large sum of money.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 24.--Ex-Chief of Police Yates was to-day informed of the murder of his nephew, John McMurray, living at Harris Station, Osborn County. McMurray was stabbed to the heart by an employe, who fled, but was pursued by a posse, who threaten swift retribution should the murderer be captured.

Callers yesterday at Republican headquarters were quite as numerous as usual but nearly all of them dropped in for information, of which there was a scarcity in the committee beyond the habitual assurances that the outlook was encouraging.

ALBANY, July 24.--Gov. Cleveland has received a communication from Gen. D. D. Wylie, Chief of Ordnance, asking for a court of inquiry to examine the charges against the management of his department, preferred by the special Assembly committee which investigated the arsenal frauds.
WASHINGTON, July 24, 1884. The President has postponed the time of his departure for New-York until Saturday.

SARATOGA, N.Y., July 24.--The morning was bright and clear and as a result there was a larger attendance at the race track here to-day than there has been on any previous day of the meeting.

RICHMOND, Texas, July 18.--Matt Ware, an old Texan and a life-long Republican, has announced himself as a candidate for Congress in this district. Mr. Ware has resided on the Rio Grande, speaks the Spanish language fluently, and is solid with the frontiersmen.

COLUMBUS, July 24.--The Democratic State Executive Committee, as organized under the McLean regime, met here to-day for the purpose of consultation and to decide upon the work of the campaign. BARBOURSVILLE, West Va., July 27.--There is great excitement among the mountaineers living in the eastern part of Wayne County over the alleged appearance of the ghost of Harvey Fairman, a farmer, who mysteriously diappeared in 1879.

ATLANTA, Ga., July 27.--There is something pathetic about Gen. Longstreet as he passes along the street, out of position, poor, thrown overboard by his party friends, and avoided by those who cannot help feeling a sympathy with the historic figure, whose bulldog tenacity made him one of the most feared of Confederate Generals during the late war.

Joseph Brown, of Glens Falls, N.Y., and a delegate from that place to the last National Republican Convention, walked into Justice Rusch's office, in Hoboken, Saturday night, and asked for the arrest of his wife.

WASHINGTON, July 27.--Secretary Frelinghuysen has received intelligence from the city of Mexico to the effect that, in compliance with the request of the United States Government, the two Americans, William Harwood and Edward Velach, who were recently arrested there upon the charge of defaming the President of Mexico, have been released.
ALBANY, July 27.--Twelve comrades and several converts of the Salvation Army opened a campaign in Albany to-day. They held four meetings, which were all attended by large crowds.

PORTLAND, Oregon, July 27.--Yesterday the mutilated body of Fee Gung, a well known Chinese merchant of Olympia, Washington Territory, was found in the timber near that place.

"Turtle baiting" has become a popular pastime among Staten Island sporting men. On Saturday evening nearly 200 persons assembled in a large and unoccupied house near Clifton, Staten Island, to witness a "baiting" between the two largest turtles that have yet been pitted against one another.

From the St. Paul (Minn.) Pioneer Press, July 24. The Catholic cathedral is elaborately decorated with a large portico of colored bunting trimmed with evergreen crosses and wreaths around the main entrance. The interior of the cathedral is festooned with flowers and wreaths, and displays a very tasteful appearance.
BOSTON, Mass., July 27.--The Chicago Bicycle Club were taken to Nantasket Beach today as the guests of the Ramblers' Bicycle Club, of Boston, and were entertained at a banquet.

ALBANY, July 26.--Following is an installment of eight of the official semi-annual reports of the savings banks transacting business in the city of New-York, as made to the Superintendent of the Banking Department, showing their condition on the morning of July 1, before the transactions of that day.

MIDDLETON, N. Y., July 27.--An instance of extraordinary animal instinct and intelligence is reported from Ellenville, Ulster County. Mrs. Sarah Brown, of that village, has a large Maltese cat which is the mother of three kittens, now nearly half grown.
Significant remark of the London Times: "With Wagner dramatic music practically died in that country [Germany] and, to judge by historic precedent, is not likely to revive again for years to come."

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 27.--Mrs. Deville, an aged widow who resided alone in Henderson County, was found dead to-day near her cabin. Part of her face and breast had been eaten by hogs. It is reporter that her daughter and her husband are in custody on the charge of having killed her for her money.

MARSEILLES, July 27.--There have been 36 deaths here from cholera during the past 24 hours.

BALTIMORE, July 27.--Irving J. Mills, a prominent young man of Pocomoke City, Somerset County, Md., yesterday shot and killed Thomas J. Davis, the father of the young lady to whom he had been paying attentions. Mrs. Mary N. Ross, the daughter of her lover's victim, is a handsome widow, 24 years of age. Her husband died two years ago.

BLOOMSBURY, N.J., July 27.--It is probable that all those poisoned at Miss Robin's tea party a week ago will recover, though five are still very sick. Mrs. Susan Cleveland, who partook of the chicken sent her after the supper, died yesterday. There is no longer any doubt that the fowl was afflicted with chicken cholera.

In a quarrel last night at Mott and Grand streets Bartholomew Grandioso, of Newark, N. J., received a severe stab wound in the back at the hands of a strange Italian who fled. Grandioso was taken to St. Vincent's Hospital.

FORT SMITH, Ark., July 27.--A shooting affray occurred at a dance at Deep Fork, in the Creek Nation, last Wednesday morning at daylight, in which Samuel Haines and Samuel Suchie, two Indians, were mortally wounded by John Tiger, also of the Creek Nation. Tiger escaped.

Two years ago Valentine Strehl opened a butcher's shop on the corner of Flushing-avenue and Woolsey-street, Astoria. He was the only butcher in the neighborhood at the time and made money fast.

The audience at the Casino last evening although not exactly numerous, was surprisingly large if the state of the weather is taken into consideration. The concert was given, of course, in the restaurant.

A huge tidal wave was reported yesterday to the City Engineer and Board of Public Works as having occurred the previous afternoon in the lake. The effects were felt a long distance up the Menomonee and Milwaukee Rivers.

The Central Labor Union held its usual Sunday afternoon meeting yesterday. The proceedings were taken up almost entirely with receiving and discussing the reports from the various trades unions.
LONDON, July 27.--The French Government will accept the provisional budget for the government of Egypt for two years upon the basis of a modification of the law of liquidation.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., July 27.--Sheriff Fowler returned here to-night without Jesse Plater, for whom he went to Washington on Friday with a requisition from the Governor of Maryland charging Plater with abducting an insane woman.

WEST POINT, Ga., July 27.--"Poor Betts," said an old citizen this morning, as he read the brief telegram from Washington announcing the death of William H. Betts in that city. "Poor Betts! He is better off now, and he was a mighty good shot in his day."

NASHVILLE, Penn., July 27.--Green Crews, of Marlboro, Carroll County, was killed to-day by his stepson, whom he attacked with a knife for beating a mule. After the boy had been cut by Crews he drew a knife and cut his stepfather's throat from ear to ear.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 27.--Whatever effect the Scott liquor tax law may have on the Fall elections, it certainly is keeping the Ohio courts busy and ranging the saloon keepers and County Treasurers against each other in legal array.

Recently charges have been made against the Rev. William Jackson, Pastor of the Bethany Colored Baptist Church, Newark, N.J., for misappropriation of funds. He promised to make an explanation in his sermon yesterday morning, but failed to do so. In closing his services last night, however, he tendered his resignation as Pastor of the church.

NEW-YORK, July 26.--Your correspondent has been informed on what he considers reliable authority that the Tammany Electors on the Democratic State ticket are about to tender their resignation to Mr. Manning, Chairman of the Democratic State Committee.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 27.--The first electric railroad for public use in America went into operation in this city yesterday in connection with the East Cleveland Street Railroad Company, which has just completed a mile road.

August Becker, of Elizabeth, to-day deeded his property to Jo Daviess County. The circumstances are rather unusual. His wife died last Fall, and her loss weighed so heavily upon him that he neglected his business and became quite moody and depressed at times.

NEWARK, July 27.--The front doors of all the saloons in East Newark were closed today, and a few of them were closed both front and rear. No beer was sold in pails or pitchers, nor was there any billiard or card playing. The informers under Father O'Connor who started the war on the saloons were active and took the name of every proprietor the back door of whose saloon was open.

Henry A. Elkins, the well-known Chicago artist, died at Georgetown, Col., yesterday, of mountain fever. He had gone to Colorado from Kansas City, where he had been living for a time, intending to take his family with him and proceed to California, and thence to Mexico.

RUATAN, Spanish Honduras, July 6.--The general impression of those who have never been there is that Central America is a very hot and unhealthy country. The truth is, it is not nearly as hot as one would expect.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 27.--Three men drove from Wooster in a two-wheeled cart last night to the residence of Christian Fair, in Plain Township.

We are gratified to learn that our old friend, Gen. A.M. West, declines to work in the same harness with Ben Butler, and has not accepted the Greenback nomination for Vice-President. We have no doubt he will cast his vote and influence for Cleveland and Hendricks.

ASHLAND, Penn., July 27.--John Stanton, an employe at the Bast Colliery, was instantly killed last night while being hoisted up the slope. His body caught under the timbers above and he was crushed to death.

There are so-called courts in the District of Columbia, and the national Department of Justice occupies a large and imposing building there. There are Judges in the District. Grand Juries sit and accused persons are occasionally indicted.

The principal fruit to come into the market this week are peaches, and they will be more abundant and better than at any time before this season. The greater part of the supply will be Hales Early, and they are this season somewhat better in quality than ordinary, and those to come this week are mostly those allowed by the grower to remain on the trees until nearly matured.

TOWANDA, Penn., July 27.--For years J. Van Rensselaer Hagadorn, who from his great strength and the fact of his having only one finger on his right hand is called the "onefingered Samson," has been the terror of the border counties of this part of Pennsylvania.

In a few days the elevated railroad companies will hold meetings for the purpose of finally consolidating their interests by the formation of a new corporation which shall embrace all of the existing organizations.

Patrick Cronin took a steerage passage on the White Star steamer Britannic at Queenstown on July 17. He appeared melancholy after the vessel had been out two or three days, and last Thursday he cut his throat, dying in a few minutes.
A passenger train rolled into the Pennsylvania Railroad station last evening with several carloads of passengers. Several cars stood in the station on the track.

One day in October I received an anonymous telegram, surreptitiously passed out from the jail at Tantah, to the effect that 75 persons were wrongly there confined, were being tortured to death, and that two had already died. I at once sent Dr. Crookshank, who then had not taken charge of the jails, to examine every prisoner in the jail and report.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., July 27.--A storm yesterday in Eau Claire County damaged crops and buildings to the extent of $20,000. Hailstones fell which are alleged to have been 6 and 3 inches in diameter.
PARIS, July 14.--Little is said nowadays about the two Mahdis--the Dongolawi and the Briton, Gen. Gordon--whose relative situations so engrossed public attention a few weeks ago.

PHILADELPHIA, July 27.--A special dispatch to the Press from York, Penn., says Mrs. Adam Miller was shot through the body last night while sitting at a window of her father's residence, about five miles from York, holding her sick infant on her lap.

WASHINGTON, July 27.--The extension of leave of absence on account of sickness granted Post Chaplain Sherman M. Merrill Feb. 2, 1884, has been still further extended two months on account of sickness. Leave of absence for three months, to take effect soon after Aug. 1, 1884, has been granted Major Charles A. Reynolds, Quartermaster, United States Army.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 27.--For some time a strange wild animal has been heard in a swamp in Summit County, and glimpses of it have been had by children and others, who were unable to classify it. Great excitement and terror has prevailed. Yesterday 300 men, armed with guns, surrounded the swamp, but failed to find anything. It is supposed to be a panther.

The west bank of the Harlem River at Two Hundred and Fourteenth-street is known as the "Sandbank," from the firm, sandy formation of the soil. Here is one of the best bathing places on the river, though very dangerous for those not familiar with the ground.

In Sullivan-street, between Third and Bleecker streets, yesterday morning, Officer Louis Tancredi, of the Fifteenth Precinct, found James McGrath, a longshoreman, of No. 83 Seventhstreet, drunk and lying in the gutter. Tancredi aroused him by tapping the soles of his boots with his club. McGrath was angry at being roused and was very profane.

The Manhattan Temperance Association held a meeting last evening in the Alanson Methodist Episcopal Church, on Norfolk-street. The funeral of Peter S. Porter, the wellknown colored abolitionist, of this city, took place yesterday in Union Church, on West Fifteenth-street, of which he had been a member for 40 years.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., July 28.--A special to the Journal from Stillwater, this State, says: "Mrs. Alice Walker and C.H. St. Clair have been arrested for arson. The woman confesses that she burned the Judd residence at the institation of St. Clair, who had a fancied grievance."

HAVANA, July 28.--At Matanzas, Saturday night, fire destroyed the lumber yard of Senor Zabala. The loss is estimated at $100,000; uninsured. The fire continued to burn for 15 hours. The absolute want of a first-class fire department was demonstrated.

NORFOLK, Va., July 28.--News has reached this city of a terrible storm which struck the litele town of Edenton, N.C., on Saturday night. The path of the storm was only 200 yards wide, but it carried destruction before it. Several warehouses and storehouses were either blown down or unroofed, and a church was unroofed while the congregation of colored people were worshipping there, killing two little children. The damage to property is estimated at $40,000.

BOSTON, July 28.--Arrangements for the collar-and-elbow wrestling contest between Col. J.H. McLaughlin, of Detroit, and H.M. Dufur, of Marlboro, for the championship belt of the world and $250 a side have been completed. The match takes place, rain or shine, on the Union Athletic Grounds, on Huntington-avenue, on Wednesday evening next at 8:30 o'clock, and will be wrestled to a finish. James Boyle O'Reilly, editor of the Pilot, will officiate as refered.

MOBILE, Ala., July 28.--Col. J.S. Murply, a prominent citizen and President of the Mobile Life Insurance Company, was shot and killed last night by Reuben Tripp near his residence in the lower part of the county. The suspension of De Wolf Swan, brokers, at No. 30 Broad-street, was announced in the Stock Exchange at about 2:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon. The transactions of the firm were not large, and the effect of the failure would have been slight had it not been for the allegations of forgery which accompanied the explanations of its cause.

KANSAS CITY, July 28.--A dispatch to the Times from Dodge City, Kan., says: "A cyclone visited Cimarron Station, 18 miles west of here, at 10 o'clock last night, demolishing about a dozen houses. Mrs. Barton and her child were seriously hurt. Several other persons also received painful injuries. The wind reached a velocity of 87 miles an hour."
PORTLAND, Me., July 28.--The steamer Eleonora, from New-York, reports that the automatic buoy northeast one-quarter north of the Pollock Rip Lightship has been gone from its moorings 10 days or more.

UTICA, N.Y., July 28.--Pomeroy Jones, the oldest native resident of Oneida County, died to-day on the farm at Lairdsville, where he was born Dec. 30, 1789, and where he had lived the whole of his life. He served in the war of 1812, was a member of Assembly, and had filled local offices. He was a cold-water man, but a habitual smoker for many years.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 28.--The American Worsted Company, of Woonsocket, has given notice of a 10 per cent. reduction of wages, to go into effect Aug. 1. The company employs 250 hands.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 28.--At 7 o'clock this morning a freight engine attached to a train of cars that was just about to be pulled out blew up with tremendous force.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 28.--The first test of telephoning over a long distance was successfully accomplished to-night. The experiment was made in this city by the United States Telephone Company.

TROY, N.Y., July 28.--In order to frighten off some boys found in his orchard yesterday Daniel Rooney, the Superintendent of St. Joseph's Cemetery, discharged a shotgun in the air. NYACK, N.Y., July 28.--The trial of the liquor cases brought by the Nyack Law and Order Society was begun to-day, and excited much interest. The whole day was occupied in getting a jury. There will probably be a long trial.

They encountered the home team again yesterday, and detailed their strong pitcher, Buffinton, to keep down the hits of the New-Yorkers.

CHICAGO, July 28.--A number of delegates to the Chicago Labor Convention, called to meet here next Wednesday, have already arrived in the city. The delegates represent various trades assemblies. The convention is called for the better organization of labor, in order to compel favorable legislation. The delegates declare that no action of a political character will be taken.

BOSTON, July 28.--The charge upon which ex-Gov. Moses, of South Carolina, was yesterday arrested in Chicago, on a requisition from Gov. Robinson, of this State, is obtaining money under false pretenses.
LONDON, July 28.--The Egyptian conference met to-day at the Foreign Office at 1 o'clock. It remained in session three hours and a half. It then adjourned, to reassemble for a short meeting to-morrow.

BOONTON, N.J., July 28.--The funeral services of the late Hon. John Hill were held in the Presbyterian church at 3 o'clock this afternoon. There were fully 1,000 persons in the building, and as many more outside who were unable to gain admittance. The interior of the church was heavily draped in mourning.

VICKSBURG, Miss., July 28.--To-night a large meeting of Democrats was held at Klein's Hall, and a Cleveland and Hendricks Club was organized with a membership of several hundred. NEW-ORLEANS, La., July 28.--A special to the Times-Democrat from Columbus, Miss., says: "Three inches of rain fell here to-day from 4 A.M. to noon. The Tombigbee River has risen $10 feet."

RICHMOND, Va., July 28.--After long consultation with leading members of his party and eminent counsel Gov. Cameron this afternoon announced his determination to yield to the demands of two-thirds of the members of each branch of the Legislature for an extra session of that body.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 28.--Mrs. Lieut, A.W. Greely, wife of the arctic explorer, passed through this city this evening, en route to Portsmouth, N.H., to meet her husband upon his arrival there ...

NEW-LONDON, Conn., July 28.--Th Atlantic Yacht Club squadron arrived at New-London this evening at about 6 o'clock, the Grayling being the first to make the harbor. The squadron is now anchored off the Pequot House. The weather is remarkably fine, and a light southwest breeze is blowing.
READING, Penn., July 28.--This city is gayly decorated in honor of a great Saengerfest which opens here to-morrow and will continue three days.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., July 28.--A special to the Picayune from Plaquemine, La., says: "While two colored men were wrestling yesterday at Dorseyville the smaller of the two, Moses Washington, was thrown violently to the ground and instantly killed, his neck being broken."

RICHMOND, Va., July 28.--The colored people of this city are somewhat stirred up over a denunciation by members of their race of the Rev. W.B. Derrick, lately one of the Blaine Electors for New-York. The colored Blaine and Logan Club of this city passed resolutions denouncing the Rev. Mr. Derrick as unworthy of support, and the Grand Lodge of Colored Good Templars of the State passed a resolution expelling him.

ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, July 28.-- Yesterday a serious accident occurred in St. Pierre Harbor. A steamboat, owned by the Cobissol Company, while lying at her wharf, burst her boiler, killing the fireman and shattering the steamer to pieces. Portions of the wreck were thrown 600 yards.
NEW-ORLEANS, July 28.--A man named Cunningham, about 26 years old, bought a ticket Saturday at the Louisville and Nashville Railroad office for Montreal.

CAIRO, July 28.--An Arab trader, who has arrived at Assouan from Amarar, which place he left on July 20, says it was reported there that Osman Digna, was killed on July 18 by a member of the Bishareen tribe, whose nephew Osman stabbed because he refused to join the rebels.

DETROIT, Mich., July 28.--The 14-year-old daughter of Stephen Kimball, a wealthy farmer residing near Lyons, while strolling near her father's house yesterday was seized and outraged by two tramps. Mr. Kimball has offered a reward of $500 for the arrest of the villains. A hundred men are in pursuit of them.

FAR ROCKAWAY, Long Island, July 28.-- Last night a ferocious bull, owned by Owen Reilly, got loose and dashed through the streets of this village, creating great excitement. John Lines, a wealthy butcher, while crossing the street was attacked and tossed by the animal receiving serious and perhaps fatal injures. Several of his ribs were broken, and his head was injured. Justice Healy ordered the animal shot.

BALTIMORE, July 28.--The steamboat Oriole, which left this port on Saturday last for New-York in tow of the tug Ivanhoe, of Philadelphia, sprung a leak while off Patuxent River. She was towed into shallow water in the river above Drum Point, where she sank, after every effort had been made to prevent the disaster.

Mrs. William Crawford, whose husband is a member of the firm of Simpson, Crawford Simpson, is the proprietress of a specimen of the genus Didelphys Virginius, otherwise a Virginia opossum, which was presented to her by a friend in the South.

KESWICK, Va., July 29.--A fight between James Fry, a white man, and John Roland, 3 negro, in Albemarle County, last night, resulted in the killing of Fry. For some time past the murderer has been too intimate with Fry's nurse.

NEW-HAVEN, July 29.--Michael Kennedy, aged 22, landed in New-York Sunday from the Alaska. In a saloon near the wharf he got 24 one pound sterling notes changed, receiving a one hundred-dollar and a twenty-dollar bill. To-day on his arrival here he was told that both of them were confederate bills, and such they proved to be. It was all the money he had. He cannot identify the saloon.

OTTAWA, Ontario, July 29.--Arrangements have been completed for connecting the quarantine station of Grosse Isle with Quebec by submarine cable and land lines. This route will be a boon to pilot service and also to the numerous inhabitants of Orleans Island, and will provide reliable connection with Grosse Isle. It has also been decided to establish telephonic communication between the hospital and convalescent ends of Grosse Isle.

SARATOGA, July 29.--Jupiter Pluvius seems to hold Saratoga in affectionate regard, for frequent showers have been the order of the month. The roads have been rather heavy, but the number of fine equipages does not seem to diminish.

On Sunday morning a gentleman seated near the Fifty-ninth-street and Fifth-avenue entrance to Central Park noticed the singular behavior of a girl of about 18 years seated near him.

MONTREAL, July 29.--A move is being made among a number of French Canadian Radicals in this city to organize measures with a view to working a Blaine boom among the French Canadians of the United States.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 29.--Annie Stippich, the young girl who was shot by William Donaldson, her intended husband, last Thursday, died this morning. The shooting took place in a vacant house next door to Miss Stippich's home, and has been surrounded in mystery.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 29.--Thirty-one of the Italians arrested on Street's Run for having been concerned in the Lizzie Bradley assault were released this morning, the evidence showing that they were not implicated in the affair. Twenty others of those arrested were held for a hearing on Friday.

ERIE, Penn., July 29.--An association of Erie ladies will dedicate a Faith Cure institution to-morrow where the sick, doctors say, must be restored to health by prayer. The first patient will be a woman, who has malignant cancer.

BOSTON, July 29.--Among the politicians, to-day, the report was current that Gen. Butler has finally determined to run as the candidate of the Greenback, Labor and Anti-Monopoly combination, and that a letter fairly defining his position will issue from him within a few days.

COHOES, N.Y., July 29.--This, the first announcement that the marriage of ex-Assemblyman John Tighe to Miss Josie Ross, organist for a number of years of St. Bernard's Church, will occur to-morrow morning, will be a great surprise to their many friends. The marriage was to be a secret, not even relatives being notified. Counselor Thomas Neary, of Troy, and Miss Libbie Kyne, of Amsterdam, are to be the witnesses.

TITUSVILLE, Penn., July 29.--A Warren special to the Herald says: "Barnsdale well, No. 2, at Wardwell, across the river, has been drilled in, and is no larger than Barnsdale No. 1. It may be good for 150 barrels.

There was a well-attended meeting of the New-York Clearing House Association yesterday, and a spirited discussion was had of the subject of introducing certain reforms in the practices of the associated banks of this city.

An ingenious contrivance, to be used in effecting the escape of a convict named Theodore Schelf from Sing Sing Prison, was captured by Principal Keeper Connaughton yesterday. This convict was a skilled machinist, and worked in the machine shop.

MARLBOROUGH, N.Y., July 29.--R.C. Jackson, Superintendent of the Railway Mail Service in New-York and four other States, is making arrangements to have a Sunday mail run along the line of the West Shore Railroad.

WAVERLY, N.Y., July 29.--Alanson Bennett, a well-known resident of this place, a Trustee and member of the Church of the Disciples, Treasurer of the Equitable Aid Union and Iron Hull Society, two important local benevolent...

ONEONTA, N.Y., July 29.--At a convention of residents of the Second Asssembly District of Otsego County, held yesterday in the Methodist church here, addresses were delivered by Prof. N.N. Bull, Mrs. Lillie Devereux Blake,

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., July 29.--A wheel mill at the Hazard Powder Works, at Hazardville, Conn., containing about 200 pounds of powder, blew up at 3:20 o'clock this morning. No one was injured. The sound of the explosion was distinctly heard in this city about 12 miles distant.
ST.PAUL, Minn., July 29.--Gen. Sherman is here conferring with the local committee relative to the reunion of the Society of the Army of the Tennessee on Aug. 13.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 29.--The Democratic Convention for this (the Thirteenth) Congressional District assembled at noon to-day, every township in the district being represented and 219 delegates being present.

Patrolman Foley, of the Twenty-ninth Precinct, early yesterday, surprised a young man who was industriously engaged in boring holes in the side door of John Lavery's liquor store, No. 301 Seventh-avenue.

CONCORD, July 29.--This has been the only rainy day since the School of Philosophy opened, but such is the interest in the discussion of Emerson's life and writings that there were few vacant seats in the little chapel, and the morning was, if anything, more notable than any that has preceded it.

CINCINNATI, July 29.--An account of a sensational elopement comes from Paris, Ky. Miss Susie Wells, a fashionable young lady of Georgetown, Ky., daughter of S.S. Wells, a banker, was visiting Mrs. James Thomas, of Paris.
ALBANY, July 29.--In the densely crowded drawing room of the Executive Mansion, in Eagle-street, Gov. Cleveland this afternoon accepted the Democratic nomination for President.

Officer Chiardi, of the Charities Organization Society, aided by a policeman, led into the Tombs Police Court yesterday afternoon a woman whose face and form have been familiar on the streets and in stores down town for the past five or six years.

The Caughnawaga Indians were given a close brush by a team from the New-York Lacrosse Club yesterday, in the match that was played on the grounds of the Staten Island Cricket Club, at New-Brighton, Staten Island.

The first pennant regatta of the Knickerbocker Yacht Club this season was held yesterday, the yachts sailing over the course in the midst of rain, and experiencing squally weather on the trip to Fort Schuyler and back.

The excitement created in Fresh Pond, Newtown, Long Island, and the little villages in the neighborhood of Mount Olivet and Lutheran Cemeteries by the alleged appearance of a ghost in the vicinity last week has not in the least abated.

LONDON, July 29.--At the meeting at Goodwood to-day the race for the Goodwood Stakes was won in a canter by M.A. Staub's 4-year-old Stockholm. John Hammond's 4-yearold br.f. Florence came in second, and the Duke...

TORONTO, July 29.--On Monday next the Ontario and Quebec Division of the Canadian Pacific Railway, the missing link in a new through route between Chicago and Montreal, will be opened for passenger traffic.

SARATOGA, N.Y., July 29.--The races announced for to-day were postponed until tomorrow, owing to the rain. Rataplan is a doubtful starter in the Iroquois Stakes to-morrow. The track is heavy, and a steady rain was falling during the evening.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., July 29.--The sixteenth annual conclave of the Knights of Pytnias of the Grand Lodge of the State of NewYork began here to-day. About 300 Knights are now here and otherss arriving, lodges from all over the State sending delegates.

From reliable authority the Register learns that typhoid fever prevails to a great extent along the track of the cyclone which passed through Fairfield County last Spring. Several deaths have occurred in families attacked by the fever, and physicians have noted it as a singular fact that the majority of typhoid fever cases are confined to the stretch of country visited by the cyclone.
BALTIMORE, Md., July 29.--Leonard T. Caughy, son of Noah N. Caughy, a prominent merchant of this city was on July 5 quietly wedded to Miss C. Nellie Neal, a Baltimore lady in her teens.
Chickering Hall was crowded by a most enthusiastic gathering on Monday night. But crowds and enthusiasm are not so rare here that we need be lost in wonder at that fact.
At the meeting of the Pilot Commissioners yesterday Inspector Fletcher reported that the rock on which the Vincenzo Florio struck on July 9 was 220 yards east-northeast of Diamond Reef.

LONG BRANCH, July 29.--Congressman McAdoo, of New-Jersey, represents a constituency that is made up largely of citizens of Irish birth or Irish descent. He himself was born in Ireland; he is an active member of the Land League, and was commended by the Irish papers for his attitude in Congress toward the Morrison bill.

BUFFALO, July 29.--Police Commissioner Michael Newell, who was arrested for intrusion into a public office, has sued Judge King, who issued the warrant, for $20,000 damages. Newell is under $300 bail for trial on Sept. 1.

FORSYTHE, Ga., July 29.--An attempt to assassinate Mr. W.H. Head, one of our best citizens, occurred on Wednesday morning last. Mr. Head was conversing with some of his friends in front of the store of a Mr. Ham when M.F. Bridges came up and said:

PARIS, July 29.--The debate on the revision of the Constitution was resumed to-day in the Senate. Prime Minister Ferry urged the Senate to accept Article VIII., but declined to say what the Cabinet would do in case the Senate rejected the article.

Henry Coleman, age 35, a printer, of No. 173 Fulton-street, Brooklyn, walked a short distance on the bridge last evening from the NewYork side, and then stopped suddenly. Whirling around rapidly several times, he fell on the pavement in an epileptic fit, cutting his cheek. Officer Lee dashed cold water over his face, and, as he did not revive and ambulance was summoned and he was removed to Chambers-Street Hospital.

The resignations of Jay Gould, Russell Sage, Christopher C. Baldwin, T.F. Ryan, and J. F. Green, as Directors of the Louisville and Nashville Railroad, were accepted at the meeting of the Directors yesterday.
CHICAGO, July 29.--The arrival of a number of sick cattle having been reported at the Union Stock Yards in this city, an examination was made by a number of veterinarians this morning.

ERIE, Penn., July 29.--To-day John C. Brady, Receiver of the defunct Erie County Bank, discovered more rascality. Bookkeeper Traut, who aided in exposing the villainy of President Brabender and Cashier Petit, also had a liberal portion of the depositors' money, his stealings aggregating several thousand dollars. False entries, skillfully made, concealed the deficiency until to-day. Traut has fied to Colorado.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 29.--A stiff breeze, dirty weather, numerous accidents, and a quick run were the experiences of the Eastern Yacht squadron in its run from New-Bedford to Newport this morning.

Michael Curry, a shoemaker, 71 years old, who lives alone in the basement of an oldfashioned two-story frame house at No. 2 Grandstreet, corner of Varick, shot yesterday, and it is believed fatally wounded, Henry Reardon, a bakers assistant, employed on the steamer France, of the National Line.

Anthony Wass, age 17, had been in the employ of Charles T. and J. McKim Minton, stock and oil brokers, of New-street, for more than two years up to Monday noon.

Mr. F.C. Morehead, Commissioner-General of the World's Industrial and Cotton Centennial Exposition, at New-Orleans, and his assistant, Mr. T.P. LONDON, July 29.--In the House of Commons to-day, Lord Edmond Fitzmaurice, Under Foreign Secretary, stated that the Government had not decided to recognize the International African Association in connection with the Congo country.
CHICAGO, July 29.--There was a very good attendance at the races to-day. The weather was fine, but the track was heavy, rain having fallen in the morning.

A meeting of the holders of the first mortgage bonds of the New-York, West Shore and Buffalo Railway Company has been called for next Tuesday at the request of the Trustee, the United States Trust Company.
COLLINGWOOD, Ontario, July 29.--Information has been received here that a surveying party consisting of W.O. Johnson. John Eastwood, R.J. Eardon, and F. Bleskely were drowned in Spanish River.

Anthony Comstock invaded the premises at No.13 West Twenty-eighth-street upon a warrant obtained by Elias C. Baldwin and found rouge-et-noir paraphernalia in the rooms above the basement.

TROY, N.Y., July 29.--Frederick Gruenwalder, of Amsterdam, has a 2-year-old daughter that is the possessor of two perfect tongues. Not caring to have her grow up in that manner, being an object already of much curiosity, he brought her to Dr. Rulison's office to-day for treatment. Neither tongue can be removed, as the physician fears the child might bleed to death.

While ex-Assemblyman W.S. Andrews was passing Broadway and Twenty-first-street, on Monday evening he saw three boys ill-using a cat, and he stopped to watch them. Two of the lads held the cat, while the other brute stamped upon its body.

CHICAGO, July 29.--Advices from Cottonwood, Meagher County, Montana, state that news has arrived at that place that seven horse thieves were found hanging to the trees near the mouth of the Musselshell, on July 20.

CITY OF MEXICO, July 29, via Galveston.-- The Government is adopting stamp tax reforms which are acceptable to commercial houses. Wholesale dealers are to pay one-half of 1 per cent. on their sales, while retailers are to pay yearly according to their business. The National Bank is regularly collecting personal taxes for making good the deficit in the Government budget, and for creating a sinking fund for the payment of the public debt.

MARSEILLES, July 29.--A dispatch has just reached me from a correspondent whom I engaged last week at the Bon Recontre Hospital in Toulon which says that seven deaths took place in that hospital last night, and that three occurred there this morning.

ST. JOSEPH, Mo., July 29.--The Greenback Congressional Convention of the Fourth District, held in this city this afternoon, decided not to nominate a candidate for Congress, but passed a resolution requesting the Hon. Nicholas Ford to become an independent candidate.

It was a melancholy scene at Monmonth Park yesterday. Rain began to fall before the races opened, and it continued steadily throughout the day, reducing the track to the condition of a bog and forcing the spectators to remain under cover throughout the racing.

The Metropolitan and Brooklyn Clubs played a game of baseball at Washington Park yesterday, which resulted in the third successive victory for the "Mets." In spite of the bad state of the weather there was a fair attendance, and the game, although one-sided, was a rather...
LEXINGTON, Ky., July 29.--A Democratic barbecue was held here to-day. Eighty-five head of cattle, sheep, and hogs were slaughtered. Senators Beck, Blackburn, and Voorhees and Gen. Durbin Ward spoke.
PHILADELPHIA, July 29.--The 450 employes of Saller, Lewen Co., shoe manufacturers, of No. 313 Arch-street, refused to continue at work this afternoon, and at 3 o'clock left the building in a body.

VICTORIA, British Columbia, July 21.-- Yesterday afternoon Mrs. George Rudlyn, wife of Capt. George Rudlyn, and her niece, Miss Annie Wilcox, were in an orchard attached to the family residence engaged in picking cherries, when they were startled by the loud report of a gun close at hand.

At the execution near Naples of the soldier Marino a few weeks ago between 4,000 and 5,000 persons were present, many of them being women. Seats and standing places were let to the multitude, and all the high places in the neighborhood were crowded.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 29.--Rain prevented the opening of the Grand Circuit Trotting meeting here to-day. The programmes have, therefore, been pushed one day ahead.

LONDON, July 29.--It seems likely that Australian federation will soon become an active question of British politics in London. A meeting to consider the subject, and in the interest of federation, was held to-day in London, and it is probably a, meeting of much importance.

PORTLAND, Oregon, July 29.--A report reaches here that an organized band of stock thieves have been run down and captured by a party of regulators at Willowa Valley, Oregon. Seventeen of the thieves were caught with a large number of horses in their possession. Two of the ringleaders were hanged and the remainder turned over to the authorities.

NYACK, N.Y., July 29.--The first Nyack liquor case was tried here to-day. It was that of the Law and Order Association against Lawrence McMahon, who was charged with selling liquor without a license on June 11, 13, and 14. All day yesterday was occupied in getting a jury and resulted in a panel that the people had little confidence in.

BRAZIL, Ind., July 29.--The Commercial Bank, of which Hiram Teber is President and Arthur Dillon Cashier, has suspended, with liabilities of about $140,000 and assets nominally estimated at $170,000. It is said that the entire school fund of Clay County is deposited in the bank.

FAIRFIELD, Iowa, July 29.--The official report of the Secretary of the Iowa State Agricultural Society, embracing the condition of the crops from June 15 to July 29, inclusive, shows the condition of corn to be 117 per cent., an increase of 5 per cent. over the former report;

James Reilly, who was stabbed in the abdomen on Monday night by Charles Coyle, is still lying at St. Francis Hospital in a precarious condition. When Coyle was arraigned yesterday he claimed to have acted in self-defense, alleging that Reilly first assaulted him with a bottle.

The trouble between the Commissioners of Emigration and the agents of the Anchor Line continues. Yesterday the Devonia, with over 200 immigrants on board, arrived. Emigration Commissioner Stephenson had threatened that he would not allow immigrants to land from Anchor Line steamships...
The brief speech of Gov. CLEVELAND in reply to the committee which formally notified him of his nomination as the Democratic candidate for President is highly characteristic of the man.
It is not clear what is the disease with which seventy cattle died yesterday on their way from Kansas City to Chicago, and with which twelve carloads of cattle were more or less infected.

A delegation of those who had charge of Monday night's Irish Republican meeting called yesterday at Republican Headquarters to pay their respects to Chairman Jones. The call was brief and informal. Senator Hawley, William Walter Phelps, Galusha A. Grow, Mahlon Chance, and Anson G. McCook were among the other callers. Chairman Jones now confines his official duties within about four hours a day, having taken quarters with his family at the Oriental Hotel, Coney Island.

BAR HARBOR, Me., July 29.--When the guests of the Bar Harbor hotels arose from their 8 o'clock breakfasts this morning they found the United States steamer Tallapoosa riding at anchor outside the fleet of yachts and sailboats that occupy berths nearest the landing.
"Distrust," rearranged and improved, keeps the stage at the Fourteenth-Street Theatre.

LONDON, July 29.--The Egyptian conference met to-day at the Foreign Office in accordance with the arrangement made yesterday before adjourning. The delegates, however, had not yet received replies from their home Governments to the question which they telegraphed yesterday in relation to an important point that arose in the course of their discussions.

The State Civil Service Commission has adjourned to meet at the call of President Jay. This will probably be in about two weeks, or as soon as enough returns are received from Mayors of cities to make it worth the while of the Commissioners to get together.

Superintendent of Insurance John A. McCall, Jr., has written a letter to the Fireman's Trust Insurance Company, of Brooklyn, which is in process of liquidation, asking for the resignation of Dwight Johnson, the President of the company.

MARLBOROUGH, N.Y., July 29.--Extensive preparations are being made to tender President Arthur an ovation on his trip, as the guest of Gen. George H. Sharpe, along the Ulster and Delaware, Catskill Mountain, and Stony Clove Railroads the coming week.

UTICA, N.Y., July 29.--At a meeting in the City Hall to-night, to form a Blaine and Logan Club for the Fourth Ward, the proceedings were commonplace until ex-Judge William J. Bacon was called upon for a speech.

The New-York, Lake Erie and Western Railroad Company has issued an illustrated book, with brilliantly illuminated covers, descriptive of the scenery and attractive Summer resorts on the line of this the pioneer trunk road of America.

PHILADELPHIA, July 29.--Senor Enrique R. Mexia has been delegated by the President of Mexico to represent that country at the International Electrical Exhibition which opens in Philadelphia on Sept.2.

LAWRENCE, Kan., July 29.--A letter has been received here from Senator Plum, stating that Senator John A. Logan has positively assured him that he will be present at the Old Settlers' meeting at Bismarck during the Western National Fair.

DETROIT, Mich., July 29.--The E.T. Barnum Iron and Wire Works, in this city, have been forced into making what it is believed will be but a temporary assignment, growing largely out of differences of opinion among its stockholders,...

All the Protestant churches of East Newark combined on Monday night to hold a public meeting for the purpose of expressing their approval of Father O'Connor's crusade against the saloons. Addresses were delivered by the Pastors of the churches, all of whom commended the priest in high terms.

WASHINGTON, July 29, 1884. The Treasurer of the United States has deposit ed in the Treasury, on account of the conscience fund, $150 "income tax," received by the Assistant Treasurer at New-York through the mail.
CHICAGO, July 29.--The National Labor Convention in this city was set for July 30 by a conference held in Philadelphia on Jan. 6 last.

CONCORD, N.H., July 29.--The funeral of the late ex-Gov. Walter Harriman took place at the Unitarian Church here this afternoon. At the conclusion of the services the body was taken to Warner for interment.
TORONTO, Ontario, July 29.--Reports from Montreal announcing the failure of the Federal Bank's Winnipeg ventures caused some anxiety among timorous holders of the stock this morning.

ST. LOUIS, July 29.--At a meeting of the International Convention of Exposition and Fair Association representatives held here last month the question of holding a World's Fair in commemoration of the discovery of America and to celebrate the four hundredth anniversary...

CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, July 29.--George Reed, colored, last night stabbed and killed E.H. Beaumont, the station agent at Ely, 10 miles south of this city. Beaumont ejected Reed from the station for profanity and vulgarity, where upon the negro turned upon him and stabbed him. Reed was arrested and placed in jail here.

BOSTON, July 29.--The June report of the New-England Telephone Company shows a net gain of 229 subscribers in June and a present number of 18,437 subscribers. The extra territorial messages transmitted during the month were 28,282, a gain of 1,767 over the previous month. Five hundred and ten cities and towns are now connected by telephone in this company. The net gain in subscribers since Jan. 1 is 1,438.

Parties coming up Main-street at an early hour of a recent morning were somewhat surprised to see a large and apparently tame gray squirrel hasten across the street and enter the doorway to the store of Rice Rich.

GALVESTON, Texas, July 29.--The fourth biennial session of the Naitional Grand Lodge of United Brothers of Friendship convened in this city yesterday. The order is a benevolent and social organization, composed of colored members. Ten States are represented, and about 350 delegates are in attendance. Grand Master Fred C. Morton, of Evansville, Ind., presided. The session will continue for several days.

ALBANY, July 29.--The National Democratic Committee met at the Delavan House, and was called to order by Secretary Prince, in the absence of Chairman Barnum. On motion of Mr. Miller, of Nebraska, the Hon. John Barbour, of Virginia, was chosen Chairman pro tem.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Penn., July 29.--This morning about 2 o'clock the inhabitants of Rausch Creek, a small mining village in the western end of Schuylkill County, were startied by a loud, rumbling noise, followed by an explosion which shook the buildings in the immediate neighborhood.

NEW-ORLEANS, July 29.--Major B.M. Harrod, of the Mississippi River Commission has just returned to this city from New-York where he has been to attend a session of the commission for the purpose of parceling out the funds for the several branches of the work intrusted to it.

The Eleventh Ward Savings Bank, which is going out of business as fast as depositors will draw their money and close their accounts, was organized in 1868, with E. V. Loew as President and John Englis as Vice-President. The bank was situated at Avenue C and Tenth-street.

LONDON, July 29.--In the House of Commons, this afternoon, Mr. Gladstone, in reply to a question of Mr. Labouchere's, said the Government had no intention of again moving the second reading of the Franchise bill, although the House of Lords had not formally rejected it.

PARKERSBURG, West Va., July 29.--"To fuse or not to fuse" is the one question of moment with the delegates to the Republican State Convention now pouring into this city from all quarters of the State.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., July 29.--One of the most outrageous assaults ever chronicled in this State came to light this morning. Mrs. Buchanan, a widow lady, and her daughter Mary, aged 17 years, live five miles from Spring City. Several nights ago seven men, whom she recognized as neighbors, came to the house and made insulting proposals to the ladies.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 29.--Newport presented a very dreary and uninviting appearance to-day. Rain fell nearly all day, and the thermometer ranged from 60 to 70 . But few people visited the Casino or even ventured out in their carriages. The harbor is filled with yachts of all kinds to-night--the Eastern yacht squadron having arrived late this afternoon.

FALL RIVER, Mass., July 29.--The Weetamore Mill started up this morning after a week's suspension. It will close again on Saturday for another week. The King Philip Mill will shut down on Saturday for a week.

PIEDMONT, West Va., July 29.--The most disastrous flood known in this section for years did its destructive work last night and this morning. The reported loss of life and property is great. Rain fell continuously from 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon until 10 o'clock this morning.

CHARLOTTE, N.Y., July 29.--Frederick Hutter, a brother of Jacob Hutter, of this village, residing in Rochester, has for some time lived unhappily with his wife. He owned some property and she owned the house in which they lived.

BOSTON, July 29.--The Erie Telephone and Telegraph Company to-day declared a quarterly dividend of one-half of 1 per cent., a reduction from 1 per cent. for the previous quarter.

MARLBOROUGH, N.Y., July 29.--The order issued some time ago by Secretary Folger, prohibiting any person entering the pilot house of a Hudson River steamboat while under way, save pilots or other employes whose presence is actually necessary, is being rigidly enforced.

MOBILE, Ala., July 31.--Capt. T.W. Matthews, the oldest steamboat man of this section, died in St. Louis on Monday, and the body was brought here for burial. Capt. MAYVILLE, N.Y., July 31.--A novel question in law--whether a partner is responsible for public funds appropriated by his copartner in business--is to be raised in a suit just begun by Barnes Bancroft, of Buffalo, against Porter Sperry, of this village.

A singular case of robbery which occurred over two weeks ago was made public yesterday by the offer of a reward of $1,000 for the return of $4,000 worth of diamonds and gold watches which had been stolen from the store of William Hailisy, No. 57 Chatham-street.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 31.--The Atlantic Yacht Club squadron arrived here about 3 o'clock this afternoon after a splendid race from Stonington, from which point the contest was had.

WHEELING, West Va., July 31.--Edward Ruhl, aged 8, and Thomas Healey, aged 7, were drowned in the Ohio River at the foot of one of the south side streets this evening. The drowned boys, with a number of others, were playing on the bank, when a fall of earth threw four of them into the water.
The bricklayers yesterday felt confident of the success of their strike and thought that all the men would soon be at work under the nine-hour rule.

The Commissioners appointed by the Governor under an act of the Legislature to investigate the condition of the tenement houses in this city are about to begin their work. We cannot say that we anticipate much fruit from their labors.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 31.--During the exhibition of Buffalo Bill's Wild West show at Charter Oak Park this afternoon a serious accident occurred to Major Frank North, the wellknown interpreter of the Pawnee Indians and a ranchman of Nebraska.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 31.--The weather continues to be decidedly unfavorable for Newport's interests as a watering place. The two days' storm cleared during the night, and this morning was bright and clear.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 31.--Important experiments were attempted at the torpedo station at Newport, to-day, but were not very successful.

ALBANY, July 31.--Gov. Cleveland and ex-Gov. Thomas A. Hendricks met for the first time this afternoon. The candidate for VicePresident on the Democratic ticket arrived here from Saratoga at 2 o'clock, in company with Col. E.D. Bannister, of Indianapolis, an intimate friend. They were met at the station by Gov. Cleveland's private secretary, Col. D.S. Lamont, and driven at once to the Executive Mansion.
It is now settled, beyond a doubt, that Mr. Blaine will carry the State of New-York by an Irish-American majority that will be simply unparalleled. Congressman Frank Hiscock has publicly said so.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 31.--The schooner yacht Halcyon, of the Eastern Club, returned to Newport this evening, having broken her bowsprit at 3 P.M., midway between Point Judith and Watch Hill. The yacht Ruth carried away her foretopmast at the same time.

The time for making tenders for bringing the British mails to this country expires today. The old contracts end Aug. 31. Postmaster-General Fawcett announced that it was not the intention of the English Government to renew the long contracts hereafter, but that month ...

The lease of the franchise of the North Shore Ferry of Staten Island and of the slip at the foot of Whitehall-street, from which the boats start, which has been held by John H. Starin for several years, expired yesterday, and to-day the new line will begin running under the lease secured from the city by Erastus Wiman.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., July 31.--To-day was the anniversary of the founding of Ocean Grove. This afternoon services were held in Thompson-square, the site of the first prayermeeting held here 13 years ago to-day.
TROY, N.Y., July 31.--Pittstown, a small place in Rensselaer County, is greatly excited over a peculiar case that has just developed there.

BAR HARBOR, Me., July 31.--This has been one of the most unpleasant days of an unpleasant week here. Thick fogs have drifted over the island, occasional rain has fallen, and overcoats have been almost indispensable.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 31.--Missouri Pacific stock is practically cornered by Jay Gould. To-day, in this city, a man who called himself Mr. Glandin, of New-York City, entered the stock brokers office of Babcock Andrews, S. G. Martin Co. and Edward Tracy Co., and bought upon a thousand-dollar margin a quantity of Missouri Pacific stock. Four days ago the same man succeeded in raking in a deal of about $500 to each ...
