PHILADELPHIA, July 31.--All hope has been abandoned for the overdue Spanish brig Esperanza, which sailed from Cette, France, on Feb. 2 for this port with a cargo of china clay.
St. John's Guild carried on its seaside excursion 9,000 children and mothers during the month of July. The following contributions for the Floating Hospital are gratefully acknowledged:
John Caswell Co., importers of teas at No. 87 Front-street, announced their suspension at the Importers and Grocers' Exchange yesterterday afternoon.
Mr. Edward Righton will play the dual role of the Professor and the dissipated waiter in Mr. Derrick's comedy of "Twins" upon its first production in London to-morrow evening.

WASHINGTON, July 31.--Secretary Gibson, of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen, has made public the following list of entries for the twelfth annual regatta, to be held on Seneca Lake, at Watkins, N.Y., Aug. 12 and 13, 1884:
READING, Penn., July 31.--Owing to the unfavorable state of the weather to-day, the great parade of the German singing societies was postponed until to-morrow.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., July 31.--The examination of Peter McGeoch before a court Commissioner in the litigation between Daniel Wells, Jr., and McGeoch, the millionaire speculator, was continued to-day, and much of the true inwardness of the great lard deal of last July cropped out. McGeoch has been on the witness stand for two days, but he has been very successful in wriggling out of answering questions ...

POTTSVILLE, July 31.--A decision in the final injunction case was rendered to-day by the court in favor of the Reading and Pottsville Railroad, allowing the Reading's rival to enter on their ground for the purpose of locating and constructing a new road.

WASHINGTON, July 31.--The Potomac regatta took place to-day under discouraging conditions of wind and weather. The river was swollen by a freshet, and against this and a stiff head wind the crews contended.

District Attorney Olney returned to the city from his vacation yesterday. In reference to the charges against the police in the Mandelbaum case be said that he preferred not to make any statement at present, as he was not sure it would serve the public interest to do so.

BETHLEHEM, Penn., July 31.--The Rev. Jacob Weidman, one of the most widely known members of the Lehigh Presbytery and Pastor of the South Bethlehem Presbyterian Church, has made an assignment to Robert E. James, of ...

FALLS VILLAGE, Conn., July 31.--Edward Halstead was tried before two Justices of the Peace to-day for shooting and killing Andrew German last Saturday night. The trial lasted from 10 A.M. until 5 P.M. The prisoner was defended by F.E. Cleveland, of Winsted, and after a few minutes' consultation at the close of the trial the Justices decided the murder to have been committed in self-defense, and discharged the prisoner.

SCRANTON, Penn., July 31.--An affecting marriage ceremony took place yesterday at Dunmore, a short distance from this city, at the residence of the bride, who was on her death bed, and who desired that her lover, to whom she ...
ALBANY, July 31.--An effort to keep secret the facts concerning the shooting of Superintendent McKenna, of the almshouse, a week ago, has been made, but the truth has come out.

A meeting of the Directors of the defunct Fireman's Trust Insurance Company was held last evening at the company's offices on Montague-street, Brooklyn, for the purpose of receiving the resignation of the President, Mr. Dwight Johnson.

Garden City was never half so attractive as it is this Summer. The trees have grown wonderfully and the whole place is shaded with them. The lawns, close shaven and embroidered with flowers, are brighter and greener than ever, and the fountains ...

The entire Democratic strength of Riverhead, Long Island, gathered in Foster's Hall Wednesday evening to form a Cleveland and Hendricks Campaign Club and to listen to a discussion on the issues of the present political campaign. Capt. Edward Hawkins presided. ExCongressman Henry A. Reeves, the first speaker, made a caustic arraignment of Blaine's active participation, while Speaker of the House of ...

The Irving Insurance Company, of this city, discontinued business yesterday, its outstanding risks having been reinsured by the United Fire Reinsurance Company, of Manchester, England. The reasons calling for this action were briefly given in a circular sent to all its agents under date of July 28.

ANNISTON, Ala., July 31.--Reports have reached here of the punishment of a negro brute which are of a most horrible character. On Tuesday morning the 13-year-old daughter of a well-known citizen of Tuscaloosa, who lives on the outskirts of the town, went into town for the purpose of taking a music lesson.

ALBANY, July 31.--Christian Schreiver, husband of the woman who two months ago murdered her four children and then dragged her daughter, 13 years old, and held her in front of an approaching train so that both were killed, ...
GADSDEN, Ala., July 31.--This city is in a profound sensation over the suicide of two young women, sisters, both at the same time and under circumstances such as to arouse the deepest feeling.
The game of baseball on the Polo Grounds yesterday between the New-York and Providence Clubs was called at the end of the ninth inning on account of darkness, the score being even at 3 to 3.

WASHINGTON, July 31.--The gentle but determined method of obtaining campaign funds from department employes in this city, known as the "milking process," beging to-morrow. The committee of five selected by the Republican National Committee to conduct these dairy operations has procured quarters in New-Yorkavenue, convenient to the Treasury Building, and to-day workmen have been employed in filling up the reception room, where "business" ...
CHICAGO, Ill., July 31.--The racing was continued here to-day. The weather was fine, the track heavy, the attendance good, and the betting heavy.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., July 31.--A few weeks ago John Berry, living near Deckertown, N.J., was arrested charged with poisoning a women who lived with him as his wife and her two children, the woman and one of the children dying.

CHICAGO, July 31.--If Butler waits much longer before defining his position, his position will be of slight importance in any event if the tide from him does not lessen. The last week has witnessed such a decline in Butler stock among Chicago workingmen that one of two ...

Several letters were received yesterday at the headquarters of the independent Republicans from men who have lately resigned from district Executive Committees because of their sympathy with the independent movement.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 31.--The Rev. Dr. Hinkle, a prominent clergyman, formerly Pastor of Grace Episcopal Church, in this city, was arrested to-day on the charge of seduction, bastardy, and abortion. The lady interested is a Mrs. Alexander, who has been a member of his church for years. He claims that it is a blackmailing scheme.

In its desire to do "full and exact justice to Mr. BLAINE in the investigation of his variegated career in public life" the Sun goes quite too far, and is led to substitute sophistry for sound argument and extenuating suppositions for ugly facts.
TROY, N.Y., July 31.--In December, 1881, Warren C. Bloomingdale was notified that his mother, Hannah Bloomingdale, who had been an inmate of the County House for 15 years, was dead.

The gas tank on board the Thirty-fourthstreet ferryboat Manhattan Beach was found to be leaking yesterday, and the boat was laid up until the leak could be repaired. Edward R. Odell, a machinist, of No. 319 East Thirty-thirdstreet, was engaged to make the repairs.
CHICAGO, July 31.--An element of distrust is said to have been introduced into the camp of the Illinois Republicans by the entrance of Mr. C.B. Farwell once more into the arena of politics.

NEWARK, N.J., July 31.--At an early hour this evening an old man named Patrick Quinn, living at No. 255 Norfolk-street, was taken to Police Headquarters hopelessly insane. His brother-in-law deposited with the authorities $3,300 in cash and a bank book representing $10,000, which had been found in Quinn's possession. These amounts represent years of savings, and it is believed that the care of so much money has driven him insane.

MARLBOROUGH, N.Y., July 31.--Stamford, Delaware County, where the Delaware River has its source, and which is the furthest point accessible in the Catskill Mountains by rail, desires to have a new Episcopal church building.

George F. Baker, President of the First National Bank, has claimed a preference in the distribution of the assets of the Marine Bank of $215,000 for bogus checks drawn by Ferdinand Ward on the First National and deposited in the Marine. They were allowed by the Clearing House in the settlement of the balances on May 6.

CHICAGO, July 31.--The Cattle movement was not very brisk to-day, still, in a quiet way, a good deal was accomplished, about all of the fresh arrivals and the larger part of the State Cattle changing bands during the day. In prices there was no perceptible change. Fair to best grades sold quite as strong as yesterday, and the poorer sorts were not appreciably cheaper.
The important pooling arrangement between the Baltimore and Ohio, the Postal, and the Bankers and Merchants' Telegraph Companies goes into effect to-day.

The investigation into the charges made by Mrs. Eliza A. Conner against Gertrude Herrman, an intelligence office keeper, of being willing to furnish girls for immoral purposes was continued in the Mayor's office yesterday.

WHEELING, West Va., July 31.--James H. Comerford, a member of the City Council and a prominent Democratic politician, is on trial before the county authorities on the charge of having embezzled a large amount from the contingent poor fund, on orders drawn in favor of fictitious persons. The amount involved is not yet known.

CHICAGO, July 31.--Last night, in Spencer Township, Harrison County, Ind., 25 miles west of New-Albany, a gang of 20 masked men went to the residence of Mrs. Sallie Tipton, a widow, and, taking her from her bed, tied her to a tree ...

The Executive and Advisory Committees of the Young Republican Club of Brooklyn, having had under consideration for some time the question whether the club ought or ought not to take part in the national campaign, have resolved "that the policy of these committees will be to confine their recommendations for ...

The seventeenth annual number of "Poor's Manual" has just been issued. This book contains detailed statements of the operations and condition of every railroad company in the United States for the year 1884.

WASHINGTON, July 31.--Mr. Nimmo, Chief of the Bureau of Statistics, to-day transmitted to the Secretary of the Treasury his report on the foreign commerce of the United States for the month of June, 1884, and for the year ended June 30, 1884.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 31.--The Railroad Commission has rendered a decision on the complaint of R.F. Stevens and others and J.M. Horton's Ice Cream Company against the New-York, Lake Erie and Western Railroad that the charges for milk are excessive and unreasonable.

The trial of Canfield B. Warning for the killing of his brother-in-law, George E. Frawen, at Dutch Kills, on May 26 last, terminated yesterday in Queens County Court of Oyer and Terminer, Long Island City, amid much excitement.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 31.--A special to the Journal from Lexington, Mo., says: "Jeff Wilson (colored) this morning shot and killed Jae Sanford, also colored. Jealousy was the cause of the actor Wilson surrendered himself to the officers.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 31.--The fishing steamer Albatross arrived here from Wood's Holl to-night, and will leave in the morning to continue her investigations and observations into the habits of fish in the adjoining waters.

BRADFORD, Penn., July 31.--Six of the glass blowers who took part in yesterday's riot had a hearing this morning and each was held in $200 bail for trial. John Malcolm, boss cutter, and leader of yesterday's riot, and Frank Cunningham, who were released on bail last night, have jumped their bail and left the country. Fortune Degneaux, whose eyes were gouged, was taken to the hospital at Buffalo to-night. He will go entirely blind.

The agreement merging the Metropolitan and New-York Elevated Railways into the Manhattan was ratified by the stockholders of the Metropolitan Company yesterday. W.D. Miles was made Chairman of the meeting.
The monthly reports of the visiting physicians of the Sick Children's Mission show that since June 1 medical attendance has been furnished to 760 sick children of the poor.

PARIS, July 31.--At Marseilles there were three deaths from cholera last night and there have been seven to-day. Three deaths from the disease occurred at Toulon last night and two to-day. No serious cases are in the hospitals there, and the fears that the epidemic would break out again are subsiding. One death from cholera has occurred at Creux St. George, one at Montfort, and one at Surargens.

LONG BRANCH, July 31.--The convention of the Irish National League that takes place in Boston next month will, if the indications discovered here are to be relied on, be an occasion of a good deal of contention.

TROY, N.Y., July 31.--The village of Glens Falls is worked up owing to a deadlock in the Board of Trustees, which has shut off all business transactions with the village. The corporation Treasury is depleted, a large number of bills are on hand unpaid, there are no contracts for street lights, and the village is in darkness.

BELLAIRE, Ohio, July 31.--The southern part of this (Belmont) county is intensely excited over the supposed murder and cremation of John Williams, a farmer, who has been working on the farm of Samuel Danford.
BUFFALO, N.Y., July 31.--The statistics of the flour and grain trade of this port for the month of July make a better showing than those for the preceding months of this year.
"E.E.S."--Apply to the National Academy of Design.
Alexander Jefferson, the colored murderer, who will expiate his crime on the gallows his morning, rose yesterday morning at 7:30 o'clock, having slept soundly since 11:30 the preceding night.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 31.--District Attorney Porter announced in open court to-day that the cases of the Commonwealth against A. M. Bowser, of Greensburg; Milton Weston, of Chicago; Henry Ramsley, of Murraysville; William ...

WASHINGTON, Penn., July 31.--Pittsburg capitalists, it is reported, have sold the great Meguigan gas well, with large natural gas rights, in Washington County, together with their pipe line to Pittsburg, now almost completed, to the Westinghouse gas syndicate.
The German steamship Roma, which arrived in this port last night, reports that at 5 P.M. yesterday, when three miles southeast by east of the Scotland Lightship, she collided with and sunk the ...
NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 31.--Charles Phillips, (colored,) who is condemned to be hanged at Huntingdon to-morrow for the murder of Frank Prince (colored) last Fall, has given up all hope of a respite.
In the City Court, Chambers, yesterday, Judge Hyatt handed down a decision adjudging John Kolter guilty of contempt of court, and fining him $281 65, with $50 counsel fee.

LONDON, July 31.--The race for the Goodwood Cup at Goodwood to-day was won by the Duke of Portland's three-year-old bay colt St. Simon.

Mrs. Vanderbilt Allen was as serene and composed as the gallant Colonel himslef when she arrived, with her mother and several friends, early yesterday forenoon in the handsome offices in the new Mutual Life Insurance Building of her husband's lawyer, Robert Sewell, to undergo cross-examination in her plea for alimony and counsel fees, pending the result of her suit for divorce.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, July 31.--At to-day's session of the National Convention of Photographers the first prize for the best collection of cabinet photographs was awarded to J.E. Hale, or Seneca Falls, N.Y.

A new and significant proceeding has just been begun by Attorney-General O'Brien to oust Theodore Houston and Horace Russell from their positions as Receivers of the New-York, West Shore and Buffalo Railway Company.
To each of the 2,500 members of the Young Republican Club of Brooklyn were mailed yesterday copies of a circular and pamphlet prepared by the Executive and Advisory Committees of that organization.
There will be music on the Battery this evening, commencing at 7:30 o'clock, by the Sixty-ninth Regiment Band, under the leadership of William Bayne. The following is the programme:
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 31.--An inmate of the Hudson River State Hospital named Charles Mosher, from, Troy, escaped this morning, and walked down the railroad track to this city.

Commissioner Forrest presided yesterday at the monthly meeting of the Board of Emigration. Commissioner Stephenson offered a resolution which was unanimously adopted. It recommended that the board send an official communication to the Secretary of the Treasury ...

LONDON, July 31.--The Egyptian conference met at the Foreign Office to-day. There was no hitch in the progress of the discussion, and it is thought probable that an arrangement will soon be agreed upon. The conference adjourned to reassemble Saturday.

TITUSVILLE, Penn., July 31.--The monthly oil report for July is in some particulars the most remarkable given to trade in years. It shows that during the month 156 wells were completed, with a production of 1,219 barrels at the end of the month. There were only 54 rigs erected and 123 wells drilling in the entire region.

WASHINGTON, July 31.--Secretary Frelinghuysen has received from Consul Mason, at Marseilles, a report on the alleged origin and character of the cholera epidemic now prevailing at Toulon and Marseilles, and the measures taken to prevent its inception and arrest its progress, together with a summary of the present ...
LONDON, July 31.--The trial of the suspected dynamiters, John Daly and James Egan, was continued to-day at Warwick. The same precautions were taken to guard the court as yesterday.
SHANGHAI, July 31.--It is reported here to-day that France and China have made a treaty of peace. China is to pay France an indemnity of 5,200,000 taels--about $7,280,000.
NEW-LONDON, July 31.--The squadron of the Eastern Yacht Club arrived in the harbor of this place and came to anchor off the Pequot House at 5 P.M.

The Directors of the Sixth-Avenue Surface Railroad Company held a meeting on Tuesday to consider the advisability of increasing the capital stock from $750,000 to $1,500,000, the increase to be divided among the present stockholders at par.
The Executive Committee of the German organizations of the city favoring the election of Cleveland and Hendricks held a meeting last night at Teutonia Hall, in Third-avenue, David Kohler presiding.

MARLBOROUGH, N.Y., July 31.--It is announced that the Erie Railroad has discharged a number of its employes on the Delaware Division for drinking after having been paid off. The Erie means to enforce the rule observed on the West Shore of discharging any hand who is found using intoxicants.

The Executive Committee appointed by the Tenement House Commission some time ago began active work on Monday last by inquiring into and examining the sanitary condition of tenement houses throughout the city.

Persons who are supposed to be trying to find William E. Scovil, the missing stenographer and clerk of the law firm of Lord, Day Lord, stated yesterday that they had learned nothing of his whereabouts.

Yesterday was far from being an enjoyable one at Monmouth Park, for rain, mud, and bad starting form an amalgamation that is trying to the best of natures and is especially conducive of profanity, on a race day. There had been a rainstorm during the early morning, which made the track very heavy, but the weather cleared temporarily and it was not till half the racing was over that the flood gates were again ...

RICHMOND, Va., July 31.--A cablegram received here from Mrs. St. George Mason, who is in Algiers, announces the death of her husband, Capt. George Tucker Mason, at Tonquin, China. The dispatch does not state that he died from disease contracted or of wounds received in battle.
The Receivers of the Wabash Railway sent out notice yesterday that, under order of the court, the interest on the following bonds would be paid as soon as the current earnings would admit of it:
ALBANY, N.Y., July 31.--Superintendent of Public Works James Shanahan has so far recovered from his recent illness as to be considered out of danger.

CONCORD, July 30.--This morning the essayists on the programme were conspicuous by their absence. Yesterday Mr. Protap Chunder Mozoomdar's paper on "Emerson as Seen from India" was omitted because it had not arrived from Calcutta, and to-day Mr. Walt Whitman, who was to speak on "Emerson and Thoreau," was sick in New-Jersey, and Mr. W.E. Channing, who had the subject of "Emerson's ...

SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 31.--In response to a letter from Gen. D.H. Bruce, inclosing a paragraph from the Syracuse Courier on the alleged W.A. Croffut interview, President Andrew D. White, of Cornell University, writes as follows:

All the States will elect Presidential Electors on Tuesday, Nov. 4. The Electors then chosen will meet at their respective State Capitols on Wednesday, Dec. 3, and cast their ballots for President and Vice-President of the United States.

MONTREAL, July 31.--The Directors of the People's Bank have decided to pass their semi-annual dividend, which is payable on Sept. 1. This is the first time since the bank's incorporation in 1855 that it has not paid its regular dividend.
Burglars entered on Tuesday night the cellar of No. 63 West Twelfth-street, occupied by Samuel Kerr, a tea dealer, by means of the coal chute.
G. Warren Rowley, the pretended broker, who was arrested on Thursday charged with stealing from the boarding house of Mrs. Fannie McClellan, No. 50 West Twenty-eighty-street, ...

NEWBURG, N.Y., July 31.--The West Shore Railway Company began to-day the selling of excursion tickets between this place and NewYork, good five days after date, for $1 15, which is lower than the regular rate one way, the local rate being $1 16, and the former excursion rate $2 25.

MARLBOROUGH, N.Y., July 31.--The citizens in ton towns in Ulster, eight in Delaware, four or five in Orange, a number in Dutchess and in the river counties also adjoining voted for "no license" and carried the day at the various town meetings held last Spring.
ALBANY, July 31.--Following is an additional installment of eight of the New-York City savings banks, showing their condition July 1, as reported to the Superintendent of the Banking Department:

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, N.Y., July 31.-- There was a decided sensation among the guests here this morning when it was learned that Edward S. Steers, 21 years old, and the son of Schuyler B. Steers, one of the richest men in Louisiana, had committed suicide for love. Three years ago young Steers met Miss Tese White and fell in love with her.

George Hawksley, a Sergeant in Company D, Forty-second New-York Volunteers, was killed at the battle of Antietam. His widow, Johanna Hawksley, received a small pension from the Government, which she drew regularly ...

PORTSMOUTH, N.H., Aug. 1.--The Thetis, Bear, and Alert, comprising the Greely relief squadron, arrived off Newcastle before daylight this morning, and by 2 o'clock this afternoon the squadron had dropped anchor in the harbor of Portsmouth.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Aug. 1.--This forenoon the examination of Peter McGeoch by the attorneys for Daniel Wells, Jr., before Court Commissioner Bloodgood, proved very interesting. The witness did not decline to answer so many questions as yesterday, and appeared to be in a happy frame of mind.

BOSTON, Aug. 1.--The Democrats have determined to proceed with their canvass without waiting for Butler to declare his intensions, and to-day arrangements were in part completed for a ratification meeting here to be held on next Friday night.
NEW-HAVEN, Aug. 1.--Last Wednesday night, Pauline Silliman, a cultivated light mulatto girl, 20 years old, the daughter of a respectable colored family in this city, who is ...

Dr. C.C. O'Donnell is the name of a man who arrived at the Grand Union Hotel on Thursday evening. Some time ago it was announced that this man was on his way hither from San Francisco with two of the worst examples of the horrible disease of leprosy.

A long programme, consisting of seven races, is offered at Monmouth Park to-day, and although the fields are generally small the character of the entries are such as to insure spirited contests. The Palisade Stakes is especially attractive, for with St. Saviour out the contest is sure to be close and exciting. The full entry list with the pool selling is as follows:

PROVINCETOWN, Mass., Aug. 1.--The fishing schooner Colorado, of this port, towed in today the waterlogged three-masted schooner Napoleon, Capt. Torrell, of New-York, from South Gardiner, Me., for New-York, with lumber.

Alexander Jefferson, the negro who was hanged in the Raymond-Street Jail in Brooklyn yesterday morning, suffered as cruel a death as any murderer who ever expiated his crime upon a gallows. He died not the comparatively easy and rapid death produced by a broken neck, but from the slow torture of strangulation, finally ended by congestion of the brain, caused by his violent struggles.

LONDON, Aug. 1.--The Times has a dispatch from Foo Chow, dated July 31, which says; "China has refused to pay the indemnity demanded by France. The time granted to China by France to decide upon the matter has been prolonged beyond the 1st of August.

The first month of the new fiscal year shows a reduction in the public debt of nearly $4,000,000, or about one-half the reduction made in July, 1883. The reduction was mainly in the column of the non-interest-bearing debt, which is $7,000,000 less than on July 1, while the interest-bearing ...
BATH, Me., Aug. 1.--Mrs. Thankful Donnell, of West Bath, aged 100 years 3 months and 18 days, died yesterday. Of eight children six survive her.

The Providence and New-York Clubs played off their "tie" game on the Polo Grounds yesterday, and it resulted in an easy victory for the visitors. There were 2,500 persons present, who came prepared to witness a good struggle. In this they were disappointed. Begley was put in to pitch, and the Providence men batted him rather freely.

"If the charges made in THE TIMES against Thompson's Bank Note Reporter are true, which I have no reason to doubt," said Postmaster Pearson yesterday, "it is clear that the paper does not come under the definition of second class mail matter, and its transmission through the mails may be stopped by an order of the Post Office Department."

It was Harold Frederic, formerly editor of the Albany Evening Journal, who dared the dangers of the cholera and gave to the NewYork press the best account yet published of the condition of the grief-stricken cities of the South of France.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 1.--A dispatch from Tehachapi, Cal., says that a mysterious malady has suddenly manifested itself among the workmen on a new bridge at Needles, Cal. The victims are seized with dizziness, and then fall in a fit. Two died in intense agony within two hours.

In the Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday, Judge Van Brunt handed down a decision dismissing the writ of habeas corpus secured by Justice Steckler for Aram Slovitz, who, with 51 others, was recently taken charge of by the Commissioners of Emigration on the ground that he was an assisted pauper immigrant.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 1.--Much to the surprise of the Catholics of the Diocese of St. Paul, Bishop Thomas L. A fire at No. 89 Water-street yesterday morning resulted in damage amounting to about $33,000 and the death of three persons, although the building was within 400 feet of the First Precinct station and the quarters of Hook and Ladder Company No. 15. CHICAGO, Aug. 1.--The Western delegates to the Irish National Convention to be held in Boston Aug. 13 favor the re-election of Alexander Sullivan, of this city, the present incumbent, to the Presidency of the League.

BOSTON, Mass., Aug. 1.--Mrs. William Hill, of Rockland, Mass., who has been stopping with friends at South Boston, died suddenly this morning, her death being caused, Mrs. Hill's friends assert, by the carelessness of a woman doctor.

LONDON, Aug. 1.--The British steamship Britannia, Capt. Ferrier, which left New-York July 16, for London, was wrecked off Portland, at midnight on Wednesday. The disaster was caused by a collision between the Britannia and the steamer Belicairn, which was bound from Hartlepool to Cadiz. The crew of the sinking vessel was rescued by the Bellcairn and landed at Southampton.

ALBANY, Aug. 1.--Gov. Cleveland was in the private room attached to the Executive Chamber nearly all day, and received but few visitors. It is reported that he began writing his letter of acceptance this morning.

READING, Penn., Aug. 1.--The German Saengerfest wound up its festivities to-night. There was a parade this morning, and this afternoon a picnic was held at Lauer's Park, where speeches were made by Congressman Ermentrout in English and Gustave Enolich in German illustrative of the lives and characters of Germans. The Summer night's festival this evening was well attended.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 1.--The trotting races were resumed here to-day. The attendance was very large, the weather good, and the track in fair condition. The first event was the conclusion of the race for trotters of the 2:30 class, of which two heats were trotted in the mud on Wednesday.

PHELPS, N.Y., Aug. 1.--Prof. Brooks, of the Redhouse Observatory, about 2 o'clock this morning observed a magnificent meteor moving from near the zenith toward the west. It was of extraordinary brilliancy, illuminating the country as if by an electric light, and leaving a train of sparks 40 degrees in length. It was visible several minutes, and with the telescope was seen to roll and curve like a wreath of smoke, with a slow motion northward.

LONDON, Aug. 1.--The trial of the dynamiters at Warwick was brought to a conclusion to-day. McDonnell, who pleaded guilty to the charge of treason felony, was released on bail to appear at any time if called upon. James Egan was sentenced to penal servitude for 20 years, and John Daly for life.

ALBANY, Aug. 1.--Vice-Admiral Rowan, Chairman of the Lighthouse Board, arrived here this afternoon on the steamer Rodgers, and went to Saratoga. He has just completed an inspection of the lighthouses along the Hudson River. They are reported in good working order.

LONDON, Aug. 1.--The crew of the British bark Low Wood, Capt. Saunders, at Limerick, for Delaware Breakwater, mutinied. The mate was stabbed and is in a dying condition. Two seamen received dangerous wounds. The mutiny was quelled by the police.

HOUSTON, Texas, Aug. 1.--The Houston Post publishes special crop reports from 196 points in Texas. The reports from the counties in North Texas show the cotton crop to be in fine condition. Plenty of rain having fallen in this section the crop will exceed an average.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1.--The head and tail of the American Association met to-day at Athletic Park. The "Mets" felt confident of winning a game from the Washingtons, and consequently they did not appear to realize what a difficult task was before them until the latter part of the game.

EASTON, Penn., Aug 1.--Jacob Kister and Henderson Green escaped from the jail at Belvidere, N.J., last night. Elkins, of the Republican National Committee, and held a conference, with doors closed and curtains drawn, which lasted about three hours.

The annual convention of the American Bankers' Association will be held at Saratoga on Aug. 13 and 14. Invitations to attend the meeting have been addressed to the 2,647 national banks, 3,498 private bankers, 1,126 State banks, and 584 savings banks of the country.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 2.--Favored by good weather and a fairly good track the attendance to-day was the best of the meeting so far, nearly 6,000 people being precent. A large percentage of the spectators were ladies.

PORTSMOUTH, N.H., Aug. 2.--Early this morning Mrs. Greely came over to this city from Admiral Wells's residence, and then took her two little daughters, who had remained during the night with their grandmother at the Rockingham House, over to the Admiral's house to see their father, Lieut. Greely was overcome with emotion at the sight of his little ones.
ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 2.--It is not generally known, but is true, nevertheless, that Georgia came very near having a candidate for the President foisted upon her.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2.--Col. Hains, of the Corps of Engineers, has made his annual report upon the fortifications of the Potomac Ricer to Gen. Newton, Chief of Engineers. The forts constituting the defense of the national capital are Forts Washington and Foote, situated on the Potomac, below the city.
BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 2.--Pressing demands for Mr. Blaine's presence at Augusta and other points will take him from Bar Harbor on Monday, and he will, it is announced, be gone indefinitely.

MONTREAL, Aug. 2.--Suits for libel in $25,000 each have been instituted by Drs. Migneault and Dorsonneus, members of the Victoria University Medical Faculty, against Dr. Lachapelle, Secretary of the Laval University.

LONDON, Aug. 2.--A letter from Mr. Parnell to a local Secretary of the Nationalist League in Ireland has just been made public In this Mr. Parnell says he anticipates, as the outcome of the Parliamentary committee's report, that an important improvement in the condition of the laboring classes in Ireland will be effected.

Mowat, Premier of Ontario, on his return from London, England, where he successfully argued the ease of Ontario in the boundary dispute between that Province and the Dominion before the Privy Council. LONDON, Aug. 2.--The political situation remains practically unchanged. The Liberals have held a caucus at which was displayed a fierce spirit of opposition to the Lords, and a declaration of John Morley that "we must mend it or end it" was greeted with the wildest enthusiasm.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 2.--Lillian Spencer, the actress, who has applied for a divorce from her husband, Edward Clayburg, of New-York, to-day made application to be allowed to retain her earnings. It was granted by the court, and she will return to the stage next season.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 2.--Joseph Clark, colored, having been convicted of the murder of Peter Wooten, colored, colored, in the first degree, will be hanged at Saulisbury, Hardeman County, Sept. 26. Clark was anxious to secure the affections of Wooten's wife, and removed her husband by braining him with the stock of a gun. The crime was entirely unprovoked. Clark had nothing to say when sentence of death was pronounced.

READING, Penn., Aug. 4.--At a meeting of the stockholders of the Active Baseball Club, held this evening, it was decided to disband on account of the failure of the public to give the club proper support. The association is heavily in debt, but every obligation to the players will be met.

In 1874 a guest at the United States Hotel missed a silk umbrella from his room and demanded satisfaction at the desk, which he obtained in cash--$4. SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Aug. 5.--The Republican Congressional Convention of the Eighth District, hold to-day, failed to nominate a candidate. There were 50 ballots taken, each county voting on every ballot for its own candidate without change.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 5.--The creditors of the A. W. Sprague Manufacturing Company, representing claims aggregating $4,000,000, have formally demaded an accounting of Mr. Z. Chaffee, the Trustee.

Mr. S.J. O'Sullivan, one of the Directors of the New-York Concert Company, has written a letter to THE TIMES in reference to the Casino troubles, in which he denies the statement which has been made to the effect that enough stock was transferred to him to enable him to qualify as a Director.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5.--A special to the Journal from Springfield, Ill., says: "Dr. Paaren, the State Veterinarian, has submitted to the Governor his report in relation to the recent appearance of Texas or splenic fever at Chicago.
BROADALBIN, N.Y., Aug. 5.--During the thunderstorm last night the house of George Davidson was struck by lightning. His little daughter and wife were standing in the house.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5, 1884. The Secretary of the Interior has appointed Robert E. Carpenter, of Dodge City, Iowa, Superintendent of the Yellowstone National Park, to succeed R.H. Conger, resigned.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Aug. 5.--The firm of E.C. Davis Co., dealers in fancy groceries, failed to-day. A Receiver was appointed, but before he had time to qualify the stock of goods was seized by the Sheriff on attachments issued ...

PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 6.--Groans of disgust instead of cheers greeted the efforts of the Allegheny Ball Club to play baseball at Union Park this afternoon with the Brooklyns. The game throughout was the most miserable exhibition by the home nine witnessed in this city this season.

The cornerstone of the new synagogue of the Congregation B'nai Jeshurun, in Madisonavenue, between Sixty-fourth and Sixty-fifth streets, was laid yesterday afternoon with the ceremonies of the Hebrew Church.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 6.--William Bear, of Norfolk, Va., was robbed to-day of a gold watch and chain valued at $500, $115 in money and some railroad tickets. He gave his valuables to the bathing master, and left his check in his bathing house, from which it was taken by a thief, to whom Mr. Bear's property was delivered.
The left hind foot of a graveyard rabbit, which has a potent influence among the Southern negroes, has been presented to Gov. Cleveland as a talisman in the campaign.

The members of the New-York Baseball Club are happy. They have longed to defeat the Providence Club once more before their series bras brought to a close, and their most ardent desires were satisfied yesterday when they defeated the Rhode Island men in the presence of a large number of persons.

HAVANA, Aug. 6.--The Custom House permitted from Aug. 1 the payment of all export duties half in gold and half in bank bills at their nominal value. It now claims that the official dispatch of July 29 from Madrid refers only to sugar duties, and from yesterday all export duties except on sugar will be collected in gold.

WOONSOCKET, R.I., Aug. 6.--At the water works at noon to-day Theodore T. Mowry, a painter, deliberately shot Elmer E. Mowry, an employe of the works, with a shotgun. He then fired a bullet into his own brain. They will both die. The cause of the shooting was an old feud over a horse trade.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 6.--Owing to the foggy weather the race for the Goelet cup was again postponed. It will take place to-morrow if the fog lifts, which does not seem probable to-night. Capt. Ogden Goelet gave a magnificent entertainment this evening on his yacht, the Norseman, to all the yachtsmen in the harbor and their guests.
The library of an old German doctor named Adolphus, who died in the poorhouse about six months ago, was sold yesterday at auction, at the corner of First and Oak streets.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Aug. 6.--Margaret Freunscht, a German girl about 19 years of age, arrived in New-York from "over the Rhine" about a month ago. She was employed by a gentleman residing at Ellenville, in this county, ...

STRATFORD, Conn., Aug. 6.--A party of berry pickers, while picking blackberries in Milford, about two miles up the Naugatuck Railroad, yesterday was startled by finding a human skull and other bones under an apple tree. The flesh had entirely disappeared from them. How the bones came there no one appears to know. An investigation will be had.

A caucus of Republicans and independents of the towns of Greenburg and Mount Pleasant, to elect delegates to the westchester County conference, to be held at Mount Vernon to-day, was held in the Lyceum Building in Tarrytown last evening.

QUEBEC, Aug. 6.--Bears have become such a nuisance in the Megantic districts that the municipal authorities have offered to pay $5 per capita for their destruction.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 6.--Prof. James Garland, 60 years of age, a prominent music teacher here, committed suicide this morning by shooting himself with a revoler in the right temple, the bullet entering his brain. He attempted to commit suicide once before about eight years ago.
